And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE ART AND ARCHITECTURE OF ISLAM, 1250-1800, by Sheila S. Blair and Jonathan M. Bloom. (Yale University, $65.) A bold, competent and fresh attempt to rewrite the history of later Islamic art from scratch, with plenty of splendid color illustrations and other useful graphics.
 
BOREDOM: The Literary History of a State of Mind, by Patricia Meyer Spacks. (University of Chicago, $24.95.) A persuasive account of a concept invented in the 18th century; its roots include a growing concentration on "inner experience" as the locus of personal reality.
 
THE FIRST WORLD WAR: A Complete History, by Martin Gilbert. (Holt, $35.) Mr. Gilbert's enormous breadth of view seeks to render this dreadful conflict as soldiers lived it on many fronts, often relying on the poetry and prose of the many gifted writers who saw action.
 
GENTLEMAN SPY: The Life of Allen Dulles, by Peter Grose. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $30.) A biography, full of new information, of the irresistibly charming (and manipulative) man who headed -- and embodied -- the Central Intelligence Agency from 1953 to 1961.
 
IN PHARAOH'S ARMY: Memories of the Lost War, by Tobias Wolff. (Knopf, $23.) The follow-up volume to Mr. Wolff's memoir "This Boy's Life" is a series of small, elegant, personal sketches of his year in Vietnam.
 
KONFIDENZ, by Ariel Dorfman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.) This novel in dialogue reveals only gradually that its frightening political developments are taking place in 1939, suggesting that fear is always appropriate.
 
LONG WALK TO FREEDOM: The Autobiography of Nelson Mandela, by Nelson Mandela. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) On the evidence of his own version of his amazing life, the President of South Africa is no moralist or messiah but a pragmatic politician who always chose what might work over what was ideologically agreeable.
 
THE MASTER OF PETERSBURG, by J.M. Coetzee. (Viking, $21.95.) The hero of Mr. Coetzee's grimmest novel yet is Dostoyevsky himself, trapped in generational and political clashes, trying to scrape meaning from the death of a son.
 
MASTER OF THE DAY OF JUDGMENT, by Leo Perutz. (Arcade, $19.95.) First published in Austria in 1921, after the empire's collapse in the Great War, this elaborate joke of a novel takes the genre itself as a stage for brilliant clowning.
 
A NATION UNDER LAWYERS: How the Crisis in the Legal Profession Is Transforming American Society, by Mary Ann Glendon. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A Harvard law professor sees hyperactive litigators and "romantic" judges as depriving the nation of lawyers' real talents: solving problems and designing social structures.
 
ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON: A Biography, by Frank McLynn. (Random House, $30.) A thoroughly detailed life, taking the most recent scholarship into account, of the great Scottish writer of English prose who died at 44 in 1894.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 906 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:

THE SORCERER'S APPRENTICE: Tales and Conjurations
By Charles Johnson. Plume, $9.95.
Magic is the theme connecting these eight short stories, which sometimes deal with contemporary sleight of hand and sometimes hark back to the ancient tribal powers of African wizards. "Mr. Johnson's spell of a book comes on with the authority of a classic," Michael Ventura said here in 1986.
A DIFFERENT PERSON: A Memoir
By James Merrill. HarperSanFrancisco, $14.
This acclaimed American poet looks back on his youth, writing of the trip he made to Rome in 1950 at the age of 24. There, he came to embrace more fully both his poetic voice and his homosexuality. "What sets this memoir apart is the writing and the humor," Brigitte Weeks said here in 1993. "Every page contains a sentence one wants to quote to a friend." Also reissued is Mr. Merrill's (DIBLOS) NOTEBOOK (Dalkey Archive, $9.95), which takes the form of notes for a novel about the narrator's brother and his experiences in Greece. In 1965 our reviewer, Wilfrid Sheed, called it "a disciplined, adventurous performance in the best tradition of fictional experiment." 

ON THE REAL SIDE:
Laughing, Lying, and Signifying -- The Underground Tradition of African-American Humor That Transformed American Culture, From Slavery to Richard Pryor
By Mel Watkins. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $15.
The author analyzes the comic spirit of black Americans, showing how humor was often forged from oppression and how the self-deprecating, wry tone of many jokes and routines masked strong defiance and incisive social commentary. "Mel Watkins's book is the most comprehensive and penetrating history yet written," Lawrence W. Levine said here last year.
GRINGA
By Sandra Scofield. Plume, $10.95.
The setting for this novel is Mexico City in 1968, where a young woman, Abilene Painter, has gone to seek an abortion but finds herself caught up in the local student protests. Her new political awareness helps her shed her passivity. In 1989 our reviewer, Michele Wolf, said, "Abilene's coming of age is masterfully conveyed through fully realized, complex characters."
36 VIEWS OF MOUNT FUJI: On Finding Myself in Japan
By Cathy N. Davidson. Plume, $10.95.
The author, who taught in Japan in the 1980's, immersed herself in the country's culture, which she found welcoming rather than distant. "This appealing book is always sincere," Francine Prose said here in 1993. Also reissued is THE WORLD OF THE SHINING PRINCE: Court Life in Ancient Japan, by Ivan Morris (Kodansha Globe, $15), which opens a window on the cloistered, insular universe of the aristocracy of the vanished city of Heian-kyo. In 1964 our reviewer, Oliver Statler, said the author "has made the 10th century come alive."
SAVAGE NIGHTS
By Cyril Collard. Translated by William Rodarmor. Tusk/Overlook, $11.95.
The inspiration for the recent autobiographical movie of the same title, this novel traces the love affairs of Jean, a bisexual film maker who loves a young actress but cannot give up his "savage nights" of brutal and depersonalized encounters with men. Collard, who died of AIDS in 1993, "has indisputably created something of value," Elizabeth Gaffney said here last year.
NEVER STOP RUNNING: Allard Lowenstein and the Struggle to Save American Liberalism
By William H. Chafe. Basic Books, $15.
Exploring both Lowenstein's political career and personal style, this portrait reveals a man who frequently embraced radical tactics but was deeply committed to changing American government from within. In 1993 our reviewer, David Oshinsky, called it "both a superb biography . . . and a gripping history."
SECRETS
By Kelvin Christopher James.
Vintage Contemporaries, $10.
Uxann, a girl growing up in Trinidad, faces not only the trials of adolescence but also betrayal by her father, the man she trusts most. This novel "ambitiously examines jealousy, loyalty, the mysteries of sex and the horrors of incest," Michael E. Ross said here last year.
THE ENDANGERED AMERICAN DREAM:
How to Stop the United States From Becoming a Third-World Country and How to Win the Geo-Economic Struggle for Industrial Supremacy
By Edward N. Luttwak.
Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.
The author sees war brewing everywhere, not on the battlefield but in economics. He believes America will decline if it does not support high technology and upgrade education. In 1993 our reviewer, Jeffrey E. Garten, said he "brings a keen historical perspective and a fertile mind to a host of important questions."
CARRIAGE TRADE
By Stephen Birmingham. Bantam, $5.99.
This plot-packed novel paints the behind-the-scenes world of Tarkington's, a glitzy Fifth Avenue department store; its characters manipulate human lives as easily as they do balance sheets. The result is "as pleasurable as a fast cruise through the Chanel department at Bergdorf's," Wendy Wasserstein said here in 1993. As for the goods on a real retail emporium, there's LIKE NO OTHER STORE . . .: The Bloomingdale's Legend and the Revolution in American Marketing, by Marvin Traub and Tom Teicholz (Times Books/Random House, $15). Mr. Traub, former chairman of the business that made shopping theater, tells of the store's winning strategies while hurling barbs at his successors. In 1993 our reviewer, Stephanie Strom, said the book is "far more than a personal memoir," chronicling "changing postwar appetites." LAUREL GRAEBER

LENGTH: 1184 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Smoke-Free Flights Increase

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
SMOKE-FREE flying suddenly looks a lot more real. Beginning today, Delta Air Lines will be the first United States airline to ban smoking on all flights. On the heels of Delta's announcement in November, six other United States airlines and two foreign lines moved toward banning smoking on trans-Atlantic flights, petitioning the Department of Transportation to be exempted from antitrust prosecution if they jointly agreed to do this.
And, on March 1, an agreement by the United States, Australia and Canada will take effect, banning smoking on all scheduled nonstop flights between the countries. 
 The three-government agreement, unlike the 1990 United States regulation banning passenger smoking on domestic flights, forbids smoking by crew members in the cockpit. Because of this, and because the agreement affects long flights over the Pacific, an enforcement expert at the Department of Transportation said the pact represented a key step toward the United Nations goal of eliminating airline smoking by July 1, 1996. Because of the length of the Pacific flights, and the high percentage of smokers in Asia, airlines have been edgy about those routes.
New Zealand, which participated in the talks leading to the agreement, signed in Chicago on Nov. 1, found it needed to amend its civil aviation act before it could sign. Rob Moore-Jones, a counselor for trade and economic issues in the New Zealand Embassy, expects the legislature to approve the amendment this year and a signing soon thereafter.
In eliminating smoking on its flights worldwide, Delta acted on the basis of passenger surveys and under pressure from its cabin crews. The ban extends to its 45 Crown Club facilities in 38 airports.
 
 
Steps Toward U.N. Goal
 On Dec. 15, American, Continental, Northwest, Trans World Airlines, United and USAir, joined by British Airways and K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines, asked the Department of Transportation for immunity from antitrust action if they agreed to eliminate smoking over the Atlantic.
The airlines did not mention Delta, but pointed to the United Nations deadline and to Transportation Secretary Federico Pena's commitment to smoke-free travel.
"The joint applicants believe," the request said, "that voluntary action will permit . . . smoke-free travel in a faster and more orderly fashion than the present process of government regulation and negotiation."
Ed O'Hara, a spokesman for the Department of Transportation, said that outside comments on the request were accepted until Friday, and that a prompt response could be expected from the department.
In late October, United Airlines added smoke-free flights between San Francisco and Sydney -- which would have been mandatory on March 1 anyway -- and San Francisco and Hong Kong. It also banned smoking on two more New York-London flights. United bans smoking on its flights to and from Canada and Caribbean and Mexican resorts.
American has banned smoking on three trans-Atlantic round trips linking New York and Chicago with London, and will do the same for seasonal services linking Dallas-Fort Worth with London and Chicago with Manchester.
Northwest, which had not had an overseas nonsmoking flight, on Nov. 1 started one between Seattle and Hong Kong. On Oct. 30, British Airways added one of its four New York-London round trips to its nonsmoking list. This week, it will begin new services between New York and Birmingham, England, and between New York and Glasgow, and these will be nonsmoking. The line has also banned smoking on one of two Hong Kong-London daily round trips, one of two Los Angeles-London daily round trips and one of two San Francisco-London round trips.
Domestic airlines have usually said that banning smoking on routes between Tokyo and the United States would put them at sharp competitive disadvantage. But Delta said that its survey showed that the number of people rejecting a smoke-free flight would be more than offset by those selecting it. And Cathay Pacific, flying to Hong Kong out of Toronto, Vancouver and Los Angeles, has been smoke-free over the Pacific since 1992, although it has smoking flights linking Taiwan, Korea and Japan.
 
 
Survey Behind Delta Policy
 Delta said it surveyed 4,200 trans-Pacific passengers in August and September, distributing the questionnaire in English, Chinese, Japanese and Korean. The line said that those favoring smoke-free flights outnumbered the others, 4 to 1. Before the survey, the line had announced a Jan. 1 smoking ban for its trans-Atlantic, intra-Europe and New York-Mexico flights. In November, the ban went systemwide.
But any Delta flights operated by other airlines with which the line has a code-sharing agreement are not governed by Delta's policy. Under code-sharing, the line may sell a Delta ticket and the reservations computer may show the flight as a Delta flight, but the service may be provided by another line. Delta has code-sharing agreements with Aeroflot, Aeromexico, Austrian Airlines, Malev Hungarian Airlines, Sabena, Swissair, TAP Air Portugal and Varig. In cases of acute smoke allergy, passengers should insist on learning if the flight is operated by Delta. The United States regulation guaranteeing a nonsmoking seat to a passenger requesting one does not apply to foreign airlines.
The three-nation nonsmoking agreement was signed in Chicago to mark the 50th anniversary of the Chicago Convention, a network of agreements on international civil aviation. In 1944, before World War II ended, President Roosevelt convened a meeting looking toward peacetime air travel. The International Civil Aviation Organization grew out of the Chicago Convention, making it older than the United Nations, with which it is now affiliated.
For Canada, the pact merely put an international imprint on an existing policy: In July Canada banned smoking aboard airlines based in Canada. In addition to New Zealand, Singapore is also considering joining the pact, according to Dr. Agnes J. Huff, director of public affairs for Singapore Airlines, a publicly held company in which the Government invests. Singapore Airlines has banned smoking on 88 percent of its flights, the exception being those beginning or ending in Japan.
On the legislative front, in October the House of Representatives approved a bill that would have banned smoking on all international flights to or from the United States, but the bill died in the Senate. A staff member of the House Aviation Subcommittee said that Representative James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota, the bill's sponsor, would try again in the next Congress. But the political climate does not look favorable and questions have been raised about the ability of the United States to enforce such a law.
 
 
From Air to Sea
 Princess Cruises announced that it would have smoke-free dining rooms on all nine of its ships starting today; it joined at least four other lines in complete dining-room bans, according to a spokeswoman for the Cruise Lines International Association: Carnival, Epirotiki, Majesty and World Explorer.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 32; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: ARTS ARTIFACTS;
A Multicultural Medley of Styles, 1920 to 1945

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
CRAFTS IN AMERICA flourished increasingly at the grass-roots level between 1920 and 1945, with artisans spurred on midway by Federal money in the New Deal era. The work they produced was distinctively varied: Colonial-style chairs, Mondrian-like quilts, Hispanic images of saints, cornhusk dolls dressed as flappers and Pueblo pots bearing political statements.
Now such objects can be seen in "Revivals! Diverse Traditions: 1920-1945," an ambitious, if disjointed, exhibition at the American Craft Museum in Manhattan through Feb. 26. Five curators chose the objects and wrote much of the catalogue, published by the museum and Harry N. Abrams ($49.50, cloth; $29.95, paper). The show, the second of eight in the museum's series on the history of 20th-century American crafts, was financed mainly by a grant from the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund. 
 The 170 items on view reflect the many craft cultures at work then -- African-American, Appalachian, American Indian, Hispanic and Anglo-Saxon. Conventional items dominate, but there are remarkable pieces, too.
Among them are a glorious geometric-patterned basket woven in the 1930's by Carrie Bethel, a Paiute Indian of California; an elegantly scrolled wrought-iron window grill, circa 1940, by Philip Simmons, a blacksmith of African descent in Charleston, S.C., and a faithful 1920's reproduction of a 17th-century armchair, made under the direction of Wallace Nutting, a Framingham, Mass., expert in Colonial furniture.
While stimulating, this multicultural mix of materials and styles is also confusing, since the items in one category rarely seem esthetically related to those in another.
"The exhibition celebrates diversity," said Janet Kardon, director of the museum and the project. "There are lots of parallels, especially technical ones, in the basketry and the quilts. The exhibition brings material together that the scholars have not yet analyzed."
But perhaps the show's most provocative aspect, mentioned often but never fully developed in the wall texts or the catalogue, is the Government's role in advancing crafts in all ethnic categories in the 1930's. By then the Arts and Crafts movement had lost its luster, and its dynamic pioneers were long gone. But the 19th-century message of the movement's British founder, William Morris -- that good design in handmade household articles improved society -- continued to make crafts desirable.
Federal support under President Franklin D. Roosevelt helped renew the movement, reviving handblown Colonial-style glass at the Works Progress Administration's factory in Vineland, N.J., and subsidizing the production of chairs, tables, hooked rugs and woven draperies at Timberline Lodge, a ski resort at Mt. Hood in Oregon that was and still is partly owned by the National Forest Service. The Civilian Conservation Corps, the National Department of Indian Affairs and the Farm Security Administration offered other programs, training artisans in ceramics, metalworking, quilting and basketry while easing unemployment.
The results, as seen in this show, were often impressive. Mary Histia, an Acoma Indian potter from New Mexico, celebrated Government involvement in crafts by emblazoning a large earthenware jar, circa 1930, with the American eagle and the words "Our President, Franklin D. Roosevelt, U.S., We Do Our Part." In the 1940's, an unknown artisan in a W.P.A. factory updated an 18th-century pitcher by audaciously lengthening the curved handle and changing its faintly tinted coloring to a brilliant blue.
The show focuses on reproductions and reinterpretations of centuries-old craft styles, and the most traditional are the Hispanic crafts. The intricately stitched lacework by Puerto Rican women especially stands out: tablecloths and bedcovers with the same geometric motifs, delicate flowers and birds seen in the work of the artisans' ancestors.
Not everything on view in "Revivals!" appears traditional. The vivid abstract patterning on a 1940's coverlet by Susan Pless, a black quilter from Oklahoma, relates as strongly to the art of Mondrian as to the lesser-known 19th-century preference by black artisans for strips and blocks in quilts. In Appalachia, the cornhusk dolls from the 1920's seem modern, too, as fashionably dressed as F. Scott Fitzgerald characters.
The sources of African-American material seem more difficult to pinpoint. Indeed, the scrolled-iron grillwork, the colorful ceramics splashed with vivid washes or florals, as well as the quilts, seem to replicate those made by white artisans. The exhibition fails to show or report how blacks developed their own crafts in the 18th and 19th centuries.
As for scope, this museum project is certainly daring. Chock-full of information about the people who produced and distributed crafts, the exhibition nevertheless leaves the viewer with more questions than answers.
"This is a period that needs more work by scholars," Mrs. Kardon said. "Being the first ones out there to do such an exhibition, we may get clobbered, but it will be worth it. We want to raise questions that will invite further discussion."

Roosevelt Library, Hyde Park, N.Y.) -- Among 170 pieces in "Revivals! Diverse Traditions: 1920-1945."

HEADLINE: On the Weicker Watch: Stand Up or Stand Back?

SERIES: Kirk Johnson, a reporter for The New York Times, covered the election campaign and administrationof Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
AS a reporter covering Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in Hartford, it was wise to get a firm and early grasp on the coded format of his news conferences: Would the Governor be standing in front of the fireplace? Seated behind his desk? On the couch? Each variation carried a hidden message about the tone of the event and whether or not you could expect to have your head handed back to you for asking any particular question.
The couch was almost always best. It conveyed informality. The reporters sat. Mr. Weicker took his jacket off, and when he sank down into the cushions, his pants rode up his ankles, exposing his socks and making him seem almost folksy, or in any case less formidable. 
 Seated-at-his-desk news conferences were the next most preferable. In the chair, with television cameras bearing down from the front and the reporters all standing, it was possible to create and briefly sustain the illusion that Mr. Weicker was surrounded. He could be pressed on things.
A stand-up at the fireplace was a wild card, though not as unpredictable as the hallway ambush, where you didn't have a clue until the first question whether the Weicker you encountered would be brusquely dismissive at the stupidity of your questions or thoughtfully eloquent.
In a fireplace news conference, everyone stood, and the distance between the 6-foot-6 chief executive and the -- by comparison -- diminutive reporters of the capitol press corps was, by my guess, about two long strides on his part, if he ever chose to close the distance. In any event you were inescapably aware that he was on his feet, mobile, ready for action.
The bottom line of the Weicker years, though, was that tea leaves and guesswork was all you had to go on. The Governor's mercurial, essentially unpredictable nature -- what would set him off, what his next surprise legislative proposal would be, even, in the end, what made him go -- defined his administration and his every move within it.
From the bombshell announcement in his first budget in 1991 that he would break one of the longest running political taboos in Connecticut and propose a tax on wages, through his sudden announcement last year that he would not seek a second term, tracking the Weicker trajectory was often a lot like watching a Punch and Judy show. At any moment, somebody might jump out of nowhere, hollering. You had to be ready, and you learned to watch for the telling Weicker moment.

 Just before noon on Oct. 5, 1991, despite the anguished pleadings of his State Police body guards, the Governor walked directly into the middle of one the biggest and loudest protest rallies in modern Connecticut history.
The state's new income tax, which Mr. Weicker fathered, had just started biting paychecks, and about 40,000 people had gathered on the capitol grounds to shriek. Straw-stuffed Weicker dolls were hanging in effigy from the trees.
And when the protesters saw that the man himself had had the effrontery to enter their midst, they erupted. They screamed, they waved signs and fists, they hurled obscenities directly into the Governor's smiling, placid face as he moved out among them, surrounded by his ring of tense troopers.
Afterward, in the muted marble calm of the capitol, Mr. Weicker explained that as a point of democratic principle he would not be stopped by anyone from walking on public grounds where and when he chose. If people were vile enough to try and spit on him, as they had, so be it. But anyone who'd seen his face out there, at the center of all that wrath, knew the real truth: He'd enjoyed every minute of it -- reveled in it, like a boy stirring up a hornet's nest with a stick.

 In early 1993, press aides invited reporters to an early morning news conference in the Governor's office. The event had been described only cryptically as having something to do with the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, but it was made clear that one would best be advised to be there. The Governor was behind his desk, flanked by tribe members and attorneys. A sheaf a papers was distributed.
Gradually, as we read, the truth dawned: The Pequots, operators of the state's only casino, Foxwoods, in Ledyard, had agreed to voluntarily give over 25 percent of their slot machine revenue to the state -- so long as the tribe had no competition from Las Vegas and Atlantic City interlopers like Stephen A. Wynn or Donald Trump. In a single master stroke, Mr. Weicker -- a steadfast opponent of expanded gambling -- had crippled the movement to authorize a casino in Bridgeport.
Afterward, the pro-gambling legislators and lobbyists were just like the protestors on the lawn: red-faced, utterly flummoxed and outfoxed.

 But the reactions Mr. Weicker produced in people through his long public career -- from the Connecticut legislature in the early 1960's through the United States Congress, including three terms in the Senate -- were vivid at the other end of the spectrum as well. The people who love Mr. Weicker almost seem to worship him.
Many apparently fell for him in the 1970's, when as a Republican Senator during the Watergate Committee hearings he became a symbol of the lonely warrior, defending the Constitution from those in his own party who would subvert it. Through battles with fellow Republicans like Jesse Helms, he came to be seen as a man of the big gesture and the broad defense of moral principle in a world that often seemed populated with men and women of small-minded expedience. People gradually began to expect to be moved or enraged by whatever he did, and I think maybe Mr. Weicker also felt a need as time went on not to disappoint them.
On the day in Greenwich when he said he would not run for a second four-year term as Governor, the woman next to me in the audience suddenly began to cry. She explained that she somehow just knew -- in driving from Litchfield County to be there -- that this would be Mr. Weicker's decision. She was prepared: Her tissue was up her sleeve, ready for duty.

 But Mr. Weicker's famous truculence -- not to mention his penchant for scatological metaphors in describing his dissatisfaction with the legislature's work product -- was also, on very rare occasions, lifted to reveal the vulnerability beneath.
Over the course of his campaign in 1990, for example, and through his term in office, I wrote stories that described his arrogance and his intolerance of dissent.
But it wasn't until I wrote that perhaps not all of his thoughts were utterly and profoundly original that he hit the roof. The offending reference occurred in a story about a speech he gave to the General Assembly in 1993.
I wrote -- innocuously enough, I thought -- that the Governor's language about the urgent need to desegregate Connecticut's racially and economically divided public schools strongly resembled remarks recently given in court by the plaintiffs in the Sheff v. O'Neill integration lawsuit then -- as now -- raging in Hartford Superior Court.
The next day, Mr. Weicker cornered me and after rising, it seemed, to well beyond his full height, said he felt I'd accused him of plagiarism, that every word of his speeches was written by no one but himself, and that he resented any other implication.
I swallowed once and said I had intended nothing of the sort, but had only been pointing out the interesting parallel -- that Connecticut's chief executive would take an almost identical line as the people who are suing him to overhaul the school system. I encouraged him to call my editors if he wanted to complain further.
But his anger, like a brief, severe squall at sea, was already spent. "Forget about it," he said. "It's over."
Then, on the spot he granted me an exclusive, if utterly impromptu, interview. But no couch this time. He sat behind his desk. I took a chair in front.

And placid, below -- with voters furious at his imposing an income tax, 1991.; Splat! On stage, in "The Barber of Seville," the Governor gets his comeuppance for going after Count Almaviva (Peter Harvey). Back with the budget, left, levity was gone. HEADLINE: Q. & A.;
A Key Fee: What Can Tenant Do?

 BODY:

Q What kind of legal action can I take against the former tenant of my rent-stabilized apartment for the key fee he charged me? The former tenant (who is not a real-estate broker) put a classified advertisement in a newspaper describing his apartment and the fact that a low fee would be charged. 
 I responded to the ad and was told by the tenant that in order to apply for the apartment, I had to pay him a fee equal to one month's rent. Having no choice if I wanted a shot at the apartment, I agreed and signed a document indicating my understanding that this fee had nothing to do with the landlord and any lease-related negotiations, but that it would be returned to me if the application was not approved.
It turns out that the former tenant had broken his lease and made a deal with the landlord whereby he would find a suitable tenant to take over the apartment. . . . G. Masoni, Manhattan.
 A In New York, key money is illegal, said Eric Davis, a Manhattan lawyer. "A demand for key money is generally unenforceable," Mr. Davis said, "and if it is paid, the party paying the key money has legal recourse against the party receiving it."
A licensed real-estate broker may charge a commission for the rental or sale of real property, even if the broker has an interest in that property, though generally such circumstances require disclosure by the broker, Mr. Davis said. A nonbroker is not permitted to charge a commission.
Mr. Davis said the writer had two possible avenues of recourse: taking the previous tenant to court or filing an overcharge complaint against him with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which oversees rent administration in the city.
Lou Ganim, a spokesman for D.H.C.R., said that such a fee associated with the rental of an apartment evades the intent of the Rent Stabilization Law. Mr. Davis said the writer should contact the D.H.C.R.'s Office of Rent Administration, Lower Manhattan Borough Office, 156 William Street, 9th floor, telephone number: (212) 240-6008.
 
Entering Apartment Of Deceased Tenant
Q Can a building-owner's employee enter the apartment of a deceased tenant and remove any item without the permission of the executors of the estate of the deceased person?
What action if any may I take as executrix? The office and owners of the building were well aware that I am the executrix and knew where to reach me. I live in one of the buildings owned by the same person who owns the building where the deceased lived. . . . Brenda Tharpe, Manhattan.
 A The mere fact that a tenant dies does not allow a landlord or the landlord's agent to enter the tenant's apartment, said Michael Finder, a Manhattan lawyer.
"The landlord has to go to court," Mr. Finder said.
In fact, he said, if the deceased tenant had been occupying the apartment under a written lease "the death of the tenant does not terminate the lease, and the executrix would have the right to have the estate occupy the apartment for the balance of the lease, for winding up affairs of the estate."
If the decedent was a rent-controlled tenant without a written lease, he said, "the mere death of the tenant, without a surrender of the apartment by the executrix or without court proceedings, would not allow a landlord to simply take back possession of the apartment."
In any event, Mr. Finder said, assuming there have been no court proceedings, if the landlord's agent or employee in this case wrongfully entered the apartment and wrongfully took the decedent's possessions, "the executrix should file a criminal complaint."

SECTION: Section 13; Page 5; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 4212 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT;
Caffeine and Crackdowns: Dispatches From '94

 BODY:
STATIONED in the sky, the eye of a camera sweeping across New York would have looked down at a cranky but energized city in 1994. Its residents hungering for order, the civic life of New York's neighborhoods evolved as both prickly and aggressive, amounting to a stiffening of civic resolve that sought control over the streets and an erasure of the decades-old impulse of shrugging off disorder. Hearts hardened; community meetings often turned ugly.
Feeding off new commercial life swelling in neighborhoods from SoHo to the Upper West Side, Manhattan had a crisper feel, perhaps caffeinated by the new-style coffee bars that cropped up on some streets three at a time. Huge stores took over the empty hulks that were the dreams of turn-of the-century retailers. Themes and hooks were demanded, and the rollicking permutations of capitalism sometimes took bizarre forms. Televisions turned up above urinals in restaurants. One nightclub owner decided to have an earthquake night: the place shook at midnight as Los Angeles video imagery abounded. When the venture failed, he tried a Latin American earthquake and the imagery turned Cuban. 
 The city headed into 1995 with pockets of energy and new confidence but with the local economy still weak in key areas and residents about to feel the affects of the contraction of the municipal budget. In a special report, the reporters and editors of The City present a survey of 1994 -- not from aloft but from down on the ground in the neighborhoods -- with an eye toward what the key local issues are likely to be in 1995.
 
LOWER MANHATTAN
 
Emergency Care on Wall Street
 
 Here was a neighborhood with an identity crisis. Once the beating heart of the greed decade, the financial district continued the hemorrhage that has cost 100,000 jobs below Chambers Street in the last seven years and left vacancy rates of up to 25 percent in some of the same buildings that once represented New York's power and virility on the world scene. With real-estate interests stung and a vacuum of leadership, a Business Improvement District was formed to avoid obsolescence by diversifying the area away from financial services and into more of a 24-hour neighborhood. At year's end, the Giuliani administration offered what could be the city's largest development proposal in more than 10 years, a package that included tax breaks, zoning changes and an express taxi lane. Around town some grumbled that the plan was a bailout that could just as well have been offered to other areas. The proposal now goes to the City Council.

CHINATOWN
 
Changing Tongs
 
 "I'm late for the doctor," a frail Benny Ong told a reporter in June as two bodyguards helped him to a waiting car on Pell Street, the narrow alley where he was said to run his extortion rackets and gambling dens, and where he gained his nickname "hatchet man" for his skill with an ax. Two months later, as Mr. Ong made his final trip through Chinatown in a funeral procession with 120 black limousines, the streets were silent in reverence. The death of the 87-year-old "Godfather of Chinatown," the adviser-in-chief of the Hip Sing Association, represented the end of the era of old-time Chinese organized-crime leaders. These days, Chinese crime has focused on new quarries -- the smuggling of Fujianese immigrants and the peddling of heroin -- and has become less centralized, with loosely formed gangs practicing extortion around the city. The tongs, now wishing to be called associations, even began a campaign to cleanse their image as tools of gangsters. All in all, continued prosecutions may have shaken up some organized-crime pockets.
 
Parade Politics
 
 It seems obligatory these days that an ethnic parade be tangled in controversy. This year it was Chinatown's turn. The first official pro-mainland parade ran through the neighborhood in September, its very presence a looming challenge to Chinatown's established pro-Nationalist leadership. But the leaders of the mainland parade cried favoritism when the police gave them a route outside the traditional center of Chinatown. They were also angry that Capt. Thomas M. Chan of the Fifth Precinct did not march in their parade but had a prominent spot a few weeks later in the annual Nationalist parade, which was granted its usual central Chinatown route. Look for the parades to be an issue again this year.
 
SOHO/TRIBECA
 
Smoothing the Edges
 
 The sidewalks were jammed. Tourists poured in. Shoppers browsed. Broadway had a furious pace below Houston Street. To some lament, the cyclical waves of the city economy turned SoHo, once a manufacturing district and then a frontier home for artist/pioneers, into a location for Armani A/X and Lechters Housewares and an international marketplace for style and design. As if to punctuate the trend, Hartz Mountain announced in December that it would build a large hotel on Grand Street.
For its part, TriBeCa continued to grow as a restaurant district. Robert De Niro, who has blended his hip star image with the low rents below Canal to create what amounts to a new film district, was a partner in a very hot new restaurant, Nobu, and planned a bakery. Down the block, Bubby's became a lunchtime scene; one film executive called it "the East Coast Polo Lounge."
 
LOWER EAST SIDE/EAST VILLAGE
 
ABC's of Gentrification
 
 Renewing interest that flickered briefly in the go-go 1980's, investors are now plowing money into this once-grungy street, giving it a more trendy look, with boutiques and designer food. But even with a tamer Tompkins Square Park, the old Haight Ashbury feel isn't completely gone. And entrepreneurial inspiration can still be offbeat, as evidenced by the opening of the club Babyland, with its infantilism motif: naked Barbie dolls, a Playskool bar and mooing doors.

Master of the Brawl
 
Already known for the city's wildest and toughest brand of politics, these neighborhoods now have one of the city's most controversial politicians: Councilman Antonio Pagan. Gay, Hispanic and relatively conservative, the 35-year-old lawyer opposes low-income housing and many new social services. He has aroused such venom with his acid tongue that one local paper regularly portrays him as a cockroach; political opponents have hit him with defamation suits. Others say he is dedicated and gets things done, using his aggressive manner in many neighborhood causes. He lost one important battle when his close ally, William E. Ubinas, was deposed as superintendent of School District 1 after a tumultuous fight.

Target: The Squatters
 
Housing policy often amounts to triage, and perhaps nowhere is this more evident than on East 13th Street, where squatters are encamped in five city-owned tenements. Over the years officials have largely let these and other squatters around the city alone, but with thousands of people on waiting lists for low-rent apartments, housing officials want the buildings back. The 13th Street battle, now in the courts, has been furiously fought. At one community board meeting the squatters and their supporters caused such pandemonium that board members had to retreat behind a barrier of a dozen shield-bearing police officers to vote yes on the city's plans.
 
NOHO
 
Reassessing Astor Place
 
 Just as development smoothed out Avenue A, it began to alter the faintly industrial feel of Astor Place. Conran's closed, Cooper Square Books departed and the Greek-style diner, the Astor Riviera Cafe, shut its doors. What is coming in tells much about Asian investment in the city and the spate of large discount stores and coffee bars. The newcomers: a Barnes & Noble, taking over Conran's; Starbucks, the Seattle-based coffee chain, subsuming the Riviera, and loft-style apartments in the old District 65 union building, courtesy of a group from China.
 
WEST VILLAGE
 
It's All in the Details
 
 "You take care of the little things, and the big things take care of themselves," said Capt. Peter Cassidy, executive officer of the Sixth Precinct. And so this area, which is deluged with young people each weekend, particularly on Eighth Street, became an experiment in quality-of-life enforcement. This meant increased patrolling, stepped-up enforcement using computers to track violators, and more summonses for minor offenses, like noisy portable radios, graffiti vandalism and unlicensed vending. Some progress was reported in the area, and the police decided to expand the program elsewhere in the city.

The Tolerance Envelope
 
Neighbors in one of New York's most historically tolerant communities decided they had reached their limit of tolerance when a physician, Dr. Joyce Wallace, sought to open a home for reforming prostitutes in her West 13th Street brownstone. The proposal was killed.
 
CHELSEA
 
Doubly Pleased in Chelsea
 
 In the give and take of New York's neighborhoods, Chelsea found itself on the receiving end of economic and geographic changes in two sometimes overlapping communities -- the city's gay world and its art world. Symbolizing a northward shift of gay life, a Different Light, a bookstore that is a cultural hub in gay literary circles, moved from the West Village to 19th Street. In some people's minds, Eighth Avenue has now supplanted Christopher Street as the city's main gay thoroughfare, a notion largely confirmed by the crowds that poured into Chelsea during the Gay Games.
Farther west, amid the warehouses and factory buildings clustered about 10th Avenue, West Chelsea began to emerge as a serious player in the city's art scene. Several new galleries and dozens of studios opened, and more are coming. The area is attracting artists fleeing SoHo's high rents and galleries from 57th Street and Madison Avenue. The locals farther east, often intimidated by the goings-on across 10th Avenue, are pleased.

Life on the Pier
 
The reconstruction of the Chelsea Piers, between 17th and 22d Streets, took shape. Soon to come: a sports club, two indoor ice-skating rinks, a park and a mammoth Herman's sporting-goods store.
 
FLATIRON/UNION SQUARE
 
A New Space Age
 
 Large available spaces, rents substantially lower than midtown's and the decision of large suburban superstores to overcome their fears of Manhattan: Around the Flatiron, these were the ingredients of a throbbing blend of urban funk, suburban shopping and what is probably the city's hottest restaurant district. Bradlees opened in Union Square, and Toys "R" Us arrived, too. And in what could provide fuel for preservationists forever, a new generation of superstores needing big, uncut spaces reclaimed the grand old landmarked retail mammoths along the old Ladies Mile, Avenue of the Americas below 23d Street. On the restaurant front, places like Gramercy Tavern, Patria and C. T. were defining a new New York style of dining.
 
STUYVESANT TOWN/GRAMERCY PARK
 
Socially Saturated?
 
 In few areas was the nastiness of "quality-of-life" battles so apparent. People on Irving Place and environs, already feeling aggrieved by scores of social-service programs in the area, fought the move by a nonprofit group, Community Access, to create housing for the mentally ill on East 18th Street. When the bank that owned the building backed out, three residents who opposed the project were ordered to turn over their personal diaries, petitions and phone messages as part of a Federal investigation into whether antidiscrimination housing laws had been broken. Civil libertarians and others accused the government of conducting a witchhunt that would have a chilling effect on community protest. The housing proposal died in the courts last week. . . . Up on East 23d, residents had been exasperated for years by the legal system's sluggishness in responding to the situation at the Kenmore Hotel, where roving bands of
drug dealers took over entire floors, elderly people were robbed and sometimes killed and prostitutes plied their trade. Last June, the neighborhood's pleas were answered when Federal authorities seized the hotel and turned it over to private management.
 
MIDTOWN
 
The Disney Regeneration
 
 Since the early days of the century, the Theater District has been as much a territory of the mind as a physical location, a kind of pleasure center in the national brain, an engine of mass culture, theaters, television, publishing and music. That was before the area turned into a playground for prostitutes, pornography and runaway teen-agers, a concentration that left the city with an international reputation for municipal incontinence. Last year, the shape of the future came more into focus. The 42d Street redevelopment moved along as storefronts continued to empty out and condemnation guns were put to the heads of porn shop owners, opening the way, if the economy holds, for a new generation of theaters, offices and a hotel. The neighborhood's larger role as an office district -- serving law firms and financial services -- was underscored by the imminent arrival of Morgan Stanley and its 10,000 jobs. The new Times Square appears cleaner on the ground (up high, the towering Gulliver in the Calvin Klein ad would have astonished Ratso Rizzo), better lighted and better patrolled. And in a seminal move that could affect the tone of 42d Street for decades, Disney staked its flag on the New Amsterdam Theater, and MTV indicated that it would build a studio complex and a restaurant. Other entertainment folks are expected to follow. What lies ahead for the nation's psyche remains to be seen. But if Walter Winchell mind-melding with Texas Guinan at El Fey seven decades ago transmogrified into a national culture of celebrity, one wonders what new form will emerge from the mingling of an MTV producer with a Disney director and a Morgan Stanley analyst belly up at the bar at the flamboyant new hotel across from the Port Authority.
 
Celestial Real Estate
 
 Few topics engendered as virulent a debate as 57th Street, a boulevard with a rep once draped in Tiffany but now a noun phrase for $9 hamburgers and Tom and Jerry. With a Warner Brother's studio store, the Harley-Davidson Cafe, the Hard Rock Cafe, the Sony Arcade nearby on Madison Avenue and the coming of the restaurant Jekyll & Hyde, the street has alerted, among some, a deep atavistic New York fear of cultural colonization by Hollywood. Better pretension than superficiality, they say. Thumbing their noses at the critics, those desiring earsplitting music and coveting the Porky the Pig doll came anyway, helping Fifth Avenue to edge Tokyo's Ginza as the most expensive place in the world to rent retail space. As a further thumb-in-the-eye, the Hollywood Zeuses Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg were trying at year's end to maneuver into 20,000 feet at 120 West 57th Street, a place to park another Dive!, their Los Angeles restaurant.
 
UPPER EAST SIDE
 
A Private Affair?
 
So deep did the fear of crime cut, despite falling crime statistics, that an extraordinary idea emerged on the Upper East Side: blanket the area from 59th to 86th Streets with a security force of 500 guards and pay for it with property taxes raised through a special assessment district. Around the city, private security has taken on a much greater role in recent years, but this was by far the most extensive rendition yet. Propelled by the prominent realtor Douglas Elliman and such local institutions as the Dalton School, which had become unnerved by the increasing number of muggings of students, the proposal drew heated debate and exposed neighborhood divisions. Underscoring the particular brand of populism that holds real estate interests in suspicion in the generally well-off neighborhood, many block associations opposed the move, in part because of the image of elitism it would feed.
Opinion even had a territorial dimension, with the tonier west side of Lexington Avenue more amenable to the plan than the east. Opposition rested on several grounds: the elitist argument; the cost, and the worry that increasing private security would encourage the police to shift their resources to other neighborhoods. By the end of the year the plan seemed in grave jeopardy.

 
The Rail Link
 
The East Side found itself smack in the middle of a major regional question: plans for an airport rail link with a terminus below the old Alexander's building at 59th and Lexington Avenue. With Federal funds at least partially committed, the project would address the agony and expense of the sometimes circuitous cab rides from J.F.K. and La Guardia Airports that amount to an informal tax on tourist and business travel in the city. But many voices rose in opposition, angered by the prospect of adding to the already excruciating traffic in the area. With protests expressed along the route in Queens, the project raised the issue posed by those who fondly remember the authoritarian approach of Robert Moses: can a major project be built in New York anymore?

 
Footnotes
 
 East Side Republicans were ascendant, holding four of the six legislative positions, and with a favorite son ensconced in City Hall, phone calls were returned once again. Councilman Charles Millard, though, fell short in trying to unseat Representative Carolyn B. Maloney. . . . Zoning changes made it less profitable to build towers higher than about 35 stories. . . . Bar competition intensified, with themes abounding. "It's totally the place to party," one patron said of the Ski Bar.
 
UPPER WEST SIDE
 
Super Square
 
Is midtown moving northward? Already buzzing with traffic and pedestrians, feeding off the energy of the Lincoln Center fountains and the music buffs at Tower Records, Lincoln Square could never be described as sleepy. But the crossing of Broadway and Columbus Avenues began to emerge as one of Manhattan's most important centers of gravity with the first signs of three projects by Millenium Partners, by far the largest new development in the city. In total, 540,000 square feet of retail space is being built, including a vast Reebok gymnasium and another Barnes & Noble superstore, along with 600 rental or condominium apartments. Manhattan's largest movie theater has already arrived -- Sony Lincoln Square, with nine screens plus an eight-story-high Imax screen that shows films in three dimensions.
Perhaps lulled by the desultory real estate climate of the early 1990's and a body politic thirsting for investment and tax revenues, the neighborhood awoke late to the impact of the project. The bottom line: This new wave of development -- which also comprises Donald J. Trump's huge Riverside South development from 59th to 72d Street, the 1,000-apartment Manhattan West complex and Mr. Trump's remodeling of the former Gulf & Western Building at Columbus Circle -- could bring 13,000 new residential units to the area in just a few years.
 
'No Mas,' Liberally
 
There was no better gauge for the growing resistance to social-service programs than on the Upper West Side, with its long history of tolerance and liberal voting patterns. This year many in the neighborhood where Larry Hogue made his rounds decided they had had enough; some said even a midday walk with their children in baby carriages had a threatening air. At meetings, nonprofit leaders were shouted down with the same anger reserved for pro-war speakers 20 years before.
By one count, 80 social-service programs sat between West 90th and 110th Streets. Protests forced the Volunteers of America, a nonprofit group, to halve the number of chronically mentally ill homeless in a new site at Broadway and 101st Street. Fifteen blocks to the south, a plan to move homeless people into Euclid Hall also sparked protests.
In true contentious Upper West Side fashion, the Euclid opposition was split into three groups. "You must remember," said Joseph Levie, a lawyer associated with two of the groups, "that you are dealing with West Siders who can find an issue of principle about how they put on their eyeglasses."
 
Footnotes
 
Upper West Siders can be terriers. Seeking smooth shooting along Central Park West for a parade scene, the producers of "Miracle on 34th Street" made a number of peace offerings -- including a donation to the West 76th Street Block Association. "It's a very vocal neighborhood with very articulate people who know where power lies in this city," said Amy Sultan of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. . . . Major reconstruction work on Columbus Avenue caused major headaches. City officials said they might be able to finish the project a year early, by November.
 
HARLEM
 
The Scandal
 
It may have failed to capture the public psyche as the rebel-underdog Serpico did in the early 70's, but for sheer numbers and pervasiveness, there has been nothing else in the Police Department's 146-year history to match the scandal in the 30th Precinct: nearly one of every six officers arrested in what seems the particular brand of late-20th century police corruption spawned by the spread of heroin and cocaine: bands of officers stealing drugs and money from dealers. Perhaps because the victims themselves were drug dealers and some of the officers were actually considered effective elsewhere on their rounds, there was just enough moral ambiguity to squash a good-vs.-evil story line.
But the message was not lost on the department's hierarchy, which had to deal with the notion that such widespread lawlessness went unnoticed, or at least unreported, by the precinct's leadership. In fact two of the arrestees were sergeants, one of whom, Kevin P. Nunnery, was charged with leading an eight-team unit on a two-year binge of illegal apartment and car break-ins. The unit even had a name: Nunnery's Raiders. The department cleaned house and tried to mend fences with Harlem residents, but the reaction of residents at a goodwill meeting showed how far the precinct had to go: A longtime resident said afterward, "I don't think corruption is gone from the precinct, but I didn't want to say anything." She said she feared retribution.
 
The Vendors
 
In a local political culture built on a foundation of immigration, the idea of sweeping the streets of street vendors has always lent itself to soul-searching. But so congested have some streets become in recent years that when the city began toughening its stance, the body politic basically stood back and watched, with the few vocal objections coming from the vendors themselves. The Armageddon of this policy came on Oct. 17, when the police swept across Harlem's main boulevard, 125th Street, arresting 22 vendors. The sweep had wide support among Harlem's business and political leadership. The vendors were relocated to a lot at 116th Street and Lenox Avenue. Business, they say, is terrible.
 
Footnotes
 
After much deliberation, lobbying and interborough warfare with the Bronx, Harlem became part of a Federal empowerment zone that also includes Washington Heights, Inwood and the South Bronx. Now the hard part: what is likely to be brutal trench warfare over division of the $300 million in spoils. . . . Ralph Ellison, author of "Invisible Man," died at 80, largely unknown to the people in his neighborhood on upper Riverside Drive. "And it's a shame, too," said his postman, John B. Weaver. "He should have been king here."
 
WASHINGTON HEIGHTS/INWOOD
 
Wanted: Breathing Space
 
Around the city, rising enrollment and the budget crunch have put pressure on a number of school districts, leaving classrooms jammed and children learning in odd places. School District 6 in Upper Manhattan is one of the most crowded, complicating the logistics of education in a district with a school population that is 50 percent bilingual, the largest percentage in the state. The district's school population has risen from 21,000 to 26,000 in seven years and is expected to keep growing by 1,200 to 1,500 students a year. It is so crowded that this year 1,300 of its students were bused outside the district, some students eat in 20-minute shifts and some sit 37 in a classroom. Three new schools were ready to open last fall, to at least briefly relieve the overcrowding, but the money wasn't available.
 
Footnotes
 
A last legacy of the Washington Heights disturbances of 1992: the 34th Precinct was split in two, creating the newcq 33d Precinct, to appease community concerns and to better fight crime. . . . There will be new life at the Audubon Ballroom, the site of the assassination of Malcolm X. Columbia University is building a long-disputed biomedical-research complex around a section of the ballroom, on Broadway between 165th and 166th Streets, that will be preserved with murals to memorialize the Black Muslim leader. Also to come in the complex: a new incarnation of the West End Gate, the Columbia hangout down on 113th Street. . . . Younger residents and artists are moving to Inwood. Some have begun to seek leadership roles. The reaction of the locals has generally been favorable, though some think some of the plans -- i.e., the idea for a New Orleans-style trolley -- are a bit grandiose.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 7; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2336 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT;
Looking Back, Looking Ahead, Brooklyn

 BODY:

BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN
 
On the Waterfront
 
 Not an awful lot has actually happened there over the recent years, but the Brooklyn Heights waterfront -- or, more specifically, what to do with it -- is a perpetually, loomingly big story around the neighborhood. The reason, quite simply, is a widespread fear that development will mean losing the passionately prized Promenade view that ties the Heights's identity as much to Manhattan as to the eastward vastness of Brooklyn. 
 After years of stalemate, 1994 brought stirrings of a solution to the waterfront. The Port Authority agreed to sell the piers to the State Urban Development Corporation. Reconstruction began at Fulton Ferry nearby. And just before Election Day, Governor Cuomo announced the formation of a panel -- intended to represent a diversity of interests -- to come up with a plan for the area based on 13 "planning principles" drafted by members of the community and its elected officials. Around the Heights, a big question for the new year is whether the new man in Albany, the Republican George E. Pataki, will keep the process on track.
 
St. George's School?
 
 The St. George Hotel, rambling grand dame of the Heights turned S.R.O. (and source of much neighborhood angst), found itself the source of more neighborhood angst. The Board of Education, caught between its experimental ambitions and worsening financial straits, proposed making the St. George home to one of its new specialized high schools, the Science Skills Center. But when word got out that the board was planning to vote on the matter before presenting it to the community, the community reacted with outrage. Ultimately, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines withdrew the plan, citing concerns about the monitoring of the hotel's social services, among other issues.
 
Business, Big and Small
 
 The Giuliani administration's crackdown against illegal street vendors, greeted with such bitter resistance along 125th Street in Harlem, had mellower results on the Fulton Mall. With most of the 300 or so vendors gone from the mall, crime dropped, local merchants beamed and some of the vendors even began working with the police on a plan to set up a legal peddlers' market nearby. A grander effort to increase business downtown, the Atlantic Center commercial development near the Long Island Rail Road terminal, suffered a bit of a blow as the planned cornerstone store, Bradlee's, decided not to move in. The developers, Forest City Ratner, played down the decision, saying they were deep in talks with another retailer and would begin construction this year.
 
Express Mail?
 
 Even in a city where people have come to expect and accept less than speedy or polite mail service, the complaints were alarming: from downtown Brooklyn to Red Hook, people told of credit card bills never received, fruit that arrived three months late, a postal manager who suggested to a customer that complaints would only make service worse. In October, as part of a broad effort to put the service back in the Postal Service, Brooklyn got a new Postmaster, Antonio Corso, who promptly began cleaning house and promised to have the situation straightened out by January. Happy New Year, Mr. Postmaster!
 
You Say CAP-uh-Cheeno
 
 The coffee bar, the aggressively American knock-off of the Italian espresso bar, arrived with a vengeance in the traditionally Italian, and more recently young professional, neighborhoods of Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens. Some of the old-timers simply decided to go with the flow. "We've got 60 kids of coffee now. Two years ago, it was just two types: black and brown," said Frank D'Amico, who turned the back of his Court Street salumeria, D'Amico Foods, into a self-service coffee bar. But other longtime residents would not be moved. "They think they're trendy and new, but they're not," said Anthony Spada, a local real-estate agent, taking pains to point out that an espresso with steamed milk and foam on top is a "CUH-puh-cheeno."
 
NORTH BROOKLYN
 
Pollution, Pollution
 
 The Brooklyn Navy Yard -- polluted over the course of 150 years of shipbuilding, but newly returned to life as a busy manufacturing zone -- has long been a focus of concern around Williamsburg, perhaps the city's most environmentally blighted, and environmentally active, neighborhood. The year brought a mix of bad and good news, at least from the perspective of the bitter opponents of a garbage-burning incinerator planned for the yard: elevated levels of lead, arsenic and cadmium were found in soil and groundwater near the incinerator site, prompting a series of investigations and the revelation that the city had failed to reveal the discovery of toxic waste on the site six years ago.
The "good news": city officials put the incinerator project on hold, pending the investigations, which could also result in the site's placement on the state's Superfund list. And just weeks ago, the area gained an environmental watchdog: Barry Commoner's Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College.
 
Banneker's Blues
 
 The Science Skills Center, rebuffed in its bid to move into the St. George, was not the only experimental high school with housing problems. The Benjamin Banneker Academy for Community Development, devoted to urban planning and design, faced the loss of its lease in a dispute with its landlord, Pratt Institute. While Pratt ultimately let Banneker stay, the incident underlined the logistical growing pains faced by some of the new schools.
 
Vox Redux: Phone Theft
 
 What will they steal next? For Jean John and her neighbors in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the answer was long-distance telephone calls, thousands of dollars' worth of them, stolen by vandals breaking into the boxes that connect home lines to underground phone wires, charged to the unwitting customers. At first, the phone company refused to drop the charges; after calls from The New York Times and an inspection at Ms. John's building on Macon Street, Nynex and A.T.&T. relented.
 
SOUTHERN BROOKLYN
 
Strains of Immigration
 
 In the old and insular Italian and Irish communities of Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst, the strains of new immigration were apparent. In Bensonhurst, now home to thousands of Russians, longtime merchants protested the use of Russian-only store signs as "un-American."
In Bay Ridge -- where fears of economic competition from Asian, Arab, Russian and Hispanic newcomers has helped produce what the police and community leaders say is rising alienation, rage and violence among young whites -- the evidence was far more raw: a 40-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant was beaten to death in Dyker Beach Park by a gang of white teen-agers enraged over an earlier dispute with other Hispanic men. The boys, the police said, shouted anti-Hispanic epithets as they beat their victim with baseball bats and table legs. "Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst, you see craziness taking over kids of all neighborhoods," said Michael Vitale, a senior at Xaverian High School, a private Catholic school for boys. "I don't see a way of figuring out how to stop it. Not our generation."
 
Fast Road to Repair?
 
 The reconstruction of the Gowanus Expressway was still more than two years away, but around southwest Brooklyn, plenty of people were already plenty worried. The news that, under conventional construction schedules, the work and the traffic trauma would last 8 to 13 years prompted fears of neighborhood economic disaster and threats of legal action. Citing those concerns, and perhaps sensitized by public-relations fiascos elsewhere in the city, the city's Department of Transportation said it was trying to find ways to speed the process. A precise schedule and environmental-impact statement are due by spring.
 
Sheepshead Bay Memories
 
 In its prime, Lundy's was truly a seafood palace, the vast cornerstone of the bustling quays along Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, and just as its death in the late 70's became the emblem of the avenue's decline, the hopes of its reincarnation have long been the dreamstuff of the strip's rebound. Last spring, something more than talk actually happened: workers began a renovation that developers say they hope will bring not only a new Lundy's, but also offices and stores to Emmons Avenue. Another proposal, for a 27,000-square-foot Loehmann's store next door, remains in limbo, caught between those who argue that it would be a major economic draw and those who say it would destroy Sheepshead Bay's centuries-old maritime character. The store's first bid for a zoning variance was turned down; an appeal is in the offing.
 
Not Next to Our Temple
 
 It is far from rare for a fast-food restaurant to run up against local opposition. Traffic, litter, the danger to a neighborhood's character: These are the usual fears, and people in Flatbush made them known when McDonald's sought and received city approval to open an outlet on 18th Avenue. But this McDonald's also brought protests of a different kind: in addition to quality-of-life concerns, local Jewish leaders, including City Councilman Noach Dear, complained that the proposed location, just yards from an Orthodox synagogue, was inappropriate; they also requested Sabbath closings and a kosher menu. McDonald's, for its part, said it was eager to work with the community, but ruled out such concessions. The restaurant opened last week, with the standard McDonald's menu.
 
X-Rated Neighbors
 
 The citywide anger over the spread of X-rated businesses spread to Sunset Park. In the last two years, more than a dozen topless bars and sex-video stores have opened between 30th and 40th Streets and Third and Fourth Avenues. Residents have rallied and petitioned, and they see some hope in a City Hall plan to keep sex businesses out of residential areas. Still, the established businesses remain, along with the anger.
 
Footnotes
 
 More contention on the parade front: asserting its Irish, Bay Ridge held its first St. Patrick's Day Parade and drew barbs from the organizers of Brooklyn's original Irish parade, in Park Slope. . . . The wandering soccer field -- $80,000 worth of artificial turf that the Norwegian Government gave to Red Hook, where teen-agers promptly set it on fire -- was next offered to Bay Ridge, where the community board, afraid of congestion and general mayhem, decided not to decide till February or so. . . . One Coney Island dream actually took a step toward reality: Plans were announced for a sports complex on the old Steeplechase grounds. Next battleground: Albany. . . . In Gravesend, garbage dumping in vacant lots and along railroad tracks brought rats in droves. "They're eating good and they're housed well," said Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro.
 
EASTERN BROOKLYN
 
Redistricting Angst
 
 Drawing new district lines is one of the most delicate of political procedures. This was evident in school districts around the city, and especially in southeast Brooklyn, where the Board of Education, trying to increase minority representation on one local school board, ended up making nearly everyone -- black and white -- angry. Though the district, No. 18, in East Flatbush and Canarsie, is 72 percent black, only two of nine board members are. The central board proposed to rectify the situation by trading off schools with the neighboring district, No. 22, which covers Manhattan Beach, Midwood and Flatbush, to create two largely segregated districts.
Instead, the plan created anger and fear -- of programs disrupted and money lost -- as well as divisions among black residents: in District 18, many black parents said they opposed the plan's details but supported its intent; in District 22, which is 44 percent black but has no black board members, many cited a spirit of cooperation and said they simply wanted to stay where they were. "I grew up with segregation," said one parents' association member. "I don't want to see it again." Next stop: the drawing board. . . . A neighboring district, No. 17 in Crown Heights, was taken over last month by Chancellor Cortines, who said political infighting and mismanagement had compromised the education there.
 
After the Rebbe
 
 The death, in June, of the Lubavitcher Rebbe, Menachem M. Schneerson, removed a feeble yet powerful figure from the city's religious and political landscape, and brought grief, religious division and, perhaps most of all, uncertainty to the Hasidic residents of Crown Heights. Who might emerge as his successor? Is the Messiah's coming at hand? Would the Lubavitchers' political influence endure? One nagging and locally painful question was answered, though: the Federal Government decided to bring civil-rights charges against Lemrick Nelson Jr., the man a state jury acquitted of killing Yankel Rosenbaum during the Crown Heights disturbances in 1991.
 
In the Crime Lab
 
 Many years, the 75th Precinct in East New York has been one of the city's murder capitals. Last spring, it became a laboratory for some of the crime-fighting strategies that the Giuliani administration now says are contributing to a significant decrease in crime across the city. Among other tactics, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton poured in scores of officers specially trained to zero in on the two linchpins of street crime: drugs and guns. In a sharp break from past practice, officers were encouraged to tackle any crime they came across, rather than merely reporting it to a specialized unit. The initial results were quite encouraging: murders plunged by 31 percent in the first eight months of the year, and robberies were down significantly as well.
 
Footnotes
 
 Along Nostrand Avenue in Crown Heights, merchants reported that illicit gun dealers were going door to door, peddling revolvers, assault weapons and bogus gun permits. . . . Cable television came to two of the last frontiers -- East New York and Brownsville.
