The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 1, 1995

SECTION: Section 13; Page 6; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1690 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT;
Looking Back, Looking Ahead, Queens

 BODY:

WEST QUEENS
 
Invasion of Hunters Point?
 
 It is the closest point in Queens to midtown Manhattan, and therein lies what many consider this neighborhood's promise and others its possible demise. In September, ground was broken on the Queens West project, which is to transform a 74-acre site along the East River in Hunters Point by adding a touch of Manhattan to this industrial and residential area: a 42-story apartment tower, a four-block hotel-and-office complex catering to the United Nations, myriad parks and plazas. 
 Residents grumbled that the project would overwhelm the already congested area. Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey criticized the Queens West board -- representing the state, the city's Economic Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- as outsiders with no knowledge of the borough. "The attitude has always been that the agencies coming in are like the old Christian missionaries bringing civilization to the Hottentots," he said.

MIDDLE QUEENS
 
Prison for Glendale Vandal
 
 For residents here, "DESA" represented, more than anything else, an attack on this civic-minded community's quality of life. The tag, or graffiti signature, belonged to Robert Morrissey, 19, who was sentenced to one to three years in prison for spray-painting a subway station, and who officials said was responsible for $1 million in damage. Members of several civic associations that have struggled against graffiti attended the court proceedings and the sentencing, one of the stiffest ever for graffiti, said District Attorney Richard A. Brown.

An Insurgent in Ridgewood
 
 A fear of outsiders here, and in the surrounding, predominantly white, blue-collar neighborhoods of southwest Queens, gave a push to Frank Borzellieri's campaign for the 38th Assembly District. The Republican's platform included eliminating foreign languages from government-issued documents and banning from schools books he found anti-American, like biographies of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The Democratic incumbent, Anthony S. Seminerio, said he began campaigning widely after Mr. Borzellieri surprised him by winning the Conservative Party's nomination in what became the most closely watched Assembly race in Queens. But Mr. Seminerio -- a staunch supporter of the death penalty who voted against an expansion of gay rights and who once introduced legislation proposing that Queens secede from New York City -- was no liberal himself. In the end, Mr. Borzellieri got only 35 percent of the vote.

Fears of Crime in Woodside
 
 To many supporters of Mr. Borzellieri, this neighborhood embodied all their fears. Geographically, Woodside is a buffer between the stable white communities to the west and southwest, and the bustling immigrant neighborhoods to the east. The Brooklyn-Queens Expressway was once considered a psychological line separating Woodside from Jackson Heights's overcrowding, drugs, social clubs and prostitution, especially along Roosevelt Avenue. But these problems have spilled over into Woodside, and now residents point to a new boundary, the Long Island Rail Road station, which cuts Woodside into eastern and western halves. In October, three men robbed a club in the western section, and residents sought more protection. Police Commissioner William J. Bratton called it "a neighborhood in transition" and said, "We don't want to lose Woodside."
 
Zoning in Jackson Hts.
 
 In Jackson Heights and Corona, where tens of thousands of immigrants have settled in the last decade, tensions often grow between newcomers and old-timers. But recently, a two-year-old City Council law has illuminated an unusually disruptive problem: the unauthorized conversion of houses into businesses -- most often auto shops and bodegas -- on residential streets. It is a problem in areas with many recent immigrants from countries where setting up shop at home is common and does not require zoning changes and other permits. Immigrants from Central and South America make Corona and Jackson Heights stand out; nearly half of all businesses shut down under the new law in Queens were in Corona. Residents on streets with no commerce sometimes wake up to an altered streetscape -- an addition wedged between two row houses, a beauty parlor next door, deafening sound coming from a new welding shop.

Church vs. Elmhurst Elderly
 
 In this wildly ethnically diverse neighborhood, cultural conflicts can take strange twists. The long-running feud between the Christian Testimony Church and its tenant, the Elmhurst-Jackson Heights Senior Center, is proof of that. The fundamentalist Chinese church had long frowned on the senior center's dances and mah-jongg as scandalous. But the city-run center -- which has Chinese, Puerto Rican, Korean and Filipino members -- ignored the church, even though the lease prohibited dancing or gambling. With the lease expiring on Dec. 31, the church refused to negotiate a new lease unless both activities ceased. In November, the mah-jongg and dancing stopped, and about 40 Chinese women migrated to an Italian center for the elderly where mah-jongg offended no one.
 
Still Topless in Rego Park
 
 When Mayor Giuliani made his sweeping proposal in September to restrict sex-oriented business to relatively nonresidential areas, he was responding to a growing militance on the issue in places like Rego Park. That neighborhood's big fight came when Wiggles, an all-nude nightclub, opened last summer, just south of the Long Island Expressway. It became one of six adult-oriented businesses on a mile-long stretch of Queens Boulevard. For weeks, scores protested Wiggles every night. But the club remains.

Business Boom in Flushing
 
 Flushing continued to grow as one of the city's largest retail districts. The year-old Caldor's on Roosevelt Avenue became one of the highest-volume stores of the Caldor chain. And in early December, a 50,000-square-foot, $10 million food market called Korea Town Plaza opened, in a departure from Koreans' traditionally small businesses here.
The city also turned to infrastructure, repairing the damage caused by a decade of wild growth: it completed a $7.4 million resurfacing of Main Street, in downtown's most heavily traveled stretch. What's more, Mayor Giuliani pressed transit officials to restore $39 million for a renovation of the Flushing No. 7 subway station, even as restoration at 15 other stations was postponed.
The city also got a hint of the Korean and Chinese community's growing political clout. The Police Department had decided to move its Queens Robbery Squad and Asian Crime Investigation Team west to Long Island City. But Flushing's Asian communities, concerned about extortion and robberies by Asian gangs, protested the move. The Police Department yielded, and the units remain in Flushing.

SOUTHEAST QUEENS
 
Fire Worries in Jamaica
 
 More people die in fires here than anywhere else in the city. Also, wood-frame houses and aging wiring, especially in south Jamaica, combine to make this neighborhood No. 1 in Queens for commercial, residential and arson fires. So when the Fire Department announced in October that budget cuts would remove red fire-alarm boxes from sidewalks, the outcry here was louder than in other poor neighborhoods where many do not own phones. Removal of the boxes will start on Jan. 15.

Homeless in the Rockaways
 
 Ask oldtimers here to explain the Rockaways' decline, and they'll point fingers at the city, which they say built a disproportionate number of housing projects on the peninsula in the last four decades. Once a middle-class summer resort, the Rockaways now include some of the poorest and bleakest areas in Queens. So residents were outraged when the city Department of Homeless Services began placing single mothers in the Lawrence Hotel on Beach 116th Street in late August. The hotel, a longtime fixture on Rockaway Park's commercial spine, had housed the homeless for 11 years. But in 1993, a new law forbidding placement of families in rooms without kitchens emptied the Lawrence -- and neighbors believed that the disappearance of the homeless would help their street rebound economically.
The city returned the homeless because of an unexpected rise in people seeking shelter in late August but promised that they would leave after two months. Neighbors on Beach 116th Street took no chance, complaining and marching in front of the Lawrence, and the city kept its word.

Jamaica Bay Marsh Accord
 
 A bitter three-year battle between the only inhabited island in Jamaica Bay and the state Department of Environmental Conservation ended last fall. The agency had fined residents, sometimes thousands of dollars, for building decks, bulkheads and floats that protruded into the marshland. Residents said the structures protected their houses from tides and storms. In the end, both sides reached an agreement: residents can keep the structures and pay reduced fines, which will be used to transform an acre of city-owned land in the area into new wetlands.

NORTHEAST QUEENS
 
A Fresh Meadows Street
 
 Saul Weprin died last February, a much beloved political fixture of northeast Queens and a builder of consensus as Assembly Speaker in Albany. Councilman Morton Povman introduced a proposal to name 188th Street -- where Mr. Weprin lived for a quarter of a century and where he and his wife, Sylvia, raised three sons -- "Saul Weprin Boulevard." The proposal seemed headed for easy approval until opponents began arguing in December that changing the thoroughfare from a "street" to "boulevard" would create a four-lane highway with parking meters. The anonymous opponents began passing around fliers urging residents to attend a public hearing at which more than 100 loudly voiced their fears, to the dismay of Mr. Weprin's widow who also attended the meeting. Officials tried reassuring them that "boulevard" would not change the thoroughfare, except, of course, in name. But the residents didn't buy the explanations. And the proposal was put on hold.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT;
Looking Back, Looking Ahead, Bronx

 BODY:

THE SOUTH BRONX
 
Up From the Fires
 
 Depopulated to the tune of 300,000 people in the 1970's, the South Bronx became a national symbol of urban degradation and the city's neediest ward. 
 But fed on its deathbed by a huge housing renovation program sponsored by a mayor remembered as a conservative -- Edward I. Koch -- the South Bronx is now being presented as a survivor with fresh-faced tenements and growing pockets of suburban-style housing. Nearly 20,000 apartments have been refurbished, more than 2,500 new houses have been built for working-class home buyers and 2,000 more are under construction.
The pace of the momentum is being closely watched by those concerned that the lack of density of the new developments will fail to support the retail establishments necessary for a real boom, and that the first-generation homeowners, of moderate means, may collapse under mortgage pressures. There is also fear that the fresh paint and new kitchens can provide no more than a mask for the underlying problems of bad schools, unmotivated youths, drugs, crime and the AIDS epidemic, which is creating ever-widening circles of despair in the South Bronx.

Politics as Unusual
 
 Some of the city's rawest and most interesting politics are being played out in the South Bronx as advocates battle over whether housing money should be used for the poor or those with moderate incomes. There is also the city's impending decision on whether to finance a new police academy, the major public works project in the Bronx Center Plan, a package of revitalization efforts in a 300-block area.
Out of the recent struggles in the South Bronx have risen several intriguing figures. Perhaps only an area so desperate could produce such an unconventional leader as Matthew Lee, a 29-year-old building superintendent who grew up in the Boston suburb of Brookline and is drawing wide attention for using the Federal Community Reinvestment Act to force banks to invest tens of millions of dollars in the Bronx.
There is also the poker game at Yankee Stadium, where George M. Steinbrenner 3d is threatening to leave. The Yankees left ill feelings when a team official was quoted as referring to youths who hang on the area's basketball rims as "monkeys." Another affront was a state proposal to build a bridge over the Harlem River. Under the proposal, fans would not have to set a tire on the streets of the Bronx.

Felipe's Family
 
 If he can keep life and limb, Felipe Lopez will soon be able to finance part of the South Bronx redevelopment. A hefty pro contract likely awaits the basketball star, who honed his skills at the legendary Gauchos Gym and decided last year to use his talents on behalf of the St. John's Red Storm.
 His success overshadowed a subtler story of the South Bronx, an area portrayed in undifferentiated form to the outside world. His family moved from Mott Haven to Melrose in 1993. The nine-block trek north brought great relief to the Lopez family. Their new apartment is in a working-class neighborhood, rough perhaps, but a step up from their nightmarish digs on 142d Street. Felipe recalled one incident: "At I.S. 139, they've got a playground. All I was doing was playing ball. But there were always people selling drugs and people standing around in line for them. One time, this guy came out with an Uzi and started shooting. The guy selling had a handgun. I was out of there. You never know when you'll be in the wrong place at the wrong time."

CO-OP CITY
 
Come One, Come All
 
 There was good news at Co-op City, the largest co-op housing project in the United States. It rebounded with a surge in newcomers, even as longtime residents complained that the surrounding area was being overdeveloped. In early 1993, deaths and retirement had left 1,500 empty units, an all-time high in the 15,372-unit, middle-income complex. That same year, the Co-op City board cut the price per room from $2,800 to $1,750, and in August 1994 it received a state grant of $3 million to attract buyers. The efforts appeared to have worked: by the end of November, vacancies were at their lowest in a decade, at 579 empty apartments.
When Co-op City was built in the late 1960's, many of its original residents had just fled the streets off the Grand Concourse in the South Bronx. Co-op City offered larger apartments, wider streets and easier living in the northeast Bronx. It is no surprise, then, that longtime residents have bitterly opposed commercial expansion in their area. In November, a giant Kmart opened in Bay Plaza, a retail and office development just south of Co-op City, and it has attracted thousands of shoppers and cars. Residents are now rallying against another developer who is eyeing city-owned land north of Co-op City.

KINGSBRIDGE/FORDHAM
 
The Once and Future Bronx
 
 In the last year, residents pondered, declaimed and fought over the uncertain future of three landmarks in the north central Bronx. Nothing really linked the three -- except the timing of the debates and, perhaps, their secure place in the Bronx's history and their unclear role in the future of a borough in transition.
Loew's Paradise, on the Grand Concourse at 187th Street in Fordham, may become a center for performing arts after showing movies for 65 years. A task force is in the middle of a $70,000 study of the prospects for the Paradise, which fell on hard times in this age of multiplex theaters . After it closed in early 1994, its new owners, A.B.I. Property Partners of Delaware, considered turning the ornate theater into a shopping center. Local officials continued to press the Landmarks Commission to protect the theater's interior.
Neighbors of the Jerome Park Reservoir pressed their fight against the city's plan to build a large water-filtration plant at the site. The city's Department of Environmental Protection has postponed a draft of an environmental impact statement until next year, and is looking at alternative sites in Westchester. The project was first proposed in 1990 when the Federal Government mandated that drinking water that is transported above ground through a system of lakes and reservoirs must be filtered. The project must be completed by the end of 1999 to comply with the mandate. Residents say the huge plant would destroy the surrounding area of playing fields and the campuses of three high schools and Lehman College.
The last of the National Guards left the Kingsbridge Armory in the fall as post-Cold War military cutbacks padlocked the 77-year-old building. The armory is in disrepair. And the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation continued its study on how best to use the site, as various groups, from the local schools to supporters of amateur athletics, voiced their desires. A nine-story, red-brick structure, with two great towers that emphasize its medieval-style exterior, the armory covers an entire block, and was designated a city landmark in 1974.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL;
Speed Demons in Disguise

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
"BUT officer, the school Christmas pageant starts in 10 minutes, and my daughter forgot her halo."
This excuse for going 45 in a 30-mile-an-hour zone is unlikely to make much headway if you are driving, say, a swoopy new Camaro. But it might work if you are behind the wheel of a Plymouth Voyager, with the built-in infant seat and Raffi tapes in the cassette player. But, then, hardly anyone would be tempted to speed in a mini-van. 
 What's needed here -- and just about any place where discretion is the better part of driving valor -- is something subversive in a plain brown wrapper. The kind of car that auto enthusiasts call a "sleeper."
The classic of the genre is surely the BMW 2002 of the 1970's, a tough sports sedan with as much visual pizazz as a Ford Falcon. In more recent years, car buffs were drawn to the dowdy but rip-snorting Nissan Sentra SE-R, which has been discontinued. But by accident or design, auto makers continue to build hot cars in tepid garb.
Few cars will turn fewer heads than the Acura Integra GS-R Sports Sedan , a generic-looking Japanese subcompact with an appearance distinguished only by its tiny, goofy-looking halogen headlights. But the innards of the GS-R are testimony to how much the Acura line benefits from the trickle-down of race car technology developed by Honda, the parent of Acura.
Turn the key and take measure of the slightly menacing buzz from an engine that produces 170 horsepower from four cylinders displacing a mere 1.8 liters. Slip into first, ease off the clutch and before you can say "wow" the engine is shrieking toward 8,000 revolutions a minute. But not to worry: this power plant is built to run faster than any production auto engine in the world.
And the gearbox, with short, precise throws into the five close-ratio speeds, requires almost no time to learn to use well.
Getting from zero to 60 in less than seven seconds in the GS-R is a kick; accelerating hard out of a curve is even better. The tight (but never unpleasantly stiff) suspension, oversized Michelin tires and variable power-assisted steering make this light sedan (2,765 pounds) feel even lighter. Front and rear disk brakes, with a standard anti-lock feature, are great confidence builders.
Quibbles? Sure. The front seats offer fine side support, but nothing in the lumbar (lower back) region for those of us who are only young at heart. The power steering is a touch too powerful. And the high-revving engine is annoyingly noisy for interstate cruising, even in fifth gear. But, hey, where else can you find so much road-friendly technology for so little money (about $21,000, including alloy wheels and a very nice radio) in so modest a package?
Try a Volkswagen showroom. VW has just repackaged a blast from its past, an econobox with the heart of a lion called the Golf GTI VR6 . Like the GTI of the 1970's, this one is a visual ringer for the plain, bottom-of-the-line model. But unlike the earlier GTI, this coupe has a dazzling, 172-horsepower engine and a sophisticated suspension.
While the statistics on the GTI's acceleration and cornering -- not to mention the sticker price -- are in the same ball park as those for the Integra GS-R, the personalities of the cars could hardly be more different. The Acura is as austere on the inside as a school bus; the cloth seats in the VW flaunt a brightly colored abstract design. And while the Acura's suspension and steering do everything with utter predictability, the VW has a mind of its own: at full throttle in first and second, the GTI wanders a bit before heading in the assigned direction.
Once pointed in a straight line, though, the VW is the better cruiser. The seats are exceptionally comfortable, with plenty of support all round. And while the GTI is no Mercedes in noise suppression, the drone of the V6 is soothing at highway speeds.
Some drivers will no doubt be put off by the fact that the headlights are always lit when the car is moving, a safety feature that seems likely to make its way soon onto all new cars. But the GTI's only unpardonable sin is the paucity of interior storage: a passenger-side air bag displaces what might have been the glove box.
Sleepers don't all come in small packages. Consider the Ford Taurus SHO , a sensible front-drive sedan transformed into a hot rod for the 40-something set.
The SHO, which first appeared in 1988, is a triumph of engineering over bean counting. Ford replaced the Taurus's boring, home-grown V6 with a more powerful (220 horsepower) V6 made by Yamaha. Then it modified the suspension, tuned the steering for more road feel, added beefier tires and replaced the front seats with perhaps the most supportive and comfortable buckets available on any car.
The 1995 SHO (the last model year for this SHO, and for that matter, this Taurus) that I tested, like two-thirds of those sold, came with a responsive 3.2-liter engine and a four-speed automatic. The automatic adds at least a second to the 0-60 acceleration time and the extra weight is noticeable in cornering. Still, it fits well in a car that is likely to spend an hour in commuter traffic for every minute on open winding roads.
Apart from stealth, versatility is the key to the SHO's allure. When nothing much is asked of it, the car acts like just another near-luxury sedan with dual air bags, anti-lock brakes and room for five. But when the pedal hits the metal, it delivers the punch and the handling you might expect from a Nissan Maxima, along with a muted growl reminiscent of the big Infiniti Q45.
The SHO is hardly perfect. The Taurus's ubiquitous jelly-bean shape has been tarted up with a vestigial rear spoiler. The leather seats are a bit slippery. And the price (about $26,000, loaded) could be a deal-breaker. Still it is a kick to drive a car this good that won't draw a second glance from your stick-in-the-mud boss -- or from Officer Smokey.
INSIDE TRACK: For great engineering, go with the Acura. Those who like to walk on the soft side will love the SHO. For sheer fun, hardly anything beats the GTI.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Looking for the Enemy;
For C.I.A., History Is the Big Traitor

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The failure of R. James Woolsey Jr. as chief of American intelligence was a political horror movie: Return of the Vision Thing.
 After the dust cleared from Operation Desert Storm back in 1991, President George Bush, who had run the Central Intelligence Agency himself not so long before, could not articulate where he wanted to take the United States. And with victory in the cold war secured, Mr. Woolsey had no vaulting vision of where to take the C.I.A., whose sense of mission has wandered off the map and whose morale is lower than Death Valley. 
 Awful as it was, the story of Aldrich Ames, the mole for Moscow, was only part of Mr. Woolsey's problems. A bigger problem was that Mr. Woolsey, a lawyer by temperament and training, wound up becoming the combative advocate for the C.I.A. in the court of public opinion. And in these fast-changing times, the C.I.A. has been a difficult client.
 When the enemy lived in Moscow and his agents were everywhere, the C.I.A.'s tasks were clear. Now the enemy lives in places few Americans can pronounce. With a tip of the hat to James Bond, we will call him Dr. No. He might be in Tajikistan, a former Soviet republic, with 1,000 acres of opium poppies under cultivation, 2,000 loyal gunmen from Afghanistan, $1 million in a Swiss bank and a firm offer for another million from Iran in exchange for a small tactical nuclear weapon under lock and key outside Dushanbe.

 
 
Out of Their Element
 These are not problems for subtle, secret statecraft. This is not spy-versus-spy stuff. This is law enforcement, a task for which spies are ill-suited. A cop confronted with an evildoer wants to string him up. A spook wants to string him along. The C.I.A. can do this kind of work only in liaison with intelligence services it has either worked against or tried to ignore, like the Russian agency that succeeded the K.G.B., as well as America's own Federal Bureau of Investigation.
 Those liaisons exist, but the links are still weak. If it wants bragging rights as the world's greatest intelligence service, the C.I.A. must bust Dr. No -- and then tell the world about it.
 All year long, Mr. Ames himself and Mr. Woolsey struggled like Professor Moriarty and Sherlock Holmes, grappling in mortal combat to influence public understanding of the meaning of the Ames case. People in Washington believed the traitor when he said that spying had decayed into a pointless sideshow; they cocked an eyebrow when Mr. Woolsey argued that it was still a sword and shield for the United States. That Mr. Woolsey was more right than wrong mattered little.
 Five years after the end of the Communist threat that drove American foreign policy after World War II, no one has set the course for the secret agencies of the United States. That job properly belongs to the White House and the National Security Council. If they can't do it, the Director of Central Intelligence must. A hundred top-secret papers on the subject, offering various suggestions and written by graduates of the old school, lie moldering in classified vaults. No one has done the job. No articulate vision exists.
 What can the C.I.A. do that the Rand Corporation, Lockheed, Army commandos and the Brookings Institution cannot? Plenty, in theory: a C.I.A. officer abroad has freedom and power to carry out foreign policy through behind-the-scenes contacts when open diplomacy fails. But he needs the confidence of the White House and the State Department, and that has been lacking.
 The Director of Central Intelligence spends $75 million a day on an empire largely controlled by the Pentagon's military agencies, which have fantastically expensive machines that steal words and images from the ether -- taking pictures from satellites and eavesdropping on the world's telecommunications.

 
 
So Much to Rethink
 But the C.I.A. remains central, the sun in the secret solar system. Its analysts write papers on every topic under heaven. Its operators, the people who work overseas stealing secrets, spend their days trying to suborn the second secretary of some third world embassy. An extraordinary few save lives by telling lies.
 Reforming the agency would require rethinking a lot of roles. Seven thousand analysts focus on a thousand subjects; too often, the results are those of a second-rate think tank. Morgan Guaranty knows more about the Mexican peso than the C.I.A.; the bank has better informants, and its analysts make better money.
 Focusing on "open sources," meaning those that aren't secret, is self-defeating; newspapers, CNN and The Economist do that fairly well. Unless the analysts concentrate on what's truly secret, they will be a good-enough-for government-work research institute, which is to say second-rate. Today, a scholarly hacker can get more information about Russia in a day than the C.I.A. collected in its first 20 years. Most of what the C.I.A. had to steal from its old enemy is now free or for sale.
 That means the covert operators have to steal real secrets. The spies say they have been defamed as a drunken and debilitated boys' club, that they are perfectly capable of policing themselves and that they have an important role to play in a world without an Evil Empire. Whether they have sufficient talent to play that role is an open question.
 Some threats the C.I.A. can do nothing about: ecological, environmental and economic catastrophes. It can -- and sometimes does -- stop weapons smuggling and terrorism by rogue states and tribes with flags. Its highest calling in years to come may be as a global cop forcing people to check their weapons at the door of Western civilization.
 The Ames case was the endgame of the old secret war. The collapse of the Russian enemy, ironically, insured the old C.I.A.'s decay. That a slacker like Mr. Ames could flourish in the clandestine service destroyed what reputation the old school had left.
 So a vision for the secret agencies now depends on figuring out what really threatens national security apart from second-rate schools and cheap handguns and social entropy, how much of the threat is susceptible to spying -- and how willing American spies might be to learn strange tongues and improvise new roles.

LENGTH: 1333 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Epic Political Realignments Often Aren't

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Newt Gingrich and the Republicans arrive at the Capitol this week for the opening salvo of a rightward revolution they say will bring about the biggest transformation in American politics since the New Deal. Next target: the White House.
 To hear it from many Republicans, there will be no turning back. 
 "Ronald Reagan has been re-elected, not once but hundreds of times," Edwin J. Feulner Jr., president of the Heritage Foundation, declared in his 1995 "state of conservatism message." Each year, Mr. Feulner delivers such a message, but this year there was a note of glee in it: "American voters sent to Washington and the statehouses and legislatures of America an army of soliders who will fight to finish the revolution President Reagan began."
 Such expectations among Republicans are reminiscent of the hype that accompanied the Democratic sweep of Congress in 1974, after Watergate, and Jimmy Carter's election in 1976. Republicans were so dejected those days that Ronald Reagan and other conservatives went as far as to propose changing the name of the party to the "New Republican Party." And former Gov. Tom McCall of Oregon said his party had "made so many fatal mistakes it finds itself an endangered species at its own graveside."

 
 
Staving Off Extinction
 Just four years later, with the victory of Ronald Reagan and the Republican takeover of the Senate, some joyous Republicans with short memories proclaimed that Democrats were on the verge of extinction.
 Each recent election has led the victors to predict that their party had so captivated the electorate that it would lead to a realignment, with one party and its ideas dominating the branches of government and political dialogue for years to come. But the forces that move people and sway elections are always easier to understand years later than while they are unfolding.
 The current realignment talk seems to flourish not because there is a new yearning for Republican philosophies in the electorate but because people are yearning for change. Even though the nation is not at war and the statistics point to a vibrant economy, people perceive a crisis. The world is unsettled, and many people do not feel financially secure.
 As a result, Americans, increasingly impatient with their leaders and eager for solutions to pressing national problems, are inclined to invest more hope in what elections will bring about than may be realistic. They long for fundamental changes that may only be carried out by a years-long shift in party dominance.
 "It's not so much that realignments fall apart as that they are too eagerly anticipated," said Richard G. Niemi, a political scientist at the University of Rochester and expert on voting behavior. "We always tend to react to what's new in politics, to what's changed, because none of us is completely satisfied with the way things are."
 Martin J. Wattenberg, a political science professor at the University of California at Irvine and an authority on the decline of the parties, said the apparent seismic shifts in the recent midterm elections may prove illusory. "These realignments have happened every 30 or 40 years throughout American history," he said. "What people don't seem to appreciate is it's just not likely to happen again. The new political order is different. This is not going to be a partisan realignment because people don't have strong party loyalties anymore."
 As much as Speaker-to-be Gingrich talks of revolution, fundamental changes in American political history have always been more evolutionary than revolutionary. The most significant realignment of this century -- of the same magnitude as the rise of the Republicans with the elections of Abraham Lincoln in 1860 and William McKinley in 1896 -- was the Democratic triumph in 1932 with the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
 The argument of Republicans like Mr. Feulner is that the November elections marked the true finale of the New Deal era, an event that could lead to Republican dominance in Congress and the White House for years. "We've finally reached the end of the New Deal," said Harvey C. Mansfield, a professor of government at Harvard University. "This is the completion of what Ronald Reagan began."
 Mr. Mansfield may be perceptive. Or he may be premature. There is no question that the 1994 election was historic; there are legitimate reasons why it could lead to a full-fledged political transformation. The fact that not one Republican incumbent was defeated for national office or for governor suggests sharp dissatisfaction with Democrats. In the South, Republicans added greatly to their strength in Congress and state legislatures and are poised to add to their spoils. And while realignments usually come about with a strong leader at the top of the ticket, the fact that Republicans did so well in an off-year election may prove that something bigger was stirring in the electorate.

 
 
Eras Come and Go
 But what stirs the electorate can change quickly and unpredictably. Pundits and pollsters would do well to remember that Gerald Ford lost the White House in 1976 in part because he pardoned his predecessor, and that the luckless Jimmy Carter lost in 1980 not just because he faced discontent (and a telegenic opponent) at home but because a band of revolutionaries thousands of miles away were holding Americans hostage. For that matter, Harris Wofford embraced the health care issue to win election to the Senate from Pennsylvania in 1991. Three years later, Mr. Wofford was turned out, and many Democrats were undone by that issue.
 Kevin Phillips, a Republican analyst, said Republicans claiming a realignment are overreaching. "You could get a circumstance where in 1995 and 1996 you've got a Republican Congress squabbling with the Democratic White House and the heads of both of them, Gingrich and Clinton, have lousy ratings," he said. "That would set the scene for something that hasn't happened before: a simultaneous disenchantment." Rather than a generational dominance of one party, Mr. Phillips said, "I can see a real battle for the House from now on. I think it will be very serious in 1996."
 Some analysts argue that a more likely scenario is not a realignment to the Republican or Democratic parties but movement to a third party. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, Mr. Clinton's most successful rival in the 1992 Democratic Presidential primaries, is the latest political figure to seek a third-party candidate in 1996. "It's more likely that people will look back 50 years from now," Mr. Wattenberg said, "and say this was the beginning of a real serious movement for a moderate third party."
 But predicting realignments or political shifts is as unreliable as conducting an opinion poll three weeks before the election. Every recent election has seemed to spawn a political era that never came to be. Only two years ago, the election of Bill Clinton was portrayed as the end of any remnant of Reaganism and the ascendancy of Democrats. Only three years ago, in the afterglow of the Persian Gulf War, President Bush was on top in the polls and a Democrat in the White House was unthinkable. The cycle has come full circle: now, the prospects for a Democrat in the White House after 1996 seems unthinkable to many people.
 Republicans are determined not to squander the opportunity. But it takes more than a politically skilled Speaker or President to insure a party's continued dominance. So what will historians 50 years from now write about the Nov. 8 election?
 "Certainly, not a chapter," said Ross K. Baker, a professor of political science at Rutgers University. "Somewhere between a paragraph and a page. It will show a kind of broadening of a Republican beachhead."
 Mr. Gingrich believes the beachhead will become a permanent base, worthy of a book or even several. Clearly, he was thinking in epic terms when he decided to call his next volume: "To Renew America."

HEADLINE: The World: Auld Lang Syne;
A Toast! To the Good Things About Bad Times

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
In Soviet times, the real living room was in the kitchen, a cramped, dingy space where friends laughed, drank, smoked, sang, quarreled and talked intensely into the night, night after night. Back in the days when nothing was permitted, only relationships could really flourish. Russians cultivated those friendships with fierce attention, focusing their ample free time and creative energy on the never-ending conversation in the kitchen.
 Now the conversation has petered out. 
 For educated Russians, Communism's collapse brought freedom, uncertainty, opportunity and risk. For some, it brought high-powered careers, travel and money. It also took something from the nature of Russian friendship. And that has left many Russians with a hollow feeling at New Year's, once the occasion for celebrating friendship. Now, as the resurrection of Christmas steals some of the glow from the New Year holiday, the turn of the year has become a bittersweet occasion for burrowing deep into nostalgia for what was good about the bad old days.
 "So often I used to have dozens of people squeezed around a table in a kitchen the size of a closet," said Olga Kravchenko, a former school teacher who has begun a new life as an office manager for an American company. "And now I have a big modern kitchen but I don't have the time or the energy to invite friends to dinner."
 These are nostalgic times, and not only in Russia. Reborn nationalist movements in Europe and elsewhere celebrate some of the darkest moments of recent history, giving sinister new meaning to "Auld Lang Syne." Triumphant American conservatism often ignores the underside of the 1950's as it looks back for models of the future.
 In Russia right now, the privations of the past are sometimes overlooked in the longing for friendships eaten away by new forces -- long hours, demanding careers, busy social lives and, most of all, money.
 In Soviet times, work was low on most people's list of priorities. For factory or office workers, the massive inefficiencies of central planning meant that steel or concrete or paper were only sporadically available, so work was sporadic. For the intelligentsia, work could also be slowed and distorted by the byzantine whims of the Communist Party bureaucracy.
 There was no shame to poverty when only criminals and party officials were rich. Obscurity was noble when professional achievement was bound up with political compromise.
Dedication to one's friends offered far more rewards. So it became customary to put the demands of friendship -- the queuing to treat friends to scarce delicacies, the journeys through the bureaucracy to help get their children into a good camp -- ahead of the demands of a job. "Better to have one hundred friends than one hundred rubles" was an oft-quoted axiom.
 Now, when 100 rubles won't buy a subway token, time and money play a different role. Obsessive work habits are pervasive, soaking up time once lavished on friendship. And now even close friends are estranged by disparities in salary level and social status, the restaurants they can afford, even the toys they buy their children.

 
 
A Party for the Past
 On a recent Friday night in a downtown Moscow office building, in a vast reception room filled with shiny black lacquer furniture, some of it still in its plastic wrapping, a large circle of friends -- actors, former dissidents, poets, teachers, engineers, folk singers, gathered to relive old times. They did so at the behest of Sergei V. Korniyko, 35, a new millionaire, who watched from the back of the room, wearing a smile and a beeper -- a genial, unenigmatic Gatsby.
 Mr. Korniyko spent much of the evening in the next office, seated at a giant circular black desk, his two bodyguards seated on a couch watching television. Occasionally, he wandered in and smiled fondly at the shabbily dressed men and women talking and strumming guitars wreathed in cigarette smoke. "Back then I was nobody, just a fan among millions," he said of the days when he was a low-level defense engineer. Gesturing at the tableau of the Russian intelligensia, some famous, most not, he added, "These people were my gods."
 He explained that he wasn't giving these evenings merely for his own entertainment or ego. "I'm not holding a personal concert for myself," he said. "These talented people gave so much in the old days. They need a big space where they can get together again, and sing and just talk."
 Not quite. "We go for the free food," said Irina Mikhelova, a translator for an American broadcasting company in Moscow who insisted there could be no comparison between Mr. Korniyko's salon and the kitchen parties of the past. "The food is better, the champagne is French, but we don't really feel warm," she said. "It's not the same. It just doesn't work."
 Ms. Mikhelova said she had no sentimental attachment to the past. She said she found the 1960's nostalgia concerts she used to attend irritating.
 "I don't have time for that now, and I'm glad," she said. "Now we can go to an office, do real work or go to Cyprus -- our lives are so much more interesting than before." She too spent long, vodka-soaked evenings around a table, leisurely dissecting love and life. "Then, the kitchen was our hiding place, our only permitted pleasure," she said, adding with a harsh laugh, "How many years did we waste in that damn kitchen!"
 For Westerners fleeing their own workaholic world, the Russian kitchen had its own exotic allure. More than the Hermitage museum or the Kremlin, it was that cramped, overheated room, with its fellowship and capitivating talk, that drew many Westerners to Russia.
 "Life in Russia then was meager, but it had a different richness," said Ellen Solowey, who lives in Moscow now and has been visiting Russia since 1979. "You can't transfer that kind of hospitality back to the States. You were Western, so people wanted to know you. Even if you were nobody special at home, you were special here."
 That too, has waned. "I have fewer Russian friends now," she said. "The novelty of Westerners has worn off, and people are busy. They're hustling."
 Now there are Russians with exciting careers who say they sometimes miss the freedom of a routine, undemanding job.
 "On one hand it was a kind of slavery," Denis Yevstigneyev, a 33-year-old film director, said about the Soviet era, "but in another way it was very beautiful and comfortable." As he recalled the long, meandering discussions around the kitchen table, he was seated alone at a long table in his gleaming modern kitchen in an elegantly renovated apartment in central Moscow. He did have not a lot of time to talk. He was getting ready to fly to Paris.
 Mr. Yevstigneyev recently released a successful film entitled "Limita," a bleak tale of post-Communist alienation that explores the toll on friendship brought by sudden wealth. The movie is set in the harsh, sootily glamorous new Russian business world.
 He said that in his own life, money had riven him from old friends. "I can't say our relationship ended," he said. "I simply can't meet with some people. I don't have enough money to go to their restaurants. We go to different resorts, live in different hotels. There is a kind of physical separation. We don't run into each other."
 It was in the hope of breaching that gap that Sergei Makharov, a pianist's son who had emigrated to Paris and became an overnight millionaire doing deals on the Russian sugar market, contacted his old, friend, Denis Yevstigneyev. A young man with a grandiose life style, Mr. Makharov offered to finance his friend's film, and together they started a studio and conceived of "Limita."
 The protagonist, a computer hacker who becomes rich by helping mobsters rob banks, tries to cure his anomie by reconnecting with his former best friend. But when the good-natured, hapless friend is murdered by the hero's mobster associates, the film ends tragically.
 So did the actual making of the film. Sergei Makharov was found murdered in his apartment in November in what the police described as a probable mafia hit.
 Getting ready to fly to Paris to attend Makharov's funeral, Mr. Yevstigneyev explained, without irony, that the show must go on. Life at the top in Russia, he suggested, was lonely. "People are now dependent only on themselves," he said, "and that is the great burden of our time."

HEADLINE: The World;
In Europe, Touches of Leanness and Meanness

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
One of the joys of the holiday season for Western European salaried employees is something the Germans call "Christmas money" -- usually a whole 13th month's salary, sometimes less. Like most of the social-welfare benefits introduced to help get Europe out of its post-World War II miseries, the bonus is now taken for granted.
 You didn't get a 13th month's salary this year? You probably didn't get the 39 paid holidays and vacation days that Germans get, either. Even a first-year employee here gets four to five weeks' paid vacation, 20 to 25 days, often with "vacation money" thrown in. 
 Working between Christmas and New Year's is almost unheard of; then there is about a week of unofficial goofing off around Mardi Gras in late winter. There are so many religious and state holidays in May that most people think of it as an extra summer vacation month.
 Yet doing away with just one of the 11 legal holidays -- the day of prayer and repentance in November -- stirred such strong opposition among German workers that it almost scuttled the Government's plan to introduce a new system of social insurance to pay for long-term old-age care.

 
 
Ex-Communist Competitors
 The uproar was a reflection of a gradual and painful economic revolution under way not only in Germany but throughout Western Europe. The Iron Curtain once shielded these well-off, socially beneficent states from the continent's poor (while the United States helped shoulder their defense burden), but the end of the cold war has given rise to keen competition from the formerly Communist countries to the east.
 Just across the Bavarian border in the Czech Republic, wage costs are only a tenth of what they are in Germany, though the workers there are nearly as well qualified. And over the last few years, hundreds of German companies, small and large, have rushed to move their assembly lines eastward.
 Restoring competitiveness is on every politician's lips in Europe these days, and for good reason, employers say. If German workers had time off only as often as Americans, who have an average total of 23 vacation days and holidays a year, Germany's gross national product would be approximately $100 billion bigger, according to the Institute for the German Economy in Cologne, an employers' group.
 "If Germans would stop laying down their tools at 11 A.M. every Friday, we could create 500,000 new jobs in the next two years," said Klaus Murmann, the head of the German Employers' Association. Factories, he said, ought to be allowed to run on Saturdays if they have enough orders to fill, with the few workers called in for extra shifts given extra time off in the days following.
 With nearly 3.5 million Germans out of work, you would think Mr. Murmann's proposal would be welcomed. Instead, union leaders called him a modern-day Scrooge.
 Some people think Germans have forgotten what hard work is. Even when they are working, they work fewer hours -- 1,639 a year, compared with 1,904 for Americans and 1,888 for Japanese. And German workers make more money than Americans -- an average of $14.93 per hour last year, compared with $12.39 for Americans. Danes, Swiss and Norwegians make even more.
 Even the poorest countries of the European Union -- Italy, Spain and Portugal -- have the comprehensive systems of state-mandated health insurance and generous welfare and unemployment benefits, financed by heavy taxation that Americans keep rejecting as too onerous.
 The difference is that highly taxed middle-class Europeans believe they get something for their tax money -- first-rate public transport, such excellent public schools that private ones are practically nonexistent, universal health care and government-administered social security pensions that they can live on.
 But Europe is afraid that it is slowly pricing itself out of world markets. German workers are now among the world's most expensive to employ.
 When employers' contributions to social security, worker's compensation, vacation pay and other fringe benefits mandated by the Government or labor union contracts are added to wages, they cost their companies $27.18 an hour in 1993, half again as much as Americans, which is one reason why BMW started manufacturing cars in South Carolina last year.
 And even though European economies began a strong recovery from the 1992-93 recession and are expected next year to keep growing nearly at the 3.1 percent rate projected for the United States, growth is not expected to have much effect on unemployment. At least 18 million Western Europeans are out of work, and many of them have been jobless for years.
 European companies, like American ones, have been shedding jobs to cut costs and make themselves more competitive, and they are unlikely to take on new hires unless laws change to reduce the burden of social costs.

 
 
Keeping Up
 Americans have been undergoing this painful process for more than a decade, during which average income for most middle-class families has shrunk. Europeans are still used to annual raises that keep them ahead of inflation. When governments in Italy and Belgium did away with automatic indexing, or tried to in Belgium last year, the biggest strikes in years ensued.
 German workers agreed to wage settlements below the rate of inflation in the past year, but only reluctantly. The major manufacturing unions have announced that this year, with production booming and inflation expected to be only around 2.5 percent, they will go into negotiations demanding raises of 6 percent.
 The unions had already agreed to sacrifice a paid holiday to get the plan for old-age care enacted. German industry insisted that it could never become competitive on world markets unless it got compensation for its contribution to the cost of this new social benefit -- 0.5 percent of every employee's salary this year, 0.85 percent next year, with workers paying a matching amount. To give companies an extra day of production and profits, one holiday was eliminated in every German state except Saxony, where workers will pay the whole contribution themselves.

 
 
Less for All
 At a summit meeting in Essen last month, 12 European Union leaders agreed that all needed to reduce unemployment benefits to the point where it pays to look for work, to encourage employers to hire part-time workers and to try to insure that wage settlements stay below the rate of inflation.
 This is much like what Americans have put themselves through. European workers, who naturally don't want their standard of living to decline, are already complaining of erosion.
 Helena Bohne, an employee in a clothing store in Bonn, makes a little over $550 a week and sees only $360 of it after taxes, mandatory health and old-age pension insurance and state-collected church tax are taken out. By the time she pays her rent and her utilities, she said, she has $200 a week left.
 "I have to worry about the new deduction for old-age-care insurance and a 7.5 percent 'solidarity' surcharge on income tax to pay for unification with East Germany," she said. "I don't expect much of a raise in the next year, because business in the retail sales industry has been terrible. But our government seems to believe that the people at the bottom of the scale should bear the entire burden."

HEADLINE: THE NEW GOVERNOR: THE PEOPLE;
New Year and New Governor Create New Hopes

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The arrival of a new year and a new government is starting to tickle New Yorkers. Maybe it's chemical, like a low-grade spring fever. But the change of seasons in Albany seems to be stirring among many a feeling not unlike hope.
"You have to be optimistic," said Joseph Mechanick, 48, a plumber who lives with his mother and son in Flushing. "You get so depressed being anything else that you've got to hope." 
 The problem is, so many people are hoping for so many things. The list reads like a letter to Santa, jam-packed with everything from painless commuting and snow-free sidewalks to reinvented government.
Their expectations may become the burden of George E. Pataki, who takes office today after campaigning for Governor so effectively on the splendidly nebulous promise of change.
For many, the hopes touch directly or indirectly on their own lives and work. Clement Salama, a computer programmer from Crown Heights, wants faster, cleaner subways. Rocco Landesman, the theater operator and producer, wants Broadway to flourish. Robert Fenton, a retired purchasing agent from Williamsville, outside snowy Buffalo, wouldn't mind if someone on welfare shoveled his sidewalk.
Floyd Maines would like a better business climate for his giant food distribution company in Conklin. Ann Roberts, a pattern-maker from Flatbush, wants better housing and less crime. Larry Rockefeller, an environmental lawyer and a fourth generation heir to the Standard Oil fortune, wants laws more efficiently and effectively applied.
In interviews in recent days, New Yorkers largely expressed optimism about the new administration, even some who voted for Mario M. Cuomo. Some seemed to look to Mr. Pataki to restore their faith in the future, to make New York a place where their children and grandchildren could thrive, a place where lives have continuity -- the Empire State again.
At the same time, many said they would welcome a revolution in state government -- an enlightened re-examination of the role of the public sector, then a sloughing off of obsolete functions toward a leaner, more vital operation.
"They expect a governor who is a larger-than-life figure," said Gerald Benjamin, director of the Center for New York State and Local Government Studies in Albany. "This is a little dangerous because the expectation/disappointment cycle sets in too fast."
Some insist the time is ripe for change in New York. They say the political planets are propitiously aligned -- with a new Governor and an almost-new Mayor of New York City, both Republicans, in the one year in every four in which neither they nor the New York State Legislature is up for re-election.
It's the year that Peter Goldmark, the former New York State budget director and current president of the Rockefeller Foundation, calls "the year of heavy lifting," that phase in the four-year cycle when politicians grit their teeth and "know there is some heavy water to be carried."
Adding to the challenge, he and others said, is a sense of crisis. All three levels of government -- Federal, state and local -- are under heavy fiscal pressures. The economy, at least in theory, is already in a recovery, so there is little promise of a dramatic upturn in tax receipts to bail government out.
"It is very likely that in 1995 we are going to see people who got a tax cut at the same time they got laid off from a state or city job," said Mr. Goldmark. "Clearly, things are out of whack when that happens. I use that to underline the perversity of the intersection of political and fiscal forces."
Yet in that challenge, many said, lies opportunity.
"It's a moment in time when you can look anew at the way you were doing things," said Professor Benjamin, who also teaches political science at the State University of New York at New Paltz. "That doesn't mean that every alternative is smart. It simply means that windows of opportunity open."
New Yorkers are divided on how the state will fare.
Dr. Manuel Alvarez, 38, the director of obstetrics at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, is feeling optimistic: "Change, in whatever form, is good. People run out of ideas and it's always good to bring in a new crew."
But Tom Stoddard, 46, a New York City lawyer active in gay issues, described his mood as profoundly sad: "Change is not invariably good. This change is certainly not good. It's a sign of distress without solution."
As for their own lives, many seemed to be hoping for improvement.
Floyd Maines, 74, a business owner, said he hoped Mr. Pataki would lower his costs. Feeling oppressed by high taxes, utility rates and workmen's compensation fees, Mr. Maines said he could save $1.5 million immediately if he were willing to move his company, Maines Paper and Food Service, to Pennsylvania.
But the company has been in New York for 75 years. It has grown from a candy business started by Mr. Maines's father into a vast enterprise selling food and supplies to 5,000 customers in 18 states. "It's a family business," said Mr. Maines, whose sons now run the company. "You hate to give up your roots."
Mary and Ray Clapper expect tax relief, too. They own and operate Muffin Mary's Restaurant near the City Hall in Syracuse. They opened the business several years ago, after Mr. Clapper's employer went bankrupt. At age 61, they said they work 75 to 80 hours a week. They can't afford part-time help.
The Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, the president of Fordham University, wants strong state support for higher education. Reading the transition tea leaves, he is feeling encouraged. Charles Ohebshalom, an exporter from Great Neck, L.I., believes crime will indeed drop should Mr. Pataki succeed in reinstating the death penalty.
Even Esther Murphy, 70, a retired insurance-company supervisor from Flushing who voted against Mr. Pataki, is entertaining the possibility that things might get better: "I still have a little hope. We have to give him a chance. Because he's in and we're stuck with him."
Not everyone, of course, managed to muster enthusiasm.
Frank J. Mauro, director of the Fiscal Policy Institute in Albany, which does research on state and local finances, said Mr. Pataki's plan to cut income tax rates could end up hurting the very people to whom the idea most appealed.
Mr. Mauro said his group had watched New York State's top income tax rate drop from 15.38 percent in 1975 to 7.88 percent this year. At the same time, he said, more than half the state's counties raised their sales tax at least once, and property tax revenues rose twice as fast as income tax revenues.
Because the income tax is a more progressive tax in that it burdens the wealthy more, Mr. Mauro said the tax structure had become less fair. To continue cutting the income tax, as Mr. Pataki has promised, will worsen the inequity and put even greater pressure on local governments to either cut services or raise their taxes, he said.
"The rural counties have the most at risk from his plan," said Mr. Mauro, because income tax receipts come primarily from high-income areas like New York City and its suburbs, while rural areas receive the most, on a per capita basis, from state aid financed by income taxes.
Ester Fuchs, director of the Barnard-Columbia Center for Leadership in Urban Policy, suggested that Mr. Pataki's agenda would do little to solve New York's ills: "I might have some more money in my pocket, but I will find the quality of my public life deteriorating."
Khalid Abdul Qudus, 24, a security guard from Washington Heights, called some of Mr. Pataki's views "barbaric." He said minority groups, in particular, would suffer. Of the new administration, he said: "They're going to ruin the cities and there's going to be a lot of violence."
At least a few people doubted that anything would change.
"How can you take something so bad and make it better?" asked Anthony Smith, 35, of Harlem, a father of two who was laid off a year ago from his job as an overnight courier. One morning recently, he had managed to land a day's work handing out flyers on a Brooklyn street for $3 an hour.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin's War: A Troubled Presidency Stained Indelibly

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 31

 BODY:
As Russian troops enter the bombed-out center of Grozny, the capital of the breakaway Chechen republic, this has inescapably become Boris Yeltsin's war. It has gravely stained his presidency and damaged his reputation, and with elections scheduled 18 months from now, he is increasingly seen as a lame duck.
If Mr. Yeltsin's nose operation on the eve of the invasion, Dec. 10, was an effort to hide from direct responsibility for Chechnya -- or, as some liberal democrats here suggest, without any evidence, the Russian President was pushed into war unwittingly -- he has identified himself with it now. And it is not too soon to look at the likely aftermath. 
 While only 63, Mr. Yeltsin is hardly in the pink of health, and has had an excruciatingly difficult three years. Russia's painful, lurching transition to a semi-democracy and semi-market economy have ground Mr. Yeltsin down, eroded his popularity and stained his aura of political righteousness.
It was always a question whether he would run for a second four-year term in June 1996, or whether he was simply going through the motions, to forestall a precipitate scramble for succession.
As the former British Prime Minister Harold Wilson once said, "A week is a long time in politics." But there is a growing judgment that now, after Chechnya, Mr. Yeltsin will not run or, if he does, he will not win. Many politicians and diplomats now fear that he may cancel the elections altogether.
"Yeltsin has no political future," said Sergei N. Yushenkov, the chairman of Parliament's defense committee, a member of the liberal Russia's Choice party and an opponent of the Chechnya war. "Even if the situation improves in Chechnya, the most he can expect is a decent departure from political life."
Many Russians are grateful for the astounding changes and opportunities the last three years have brought, since the Soviet Union collapsed at the end of 1991 and prices were liberalized a week later. But Russian voters are no more grateful than American ones, and many Russians have also had a wrenching three years that have left them poorer, less secure and more anxious than even at the end of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's rule.
Mr. Yeltsin may have survived the moral stigma, however necessary it might have been, of shelling the former Russian Parliament building to defeat a revolt against him in October 1993, an act supported by Westernized reformers and liberal democrats like the former Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar.
But Chechnya, and the use of the military to crush Russian citizens, is a shame that is sure to linger. The Chechen campaign has already been too disorganized, messy and bloody to please many conservatives, who are appalled by the condition of the army. And it has alienated those same reformist politicians, like Mr. Gaidar and the economist Grigori A. Yavlinsky, who fear that the financial burden of the war and the political cadre prosecuting it may spell the end of economic and political liberalization. They fear new restrictions on the press, on dissent and even the cancellation of the elections themselves.
They see Mr. Yeltsin, like Mr. Gorbachev before him toward the end of the Soviet Union, as a captive of the Kremlin, manipulated by the military and the secret police, given, as Mr. Gaidar has said, a false view of Russian public opinion.
Georgi A. Satarov, a liberal-minded Yeltsin aide, defends his boss.
"There is a circle of people Yeltsin meets with, and it's quite wide," Mr. Satarov said in an interview. "It's a myth that he's driven into a corner."
But when asked, Mr. Satarov said the last time Mr. Yeltsin met with a group of legislators who largely disagreed with him was over the summer, at a conference of the Agrarian Party.
"To call that a mistake isn't the right word," Mr. Satarov said. "It's a question of political culture. Personally, I think he should do it more often, but he has an idea of the presidency that is not necessarily mine."
After the elections a year ago, Mr. Yeltsin clearly took stock. The ultranationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky won nearly a quarter of the party preference vote and the re-legalized Communist Party, with its Agrarian allies, did even better. But more important for Mr. Yeltsin was that Mr. Gaidar's Russia's Choice, while becoming the largest single party in Parliament, did not do as well as expected.
In the year since then, the democrats have done little to unify themselves in the face of a nationalist-Communist opposition. Instead, they squabble with one another. Even over Chechnya, members of Mr. Gaidar's party have quit because he has not opposed Mr. Yeltsin sharply enough, not understanding that practical politics may require compromise, and then call for unity.
Mr. Yeltsin seemed to understand that the liberal democrats were too thin a constituency on which to base the rest of his presidency, let alone win a second term. While trying to press ahead with some slower version of economic reform, on other issues, Mr. Yeltsin has moved more clearly into the "rational" nationalist camp, which he perceives to be the country's center.
Mr. Gaidar now says he is breaking with Mr. Yeltsin over Chechnya, but in fact Mr. Yeltsin broke with Mr. Gaidar many months ago.
"Maybe he still wants to be a democrat," a senior Western diplomat said of Mr. Yeltsin. "But shelling the Parliament, pushing through a Constitution with no debate and using the military in Chechnya without exhausting political options are decisions based on a psychology that isn't very democratic. I don't think he can win again, and if he doesn't think so, someone will probably find some pretext not to have elections."
Mr. Satarov thinks the state has the right to use violence when threatened, as in Chechnya. But he wishes Mr. Yeltsin had made his case to the nation before the invasion, not two weeks into it.
"When the state is waging war there's additional insecurity," Mr. Satarov said. "Given that, and our specific politics, it's a critical moment." He said that for Mr. Yeltsin, in Chechnya, "without question, his presidency is at stake."

HEADLINE: Earthwinds Balloon Takes Off But Is Back on Ground in Hours

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: RENO, Dec. 31

 BODY:
After a nearly perfect liftoff, the Earthwinds Hilton was thwarted for the fifth time today in its quest to become the first manned balloon to fly nonstop around the world.
"The crew of the Earthwinds Hilton has just landed safely about 100 miles east of the launch site," said a spokeswoman, Pat Godefroy. 
 The 370-foot, hourglass-shaped craft developed problems in its lower ballast balloon two hours into the flight and slowly descended into the Nevada desert, Ms. Godefroy said.
"We don't know what happened," said the search and rescue coordinator for the project, Phillip J. Conley Jr., a retired Air Force general.
Earthwinds consists of a 190-foot helium gas bag, a small compartment for the three-member crew below that and a 110-foot, air-filled anchor balloon on the bottom as a stabilizer. It cannot fly without the bottom ballast.
Mr. Conley said the crew brought the craft down in a "feather landing."
"The reaction was really a professional, test pilot reaction," Mr. Conley said. "They took all of the right actions at the right time to pull off an incredible feat of airmanship."
Mr. Conley and Cliff Robertson, the actor, who is the Hilton spokesman, were the only project members who would discuss the failure. Mr. Robertson said crew members were meeting to evaluate the setback and it would be several weeks before any decision would be made on the future of Earthwinds.
But, Mr. Robertson said, "We're wedded to a balloon going around the world."
The craft lifted off just before dawn to cheers from volunteers and well-wishers.
Mr. Robertson, who was in a chase plane, said the bottom balloon failed suddenly about two hours into the flight. The crew spent the next three hours slowly lowering the craft from its cruising altitude of 35,000 feet to its landing in a desert valley.
Two previous liftoffs from the Reno Stead Airfield in recent years were carried west by surface winds instead of east.
Today's failure was the fifth defeat for Earthwinds.
Strong wind scotched the first attempt at launching in February 1992 in Akron, Ohio, and sent the project to the Reno area in search of calmer weather. An attempt on Jan. 12, 1993, nearly ended in disaster when the bottom balloon brushed a mountain peak and Earthwinds came down in a snowy canyon in California 10 miles west of here.
A third launching attempt failed on Nov. 5, 1993, when an anchor bolt snapped as the helium balloon neared full inflation. And in January 1994, the craft soared into the sky but the flight was aborted after a crucial valve froze and its finger-thin control shaft snapped.
In a successful liftoff, the craft would soar about 35,000 feet to link up with the jet stream for an eastward trip around the world that is projected to take 12 to 21 days.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Earthwinds Hilton balloon descends to the desert in Nevada yesterday after having problems less than four hours after launching. (Associated Press)
