HEADLINE: U.S. Threatens $2.8 Billion Of Tariffs on China Exports

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
In the latest of an escalating series of confrontations with China over trade, the Clinton Administration threatened today to impose retaliatory tariffs against $2.8 billion of Chinese exports to the United States unless Beijing cracked down immediately on rampant pirating of American music, movies and computer software.
The move came after an end-of-the-year deadline ran out on negotiations with the Chinese Government, which has refused to close down 29 factories in southern China that churn out 70 million compact disks and other illegally copied products every year, at a cost to American industry that the Administration estimates at $1 billion in sales. American businesses are especially concerned by Chinese exports of these illegal products to other countries in Asia. 
 If any sanctions ultimately take effect, they may hurt a variety of Chinese industries -- including some state-run factories closely linked to Government leaders and their families. But they could also cost American consumers. If the sanctions go into effect on Feb. 4, at the end of a statutory deadline, the prices of items ranging from Chinese-made consumer electronics to toys and clothing will go up.
"We have to send an unambiguous message to Beijing," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, who has demanded that the Chinese Government create "strike forces" to close down the factories. "By the year 2010 China could be the second-largest economy in the world, and now is not the time to let them continue to act as they have in the past. They have too much impact on the world economy."
Unless the pirating issue is resolved, he said, the United States will continue to block China's effort to join the World Trade Organization, the new international rule-maker and arbiter of trade, which comes into existence on New Year's Day.
In the past, retaliatory threats like the one made today have often proved effective at forcing concessions from China and Japan in a variety of disputes.
But the record has been mixed. Two years ago, the United States threatened similar sanctions against China on the same issue, but backed off when Beijing agreed to pass laws to prevent the illegal copying of foreign products. But none of those laws have been enforced.
In the case of textiles, however, a similar threat from Washington accomplished the American goal of resolving a trade dispute.
The Administration's recent collisions with China extend beyond the immediate arguments over products like the videotape of "The Lion King," which was illegally copied and distributed in China even though it has not been released in the United States. They raise the question of whether President Clinton's decision in May to reverse American policy toward China, renewing its trade benefits without regard to its treatment of political dissidents, is improving either trade relations or human rights. The United States' huge trade deficit with China continues to grow, and repression of Chinese dissidents has continued.
In an angry response just an hour or so after Mr. Kantor's announcement, the Chinese Government threatened to meet any sanctions with retaliation of its own, including a suspension of talks on joint ventures with the big American automobile manufacturers.
"China will have no other choice than to take the counter-retaliatory measures against the trade retaliatory measures of the United States," the official New China News Agency said, quoting from an announcement by the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation. It also threatened to hold up applications of American companies and their subsidiaries to set up holding companies in China, implicitly suggesting that it would give an edge to companies from Japan and other countries that are racing into the Chinese market.
 Despite their heated reaction, Mr. Kantor said Chinese authorities also delivered a letter to the American Embassy in Beijing this morning offering "some criteria for further negotiations." But he said that the document had not been translated yet and he noted that eight previous negotiations on the subject had been fruitless.
Mr. Kantor acted under what is known as the "Special 301" provisions of the 1974 Trade Act, which covers intellectual property. The law requires that after an investigation, which can last up to six months, the trade representative must make an initial determination of whether a country's trade practices are unreasonable.
Mr. Kantor formally announced that decision today and published a list of products that will be the subject of retaliation. That starts a 30-day period for American companies to comment on the list, and to argue -- as many have done when similar action was taken against Japan -- that the sanctions will raise the price of foreign components, and ultimately raise prices for American consumers.
Although Mr. Kantor published a list of $2.8 billion of goods that could be subject to retaliation, the final list will likely be pared to something closer to $1 billion.
When Mr. Clinton abandoned his campaign position last summer that China's "most favored nation" trade benefits should be canceled if it refused to protect the rights of dissidents, he argued that his move would be good for American business and good for the dissidents. American businesses would no longer be handicapped by Washington's political objectives, and thus could compete on equal footing with Japanese and European companies.
Moreover, he argued, "commercial engagement" of China would expose more Chinese to American culture, American business practices and American technology, and probably be more effective in nudging the country toward democracy than any list of sanctions could.
But in the first six months since Mr. Clinton's announcement, evidence is scarce that the strategy is working. Crackdowns against dissidents have only worsened, and China has not followed through on commitments to let the Red Cross visit imprisoned dissidents to check on their conditions in jail. Nor is there much indication that Mr. Clinton's decision to back down has encouraged the Chinese to open their markets to more American goods, or to end the kinds of violations of American intellectual property protections that have poisoned commercial relations.
"I think it is too still early to tell what kind of impact the new policy is having," Jeffrey E. Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce, said last week. "It may be years before we see the kind of benefits we hope for."
The short-term economic impact of trade problems with China is already evident, however. In 1994, according to preliminary estimates, America's trade deficit with China surged to nearly $30 billion, triple the level in 1990. It is second in size only to Japan's trade imbalance with the United States, which is expected to break all records and exceed $60 billion for the year just ended.
China's restrictions on American imports are legion, and many go far beyond some of Japan's most protectionist policies. Because only 10 American films are permitted to be shown in China each year -- a restriction that has both political and commercial roots -- there is particular demand for bootleg copies. Mr. Kantor said recently that when a delegation of American negotiators and business officials visited Beijing to negotiate on the violation of copyrights, their hotel offered them, for a price, a choice of videotapes to watch in their rooms.
"All the videos were stolen off satellite broadcasts," Mr. Kantor said. Even worse, "it turned out that the hotel is owned by the Chinese trade ministry -- and they are the people we're supposed to be negotiating with."
Other American movies have turned out to be hits in China's "video cinemas," which show pirated videos. But Washington's complaints go beyond movies: illegal copies of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows operating system software are widely sold in small computer shops for a fraction of the retail price. Even George Bush's autobiography, which detailed his time as America's first representative to Beijing after the Nixon Administration's opening to China, was published in four pirated Chinese editions.
American industry, however, is less concerned about China's domestic market than its ability to export elsewhere in Asia. By some estimates, China can now produce 75 million compact disks, laser disks, and CD-ROM's -- the computer-data equivalent of CD's -- each year. The Business Software Alliance, which represents leading software publishers, estimates that its members lose more than $300 million a year because of Chinese piracy, and industry officials fear that the number will surge as more software comes out in CD-ROM form.
Chinese officials argue that while they want to stop the piracy, they have little control over it. Most of the factories producing the CD's are in freewheeling southern China, where Beijing's influence is weakest. But Mr. Kantor rejected that argument today.
"They seem to be able to assert control in other areas," he said, a clear reference to the suppression of political opposition. "There is a failure of will here, not a failure of ability." Many of the factories are enterprises run by the central Government or the provinces, and frequently they are closely tied to local and national political leaders.

HEADLINE: THE NEW GOVERNOR: THE OVERVIEW;
Happy Republicans, In From the Cold, Gather for Pataki's Inauguration

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 31

 BODY:
After 20 years in the political wilderness, thousands of jubilant Republicans converged on Albany today to install one of their own, George E. Pataki, as New York's 53d Governor, and to witness the first Republican inauguration since Nelson A. Rockefeller took the oath in 1971.
After a day marked by happy reunions and partisan pride, Mr. Pataki took the oath of office tonight in a private ceremony witnessed by about 100 family members, friends and political supporters in the drawing room of the Executive Mansion, the 40-room house he moved into on Friday night. Although Mr. Pataki wore gray pin stripes, the scene was casual enough that the eldest of his four children, 15-year-old Emily, came barefoot and in bluejeans. 
 At 7:22 P.M., Mr. Pataki placed his left hand on a King James Bible that his wife, Libby, gave to Emily this Christmas and repeated the oath dictated by his counsel and close friend, Michael C. Finnegan, who is also a notary public. Afterward, those in attendance clinked champagne glasses in salute as Mr. Pataki thanked his friends, including his political patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
"Senator D'Amato, you get up here," he said. "This is your home, as well."
Tonight's swearing in was designed solely to insure a seamless transition between Mario M. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki at midnight. The ceremony will be repeated on Sunday at a gala inaugural for 14,000 people in Knickerbocker Arena.
Mr. Pataki, a 49-year-old lawyer and legislator from Peekskill, spent the morning at the mansion rehearsing a 30-minute inaugural address that he said would focus on the importance of personal responsibility. Unlike his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Pataki is not known for his oratorical flourishes and he said his aides chastised him today for speaking too fast during a dry run.
Mr. Pataki said his speech would stress the importance of the individual. "That's something that I think we've gotten away from too much in government," he said at a news conference this afternoon. "We rely too much on government and not enough on the ability of the individual."
In the drawing room at the mansion where Mr. Pataki rehearsed, he had already removed the portrait of Frankin Delano Roosevelt, which Mr. Cuomo gave a place of honor above the mantelpiece, and replaced it with that of his own favorite Governor, Theodore Roosevelt, an advocate of both activist government and a free-market economy.
As they took over the offices in the Capitol occupied for 12 years by Mr. Cuomo and his staff, Mr. Pataki and his top aides showed the inexperience and wonderment of strangers in a new place.
To the delight of photographers, whose shutters clicked giddily, Mr. Pataki spent much of his news conference rubbing his eyes and picking at a nettlesome speck of dirt on a contact lens. His press aides devoted a good bit of their morning to figuring out how to switch on their telephones, and his counsel, Mr. Finnegan, found himself rapping on a locked door, trying to get into the Governor's office.
After the news conference, Mr. Pataki walked down the hallway outside his new office, peering up at the portraits of his predecessors like a schoolboy at a museum. Then he toured the ceremonial gubernatorial office known as the Red Room. Sitting at the broad desk that has been used by a long line of governors, he crossed his long legs and laced his fingers over his knee.
"This was F.D.R.'s desk?" he asked his aides. "This was his office?" Then he and his aides began systematically opening all the drawers and peering inside.
In his first official act, and one that would not take effect until after midnight, Mr. Pataki signed papers reappointing 10 appellate judges whose terms expire today. "Here goes," he said, as he took the gubernatorial pen for the first time.
The Patakis also took a tour of the mansion grounds, with the 6-foot-5 Republican inspecting the basketball court closely. As Mr. Pataki and his wife prepared for the weekend festivities, Emily entertained six school friends whom she had invited to spend Saturday night.
"The kids had a great time," Mr. Pataki said at an afternoon news conference. "They were running all over the place. For me, it's still a little bit uncomfortable. It's going to take some time to feel settled in. I'm used to living in my house and this is not my house. It's the people of the State of New York's house."
The guest list of 14,000 for Sunday's inaugural, which ranges from Mr. Pataki's Yale roommate to the disk jockey Howard Stern, will make the event the largest inaugural in state history. And with a price tag of more than $500,000 in privately raised funds, it is likely to be one of the most expensive as well.
The lavishness of the Republican celebration, which includes a First Lady's luncheon, a performance of children's music, a Roman Catholic Mass, a black-tie gala, and an open house at the mansion, stands in stark contrast to the austerity that Mr. Pataki has promised to bring to state government.
Perhaps more significant than Mr. Pataki's arrival as the first Republican Governor in 20 years is his positioning as the first fiscally conservative Governor in recent state history. He has pledged to cut state income tax rates by 25 percent during his four-year term, to streamline a state bureaucracy of 242,000 workers and to make vast changes in the state's welfare system. He has also said he will restore the death penalty by signing the bill that Mr. Cuomo and his predecessor, Hugh L. Carey, had vetoed every year since 1977.
Mr. Pataki will begin to outline his plans for cutting state spending in the next four days, first in broad terms in his inaugural address on Sunday and then in more detail in his State of the State speech to the Legislature on Wednesday.
Mr. Pataki's inauguration signifies a remarkable transformation of Republican fortunes in New York. Four years ago, the party was deep in debt after a hapless gubernatorial campaign by Pierre A. Rinfret. Today the Republicans control the governorship, the State Senate and New York City's mayoralty.
"I just don't think it gets much better than this," said William D. Powers, the state Republican chairman.
The rank-and-file clearly agreed. "My feeling is jubilation," said Ruton Beauter, a 57-year-old insurance salesman from Owego, who was on his way to witness the swearing in of Dennis C. Vacco as the new Attorney General in the Capitol. "It's exciting and hopefully we can after 20 years be able to get back to what we once were in New York State." His friend, Charles Farrell, a town official from Tioga, chimed in: "100 percent."

Pataki took the oath of office in a private ceremony in the Executive Mansion last night. While Mr. Pataki's wife, Libby, held a family Bible, his counsel, Michael C. Finnegan, right, administered the oath. On the left are the couple's children, along with other friends and supporters. (Associated Press) (pg. 33)

HEADLINE: THE NEW GOVERNOR;
Assembling an Administration: Old Friends, Campaign Comrades

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
George E. Pataki begins his term today as the 53d Governor of New York with a team of top advisers who were mostly outsiders to state government. Of the appointments Mr. Pataki has made so far, only one, a holdover from his Democratic predecessor, has held a top position in the New York State executive branch.
Instead, Mr. Pataki has turned to a mixture of old friends, local officials, campaign comrades, business people and associates from the Republican minority in Assembly. He recruited two aides -- his budget director and health commissioner -- from out of state. 
 Another constituency reflected in the new administration are those close to Mr. Pataki's political patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Three advisors, including his directors of economic development and of communications, are D'Amato associates.
Mr. Pataki has also taken the untraditional step of making two appointments for only 90 days: He says he recruited Mary E. Glass as commissioner of Social Services and James F. Gill as director of Employee Relations to accomplish the specific tasks of reforming welfare and negotiating with state workers. IAN FISHER

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
The Night Hunter Made History

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The last of 360 checks for $4,166.67 arrived a couple of weeks ago. One college education provided by a $25,000 annuity policy has been completed; another paid for by the other $25,000 annuity is nearly completed. A third child is a few years away from college, but who knew to ask for an annuity to be named later?
Who knew anything that would come later, after Jim (Catfish) Hunter, free agent, signed with the Yankees 20 years ago last night? 
 "It really was the beginning of the turmoil in baseball's economy," said Peter Bavasi, who as general manager of the San Diego Padres pursued Hunter and thought he had him. "It was the defining moment. If you say how did we get here, how did we get into this mess, a mess that apparently will be solved by legions of lawyers, it happened in Ahoskie, North Carolina, 20 years ago."
Catfish Hunter and his wife, Helen, live in the same house in the tiny town of Hertford, N.C., that they lived in 20 years ago. But the 100 acres of farmland they had then has grown to a sprawling 1,000 acres of farmland and other land.
"It will take over for the payments from the Yankees," said Hunter, now 48 years old and 15 years retired. But he added, updating his resume: "I'm not a full-time farmer anymore. For 10 years I was. I got out of it and turned it over to a friend, who leases my land. I help him some. Mostly I work with Upjohn doing things for them on diabetes. And I work with the baseball alumni."
The monthly payments from the Yankees were part of the $3.1 million package they gave him that memorable New Year's Eve in 1974. Under a provision that would pay him $100,000 a year deferred for 15 years, Hunter received $4,166.67 on the first and 15th of each month beginning Jan. 1, 1980.
The end of the payout period, occurring simultaneously with the owners' implementation of the disputed salary cap, marks an end to the first phase of baseball's freedom era.
The period technically didn't start with Hunter's free agency; that came a year later in the Messersmith-McNally case with the decision by the same arbitrator, Peter Seitz, who declared Hunter free in a breach-of-contract grievance. But Hunter's experience demonstrated to his fellow players what the owners really thought they were worth.
"It served as a wonderful demonstration that players should be paid a lot more than they had been paid," said Richard Moss, who as the Players Association's general counsel argued and won both cases. "The fact that a player who was a free agent could make so much more than if he were confined to one club was a lesson to the players."
In 1974, Hunter had a $100,000 salary with the Oakland Athletics. Bavasi recalled that the Padres thought they could get him with that same salary for each of four years. By the time 23 of the-then 24 major league clubs had sent representatives to Ahoskie or telephoned the pitcher's lawyers there, the price was just shy of $4 million for five years.
The pursuit of baseball's first legitimate star free agent, one who had won 25 games and the Cy Young award that year, shattered the rural serenity that had previously enveloped Ahoskie, a town 60 miles west of Hertford, which is about 70 miles south of Norfolk, Va.
"Gene Autry came down here handing out records of 'Rudolph the Rednose Reindeer,' " Hunter recalled of the California Angels' owner. "That was the biggest thing that ever came to Ahoskie."
Included in the financial package Hunter wanted were the $25,000 payments for annuities for college tuition for Todd, then 5 years old, and Kimberly, 2. Paul was five years away from being born ("I forgot I might have one more after baseball," Hunter said. "I have to pay for him myself.")
When the annuities were being discussed, Bill Posedel, Hunter's first pitching coach, who accompanied Bavasi, looked at his old student and said, "Pal, with what you're going to get, you can buy a small university."
But the Yankees had their own early link to Hunter. Clyde Kluttz, one of their scouts, had signed Hunter to his first professional contract, lived in North Carolina and had remained close to the pitcher. Kluttz was instrumental in luring Hunter to New York even though the Yankees offered nearly $1 million less than the Padres.
Actually, by the time the Yankees became serious about wanting to sign Hunter, Bavasi thought he had a deal. J. Carlton Cherry, one of Hunter's lawyers, seemed to think so, too, though he apparently was looking for an honorable way out.
In a conference call, Bavasi related, one of the Padres' lawyers said there was one thing more. Ray Kroc, the team's owner, who also owned McDonald's, wanted Hunter to serve as the McDonald's spokesman in the Southeast.
Seizing the opportunity, Bavasi said, Cherry yelled: "That's impossible! My client doesn't smoke or drink or dissipate. The deal is off."
Then he turned to the Yankees and negotiated the deal that was finally completed after 8 o'clock on New Year's Eve 20 years ago.
 
Too Much for Too Many
 From the perspective of the player who gained baseball's first multimillion-dollar contract, the attitude of the players 20 years later is alien.
"When Mays and Mantle were making $100,000 or $120,000 or $150,000, something like that, you knew you weren't going to make that much," Catfish Hunter, the Hall of Famer, said. "They were the cream of the crop. But now they act like everybody should make the same. The way guys live now they'd need a million dollars a year to live."
Hunter has always been an unassuming, unpretentious man who did not let his rich contract keep him off his tractor and away from his peanut fields. Whether he had earned $10,000 or $100,000 a year, he would have been the same person.
"Like Clyde Kluttz, who signed me twice, told me," Hunter related. "He says when you're playing baseball, you're making a lot of money, you're going to spend a lot of money, but when you get out, that money isn't going be coming in. You better make sure all your payments are paid up and don't have any left because you won't be making the money."
Having followed that advice, Hunter can only shake his head at the players who live as if they need $1 million just for starters.
 
Tales of Two Stars
 Strike-breaking stories of the week:
A former player who lives in the San Francisco area said he heard that Barry Bonds planned to go to spring training, strike or no strike. Bonds declined a request for an opportunity to respond, but his agent, Dennis Gilbert, vehemently denied that the game's highest-paid player harbors any such thought.
"He's indicated quite the contrary," Gilbert said. "He's going to support the union. Remember, he's got a father who's a former player. That's just so far from the truth. People love to start this stuff. Why would people say that? That's so offensive. It's not the truth. I talk to Barry quite often. Barry is supportive to the union's position."
Whether or not anyone in the union has told Cal Ripken he may play in replacement-player games to keep alive his consecutive-game streak now at 2,009, a Houston pitcher, Todd Jones, was quoted as saying that Ripken has said he intends to remain on strike with the rest of the players.
He hasn't said anything about it recently, but at a meeting in New York in September, the Baltimore shortstop said, "If it's replacement players, it's not major league baseball and I won't be playing."
Greg Swindell, another Astros pitcher, said he would consider playing even if the strike continued. "I've got house payments, I've got ex-wife payments, I've got a 5-year-old, a 3-year-old and a 7-week-old," Swindell said.
Everyone who ever has been on strike has expressed concern about similar economic problems, but probably more often than not, the strikers are workers who earn about $25,000 a year. Swindell has earned $7 million the last two years.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 8; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 523 words

HEADLINE: The Quality of Mercy in 1995

 BODY:
Just over a decade ago, Walter Mondale spoke honorably in a losing Presidential campaign of the need for fairness in Government policy. Democrats in those days talked about the "compassion gap" in a Reagan Administration that conceived of budget cutting mainly as an exercise in taking from the poor. By 1988 the Republican candidate, George Bush, was talking of blending fiscal stringency with a caring heart. The election of Bill Clinton in 1992 seemed a declaration that Americans wanted a government that lifted the needy instead of punishing them.
 But as 1995 dawns, a new band of hard-talking officeholders and social engineers has created a compassion crisis in American political life. Their political energy flows in part from the well-crafted fiction, originally promulgated under President Reagan, that the wealthy are embattled. In fact, of course, wealthy Americans have never been more numerous or more cosseted by Congress, the executive branch and the Federal Reserve Board. 
 Another fiction is that the American people themselves no longer believe in acts of pure mercy toward the powerless and instead want to adopt group punishment as a thematic principle of welfare policy. How else to explain the idea of withdrawing all aid from an infant whose mother does not meet Congressionally mandated rules as to work and sexual behavior?
 In the new anti-compassion demagoguery, anyone who does not embrace primitive remedies is accused of endorsing the imperfections of current policy. But the public-opinion polls show that the American people are not as simplistic as those who propose to speak for them.
 There is, indeed, a decline in support for increased spending on aid to minorities and the unemployed. But a New York Times/CBS News poll found that a majority still favored increased spending for helping the homeless and AIDS victims, for health care, for worker retraining. A Time/CNN poll found that while 78 percent favored welfare reform, a majority opposed ending payments to the destitute after two years. The poll also found that 69 percent would agree to spend more in the short run if that is what it took to get welfare reform started.
 American voters, to be sure, want more efficient social spending and a return to bedrock values of family and community. But one of those values is compassion. Ideologues who cruelly argue that reform means that the majority culture must make war on the underclass are misreading the mood of nearly everyone else.
 Time also reported that Representative Newt Gingrich has called in a psychotherapist to coach the new Congressional majority on how to promote their reforms without looking cruel. Perhaps their dialogue will touch on the fact that the great American leaders of the 20th century have depended on inspiration, not punishment, as their core principle.
 True, the rhetoric of human kindness is out of fashion right now. Those who speak for the old humanitarian ideals are in retreat in Congress and shouted into silence on the talk shows. But that will change in time, or else 1995 will be remembered as the bleak start of a bleak epoch.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Come The Revolution

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Today marks the return of the "Foreign Affairs" column to The New York Times. "Foreign Affairs" is actually the paper's oldest column. It was begun in 1937 by the remarkable Anne O'Hare McCormick and was originally called "In Europe." In those days "In Europe" was foreign affairs for most Americans, and it seemed perfectly natural that the paper's one overseas columnist was rooted on the European Continent. Mrs. McCormick's 1954 obituary in The Times said she got her start in foreign reporting "as the wife of Mr. McCormick, a Dayton engineer whom she accompanied on frequent buying trips to Europe."
 Obviously, I was born in a very different era, one in which columnists only have to accompany their curiosity and engineers travel to Tokyo for buying trips, not Paris. Both factors have led me to start my column from Japan. While I have no intention of calling my column "In Asia," the thought did cross my mind. Let's face it, when the history of the late 20th century is written, the most important event may not be the reconstruction of Europe, the cold war or the collapse of Communism, but rather the rapid modernization in one generation of two billion people from Japan to the border of India. Never have so many raised their standard of living so far so fast. 
I was recently in Singapore when its Government decided that to keep attracting top-quality Cabinet ministers, it would pay them a percentage of the average salary of the country's senior doctors, bankers and C.E.O.'s. That came to $765,000 a year for the Prime Minister and $400,000 for the others. No wonder an American diplomat in Hong Kong told me: "I go to parties here and without fail I am the poorest person at every event. The BMW's and Rolls-Royces roll in one after the other, and then I show up with my little Japanese car. During my first tour here a decade ago, I felt like Gulliver among the Lilliputians. We represented the future. Now I feel like I am brought along to parties as a potted plant for adornment."
 Yet, Walter Mondale, our Ambassador to Japan, complains that many American business, educational and news organizations "still don't get it, still don't grasp how rich and dynamic this region is." He should know. The historic American ambassador's residence in Tokyo is being restored by a Japanese construction company because there were no American contractors here skilled enough to do the delicate job. A new study by the Mansfield Center found that there is still four times as much news about America on Japanese television as news of Japan on American television.
 But if we are still smug about Asians, always waiting for their bubble to burst, it is nothing compared with their smugness toward America. They think they can defy the laws of gravity -- that economic consequences won't have political consequences. You can't have a conversation in Asia without being verbally caned over how flawed America has become and how superior is the "Asian Way." Their smugness, though, is as misplaced as ours.
 How long can Asian governments keep their people so regimented and focused on export growth when their middle classes are growing so wealthy? Take Singapore. Thanks to its heavy-handed Government, it is clean, rich and seriously boring. Singapore is a shopping mall with passport controls. Any wonder American televangelists and Oprah Winfrey are increasingly popular out there?
 How long can Japan's Government keep telling its youth that they have to accept lower wages and live in apartments as big as my garage so that Japanese companies can put all their profits into expanding markets abroad? How long will Japanese consumers pay $70 for a watermelon because Japan protects its highly inefficient food industry from foreign competition?
 How long is China's leadership, the smuggest of all since it forced President Clinton to eat crow on human rights, going to be able to keep the lid on a country that is economically becoming North Carolina and politically still North Korea? And how long will Asians tolerate the fact that the economic boom has left them with five of the seven most polluted cities in the world?
 The answer to all of the above is: not much longer, and that's why I chose to start here. Asia is not only going to be the world's biggest business story in the coming years. The economic revolution here is well under way, but the political revolution has just begun.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1395 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary

 BODY:

It Makes Perfect Sense to Be a Good Neighbor
 
Looking at it from a coldly practical angle, this nation can't afford to have the Mexican economy fall apart. Just as a ramshackle house stains a whole neighborhood, a tattered Mexico would be a big headache for its mighty cousin to the north. So it made total sense last week when Washington decided to pump billions into Mexico to prop up the battered peso. And President Ernesto Zedillo soon saw the necessity of some falling on swords, accepting the resignation of his Finance Minister, Jaime Serra Puche, whose prints were all over the currency mess. Mr. Zedillo also announced a drastic emergency plan, including deep concessions from labor, big spending cuts and a slowdown of economic growth. As it happens, Mr. Serra's replacement, Guillermo Ortiz Martinez, tried in the fall to show the need for an orderly devaluation, but no one listened. They are now.
 
Give and It Shall Be Taken
 
From Britain, today's lesson: Never, ever underestimate the public's willingness to take full advantage of anything that's free. A mobile-phone company called Mercury One-2-One wanted a catchy promotion for its "personal communications services" -- it's among the first in the world to offer this radio-wave-based phone technology -- so it offered free calls on Christmas for new subscribers. What it no doubt figured on: customers merrily making a few calls to relatives, then getting back to the day's festivities. What it got: jammed lines, 10 times normal volume, 12-hour international calls, some people making 100 calls, others not able to get through at all. In short, chaos.
 
Japan's Humbled Self-Image
 
Japan strikes a bit less terror in American hearts these days, and even the Japanese admit that their mighty economic machine has been badly humbled. Just three years ago, 53 percent of Japanese said they expected Japan to lead the world economic pack for quite a while. A recent poll shows, though, that that's plummeted to 25 percent. And what's the next powerhouse? A big difference of opinion on that one -- fully a quarter of the Japanese, but a scant 4 percent of Americans, picked China. One feeling persists in Japan, though: 83 percent of Japanese believe their blue-collar workers work harder than Americans -- and that number's held pretty steady.
 
Mr. Pataki Seems to Mean It
 
George Pataki sent some powerful signals last week that he is dead serious about his economic vision for New York. First he named a new budget director, Patricia Woodworth, who as Michigan's budget director has zeroed in on cutting taxes and state spending. A key item on her resume: Michigan's move this year to end local schools' dependence on property taxes. She said that approach would be tough in New York, though. Mr. Pataki also found a Commissioner of Social Services in Mary Glass, who holds the same job in Westchester (she'll have to work fast; she's returning to that job in three months). On her watch, 60 percent of those on home relief were dropped for failing to work. The ship of state is clearly shaping up as a tight one.
 
The West, Yes; the Coast, No
 
It's really true. Though New Yorkers persist in thinking they are at the center of the universe, New York, alas, has suffered the indignity of falling behind Texas to be No. 3 on the state population list. But Census figures out last week also highlighted an interesting aspect of this nation's great tilt westward: it stops before it gets to the ocean. The big growth spurts are coming one or two states in from the West Coast, like Nevada, up 5.4 percent, and Arizona, up 3.3 percent. And how about California? Yes, it's still easily No. 1, but it now ranks just 35th in growth. The state's sour economy is clearly no draw these days.
 
Mutual Funds: Doing Fine (So Far)
 
The public made a startling discovery last year: mutual funds are not invincible. Investors scurried away from bond funds, but a sickly stock market couldn't stop stock funds from slogging ahead. True, the net $3 billion that flowed in in November was the lowest since 1991, but that marked the 49th straight month that more has come in than gone out -- easily the longest streak ever. Maybe people, even when gloomy, can't think of a better place to put their cash.
 
Shoppers Always Show Up
 
It makes no sense. Stores panic in early December, then run sales even before Christmas, and -- wonder of wonders! -- the hordes arrive. Don't retailers know that this nation's citizens are genetically programmed for holiday excess? They have to show up, always at the last minute. So it was that retailers, tallying it all up last week, found that sales weren't bad but profits were poor -- because of markdowns. One footnote: plastic was big. Visa and Mastercard both reported hefty increases in credit-card purchases. Maybe people are using cards more for their daily bread, but it could also spell empty stores now as people wrestle those Visa bills back to earth.
 
Something Completely Different
 
On New Year's Day, this page would be incomplete without a roundup of Top Stories of '94. On second thought, that's a dumb idea. Instead, here's an exclusive look at what will surely be the Top Story of '95: All the people who made money on derivatives (if billions were lost, billions had to be made, right?) will be overwhelmed by remorse and holiday spirit and send checks to Orange County.
 
BRITS ZIP UP TMS. SQ.!
 
It's called the zipper, that ribbon of lit-up news on the 43d Street end of Times Square. And even in an age when people get up-to-the-second news practically piped into their brains, the passing throng can easily be seduced into watching the headlines emerge, word * by * rolling * word. In 1928, soon after it was born, the zipper carried news of Hoover's victory, and with a few interruptions, it's been blinking ever since. But Newsday, which has run the billboard since 1986, pulled out recently, raising the possibility that zipper junkies would go headline-less come New Year's Eve. Relax. Last week Pearson, the British conglomerate that puts out The Financial Times and The Economist, picked up the lease.
 
Senate to House: Drop Deal
 
Newt Gingrich's sojourn in the land of big-bucks publishing was a brief one. Last week Bob Dole raised his powerful eyebrows at Mr. Gingrich's $4.5 million deal to write two books for a publisher owned by Rupert Murdoch, who happens to have regulatory business with Congress. Mr. Gingrich soon scrapped the deal, saying he'd take just a $1 advance and patiently await his royalties. He had to "do what's good for the country," Mr. Gingrich said; even though it was a "legal and ethical deal," he didn't want the new Congress "to be slowed down or distracted," even for a second. David Bonior, the Michigan Democrat who is showing signs of being a feisty anti-Gingrich, said Mr. Gingrich "finally got the message."
 
Insurance With a Difference
 
Life insurance. It conjures images of endless mailings and sales pitches -- and it's the last thing people want to think about anyway. So selling it is tough, and many agents don't last. But a New York sales agent named Steven Genovese, prosecutors say, had a better idea. An indictment last week asserted that for years he presented phony applications, wrote bad checks for a few payments, and pocketed his commission -- perhaps half the first year's premium. If a policy's canceled, part of the commission should be returned, but that didn't happen this time -- and no procedure was in place to track such fraud. Agents can job-hop leaving barely a footprint. Even Mr. Genovese's lawyer admitted that the system "could almost seduce people into fraudulent conduct."
 
A Bullet Too Far
 
Well, David Keen decided last week that the world did not need, just yet, a bullet that not only pierces armor but splits into razorlike shards and does all sorts of nasty, nasty stuff. Mr. Keen, who heads an Alabama company called Signature Products, backed down after stiff police opposition to the company's bullet, which he says is needed because criminals often wear bulletproof vests. Of course, some people say that his bullet isn't even possible, that it's all a hoax, that he was helping the gun-control lobby more than anyone. The one thing that's certain: he got a lot of attention.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Man of the Year: High-Wire Artist Alan Greenspan

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
BURSTING a speculative bubble is easy for a central banker. Doing so without killing a lot of innocent bystanders is not. Alan Greenspan may have accomplished the task.
 The operative phrase is "a lot," and there are many people who would disagree with it. Certainly there were many speculators who suffered greatly as a result of the Federal Reserve's tightening of credit, including some who did not know they were speculating. But the Fed managed to unwind huge speculation on interest rates with only minimal damage to the stock market and the economy. 
The bubble was, to be sure, in large part a creation of Mr. Greenspan. When the American banking system was reeling from the effect of bad loans in 1990, the Fed and its chairman helped to engineer a prolonged period of falling interest rates and -- perhaps more importantly -- a very steep yield curve. With short rates much lower than long rates, banks could pay less for deposits and make a nice profit buying government bonds.
 As time went on, more and more people began to play that game, and to convince themselves they were geniuses because the money rolled in. The derivatives market made it easier to make those bets, and easier to conceal from the unsophisticated just what was being done. Getting out of the way when Mr. Greenspan changed the rules in February required nimble footwork that few could manage, and 1994 produced a line of humiliated speculators including Piper Jaffray's Worth Bruntjen and Orange County's Robert Citron.
 "There was," says Ed Yardeni, C. J. Lawrence's chief economist, "a lot more speculation on the yield curve than anyone imagined."
 It can be argued that the bond market carnage would have been less if the Fed and Mr. Greenspan had moved sooner, but that is asking for a lot. The Fed's freedom of action -- and the remarkable lack of political opposition -- came in part from the fact it did not act hastily. By Feb. 4, when it first moved to push up short-term interest rates, it was clear that the economy was strengthening. Even the American Bankers Association was pushing for Fed action, which is a little like the Saloonkeepers' League proposing an increase in the minimum drinking age.
 As 1994 began, three-month Treasury bills paid 3 percent and 30-year Treasury bonds yielded 6.3 percent. Now the figures are 5.5 percent and 7.9 percent, and bond market investors have lost a lot of money. But the Dow Jones industrial average actually eked out a small gain for the year, something few would have predicted had they correctly forecast the rate picture.
 To be sure, that is a bit misleading, concealing volatility that was especially damaging to interest-rate sensitive stocks such as homebuilders and utilities. But it is remarkable that there was no notable bear market, even as the Fed was choking off intense bond market speculation. It helped that the tightening came as corporate profits were exceeding expectations. It also helped that stock prices, while not cheap, were not at the ridiculous valuations that preceded Mr. Greenspan's baptism by fire as chairman, the 1987 crash.
 "A bubble can easily be punctured," John Kenneth Galbraith wrote in reviewing the 1929 crash. "But to incise it with a needle so that it subsides gradually is a task of no small delicacy." It may be that Mr. Greenspan has done it.

HEADLINE: Big Environment Hits a Recession

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

 BODY:
CONSUMERS respond listlessly to much of their marketing and research. Revenues are tumbling. Energetic competitors are making inroads into the core customer base. In Washington, credibility and clout are at a low point.
 An assessment of a flagging industrial corporation? Hardly. Rather it is a summary of the dismal performance that made 1994 the most troubling year ever for many of the nation's largest environmental organizations. 
What happened? As the year ended the national media took a crack at the question. "Past its prime," USA Today said of the national environmental movement. "Groping for a vision," added The Los Angeles Times. The Nation, in perhaps the harshest critique, accused the movement's senior executives of being "elitist, highly paid, detached from the people, indifferent to the working class and a firm ally of big Government."
 Time for a shakeout? Though painful for those executives and staff members involved, it probably would not be such a bad thing for American environmentalism. At least that is the conclusion reached by the Center for the Study of American Business, an economic research group affiliated with Washington University in St. Louis.
 In a report published last month, "Restructuring Environmental Big Business," the center said the turmoil in the national environmental groups had largely been caused by their own mismanagement. During the 1980's, when times were good, the groups lost focus and direction in a headlong drive for growth, only to suffer later. In short, the report concludes, the environmental groups made the same mistakes that many American corporations made during the 1980's.
 "By significantly expanding the scale and scope of their groups' activities, the directors of environmental organizations hoped to capitalize on Americans' increasing demands for environmental quality," the report stated. "Unfortunately, as many U.S. corporations have discovered, expansion away from an organization's core competency often has numerous disadvantages."
 The center's study has created a stir in the environmental movement, prompting both criticism and soul-searching.
 Some environmental leaders, like John Adams, the executive director of the Natural Resources Defense Council, say that the report's conclusions are wrong. Mr. Adams calls the report "a political document and not a scientific study," noting that the center's director is Murray L. Weidenbaum, the former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Reagan Administration, which was viewed as an enemy by environmentalists.
 Others say that a softening economy and the Clinton Administration's professed support for the environment is a more accurate explanation for the loss of backing for conservation groups.
 "The No. 1 cause of our problems has been the economy," said Ben Beach, the chief spokesman of the Wilderness Society in Washington. "When the economy went down, so did our membership. The election of Clinton and Gore also didn't help. Some people believed there was less need to support environmental causes."
 But the center's conclusions are being embraced by other environmental leaders as an accurate appraisal of some of the causes underlying the turmoil in their movement.
 "We in the not-for-profit business are subject to the same forces as any other business," said Ted Eubanks, a director of the National Audubon Society who has ordered 50 copies of the report to distribute to the group's senior leaders. "Our business is basically communications and we've lost the imagination of the average guy in the street."
 The study's authors, Christopher Boerner and Jennifer Chilton Kallery, are researchers at the center. They spent more than a year studying the financial statements, tax documents and other information collected from five of the most influential environmental groups: the Natural Resources Defense Council, the National Audubon Society, the Sierra Club, the Wilderness Society and the Nature Conservancy.
 Those five organizations, which in the early 1970's were either small or brand new, have become the core of a quite substantial nonprofit industry that employs thousands of highly educated professionals. The five groups still claim 2.1 million dues-paying members, down from a peak of 2.4 million in 1990. In 1993, they collected $396 million from membership dues, foundations, contributions and sales of publications.
 The Nature Conservancy, which alone accounted for $278.5 million in revenues and nearly $1 billion in assets in 1993, is cited by the authors as the only one of the five groups that has not been buffeted by declining revenue or membership. The study says the reason is that the Nature Conservancy, which avoids the political fray, also did not swerve from its sole mission of buying and conserving wild land.
 The other groups diversified at their peril. Starting with core campaigns in the 1970's to make the air and water cleaner and protect natural resources, those groups in the 1980's established large and elaborate programs to address a wide array of more scientifically complex and politically difficult issues like global warming and saving obscure animals. To support such work, the groups expanded their lobbying and public relations staffs, particularly in Washington, and helped to pioneer the media-driven techniques of modern public interest campaigns.
 The authors argue that the new strategy was not only designed to address an expanding menu of environmental concerns but also to attract the extra financing and membership that would support growth. From 1983 to 1990, for example, the Wilderness Society's budget more than quadrupled, to $17.9 million, from $4.3 million. From 1974 to 1993, the budget of the National Resources Defense Council grew to $20.5 million, from $1.5 million.
 Ms. Chilton Kallery and Mr. Boerner argue, though, that there were both limits to the financing available and the number of Americans that were truly interested in all the new issues. The competition for financing became so fierce, the authors said, that it led to two unexpected outcomes.
 First, to "differentiate themselves and rally public support, environmental groups began employing highly emotional, and often misleading, campaigns," the report said. "Organizations have used fear and apocalyptic prophecies to further their political objectives." For example, a recent fund-raising mailing from the National Audubon Society said the group could "project with some accuracy the eventual end of the natural world as we know it."
 "That is no trees," the letter said. "No wildlife."
 And second, such tactics helped generate a powerful countermovement of scientists, city officials, business executives and landowners who began to ask questions about the methods and priorities of national environmental groups. To some extent the critics have been joined by grass-roots environmental leaders who also have been attacking the national organizations as too bureaucratic and uninterested in the land-use questions and community pollution concerns that are important to many more Americans.
 Mr. Boerner and Ms. Chilton Kallery said the critics raised doubts about the credibility of national environmental groups, an erosion that was responsible for slowing growth, and in some cases reversing budgets and membership. The Sierra Club now counts 500,000 members, which is 130,000 fewer than in 1990. Since 1990, the Wilderness Society's membership has fallen by 125,000, to 275,000 today, while its budget of $15 million is $2.9 million less than in 1990. The National Audubon Society recorded a deficit of $1.7 million in 1993 and is reducing its staff and cutting programs.
 The solution, the authors say, may come only after more cuts are made. "In order to regain their influence on public policy," the report said, "environmental big business should follow many of their private-sector counterparts -- trim down and stick to core competencies."

HEADLINE: Is the Administration Really Business Friendly?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I was gratified to see recognition from a variety of business executives of the substantive progress achieved during the Clinton Presidency. 
The litany of lower interest rates, increased employment, passage of Nafta and GATT is familiar, yet many members of the business community are still carping about President Clinton. I believe the President has surrounded himself with talented economic thinkers and doers through the creation of the National Economic Council.
 The President has followed through by elevating the focus on the American economy to the level of the National Security Council. Furthermore, this is the first administration to include the head of the Small Business Administration at the Cabinet table.
 I have benefited from Clinton economic policies, not only through the historic bond rally in 1993 creating the lowest interest rates in 20 years, but also through a pilot program I am conducting with the S.B.A. to sell surplus Government assets on the information highway.
 I mention this to emphasize the need to appreciate the progress made by this Administration. I am reminded of the story of the mother giving two ties to her son for his birthday. One day he comes downstairs wearing one of the new ties. His mother then asks, "What's the matter, you don't like the other tie?" Similarly the business community has accomplished a great deal since the Clinton Presidency has begun, but it still complains and question.
STEVEN A. LUDSON Manhattan, Dec. 5 The writer is an investment adviser.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Awaiting Mexico's Plan to Revive Peso

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis

 BODY:
THE financial community awaits the address that President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon will make to the Mexican people -- not to mention their foreign creditors -- on Monday, discussing his plan for restoring confidence in the country's battered currency and economy.
 Bankers and analysts in London and New York are unanimous in believing that the Zedillo and Clinton Administrations have mishandled the peso devaluation so far, turning a manageable crisis into a major monetary disaster that could hamstring the Mexican economy for years to come. 
One senior New York banker, with expertise in Latin America, who asked not to be identified, is convinced that President Zedillo could have avoided floating the peso completely if he had coupled the devaluation announcement with a strong package of domestic and international support measures, including a ringing declaration of confidence from President Clinton.
 Instead, the markets received a steady drip of hesitant, poorly explained moves by the Mexican authorities, with no ostensible backing from the United States, which only encouraged capital flight, bankers say.
 The key issue now is whether President Zedillo will announce credible national and international steps on Monday to control inflation, service Mexico's foreign debt and raise additional revenue from privatizations to keep the budget balanced in 1995.
 "They lack experience in crisis management," said the Latin American strategist for Salomon Brothers, Alfredo Viegas. "What we need is leadership. But there's an unfortunate confluence of events, a new, divided Government in Mexico, no Treasury Secretary in the United States and the Republicans taking over Congress next month."
 Sarah Lavers, of the London research firm Latinvest Securities, added: "Everything has been too late. No one seems in command. It doesn't instill confidence."
 Global Investing, a newsletter tracking foreign stocks traded in New York, said in its latest issue that "there hasn't been such a mishandled devaluation since Harold Wilson's in England in 1967."
 After Mexico attempted a devaluation of 15 percent but was forced to float instead, former Finance Minister Jaime Serra Puche rushed to New York to give a secret pep talk to leading bankers. The move backfired. The economic measures that Mr. Serra promised were vague. And the Under Secretary of the Treasury, Lawrence H. Summers, made matters worse by appearing without giving the Mexicans any public support, those who attended said.
 "There is a very strong view expressed among investors that the Government is not fully in control of economic policy" Salomon Brothers told its clients afterward in a confidential fax.
 Last week, as rumors of an American-led support package for Mexico circulated, the United States Treasury refused to provide details or even a clear statement that help was on the way. Only the replacement of Finance Minister Serra by Guillermo Ortiz brought markets some cheer.
 "The public relations side of this has been a disaster," said James Colmenares of Morgan Stanley Asset Management. "But Ortiz is good news. Very sharp. Very market-saavy."
 Of course, handling the public relations side of a currency devaluation is not easy. And Mexico is far from the first country to get things wrong.
 In the winter of 1967, leaks indicating that Prime Minister Wilson's Labor Government was frantically shopping for new loans cost the Bank of England billions of dollars in lost reserves, including $1 billion on Nov. 18 alone, the day before the Government threw in the towel.
 More successful was President Charles de Gaulle's emphatic "non" a year later to a devaluation considered inevitable. This put the mother of all bear squeezes on speculators, enabling the franc to hold its own until President Georges Pompidou's surprise devaluation the following August.
 If President Zedillo gets it right on Monday, what should investors buy? Ideally, strong exporting companies without dollar debts.
 "The trouble is, there aren't many around," said Jean ven der Walle of Alliance Capital Management. He said he liked Interceramica, a tile manufacturer with substantial exports to the United States, and the San Luis mining and auto parts company, which makes auto parts for the American market.
 But many analysts suspect Mexico's woes will encourage investors to look south toward Brazil, whose economic prospects seem more hopeful. "Brazil will be the winner," Mr. Viegas said, noting that the Sao Paolo market was only 17 percent foreign-owned, compared with 35 percent for the Mexican market.
His favorite choices are Companhia Rio do Valle Doce, the world's largest exporter of iron ore, and the Government-controlled electricity and communications monopolies, Eletrobras and Telebras, which are candidates for privatization.

HEADLINE: In Ukraine, a Free-Market Lesson Learned Too Well

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
FOR three years, the United States lectured a recalcitrant and bankrupt Ukraine about the virtues of a market economy with little effect. But some enterprising factories understood. The trouble was, they understood too well.
 Stylishly cut and well-finished women's wool coats from Ukraine became such hot items on Seventh Avenue that Washington slapped a quota on them in November. 
The curb threatens to halt the strong growth in a new export industry that Ukraine badly needs. The Ukrainian economy has been in a free-fall since independence from the Soviet Union was declared in 1991, raising worries about the new country's stability.
 The Clinton Administration has stressed repeatedly that Ukraine -- a nation straddling Russia and Eastern Europe, with 52 million people -- is strategically important to America. At the same time that Washington is restricting its commercial access to the United States, Ukraine is a leading recipient of American foreign aid -- $700 million pledged in 1994.
 So, to shield a relative handful of coat makers in Maine and elsewhere from overseas competition, Washington seems to be endangering its foreign policy goals. Perhaps, but American officials reply that the quota was mainly a routine case of applying United States trade rules.
 For coat makers and workers here, the American move seems like a slap in the face, and it has made their future suddenly uncertain. At the Yunost coat factory, Svetlana V. Gorchinskaya worries that a shipment of double-breasted camel coats, slickly packed in plastic covers and bearing the Donnybrook label, might be the last big order from the United States.
 Until recently, her factory had been adding to its payroll to handle the surge in business, with orders for 1995 increasing sharply. But the quota on coat shipments from Ukraine has dashed the Yunost factory's plans for 1995. To cope with the expected slowdown in orders, Mrs. Gorchinskaya, the factory's technical director, has already laid off 300 workers, nearly one-third of the work force.
 "If there's no work, there's no money for us to pay," she said, surveying bolts of camel and black fabric ordered for this year's coats that lie on the floor of the warehouse. "Our people are at home without pay because of this quota problem."
 The wool coats -- trench, double-breasted, single-breasted, swing, belted, indeed any way customers want them and selling at department stores and clothing retailers across the United States for $89 to $139 each -- brought protests of unfair trade from the American woolen textile industry.
The imports of coats from Ukraine, estimated at $30 million a year, are tiny compared with America's yearly apparel import bill of $30 billion, according to the United States Association of Importers and Apparel, a trade group. But shipments have increased sharply. In the year ended last September, Ukraine exported 88,898 dozen women's coats -- or 1,066,776 coats -- to the United States, up 155 percent from the year before, the Commerce Department said.
 By 1994, Ukraine's coat exports to the United States had mushroomed to such an extent that they were outstripped only by coats from the Dominican Republic and Guatemala, two countries to which the United States gives preferential trade. Under the Caribbean Basin Initiative, the Dominican Republic and Guatemala do not face quotas on women's coats.
 The sudden surge of Ukrainian imports brought pressure for import restraint from domestic coat makers, who were supported by Senator George Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, and the Commerce Department. Textiles and apparel remain among the most protected sectors of trade in most nations, even though the new rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will eliminate many curbs. And even without the quota, American producers are protected by a tariff of 21.5 percent on wool coat imports.
 The Ukrainian coat imports were classified as "disruptive" to the American women's manufacturing industry. The disruptive finding, though vague, was sufficient to justify imposing a quota in a niche of the American apparel industry where employment has declined fairly steadily for years.
 According to a senior official at the United States Trade Representative's office, some of the Ukrainian coats were landing in the United States at $212 a dozen. "This was not the absolute lowest, but among the lowest" price of imported coats, the official said, adding, "they're very nice looking coats." Indeed, the coats made in Ukraine have a reputation in the industry for being of higher quality than those sewn in other developing countries.
 In theory, the coat quota was negotiated with Ukraine's Government. But the Ukrainian officials were informed by Washington that the United States could unilaterally impose import quotas on them if they did not voluntarily accept restrictions. Besides Ukraine, the United States has quota agreements on women's wool coats with 15 other countries, including Hungary, Slovakia, Bulgaria, Romania and Poland.
 The quota on Ukrainian coats maintains imports at roughly last year's levels. The quota, the trade representative's office says, was set during negotiations with the Ukrainians at 85,000 dozen for 1995, or 1,020,000. And an extra quota of 25,000 coats, which can be added to shipments in 1995, was set for the last three months of 1994.
 But the restrictions will slow growth abruptly in 1995. Ukrainian coat makers here say the quota represents half the orders that the Ukrainian coat industry received from American importers for this year.
 For Ukraine's Government, the curbs on coat shipments is a setback for the reformers who are just beginning to win a battle for liberalization of their economy.
An official at the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations, Andre Houcheruk, said he was "really disappointed" that one of his nation's strong export industries was being penalized.
 "We have just liberalized our export policy and I don't think America should hurt us in exports that bring us hard currency," Mr. Houcheruk said. "When I spoke to people at the State Department, they were just shaking their heads. They had no answer."
 The biggest importer, Donald Levy, president of Lou Levy and Sons, a Seventh Avenue coat company, who brought in close to one million Ukrainian coats in 1994, described the quota as "the most ridiculous thing I've ever heard of."
 "It's ridiculous because it's not saving anything here in the United States; the industry is dying anyway," said Mr. Levy, whose labels include Donnybrook.
 THE quota would hurt the Ukrainians who needed the business but it would not affect him, Mr. Levy said. If he was barred from getting the number of coats he wanted from Ukraine, he said he would go elsewhere for them.
 Another importer, Irwin Bercovitch, director of Irwin Fashion Imports, said: "Ukraine is exporting its labor and importing our currency; it can only help the country. I can't understand why Washington is doing this."
 Both importers said that while they would still be able to buy Ukrainian coats, though not in the quantities they would like, the mere presence of the quotas made the business less attractive and more bureaucratic.
 The Ukrainian coat industry owes its development partly to the collapse of the Soviet Union, but it was also helped by Communist central planning.
 American fashion importers, who are constantly scouring the world for new sources of inexpensive goods, discovered Ukraine after the Soviet Union fell apart in 1991. They found that a century-old tradition of good sewing had not been completely corrupted by the Communists. And because of a state planning decision in 1989 to upgrade the textile industry, some factories, like the Yunost plant, are equipped with modern automated European and Japanese equipment. The renovated Yunost plant, for example, boasts computerized pattern making.
 Both Mr. Levy and Mr. Bercovitch said they dealt with factories all over Ukraine and not all were as modern as the Yunost operation. Some plants, which were making fashion coats after years of producing military uniforms, were located in remote areas reachable only by hard and long travel on rough roads.
 Most of the Ukrainian coat makers are essentially cutting and stitching shops. The importers typically provide the fabric -- usually bought in Russia but also purchased in Europe -- the designs, the trims, even the labels.
 Mrs. Gorchinskaya said her factory was paid $4.50 a coat by the American importers. The price covered labor for cutting, sewing, pressing and packing, she said. Her workers, she said, receive the equivalent of about $40 a month.
 For Mrs. Gorchinskaya, who has been in the Ukrainian textile business for nearly 40 years and also now sells to Germany, the American coat quota is mystifying.
 "It's not a secret that our textiles are cheaper and that our labor force is cheaper than in the United States," she said. "I hope things work out, because at bottom it's helpful to us and to Americans -- they get cheap, good quality coats from us."
 And there was a darker side, she said. The American decision to restrict Ukrainian imports, Mrs. Gorchinskaya added, played into the hands of the reactionary forces in the Government opposed to the new liberalization policies of President Leonid Kuchma.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Summing Up a Gruesome Year

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
CALL it ugly.
 For mutual funds, 1994 was ugly in terms of performance -- most stock and bond investors lost money. And from the industry's viewpoint, it was ugly as one scandal followed another and even uglier as the cascading cash inflows of the previous year began to falter. 
But 1994's tough market was bound to come along sooner or later, and it pulled down lofty valuations to more reasonable levels. Accordingly, investors are well-advised to adjust expectations; the incredible bull market returns many have come to consider usual are over, at least for now.
 Despite some industry embarrassments, ranging from losses in government bond funds created by investments in derivative securities to Fidelity Investments' mispricing of its funds' shares, "no issue affected a majority or even a vast minority of funds," said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds in Chicago.
 So how did cash beat stocks and bonds in 1994? The biggest culprit was the Federal Reserve, which has pushed up interest rates six times since February. Higher interest rates play havoc with bond prices, and Treasury bond funds, often viewed as a safe haven, lost more than 4 percent of their value, on average, through Dec. 29, because they tend to own longer-term issues, which react most violently to rate shifts.
 Not that other bondholders had much to brag about. Among taxable bonds, corporate bond funds lost 3.7 percent -- their first loss in more than 20 years. Junk bonds lost almost 4 percent.
 Municipal bond funds did even worse, losing slightly more than 5 percent. Funds owning mortgage-backed securities fared slightly better, down 3.5 percent. True to their charter, adjustable-rate mortgage funds were the group's best performers, down slightly more than 2 percent.
 Among equities, nearly all funds were losers, down 2.1 percent on average.
 The two winning categories of funds invested in small sectors of the market, with technology funds up 12.5 percent and health care funds up almost 4 percent.
 Funds investing in European stocks managed to break even. But funds in Pacific Rim stocks were down more than 7 percent, on average, surpassed only by gold (down 9.3 percent).
 As for bad news in the industry, the year started with the Invesco Group of Denver dismissing John Kaweske, a fund manager, after accusing him of not complying with rules on personal trading. That led to a study by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which concluded that there were few personal-trading cases in the industry.
 Then there were spectacular blowups in government bond funds that owned derivative securities. Those came to be symbolized by huge losses in Piper Jaffray closed-end trusts. Shareholders in Paine Webber's Short-Term U.S. Government Income Fund were reimbursed by the company for similar losses, an acknowledgment that funds sold as conservative should manage their portfolios that way, Mr. Rekenthaler said. Derivatives are a continuing problem, he added, as evidenced by the fact that some funds hold issues of Orange County, Calif., which has declared bankruptcy.
 In the fall, a bank-run money fund finally "broke a buck" -- falling below $1 a share -- the first in the industry to do so and a sharp reminder that money funds are not insured by the Government.
 The lesson for investors: Be informed and wary, Mr. Rekenthaler said. Watch out for yields that look too good to be true because they probably are.
 From the industry's perspective, cash flow into bond and fixed-income funds has been fairly light. The funds grew by an estimated $15 billion in 1994, compared with $145 billion in 1993, said Dean P. Eberling, first vice president specializing in financial services at Prudential Securities Inc. in New York.
 On the other hand, redemptions have been light, too, after peaking in March. "Considering the severity of the bond market declines, it's surprising that the retail investor has been so calm," Mr. Eberling said.
 Over all, net new sales of stock and bond funds should total roughly $140 billion this year, compared with $280 billion in 1993 and $197 billion in 1992, he said.
 Mr. Eberling said the most important event for the industry this year was the flattening of the yield curve in December. When the spread in yields between short- and long-term issues narrows, people tend to keep their money in money market funds or short-term investments.
 Growth in the fund industry in 1995 "will come from short- and intermediate-term products," he said, while growth in equities and long-term bonds could slip below 1991 levels.
 Even so, the fund industry "is still in a position to become the dominant intermediary of the wealth-creation process in the U.S.," Mr. Eberling said. And that could be helped by a comeback of individual retirement accounts -- "which won't affect 1995 but could be a psychological plus for stocks in 1996," he said.
