HEADLINE: Wall Street;
With the New Year, New Scams

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
AN investor stampede for mutual funds that invest in "Republican" investment plays? A brokerage firm that cleans up selling its underwritings of Chinese cellular phone companies to United States municipalities? Where will the financial scams, disasters and embarrassments of 1995 be found? And will the D-word -- derivatives -- stay in the headlines?
Derivatives disasters no doubt will continue, the pros say, as will misleading enticements to investors who log on to the financial screens of on-line services. 
But, "I promise you there will be a new scam in 1995, because there is one every year," says Michael Stolper of Stolper & Company in San Diego, who evaluates money managers for rich people. And where might the blowups and shady dealings of 1995 be? The pros came up with their best bets:
* Precious metals scams. Mr. Stolper says it is a no-brainer to predict that investors will be getting cold calls from boiler-room operators pushing the ultimate inflation-avoidance play: gold, silver, and diamond mining companies. "The world is really negative on stocks and bonds," he says, "and with the Fed raising rates, you can write a pretty good script that plays on the idea that Alan Greenspan knows something" about a looming inflation crisis.
 Watch for cold-callers who tell a tale of a great supply-demand picture boosted by everything from the hoarding of gold in Asia to the inability of mines to get production at full throttle. "Whether it's futures, commodities, options on futures, or some piece-of-garbage company that trades in Salt Lake City, you'll see the boiler rooms selling the idea over the phone," he says.
 * Initial public offering blowups. The casualties are already being counted, but the real carnage is yet to be seen, says money manager David Dreman of Dreman Value Management. In 1995, "all these sizzling new concepts and funds" will be further humbled, and investors further educated, Mr. Dreman says.
 Mr. Dreman is expecting the worst from the companies that went public in 1993 and early 1994 and played on the stories of the day: health care, the information highway, and emerging markets. He says investors were particularly vulnerable to "anything to do with China," seduced by the notion that a billion Chinese would be suddenly among the world's consumers. And indeed, "there are billions of Chinese ready to buy something," Mr. Dreman says, "it's just that they don't have any money."
 * Mutual fund surprises. For years, the hard work for mutual fund managers has been finding something to buy. But do they have what it takes to choose what and when to sell? Don Phillips of Morningstar Inc., which evaluates funds' performance, says fund managers will learn lots about selling in 1995 --particularly the selling of securities in bond and emerging markets funds that have already suffered heavy losses.
 And when they do sell, they could lose more than expected because of the glitches in the "matrix pricing" of the securities held in funds. Matrix pricing is the use of computer models to put a price on securities that do not trade very much, allowing funds to set a dollar value at the end of each day's trading. But those prices are "a best-guess estimate," Mr. Phillips adds, and 1995 may be an ugly test of the "guesstimates." If the estimates have been too high, the losses will be an unhappy surprise.
 * Stock churning. Investors have caught on to the pitfalls of limited partnerships. They're even getting wise to the game of mutual fund churning --taking clients in and out of funds and collecting a fat but largely hidden commission with each transaction. But, perhaps, they have already forgotten the lessons of old-fashioned stock churning, in which brokers buy and sell at rapid speed to drum up commissions.
 "I'm seeing more flat-out stock-churning cases," says Brian Smiley of Page & Bacek, an Atlanta law firm that represents small investors. "Now that it's not too fashionable to take a large commission bite at one time with one exotic investment, investors are getting nibbled to death with lots of little transactions."
 * Fee scams. As expectations for stock market returns get lower, investors are hearing a pitch to pay for aggressive money management rather than buy and hold, Mr. Phillips says. That increasingly means wooing investors into wrap accounts, in which investors typically pay fees of 2 percent of their assets each year to have someone move their money among individual stocks and bonds and mutual funds.
 Mr. Phillips is concerned that investors will wind up paying double fees --as much as 2 percent to the management of the fund, and another 2 percent for the wrap account guru who decides which funds to buy and sell. Considering that even optimists are making predictions of 6 percent annual gains for the stock market, the money managers had better select brilliantly or investors will barely break even.
 But investors are falling for it, says Mr. Smiley, the lawyer, who recently attended a seminar pitching wrap accounts that used mutual funds. One manager there boasted that his impressive returns were accomplished with "no risk," recalls Mr. Smiley, who has his doubts about the claim. Others in the audience were less cynical. "At the end, a woman raised her hand and said she wanted to express her appreciation for the wonderful, clear presentation," Mr. Smiley says. "I thought to myself, 'I wonder if I'll be seeing her in my office in the next couple years.' "

HEADLINE: In Newark, Prologue to an Arts Center

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
IT is known officially as the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. And the first building, now under construction in downtown Newark, is indeed that. But considering the long-range plans, it might as well be called the New Jersey Office, Shopping, Dining and Performing Arts Center.
 Ultimately, less than one-third of the floor area to be built on the site, or about 400,000 square feet, would be devoted to performances or subsidiary commercial uses. The rest of the space, 1 million square feet, would be in two large office towers across Center Street, on land controlled by the arts center. 
Doesn't Lincoln Center wish it owned all that land across Broadway?" asked Lawrence P. Goldman, president and chief executive of the center. "We're trying to own all our land, except our Broadway is called Center Street."
 "Why should private real estate developers be the sole beneficiaries?" he said. "We're trying to build in, from the beginning, the ability of a nonprofit institution to capitalize on the benefits that its creation brings to the area."
 Mr. Goldman knows something about the subject, since he was an executive at Carnegie Hall in the 1980's when it leased an adjacent parcel on 57th Street to the Rockrose Development Corporation, which built the 60-story Carnegie Hall Tower.
 Although the first building of the Newark center is scheduled to open in the 1996-97 season, it will take many more years -- perhaps decades -- before the social and economic transformation of the surrounding area is fully felt. So no one expects construction to begin anytime soon on the office towers. Their groundbreaking may not even happen in this century.
 But just the sight of two gangly red-and-white construction cranes towering high over the bare sycamores in Military Park has encouraged landlords nearby to believe that downtown Newark's slow revitalization will stay on track.
 Already, the 105-foot-high stage house of the multipurpose Great Hall has taken skeletal steel form, with the 40-by-60-foot proscenium plainly visible. One day, 2,750 seats will face this stage, on which the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, among other performers, is to play. Alongside the main auditorium is to be the 500-seat Victoria Theater, which has begun to rise over Park Place. The main lobby will be flanked on the west by a rotunda and on the east by a pavilion with two restaurants and a hall that can be used for rehearsals or banquets.
 "Military Park, with the construction of the performing arts center, will once again become a mecca of entertainment and nightlife in the state of New Jersey," said Miles P. Berger, chairman of the Berger Organization, which owns several buildings around the park, including 10 Park Place, a backdrop for almost every photograph taken of the arts center.
 The Bellemead Development Corporation is "very excited" about the arts complex, said James S. Servidea, a vice president. Bellemead built One Newark Center, a 22-story tower on Raymond Boulevard, two blocks from the new hall.
 "Here you have an area that's already started to rebound, but a lot of people don't know it yet," Mr. Servidea said. "The first step of getting them there is the difficult thing. The arts center will bring people down there to see what's happened who would not otherwise go. In terms of timing, I'm guessing 1997 or 1998 before it starts to have an impact."
The estimated cost for the first phase of the arts center is $150 million, including about $87 million for the first building, which has 230,000 square feet and will probably open in the spring of 1997. The Great Hall, whose capacity is 50 seats shy of Carnegie Hall's, would be used by a variety of companies, although only the orchestra has a contract now. The smaller Victoria Theater will be used for plays and recitals.
 ALMOST half the money, $62.5 million, comes from the state of New Jersey, with $33 million from private donors, $10 million from the city of Newark, $1.2 million from the Federal Government and $1 million from the state Arts Council. The balance, about $42 million, has not yet been raised.
 Barton Myers Associates of Los Angeles are the architects, with Wilson Woodridge Associates of East Orange, N.J., Jules Fisher/Joshua Dachs Associates of Manhattan, and Benjamin Thompson & Associates of Cambridge, Mass. The acoustician is Russell Johnson of Artec Consultants in Manhattan. The construction manager is Turner Construction Company of Somerset, N.J.
 There were three key design criteria, Mr. Goldman said: "Exciting esthetics, superb acoustics and revenue production from as many spaces as we could think of."
 The building is to have a 200-seat cafe and a fancier 100-seat restaurant, above which will be a 3,000-square-foot rehearsal space that can also be used as a banquet hall. There will be a gift shop, too, and the main lobby is to be rented for special events.
 The second phase of the project, between the first building and the McCarter Highway, closer to the Passaic River, is still tenuous. It is to be a concert hall with approximately 2,400 seats and about 200,000 square feet of space. There is no way yet to estimate its cost, Mr. Goldman said.
 It is difficult to predict the future, given the practical and political hurdles than can arise. For example, Mr. Goldman said, the "biggest negative surprise" to date was the discovery that the 1,100-space garage under Military Park was badly deteriorated.
 More recently, the United States Attorney's office has been investigating Mayor Sharpe James, whom Mr. Goldman calls "one of the great heroes" of the center, "an extremely powerful and articulate advocate in Newark, Trenton and Washington."
 Among other things, Federal authorities are examining what happened to money raised by the Sharpe James Civic Association from those who do business with the city, although Mr. James has not been charged with wrongdoing. Mr. Goldman had no comment on how the Mayor's difficulties might affect progress at the center.
 There have been many changes in the project since it was announced in 1987 by Gov. Thomas H. Kean. At that time, the center was to have five buildings on a six-block site west of Broad Street.
 The location was later moved to the east side of the park, close to the Passaic River. The New Jersey Economic Development Authority began acquiring the 14 parcels that compose the 11-acre site in December 1991. All but two contracts have now closed, said Jerry Enis, a spokesman for the arts center. The remaining parcels are owned by the state Transportation Department and the Archdiocese of Newark.
 (The chancery of the archdiocese is still in a handsome little Romanesque Revival building at 31 Mulberry Street but is to move next spring to a new archdiocesan headquarters designed by Michael Graves, at Clifton and Park Avenues, across from Sacred Heart Cathedral. The Mount Carmel Guild Multi-Service Center, which is also on the site, is moving into a renovated structure at 1160 Raymond Boulevard.)
 The Economic Development Authority paid the acquisition costs, about $20 million, with the sale of bonds. It leases the property to the state, which pays an annual rent of about $2 million. The state subleases it in turn to the arts center for $1 a year.
 Originally, there were to have been four cultural buildings in the complex, arrayed around a central plaza, not unlike Lincoln Center. That idea was abandoned four years ago, Mr. Goldman said, when the planners decided it was unlikely that the money needed for such an ambitious project could be raised in any reasonable period of time.
 Moreover, they felt, the center would be missing the opportunity to capitalize on its own real estate. Mr. Goldman, who was a vice president of Carnegie Hall, came to Newark convinced that nonprofit cultural institutions could profit from participating in adjoining development projects.
 Two parcels, on either side of the realigned Mulberry Street, have been set aside for 500,000-square-foot office and retail buildings. The sites would be leased to private developers, with the ground rent going to the arts center, which would also review the design of the buildings. The center might even take a share of the rents from tenants, as at Carnegie Hall.
 "Obviously," Mr. Goldman said, "the conditions in the central business district in Newark in the 90's are not the same as the West Side of Manhattan in the 80's, so who knows where the bargaining chips will fall."
 THE arts center is part of a larger 18-acre urban renewal area that includes vacant property along the Passaic River owned by the Newark Housing Authority. The renewal plan describes this as a potential site for a mixed-use development that would complement and enhance the arts center.
 Mr. Berger said the towers on Center Street might be under way by the year 2000. It is a "credible" project, he said, given the recent construction of One Newark Center, the Hartz Towers at Penn Station and the Legal Center, also near Penn Station.
 The Berger Organization owns several key properties around the arts center. Ten Park Place, a 10-story building constructed in 1916 for the Firemen's Insurance Company, was renovated in 1989. Mr. Berger said it is now fully occupied. The 15-story Robert Treat Center, 50 Park Place, was built in 1916 as the Robert Treat Hotel. It now has about 100,000 square feet of office space and is 96 percent occupied, Mr. Berger said.
 His next big project is an attempt to resuscitate the former Hahne & Company department store, a massive red-brick structure at 609 Broad Street. Each of its four floors covers nearly two acres. Given up by Hahne's in 1987, the 93-year-old building was bought in 1993 for $2.5 million. In 1994, Mr. Berger also acquired 605 Broad Street, an empty 17-story building -- with a 200-seat recital hall -- built in 1927 for the Griffith Piano Company.
 At Hahne's, he envisions a shopping mall around an atrium on the first floor and possibly the second. Above that would be offices and, perhaps, loft space for set designers or costume designers. But he is not pinning all his hope on the center.
 "The retailers who will entertain the possibility of leasing space here are probably closer to 14th Street than 57th Street," Mr. Berger said. "We can never lose sight of reality. It's very difficult to attract a suburban, affluent crowd to Newark, either for shopping in the daytime or for nightlife."
 "A retailer will not be able to rely on the promise of an arts center to open a store," he said. "A drug store is not going to rely on an arts center. A shoe store is not going to rely on an arts center."

HEADLINE: A New Year's Forecast for the Economy

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
IT is the new year, but with it come some old anxieties. Responses from several Westchester business leaders indicate that they are concerned about things like rising interest rates, government regulations and the cost of doing business in the months to come.
Q. What major obstacle do you believe will affect the economic recovery of Westchester in 1995? 
 P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors:
The residential real estate market has been one of the strongest pillars of Westchester's economic recovery since the 1990 recession. The number and dollar volume of sales of houses, condominiums and cooperatives reached an all-time high in 1994.
We may look forward to another strong year for real estate in 1995 if mortgage interest rates remain at manageable levels. The relatively low rates to date have enabled many first-time home buyers to afford typical Westchester housing prices. The low rates have also helped New York City co-op owners sell their units to first-time buyers and to move up and out to Westchester properties.
However, a significant jump in interest rates could lock first-time buyers out of the housing market here and everywhere. For example, just a 1 percentage point increase on a conventional, 30-year $100,000 mortgage results in added expense of about $70 monthly -- a sum that can be a deal breaker for many purchasers.
Unfortunately, we in Westchester don't control interest rates. They depend on national economic conditions, overall rate of inflation and Federal monetary policy interventions. Our best hope for 1995 is for steady, national noninflationary growth in the national economy.
Lawrence E. Dwyer Jr., president, the Westchester County Association:
I believe the major challenge facing Westchester business and therefore businesses throughout New York State in 1995 is the need for the state to demonstrate its desire to be aggressively hospitable to business. This statewide hospitality must focus on the attraction, retention and expansion of businesses.
For this to be accomplished, the first necessary step is the need to re-engineer and to effectively "right size" all government and the delivery of services. Restructuring will permit us to deliver services in a more cost-efficient, effective and people-minded manner.
An assertive leadership of partnership is necessary to respond to comprehensive needs and to set a vision of accomplishment that will create confidence in a realistic multiyear program. Westchester's future growth is dependent upon the stabilization of businesses of all sizes and by creating programs for the expanded training-retraining of our skilled work force for employment opportunities into the 21st century.
Our future must include structural change where the participants are willing to compromise in order to reach the goals of cost effectiveness and excellence for the overall good of Westchester.
Ross J. Pepe, president, Construction Industry Council of Westchester and Hudson Valley:
Interest rates! Interest rates! Interest rates! There is no other factor on the immediate horizon that could harm the industry's resurging private work sector more than the alarming climb in rates. Loan rates, equipment financing and contractor carrying costs are now at acceptable levels. If the Fed continues to hike rates, developers, builders, construction contractors and suppliers will be less inclined to take on new debt and finance new ventures.
Viewed from another perspective, after years of listless activity, the private construction market is finally showing signs of recovery. Building permits and housing starts are up in the last quarter, and the employment picture is improving. We're hoping this trend, which began in the second half of 1994, will carry through the new year.
But as we all know, nothing throws a damper on the housing market and new-venture incentive faster than the fear of higher interest rates.
But because the public work sector -- the heavy and highway segment of the industry -- still has two more solid years of funding from Federal and state sources, plans to repair and upgrade state roads, bridges, tunnels and commuter rail systems should not be in jeopardy at this time.
However, in their desire to cut Federal spending, we certainly hope policymakers don't hack away at the industry's mainstay of work, namely the state Department of Transportation's Research and Development and engineering staff and capital improvements to transportation. Surely, lawmakers must know that construction and well-maintained public works are the lifeblood of the economy.
Harold E. Vogt, president and chief executive officer of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce:
Many are characterizing the outlook for the national economy as "recovery with muscle" with plenty of steam left to carry expansion well into 1995. That's nationally, and if the assessment is accurate, what does it mean for Westchester?
I believe it will mean little unless we can come to grips with the one thing that continues to impact the county's economy: that is the cost of doing business.
The cost of doing business is both a perception and a reality. As a perception, it stems from the absence of visible action to relieve the cost burden imposed by our county and municipal governments and school districts. It's the apparent lack of will to change, to re-engineer both the scope and function of our governments. It's the apparent attitude of our elected and school officials that the only way to change is to retain what is and add even more resources to meet current needs. To them, somehow more becomes less.
The reality is increased property taxes, costly regulatory actions like the Employee Commute Option program and increases in fees. These add to the actual cost of doing business and make Westchester uncompetitive for both expansion of existing businesses and attracting new business investments.
There are signs of change in Washington and Albany. Elected officials here in Westchester must follow suit. The coming year is their defining moment.
Michael Bisceglia, chairman of the Building Contractors Association of Westchester and the Mid-Hudson Region:
The billion-dollar construction industry in Westchester and Putnam Counties is sluggishly recovering from the depths of a three-year recession. Some contractors are cautiously optimistic about the future, but unless progress is made to reduce construction costs the recovery will abort.
In order to achieve this, we need regulatory reform, fiscal reform and a handle on the cost of labor.
Private-sector expansion is directly dependent on competitive and reasonable state and local tax and spending levels. We need clarification in several areas such as bidding requirements and contract terms. The proper management of contractor risk is also an important factor.
It should be remembered that each dollar spent in construction investment generates an additional $2.50 in relative economic activity. A healthy building and construction industry is the single most important component in revitalizing the region and state.
Carl Dimaio, president of the Builders Institute of Westchester and the Mid-Hudson Region:
The overriding obstacle to growth and development in Westchester and Putnam Counties is the proposal by New York City to place severe restrictions on building in the 2,000 square miles of land north and west of the city.
These regulations were taken from the land-use and zoning authority of local government and transferred to the city's bureaucracy, affecting the jobs of thousands of workers and the ability of local communities to generate taxable income for schools and municipal services.
If the plan is implemented, we estimate the loss of $3 billion in new construction in the watershed areas over the next four years.
At the heart of the issue is the city's attempt to avoid the building of water-filtration plants by substituting stringent land-use controls, although virtually every major city in the United States filters its water.
Our housing and general building industry is conducting an aggressive campaign to protect the watershed through the building of filtration plants and for the continuation of regulations administered by local health departments and local governments.
Saul Gluckman, chairman, Apartment Owners Advisory Council of Suburban New York, serving Westchester, Putnam and Hudson Valley:
Unless three major changes in the Emergency Tenant Protection Act are achieved in 1995-96, the rental-apartment industry may be damaged beyond repair. There are over 20,000 rental units in 18 municipalities in the county with a concentration in the larger cities. Controls have been in effect for over 50 years.
Spiraling costs, coupled with very low allowable rents, have taken their toll on building maintenance, and owners are hard pressed to proceed with anything more than what is required by building codes and other regulations.
To preserve our dwindling housing stock, we believe that reforms such as vacancy decontrol must be adopted and that rent increases should be allowed when major capital improvements are made to a building.
If these reforms take place, we will have largely offset the detrimental effects of rent regulation in terms of the maintenance and improvement of rental buildings, thereby preserving our dwindling rental-housing stock in the county.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1460 words

HEADLINE: The Good, the Bad and the Uncertain

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
ECONOMIC indicators looked good -- but not that good -- for Westchester in 1994, with analysts saying that despite some gains, the county continued to lag behind the rest of the state and the nation.
The county's future is also problematic, and Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the State Department of Labor, said, "There are still some gray clouds on the horizon." 
 Mr. Surdey said that expressions of optimism from some quarters notwithstanding, the county has not rebounded from the recession -- although it is poised to turn the corner this year.
Layoffs continued at many of the county's largest employers -- and more are expected. The county's largest employer, International Business Machines, which employed 15,000 workers in the Hudson Valley in 1986, had only 7,300 in 1994. Reader's Digest in Pleasantville closed the year with 250 fewer jobs, down from 1,800 a year ago. And many smaller companies were following suit in an effort to streamline operations.
The job picture is not likely to brighten in the immediate future, Mr. Surdey said. General Motors, the country's largest automaker, is scheduled to close its North Tarrytown plant in 1996 -- which will mean a loss of 2,000 jobs. Macy's department store in White Plains is also planning to close, costing the county another 300 jobs. And Nynex, which has offices in White Plains, has announced that it is cutting its work force by 25 percent, although it is not known what that will mean in terms of job-loss numbers for Westchester.
Mr. Surdey said that last year Westchester grew at only one-ninth the pace of the rest of the country, judging by the economic indicators -- with the county growing at one-third the rate of the state and the state, in turn, growing at only one-third the rate of the rest of the United States.
On the plus side, economists were cheered by news in November that there were 1,000 new jobs in the county, the third consecutive month showing such an increase.
The latest numbers represented the best job growth the county has seen in three years. Some of the late-year growth was because of seasonal retail hiring, but most had to do with what Mr. Surdey called "real job growth" in the service sector, which includes engineering, accounting and management companies, health services and private educational and social services.
Noteworthy was an upswing in the number of manufacturing jobs to 44,200 in November, up by 4,000 over November 1993. That contrasted with the rest of the state, which saw a loss of 28,000 or 2.8 percent of its manufacturing jobs in November. Most of the growth in manufacturing jobs for Westchester was in fabricated metal products, electronic and electrical equipment and food products.
The jobless figure for November was 4.2 percent, the lowest for that time of year since 1992. But that figure could be misleading, Mr. Surdey said, because many discouraged workers -- former middle-management employees, among them -- have given up looking for jobs. Also, he said, some workers have left Westchester in search of better job prospects in other areas, a phenomenon the Department of Labor calls out-migration.
Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the county, said she was observing "a confluence of factors contributing to a turnaround" in Westchester. She cited an increase in commercial leasing -- especially a demand for light-industrial space -- and the announcement by Mastercard International that it would relocate its corporate headquarters to Purchase, on a former I.B.M. site, bringing 570 new jobs to the county.
Also, Ciba Corporation, a pharmaceutical and chemical company based in Basel, Switzerland, said in 1994 that it would keep its United States headquarters in Westchester. The concern, which had been considering a move to Connecticut, decided instead to maintain some of its space in Ardsley and also to lease offices in Tarrytown. The company employs 1,200 workers.
Geoffrey Thompson, a member of the Westchester Business Partnership, a public-private effort to promote the county, said office vacancy rates countywide dropped in 1994 to 22.3 percent, compared with nearly 27 percent in 1993.
Mr. Thompson, a partner in Thompson & Bender, a public relations and advertising firm in Pleasantville, said it was the first time the vacancy rate had declined since 1990. About 1.14 million square feet of office space was absorbed in 1994, compared with 1993 when 1.25 million square feet was abandoned.
The vacancy rate in downtown White Plains, one of the highest in the country, dropped to 30 percent from 35 percent in 1993.
"We have staunched the bleeding, stopped the hemorrhaging," Mr. Thompson said.
Despite the positive signs, Westchester continues to lag behind Fairfield County, both in terms of job growth and leasing activity, according to a report from the Rostenberg-Doern Company, a commercial realtor with offices in Stamford and Purchase.
During 1994, Fairfield saw its first office-construction activity -- 416,000 square feet -- since 1990. In Westchester, however, there was none. Yet economists said they were optimistic that as available space continued to be absorbed in Westchester, new construction would begin.
Looking ahead, Beth Abraham Hospital in the Bronx is renovating a former NCR building in Greenburgh for an adult day-care center and will hire 200 people.
Nordstrom's department store will open in White Plains at a new mall in March, hiring 600 workers. The $260 million mall, called the Westchester, will include 150 stores, in all generating about 2,500 full- and part-time jobs.
Tiffany & Company, the jewelry concern, is consolidating its manufacturing operations from Pleasantville and Manhattan to Pelham, adding about 100 new jobs.
Also, the Miles Corporation, a manufacturer of medical equipment, agreed to remain in the county after it was given reductions in its power costs in an arrangement with Consolidated Edison and the town of Greenburgh, along with other concessions. The company said it plans this year to add 200 workers to its staff of 800.
As the commercial real estate market improved, so did residential sales. Nicholas R. Wolff, director of Century 21 Wolff in White Plains and a member of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said the lowest interest rates in 20 years in early 1994 encouraged first-time home buyers. Many condominium owners traded up to first homes, and some of those who owned small houses purchased larger ones.
Third-quarter performance for 1994, when seasonally adjusted, was equivalent to a yearly sales rate of 6,930 units, which was 20 percent higher than in 1993, a Board of Realtors report said. The largest increase, 36.6 percent, was in sales of condominiums.
Meanwhile, median sale prices of Westchester homes, which had climbed by about 6 percent in the second quarter of the year, slipped back by about the same amount in the third quarter. The $288,000 median sale price of a single-family house was down $19,000 or 6.2 percent from 1993.
As 1994 wore on, however, the rise in interest rates put a damper on real estate activity. Savo Fries, president of Westchester Multiple Listing Service, said that an increase of even "a half-point or so" eliminates many buyers.
"This is especially hard on first-time buyers," he said, "and the effect is mostly felt in sales of the lower-priced properties that serve the first-time buyer market."
At the banking offices of Chase Manhattan, William H. Dickinson, a vice president, said that the volume of residential mortgages written in 1994 dropped 50 percent. Also, refinancing accounted for 75 percent of all mortgage business in 1993, compared with 1994 when it amounted to 20 percent.
John N. D'Agostino, business director for Citibank's community business division, said that it appeared that the Northeast as a whole, where housing prices traditionally are among the highest, was the first to see a growth in the 1980's and will be "the last to see a recovery."
"The economy here," he said, "is not as strong as everyone thinks it is."
Two trends indicate that customers, too, are taking a dim view of the economy, Mr. D'Agostino said. Depositors are saving more in personal accounts and paying down on their debts -- "squirreling money away now," he said, "because they are unsure about the future."
But Mr. Surdey at the State Labor Department said Westchester is well positioned to catch up and move ahead in the years ahead because companies seeking to relocate will likely find the county a desirable place to do business.
Westchester has a highly skilled employee base available for work because of layoffs from corporate downsizing, and it has commercial space available to accommodate expansion, he said.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 1, 1995

SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: Why Democracy?

BYLINE: By Alan Ryan; Alan Ryan's "John Dewey and the High Tide of American Liberalism" will be published later this year.

 BODY:

CONDITIONS OF LIBERTY
Civil Society and Its Rivals.
By Ernest Gellner.
225 pp. New York:
Allen Lane/
The Penguin Press. $27.95. 
THE collapse of Communism in the old Soviet bloc revealed that in all its years Communism had done little to change the attitudes and aspirations of its victims; such desires as political freedom, national independence and the chance of prosperity for their children had been in cold storage, but were instantly revived. It also revealed that although Communist governments had been quite ineffective in creating a new Communist human nature and a new Communist society, they had been all too effective in undermining the habits and attitudes that a liberal democracy depends on.
It is this observation that provides Ernest Gellner's starting point in "Conditions of Liberty," a witty, elegant and sharply pointed essay on the prospects for liberal democracy in the late 20th century. The task of post-Communist society has often been described as that of building or rebuilding "civil society." Mr. Gellner's book is an account of what that means, what constitutes a "civil society" and what other ways of organizing social and economic life might have as much staying power as the capitalist, liberal, democratic mix that Europe and the United States have created over the last two centuries. Mr. Gellner -- for many years a professor of philosophy at the London School of Economics, later a professor of social anthropology at Cambridge University and now director of the Center for the Study of Nationalism at the Central European University in Prague -- also asks what chance there is of other societies' creating that mixture deliberately, and how attractive we can expect the ideal to be in societies not already attached to liberal, democratic and capitalist values.
People who have read any of Mr. Gellner's many other works will know to expect a dazzling high-speed tour of the largest issues in sociology and political theory. "Conditions of Liberty" is crammed with historical, anthropological and philosophical arguments in which the religious attachments of the Berbers compete for our attention with the 18th-century Scottish Enlightenment, and the iniquities of Stalin with the insights of the philosopher Sir Karl Popper. Not every argument is convincing, but there is never a dull moment.
What is civil society? That is an oddly difficult question. As Mr. Gellner observes, until the slow decline of Communism during the 1970's and 80's, the expression was not much heard: "A person interested in the notion of Civil Society could be assumed to be a historian of ideas, concerned perhaps with Locke or Hegel. But the phrase itself had no living resonance or evocativeness. Rather, it seemed distinctly covered with dust." It is clear that civil society was something the West had and the Communist regimes had crushed or stifled. More positively, civil society meant the social and economic arrangements that counterbalanced the power of the state by providing an alternative source of power and prestige to the state itself.
BUT in order to form civil society, these arrangements must have a particular character. As Mr. Gellner points out, there are many societies in which other institutions exist apart from the state and as a restraint on it. One is what anthropologists call a segmentary society; in such societies families have far-reaching authority over their members, and the state has little authority over the families. Such societies are pluralist, but they suffer from an obvious defect -- in our eyes -- which is that they are stifling. Their inhabitants may be unbothered by the government, but they are continuously under the eye of their cousins.
What we are after, Mr. Gellner says, can only be defined as pluralism "of a certain kind" -- a pluralism that is secular, individualistic, built on capitalist economic relations and scientifically minded rather than superstitious or given to magical thinking. That is what Max Weber thought Western Europe had built on the basis of the Protestant Reformation. That creation was paradoxical because Protestantism had been anything but tolerant, secular, easygoing and worldly in its origins. Nonetheless, it turned out to be the ideal device for reducing the power of the priesthood, breeding intellectual independence and instituting an individualism highly favorable to economic growth.
The fact that civil society was thus the unexpected gift of several centuries of religious upheaval and frequently unwanted economic and technological change raises some old and famous questions. Given that liberalism, capitalism and democracy took root in Western Europe, and later in those parts of the world to which British colonialism exported it, what are their prospects elsewhere? And if those prospects are not altogether bright, how much does it matter? Are there other satisfactory ways of being a modern society, ways that would not suit North Atlantic "us" but might suit East Asian or Middle Eastern or post-Communist "them"? If there are, is coexistence possible between the inhabitants of a civil society and the inhabitants of whatever other sorts of society can survive in the modern world?
THIS is Mr. Gellner's territory; as an anthropologist he has spent his life puzzling over the conditions of modernization, and as a philosopher he has always celebrated the rise of what Karl Popper called "the open society." The philosopher and the anthropologist have coexisted in some tension, however, since Mr. Gellner has combined an unswerving defense of the moral, political and intellectual superiority of the liberal, pluralist, scientifically oriented modern world with an equally unswerving readiness to believe that many of its rivals are perfectly viable. Indeed, a good deal of "The Condition of Liberty" is devoted to a wry examination of the strange fact that Communist Eastern Europe was one of the unusual cases where a social system just imploded.
Mr. Gellner does not wish to suggest that civil society is the inevitable gift of capitalism and industri alization. Japan has effectively combined a feudal social order with striking economic success; Singapore has no wish to emulate the United States, as its spokesmen frequently remind us. Islam may or may not prove to be compatible with economic progress when the oil runs out, but thus far religious radicalism flourishes in many countries while secular radicalism fades.
Is this alarming? Mr. Gellner thinks not. It is hard on the societies of the former Soviet bloc, with which the discussion started, that they can neither expect to create a civil society by wishing for it nor find themselves creating it in the process of rebuilding their
economies. But on the international scene, we have not much to fear. In his view, the vast preponderance of economic and military power lies with societies attached to the ideals of a civil society. He concludes: "They can live with the polities which do not share the spirit of Civil Society, as long as they themselves retain that dominance and minimal cohesion, and as long as the most recent cohort of effective industrializers continues to be interested in wealth and not much else."
Whether those conditions can be expected to apply forever is another matter entirely, and one on which Mr. Gellner does not speculate. Some readers may wish that he had placed a bet on the outcome of the competition between American chaos and Singaporean order. Most will be content to have such a friendly guide to the nature of the competition, and will at any rate end "Conditions of Liberty" better able to make up their own minds.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Drug Turf Is Safer as Dealers Avoid Streets

SERIES: When Crime Recedes: Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
When Danny Cabero returned recently from two years in prison for drug possession he hardly recognized his old turf in Washington Heights, where streets were once congested with young men hawking drugs to drive-by addicts, and guns and knives were preferred means of communication.
"It's quiet," said Mr. Cabero, 20, who went back this spring to the northern Manhattan neighborhood that became a landmark in the nation's cocaine crisis. "They have less people selling drugs in the street. Less people robbing. One thing you can say about Washington Heights: you can walk down the street here and be safe." 
 Although there is no evidence that the drug trade has diminished significantly, it has become less violent. With the sharp decline in the city's crime rate, Washington Heights offers evidence that the deadly edge of the drug business has dulled, at least momentarily, with police strategies more effective and some turf wars between dealers now settled.
In 1991, when those wars were raging, 119 people were killed in Washington Heights; last year the number fell to 56. Shootings dropped by a quarter from 1993 to 1994. And possibly as a result of an increased police presence in the neighborhood, reports of other crimes, like auto theft and grand larceny, fell significantly last year.
With legions of former drug sellers now consigned to either cells or coffins, both the police and residents say there are fewer new recruits taking their places on the streets.
Everyone has his own barometer for the drop in crime. The Rev. Earl Kooperkamp of the Church of the Intercession, at 155th Street and Broadway, says he is rarely harassed by drug dealers now. "It used to be constant," he said. "When I was driving around making parish visits -- a white guy in a Jeep -- it was constant soliciting: 'Hey, Popi. What do you want? What do you want?' "
While new programs in Washington Heights are offering youths alternatives to the street and more tenant groups are fighting drugs in their buildings, the biggest changes in crime appear linked to police efforts and changes in the drug trade.
These days, the police see more organization and sophistication among dealers, whose operations have been forced from the streets into apartment buildings by years of enforcement pressure. Narcotics officers say knots of street dealers have been replaced by a handful of "steerers" on the sidewalk, directing customers to apartments outfitted as sales offices. The men on the street use electronic buzzers and walkie-talkies to warn those inside about the nearby police.
Many of the apartments are furnished with nothing more than a desk or two, scales for weighing drugs and nearly invisible custom-made compartments for hiding contraband. When officers raided an apartment on 190th Street recently, they made five arrests and seized 25 pounds of cocaine and two guns. But what surprised them most was the network of video cameras trained on the street to spot police activity.
Many drug dealers now use one apartment for transactions and others, blocks away, to stash larger amounts of drugs and money. And the police say cars are being customized so that the push of a hidden button opens a secret compartment in the dashboard.
"It's more secretive and better hidden now," said Richard Wells, a police officer in Washington Heights for the last four years. "It was so blatant before."
The crack explosion of the mid-1980's transformed the side streets of Washington Heights into wholesale cocaine supermarkets minutes from New Jersey, Westchester County and other parts of the city. In July 1986, in an undercover political event to show how open the selling had become, Rudolph W. Giuliani, then the United States Attorney in Manhattan, put on a leather vest and sunglasses, and together with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who wore a windbreaker and Army cap, bought crack as part of a buy-and-bust operation on 160th Street.
The market overwhelmed both the police and the new Dominican population, which had grown in Washington Heights since the mid-1970's.
Washington Heights, with a population of about 300,000, remains one of the most dangerous parts of the city and is still a favored destination for cocaine buyers. The police also say heroin -- which preceded cocaine as the main drug available in the neighborhood -- is now being sold with increasing frequency.
But much is different. The number of police officers has increased to 445 from 338 in the last two years. The police precinct itself has been split in two, creating a second station house for the neighborhood.
Community policing programs, expanded under the Dinkins administration, have more officers walking beats. And new powers granted to street officers by the Giuliani administration allow them to investigate and arrest drug sellers, augmenting the department's narcotics division, which previously handled most drug investigations. Through mid-December, the police made more than 2,800 drug arrests in Washington Heights in 1994, nearly 35 percent more than in 1993.
"A couple of years ago, we'd see these guys in the street; we knew they were drug dealers, but we'd just pass them by," said Dennis Rodriguez, an officer who has patrolled some of the most drug-infested streets of Washington Heights. "Maybe we would just tell them to move on. But when you went off the block, they came back. We were handcuffed."
The department has tried a variety of other strategies, including seizing the cars of buyers who travel across the George Washington Bridge and from other areas to make their purchases. And although the volume of the drug business cannot be measured, both the police and residents say it has slowed slightly.
The crackdown has pushed some drug activity south to Harlem, and some New York drug dealers have moved to less competitive markets upstate and in other East Coast cities, say both the police and others familiar with the drug business.
The trade still comprises mostly small operations, each run by fewer than a dozen people, the police say. The difference now is that is that fewer of these operations exist. "On one block you could have three or four major players," Mr. Rodriguez said. "Five years ago on these blocks you could hardly get down the street, there were so many guys. And there were shootouts all the time because of the competition."
Police officials say those battles -- which drew police attention and hurt the drug business -- have been quelled to some degree by understandings between dealers about who controls which areas.
"It's like the Mafia," said John Coyne, a lieutenant in the 33d Precinct in the lower half of Washington Heights. "You go back 50 or 60 years and they were killing each other right and left, but you put someone in charge, and they know the rules and they don't kill each other as much."
To community leaders, the reduction in crime also reflects an evolution of the immigrant community, which has increased its political power and expanded organizations to combat a host of ills, from apartment overcrowding to the high rate of school dropouts.
"It's the normal growth and development of the community," said Victor Morisete, the executive director of the Community Association of Progressive Dominicans. "When you have a stake in where you live, you will think differently, you will treat that area differently, and crime is one of the things that is affected."
A turning point for the neighborhood was five days of disturbances in July 1990 ignited by the killing of Jose (Kiko) Garcia, a drug suspect, by Officer Michael O'Keefe during a scuffle. Although the officer was cleared of any wrongdoing, the killing raised the suspicions of many residents that the police were abusive and corrupt.
At the time, crime seemed boundless, and the influx of young immigrants had overwhelmed the already-crowded schools. Many had turned to the drug trade.
"I felt that perhaps we were threatened in a way we never were before," said Guillermo Linares, who in 1991 became the first Dominican immigrant elected to the City Council. "It was overwhelming to see people standing on the street and knowing that there is something going on that is not right and that the only way to confront it is if the whole community comes together to confront it."
The disturbances, with overturned cars aflame and the police under attack from flying rocks and bottles, opened a pressure valve in Washington Heights. Since then, residents' requests for more officers have been answered, and community and police officials have tried to erase stereotypes of all cops as corrupt thugs and all young immigrants as gun-packing drug dealers.
The redoubled focus on Washington Height's youths can be seen daily behind the battered brown doors of P.S. 143, where an after-school program of athletics, academics and crafts attracts hundreds of young people, from pre-teen students to former convicts wearing gang beads.
"This becomes like a surrogate home for these kids," said Eddie Silverio, a program director.
At the school on a recent night, Mr. Silverio asked Mr. Cabero about the 10 closest friends he had before he went to prison. "Those 10 people," Mr. Cabero said, "are now behind the walls of Sing Sing, Attica . . . "
Mr. Silverio motioned to another man in the room that night. Milton Martinez, 28, who described himself as the leader of the Netas gang in Washington Heights, is a former drug dealer who has served sentences for robbery and attempted murder. Released this fall, he swears he is a changed man.
Mr. Silviero said reducing crime permanently may require more than just putting people in prison and putting more police officers on the street, especially in neighborhoods where the economy is fragile and money for youth programs is scarce.
"There are no jobs," Mr. Silverio said. "What's Milton going to do to survive?"
NEXT: A Brooklyn neighborhood where reported crime is down but gangs are increasing and people are as fearful as ever.

Charts: "BEHIND THE NUMBERS: Crime Patterns in the Boroughs"
 Although crime has been a major concern of many New Yorkers, the actual rate of crimes reported to the police has risen and fallen several times in the last decade or so. Crime reached a low point in 1985 but climbed steadily through 1990 as the crack epidemic brought a wave of lawlessness to neighborhoods throughout the city. Since then crime has fallen steeply. But the changes have not affected all neighborhoods equally. JOSH BARBANEL
 
PERSONAL FELONIES
 Only in Manhattan have the numbers of felonies against people -- homicides, robberies and assaults -- fallen below the levels reported in 1985. In Staten Island and Queens, which have relatively low crime rates, the rates are far above the levels of the mid-1980's, 33 percent higher in Staten Island, 18 percent higher in Queens. And in all boroughs except Manhattan, the homicide rate is above the level reported in 1985, with Queens recording an increase of more than 40 percent through the decade.
 
PROPERTY FELONIES
 Crimes against property, like burglary and auto theft, are also down the most in Manhattan. Since 1985 burglaries have fallen by a third in Manhattan and by almost as much in Brooklyn. Auto thefts skyrocketed from 1985 to 1990, with Queens, the Bronx and Brooklyn posting increases of greater than 90 percent. Since 1990, car thefts have declined, but by not nearly as much, and remain 20 percent higher than a decade before.

HEADLINE: WELFARE DEBATE WILL RE-EXAMINE OLD ASSUMPTIONS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
A great debate is about to begin over one of the major premises of America's social welfare policy: that low-income people are legally entitled to Government aid guaranteeing a minimum standard of living.
Many of the Republicans who will take control of Congress on Wednesday contend that welfare, Medicaid and food stamps should be stripped of their status as open-ended "entitlements." Instead, they say, Congress should appropriate fixed amounts of money each year for those programs, whose size would no longer increase automatically when, for example, a recession put more people out of work. 
 Neither Democrats nor Republicans are proposing significant changes in the largest entitlement program, Social Security, or withdrawing the entitlement status of Medicare, although the money spent on those two programs dwarfs the spending on welfare and food stamps.
Instead, the battle lines have been drawn over the use of entitlements to guarantee a minimum standard of living for the poor. That struggle transcends the debate over specific Republican proposals that would, for example, increase the use of orphanages, impose stringent work requirements on welfare recipients and eliminate aid to the children of young unmarried women.
Here is the outlook:
*The Clinton Administration is reassessing the whole question of entitlements, is receptive to some changes and has not decided on a strategy for dealing with Republican proposals to restructure welfare.
*Nonpartisan experts believe that Congress may, for the first time, limit Federal Medicaid spending, which has doubled in four years, reaching $82 billion in 1994. Medicaid provides health care for 33 million low-income people; Medicare finances health care for 36 million people who are elderly or disabled.
*Congress will consider giving states a lump-sum payment, or block grant, to help poor people now entitled to benefits under the main cash welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Block grants would be a radical departure because they would eliminate individual entitlement to benefits and would give states more flexibility in deciding how to use the money.
*The food stamp program is perhaps the most secure of the major programs for poor people. House Republicans want to put it into a block grant with other food and nutrition programs, but they expect resistance because food stamps have support from a middle-class constituency that includes farmers, grocers and the food industry generally.
The struggle will challenge Democrats, in the Administration and in Congress, to explain why entitlement programs were created and why they should be continued.
Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican on the Budget Committee, said: "We have to get these programs off autopilot. They should be subject to annual appropriations. Entitlements have taken away the power of the people, through Congress, to decide where money is spent each year." Congress would need more control over spending to comply with a proposed constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget, he said in an interview.
Democrats say the welfare and food stamp programs serve a valuable economic purpose, infusing money into a state when recession hits, unemployment rises and more families need assistance.
Representative Sander M. Levin of Michigan, a member of the Ways and Means Committee who is trying to coordinate the Democratic strategy on welfare legislation, said he strongly believed that states should have more flexibility in designing programs, but he worried about Republican efforts to replace entitlement programs. "What would happen in times of recession?" he asked in an interview. "You can't repeal economic cycles."
Another Democrat, Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, said entitlement programs responded automatically to economic and demographic changes.
Mr. Shays countered, "That's a good argument, but in the process we're going bankrupt."
In an entitlement program, the Government has a legal obligation to pay benefits to all applicants who meet criteria set by Federal law. The formulas for deciding who gets how much stay the same from year to year unless Congress votes to change them. If the demand for aid exceeds expectations, Congress must somehow come up with more money, by borrowing, raising taxes or cutting other items in the budget.
By contrast, Congress appropriates specific amounts each year for discretionary spending programs, which include defense, medical research, law enforcement, Head Start and job training.
Entitlement programs account for slightly more than half of all Federal spending, roughly $800 billion of $1.5 trillion last year. The large middle-class entitlements, Social Security and Medicare, which pay benefits regardless of financial need, dwarf the programs for low-income people -- the Government spent $475 billion on Social Security and Medicare in 1994, compared with $125 billion on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, food stamps and Medicaid. But Social Security, which both parties have found to be a volatile issue, is off the table, and Congress is not considering changing the entitlement status of Medicare.
The roots of these programs run deep. Welfare, under the name Aid to Dependent Children, was part of the Social Security Act in 1935. President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Food Stamp Act in 1964. Medicaid and Medicare were created in 1965.
While committed to the overall goals of those programs, the Clinton Administration has not decided whether or how to defend their status as entitlements. White House officials are mulling that question as they prepare for a conference on welfare with governors and members of Congress from both parties in the next few weeks.
Administration officials said President Clinton, a former governor, was sympathetic to the governors' pleas for more flexibility in using Federal money.
Asked if she would defend the entitlement status of welfare and Medicaid, Avis LaVelle, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, said: "No, I can't. There is a re-evaluation going on throughout the department as to the whole concept of entitlement programs. It's just not smart for us to take an advocacy position one way or another. The ground is shifting under our feet."
Representative Levin said Democrats in Congress and the Administration had "no clear strategy" for dealing with the Republican proposals at this time. "It's important for us to develop one quickly," he said.
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said that if lawmakers wanted to slow the growth of welfare programs, they could do so without eliminating the entitlement to benefits. For example, he said, Congress could restrict eligibility or make benefits less generous. Such changes could save substantial amounts of money, but the Government would still have a legal obligation to pay benefits to any applicants who met the criteria.
There is fierce competition for money among domestic programs, and it is likely to intensify this year. Current law imposes an annual limit on all discretionary spending through 1998, and President Clinton says he wants to maintain the ceiling at current levels in 1999 and 2000. Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the Republican in line to become chairman of the House Budget Committee, says he wants to reduce the spending limits.
If a benefit program loses its status as an entitlement, it would have to compete with all the other domestic programs for money. And that, many Republicans say, is exactly what should happen.

HEADLINE: Democrats Talk of Power on the Last Days With It

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1

 BODY:
Like the dispirited troops of a defeated army, Democrats and Congressional staff members prepared to relinquish cherished posts and cluttered, file-filled cabinets on the eve of the Republican takeover of the House of Representatives. Lunch gatherings were grim, partings tearful and wishes for the new year filled with gallows humor.
At the Ford Annex building, Judi Greenwald introduced several colleagues as they were packing: "We're with the subcommittee on energy and power. At least we are until the end of the day." 
 The absolute, and at times absolutely capricious, exercise of power on Capitol Hill was a recurrent theme throughout that long goodbye. Each of those staff members had known for nearly a year that they would be unemployed come 1995, since Representative Philip R. Sharp, the Indiana Democrat for whom they all worked, chose not to run for re-election. But not one had expected to be part of a broader exodus.
"We knew a long time ago," Ms. Greenwald said. "We just didn't have any idea that we were going to be in a whole throng of people."
For Leon Lowery, the departure had great import. "Not only have you lost your personal job," he said, "but people are telling you that the whole ideology you represent has been rejected by America. Personally, professionally, emotionally -- any level you take -- it's pretty tough."
Shelley Fidler just grimaced. "Leon has been reading the Bible," she said. "Lamentations."
Mr. Lowery raised an eyebrow. "A lot of people don't believe in government," he said with a touch of devilish revenge. "But now they are going to have to run it."
Not everyone caught up in the change was so morose. While assorted Democrats fretted, feted and gnashed, Representative Newt Gingrich and his newly minted Republican majority were champing at the bit for power. Parties around the city were full of Republican revelers still toasting the November victory, while the newly anointed seemed as anxious as first-time suitors as they prepared to move into new offices.
Washington's permanent population was already figuring to profit from the shift. Among the first businesses to capitalize on the change has been that most ephemeral and yet most constant of Washington power bases: the trendy restaurants in which dining and doing business combine.
"Republicans eat, too," said Steven Damato, the owner of Nora's, a homey-trendy restaurant that is a favorite of President Clinton's family. Mr. Damato said the restaurant would be host to a Republican event on Tuesday, one night before the 104th Congress convenes.
And the future looks good, too. "Change is wonderful for business," Mr. Damato said. "The restaurants will be packed full of special interests."
Real estate agents were crowing as well, using the most potent of Washington put-offs to inform reporters that they were simply too busy to talk. Several moaned that they could not stay on the phone for more than a few minutes since their appointments with incoming power brokers were stacked like salmon jumping the rapids.
"There has been an awful lot of scurrying around," said a very rushed Mike Frias, an agent at John Forman Real Estate.
By most accounts, the new Washingtonians were settling as near as possible to ground zero, in the Victorian row houses and quaint apartments on the tree-lined but sometimes crime-infested streets near Capitol Hill.
It makes for a blissfully short commute and great public relations bites. "These folks come in extremely early, work late. If they have a break, they want to go home," Mr. Frias said.
But few have been buying properties. "New members are not interested in giving their constituency the impression that they are becoming entrenched," Mr. Frias said. Or else, just maybe, they have a clear and present sense of the fickleness of a disgruntled electorate.
Over in Federal buildings where unsuspecting professionals have been chopped out of politics in part of a general restructuring initiated by Mr. Gingrich, confusion and resentment mixed with a poignant sense of purpose.
"I guess I am looking for a job," said Dr. Raymond W. Smock, the recently out-of-work House historian, who had to inform his staff of five that they were also abruptly unemployed since the office was decreed closed by the incoming Speaker. "But, hey, I'm not complaining. Five thousand Amtrak employees are out of work. Nobody has any sympathy for anybody on the Hill who lost his job."
In Federal buildings on Capitol Hill this week, offices were exchanged and furniture dragged about in the traditional horse trading that comes with the flip-flop of minority and majority slots. Republicans moved into majority cubbyholes. Members of the former majority slipped down to minority digs, and some offices closed for good as part of the extensive restructuring.
It is hard, though, to quantify the scope of change just now. The House historian's office cannot say because data from the 104th Congress is not yet in. By the time the statistics emerge, the historian's office itself will be long gone.
Last week, even the House clerk's staff could not answer basic questions. Inquiries about staff changes, personnel cutbacks and committee clear-outs were referred to Mr. Gingrich's office with the advice: "Ask him. He's the guy with the power. He's only one who knows what's happening."
Longtime residents of Washington are used to all of this. The capital's equivalent of a stiff upper lip is a sense of denial. "We're used to this," said countless members of the newly unemployed. "It's politics."
Subsets of the city were already gearing up for an adrenaline rush, though. John Brademas, the chairman of the President's Committee on Arts and Humanities, girded for guerrilla warfare. A longtime Democratic Congressman from Indiana and a former president of New York University, he knows how to play politics.
After acknowledging that financing for the arts, education and humanities was a prominent Republican target for the cutting board, Mr. Brademas mentioned almost casually that most of the prominent board members of major opera companies, museums, theater groups were powerful Republicans with ample funds and huge political leverage.
"We're not quite sure what's going to happen yet," he said. "But savage reductions in these programs would mark a giant step backwards. And at least in my experience -- which stretches back to Eisenhower -- every government has come up with funds."
Fine and well for opera performers if that record holds. But the House historian, Dr. Smock, really was watching history pass by. Tapping his foot against a nondescript wooden crate last week, he mentioned that its contents were the private letters and papers of Speaker Joseph G. Cannon, whose rule ended in 1911.
"It doesn't look like something out of 'The Raiders of the Lost Ark,' " Dr. Smock said, creaking the crate open. "But, hey, it's the real thing."

HEADLINE: China Revamps Forces With Eye to Sea Claims

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 1

 BODY:
As Chinese diplomats talk of peaceful coexistence with their Southeast Asian neighbors, China's military leaders are refurbishing a portion of their large and antiquated military to enforce claims of sovereignty over the South China Sea and its resources, Chinese and Western experts say.
In this effort, Chinese military leaders have nurtured specific industries to develop advanced weapons technology and are tailoring their naval and air forces for the region, the experts say, even as the country's overall level of military production is declining. 
 At stake are potentially vast oil reserves, minerals and fishing grounds that intersect some of the world's busiest shipping lanes. With energy demands surging along with the population, oil supplies are falling behind in China, which in 1993 became a net importer of oil for the first time. So any major oil discovery in the South China Sea is likely to draw Beijing's immediate attention on securing it.
A group of former American military leaders who visited China last year has reported that China is forming a limited military force "capable of rapid response" and intended to protect "island claims in the South China Sea as a matter of national priority."
The group was led by former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and four recently retired four-star military officers, including David E. Jeremiah, a former Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and James P. McCarthy, a former deputy commander of United States forces in Europe.
Although comprehensive military modernization remains a distant goal for China, these and other experts say, Beijing has in recent years taken these steps to build up its military:
*Improved its ability to fight a sustained sea battle with its fleet of surface warships, support vessels and submarine forces.
*Negotiated with Russia to buy 72 advanced Su-27 attack aircraft capable of providing close air support for naval operations at extended range. (The first 24 Su-27s were delivered in 1992 but negotiations over the terms for the rest have been troublesome.)
*Organized a handful of marine units for amphibious assault and trained airborne forces for rapid deployment in Soviet-made transport aircraft. (One such force is based on Hainan Island for quick dispatch to the Spratlys and the Paracels, two island chains in the South China Sea.)
*Developed mobile, conventional-warhead missiles to threaten any foe within 1,000 miles.
"By the year 2005, they would like to achieve a core force of 500,000 to one million across their services who are fairly modern," said one specialist on Chinese military affairs.
Apart from the recent efforts, however, this goal seems illusive to other experts because China is still technologically unsophisticated in some areas.
Chinese warships, for example, have little or no effective air defense, and their targeting radars cannot reach over the horizon. China has no hope of financing aircraft-carrier development for at least a decade. Its submarines are noisy and vulnerable and are equipped with poorly functioning torpedoes.
The Chinese Air Force has yet to produce a modern, supersonic aircraft with all-weather air-to-air combat abilities. And China's air defense system could not stop penetration by the French Mirage 2000 attack planes recently purchased by Taiwan, whose pilots get more flight training hours in a month than Chinese pilots get in a year, experts say.
"We are aware that our weaponry of all services is far behind the present equipment of the United States," Adm. Liu Huaqing, China's top military officer, told the McNamara group. "We hope to modernize, but the problem is that we have no resources; and if we compete with economic needs, we will be in competition with the economy, and that is not in China's interest."
Still, Chinese and Western specialists say, Beijing's limited buildup is threatening to neighbors like Vietnam, which lost two vessels in a clash with Chinese forces in 1988.
"The danger of what we have on the question of China's military is that people are beginning to make the case that China is benign," said James R. Lilley, a former Ambassador to Beijing and longtime Central Intelligence Agency officer in Asia.
"China says it has no military objectives, that on the South China Sea it wants to cooperate to find a diplomatic solution while exploiting the resources, that there are no military solutions and that China is focusing on the economy," he said.
Arguing that by all appearances, China's military buildup is tightly focused on the South China Sea area, Mr. Lilley added: "I'm afraid the evidence tells us otherwise. And it is quite clear that that is their objective in 10 to 20 years."
Experts point out that Admiral Liu, a member of the ruling Politburo and former chief of the navy, has been a leading advocate for seizing the rich mineral and fishing grounds of the South China Sea to support China's swelling population. The diet of China's population, Admiral Liu once told the New China News Agency, will increasingly require the protein supplied from fish. As exploitation of sea-based resources becomes more important, he added, China will need a modern navy. Indeed, China's consumption of seafood has quadrupled since 1978.
In February 1992, the National People's Congress issued its "Law on the Territorial Waters and Their Contiguous Areas," which laid claim to 80 percent of the South China Sea with a horseshoe-shaped boundary that runs the length of Vietnam's coastline and then swings southwest to waters off Malaysia, Brunei and the Philippines.
The law laid down regulations for transit through the area and called for "immediate eviction of foreign military vessels or vessels owned by foreign governments and used for noncommercial purposes that violate the laws and regulations" of China. Seventy percent of Japan's crude oil imports traverses the area.
Last month, the official Guangming Daily said 400 Chinese scholars recently completed 10 years of research on the Spratly Islands and "proved historically" that China "discovered and developed the Spratly Islands."
The Spratlys -- comprising 21 islands and atolls, 50 submerged land spits and 28 partly submerged bits of rock and reef spread out over 340,000 square miles -- "are a sacred and inviolable part of Chinese territory," the newspaper said.
The United States has never taken a position on the territorial disputes in the South China Sea, which also involve claims by Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, Indonesia and Brunei. By far the most contentious dispute is between China and Vietnam, whose naval forces clashed most recently in 1988 when Chinese warships sank two Vietnamese vessels with the loss of more than 70 lives.
In 1990, Prime Minister Li Peng offered to put the sovereignty question aside and called for joint development of oil resources by all the claimants, but there were no takers.
In mid-1992, China contracted with a small American company, the Crestone Energy Corporation, to begin oil exploration off Vietnam's coast near Ho Chi Minh City. Vietnam replied last year by granting the Mobil Oil Corporation drilling rights in adjacent waters.
Diplomats in the region say China and Vietnam pledged in November to "refrain from all acts" that could "broaden conflicts" or lead to the use of force in the region. But a state visit to Hanoi by Chinese President Jiang Zemin did little to allay Vietnam's concern about China's long-term intentions.
While future use of military force by Beijing in the South China Sea is considered possible, Michael Swaine, an expert on the Chinese military at the Rand Corporation, argues that by occupying islands and drilling for oil, China has seized "a negotiating position" and may want to avoid further military conflict.
