HEADLINE: A New President, and Brasilia Is Again a Capital of Hope

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Jan. 1

 BODY:
Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a 63-year-old sociologist, was inaugurated as Brazil's President today, promising to give all his energy to banishing inflation from Latin America's largest nation.
"The majority of Brazilians made a clear choice" for low inflation and high growth, Mr. Cardoso said, referring to his landslide electoral victory in October. 
 Mr. Cardoso, the architect of Brazil's radically successful anti-inflation plan, also vowed in his inaugural address before Congress to further open Brazil to foreign investment and trade.
With "the opening of the Brazilian economy, we are leaving behind xenophobic attitudes," said Mr. Cardoso, whose government experience includes recent stints as Foreign Minister and Finance Minister.
"Today, there is no serious specialist who does not forecast for Brazil anything but a long period of growth," he said.
While 21-gun salutes and fighter jet flyovers noisily marked Mr. Cardoso's new role as Commander in Chief today, some recalled that he was once exiled and blacklisted for his opposition to Brazil's military rule, a period that lasted from 1964 to 1985.
"It's an irony I savor," a longtime friend of Mr. Cardoso, Peter D. Bell, recalled from New York. When Mr. Bell worked for the Ford Foundation in Rio de Janeiro in 1969, United States Embassy officials unsuccessfully pressured him to withhold funding for a study group Mr. Cardoso was forming. The American officials argued that Mr. Cardoso was a Communist and that he had no future in Brazil.
"Fernando Henrique's real crime was that he was a card-carrying democrat," said Mr. Bell, who is a chairman of the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington-based policy group. "In the context of the military dictatorship, democrats were seen as upsetting the apple cart."
Twenty-five years later, Mr. Cardoso is a social democrat who enjoys heavy business support. Today, he appealed in his nationally televised speech, "Let us retire the old ideological dilemmas and the old forms of confrontation."
On a day of gray skies and intermittent rain, this young capital exuded optimism, recalling the days in the 1960's when it was called "the capital of hope."
"Exceptional flight conditions," Brazil's leading business magazine, Exame, said of Mr. Cardoso's prospects. "No President has ever started his mandate in such an auspicious situation."
In a survey released today by the Datafolha polling organization, 70 percent of respondents predicted that the Cardoso Government would be "good" or "great."
Unfazed by the dramatic devaluation of the Mexican peso over the last 10 days, many Brazilians believe that their country is embarking on an economic boom that will rival the miracle years of the early 1970's.
"Thanks to the success of the Real Plan and to the election of its author as President, we are entering a new era, with the best chances and the best expectations that the country has ever had," Roberto Civita, publisher of Veja, the nation's most influential newsweekly, wrote today.
The Real Plan, carried out on July 1, slashed Brazil's monthly inflation rate from 45 percent in June to 2 percent in December. Low inflation touched off a spending boom and a surge in factory production, cutting unemployment. Brazil recorded 5 percent growth in 1994, a level that is expected to be equaled in 1995.
The turnaround has been so decisive that Itamar Franco left Brazil's presidency today with an 88 percent approval rating, the highest on record for a departing Brazilian President.
Encouraged by the low inflation and high growth, investors have flooded into Sao Paulo's stock market, and foreign investment is expected to grow. Mr. Cardoso has also promised to speed Brazil's program of privatizing state companies.
To meet his 1995 goals of 6 percent growth and 26 percent annual inflation, Mr. Cardoso will have to marshal congressional support to change Brazil's Constitution to allow more foreign investment, to transfer health and education duties to states, to raise more taxes and to close a yawning pension fund deficit.
Brazil's Congress reconvenes on March 1, and, at least for the first few months, Mr. Cardoso is expected to enjoy majority support.
About 60 percent of Brazil's 594 congressional representatives support Brazil's new President, according to Marcos Antonio Maciel, the nation's new Vice President.
Mr. Cardoso was elected on Oct. 3 with twice as many votes as his closest competitor, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva. Today, in inaugurations throughout Brazil, Cardoso allies became governors in 9 out of 10 of the most populous states, including Rio, Sao Paulo and Minas Gerais.
In composing his Cabinet, Mr. Cardoso expanded his three-party electoral coalition to include the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, the largest of 19 political parties represented in Congress.
The Cabinet is largely composed of men who are more than 45 years old, who have American university study on their resumes, and who are natives of Sao Paulo, Brazil's economic powerhouse.
One exception is the Special Minister for Sports: Edson Arantes do Nascimento, the retired soccer star known throughout the world as Pele. The first black in memory to be appointed to a Cabinet-level post, he has vowed to bring soccer fields to the millions of Brazilian children who live in urban shantytowns without access to them.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

REGION
 
GEORGE PATAKI BEGINS NEW ERA
Calling for a new revolution to make government both smaller and more effective, George Elmer Pataki became the 53d Governor of New York with an inaugural address that promised "sweeping and fundamental change -- change that is certain and immediate." In the 38-minute address, long enough to lull 7-year-old Owen Pataki to sleep on his mother's lap, Mr. Pataki repeatedly summoned the imagery of the American Revolution and suggested that his election was born of the same discontent with taxation and bureaucracy that incited the colonials. 
 "The battle which took place on a farm not far from here near Saratoga was the turning point in that revolution," he said, returning later in the speech to what he called the "revolutionary spirit of Saratoga." Page 1.
 
CAN GOVERNOR KEEP CAMPAIGN PROMISES?
In his speech, Mr. Pataki declared war on the government he was elected to run. Like all inaugural addresses, it was bereft of detail. But Mr. Pataki did reiterate his campaign themes: along with streamlining government, he wants to reinstate the death penalty, reduce taxes, put welfare recipients to work and cut Medicaid. Can he? The death penalty will inevitably return, but the fate of other promises rests largely on two factors that got little mention: the economy and politics. Metro Matters, Page 29.
 
TRUTH IS IN THE SEATING ARRANGEMENTS
For all the pageantry of the first Republican inauguration in Albany in 24 years, it was the seating arrangements, more than anything, that hammered home how much things have changed. Reporter's Notebook, Page 29.
 
GEORGE PATAKI: PRAGMATIC CONSERVATIVE
To the friends he met at Yale College 31 years ago, Mr. Pataki was a garrulous, beer-loving freshman who knew precisely where he stood on the political spectrum (to the right), the name of the next President (Barry Goldwater) and what he would become when he grew up (Governor of New York State). To the politicians he passed along the way, Mr. Pataki was also a conservative, but often a pragmatic one. His central beliefs did not stop him from working with more moderate politicians or from sometimes moderating his own views on difficult issues to achieve his own goals. Page 1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
WASHINGTON HEIGHTS IS LESS VIOLENT
Although there is no evidence that the drug trade in Washington Heights has diminished significantly, it has become less violent. With the sharp decline in New York City's crime rate, the area offers evidence that the deadly edge of the drug business has dulled, at least momentarily, with police strategies more effective and some turf wars between dealers now settled. And with legions of former drug sellers now consigned to either cells or coffins, both the police and residents say there are fewer new recruits taking their places on the streets. Page 1.
 
THE POLICE TRACE BOMB PLOT IN NOTES
Notes and drawings found in the home of Edward J. Leary, who is accused of being the subway firebomber, show that he planned to detonate bombs with motion-sensing devices and remote controls and to gun people down with a high-powered rifle as part of a terror campaign in the subways, a law-enforcement official said. The two gasoline bombs that have been attributed to Mr. Leary were both meant to explode aboard trains while they were in tunnels, possibly under the East River, to achieve the maximum carnage and panic, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mr. Leary has denied any role in the bombings. Page 27.
 
MAN ARRESTED AFTER A RAPE IN THE BRONX
A woman going to visit a friend in the Morrisania section of the Bronx was raped at gunpoint by a man who forced her into his van, the police said. After he threw her back out onto the street, battered and bruised, she called 911 and described the attacker to the officers who responded to the call. Two hours later, the officers spotted a man fitting the description of the rapist, and after they called for help from backup units, he was arrested. The suspect, Eugenio Cruz Jr., 26, of 788 Fox Street, was charged with rape, assault and other crimes. Page 27.

HEADLINE: Eastern Germany's Road to Modernity Leads to the Shopping Mall

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LEIPZIG, Germany

 BODY:
Watching change come to eastern Germany since the collapse of Communism five years ago is like watching newsreels of life from the 1950's to the 1990's speed past in fast-forward.
Office buildings and construction cranes have sprung up in every major city. Streets have been torn up for new telephone lines, new sewers and new power cables, and then torn up again for new cable television wires. 
 New roads snake steadily out from city centers, drawing suburban housing developments with them and bringing cars, more cars and constant traffic jams.
Now comes what some think could change the traditional German urban life style more than anything else yet: the American-style suburban shopping mall, surrounded by vast parking lots with fast-food outlets and cineplexes. Leipzig has the biggest one in the country.
"We now have the greatest concentration of these shopping centers in all of Germany," said Niels Gormsen, the supervisor of construction projects in Leipzig. "We see a danger that too many could kill off downtown commercial districts, just like in America."
Mr. Gormsen and many other city planners here would like to avoid the crass commercial strips and decaying urban downtowns as successfully as they did in most medium-size west German cities over the last 40 years.
He, like many other civil servants here, came from the west to replace the Communist functionaries who emulated Soviet urban development models in the old days.
But since reunification, commercial development and social change have come so fast that the city authorities have not had the time that was granted to them in western Germany to plan their cities to remain livable and commercially viable at the same time.
There, Germans built underground parking garages, pedestrian zones and modern streetcar lines so cities and their neighborhoods could survive the automobile and monster suburban malls.
Here, the first thing that happened after capitalism came to eastern Germany in 1990 was a rush by west German retailers to open large commercial developments the fastest way they could, on undeveloped land just outside the crumbling major cities.
In the urban area around Leipzig (population 500,000) and Halle (300,000) alone, they have opened centers with a total floor space of 215 acres and have permission to build another 62 acres' worth. City planners have turned down plans for 173 acres more.
"What they are building now are bankruptcies in the making," said Dr. Ulrich Hatzfeld, an urban expert in Dortmund, who calculated that nearly half of the shopping centers now being planned in Germany were in the eastern part of the country, which has only 20 percent of the population and even less of the total purchasing power.
More than half of all retail shopping space in eastern Germany is outside the city centers, while in western Germany only 25 to 30 percent is, Dr. Hatzfield said. Apart from a few huge malls near Frankfurt and Cologne, big suburban stores tend to be specialty shops for furniture, carpeting or gardening equipment.
Even more shopping malls might have developed in eastern Germany if not for the country's restrictive laws, which require all stores to close at 6:30 P.M. most weekdays, early afternoon on most Saturdays and all day Sunday. Other laws restrict price discounts.
"The main danger we see is not to the centers of historic cities like Leipzig or Dresden, but to neighborhoods on the periphery," Mr. Gormsen said. "It wouldn't be bad, from the city's point of view, if some of these shopping centers did go bankrupt."
Already, it can take more than an hour to drive the 10 miles from Leipzig to Germany's biggest shopping mall, the Saale Park at the intersection of Highway 9 and Route 181, financed by a German savings bank. Two smaller malls have also sprouted along the way.
"Most days, you just sit in a traffic jam to get out here," said Gabriele Smetanin, who had come out to the Saale Park to do her Christmas shopping at the new Peek & Cloppenburg department store there. "Actually, their new store downtown has a better selection," Mrs. Smetanin said. "I came out of habit today, I suppose, because this one opened first."
What east German shoppers find in new malls like the Saale Park and the Sachsenpark on the northeast edge of town is the sort of thing familiar to suburban American shoppers. At Saale Park there is bland background music, a giant Toys "R" Us, a 10-cinema movie complex, an Ikea furniture store, McDonald's and acres of parked cars.
"We're bringing customers a variety of choice they never dreamed of in the Communist days," said Bernhard Jager, the manager of the Saale Park mall, "and we've created hundreds of jobs. The villages around here didn't even have decent plumbing and electric power until we brought it to them with the mall."
And the customers keep coming.
Five years ago, Leipzig was an industrially polluted mess, the late Gothic Thomaskirche where Johann Sebastian Bach spent his most creative years as choirmaster slowly crumbling and begrimed like most of the 19th-century commercial buildings around it.
Today the church gleams, restored with money from the city and the state of Saxony. After a western developer, Jurgen Schneider, disappeared early this year to avoid bankruptcy, German banks financed the completion of a new indoor shopping gallery around Auerbach's Keller, a tavern that is one of the settings for Goethe's "Faust."
The compact city center has so many shops, malls and office buildings under construction that picking through the narrow streets is like running an obstacle course. Peek & Cloppenburg's store, a dramatic stone-and-glass building designed by a Santa Monica, Calif., architectural team -- Charles Moore, John Ruble and Buzz Yudell -- opened on the main shopping street, the Petersstrasse, last summer.
What Leipzig's downtown doesn't have enough of is parking spaces. It did not even have parking meters until after Communism collapsed, and the few spaces that exist are inadequate. An underground garage is only in the planning stages in front of the modern Gewandhaus, home to the orchestra once directed by Felix Mendelssohn-Bartholdy and now by Kurt Masur, who is also the music director of the New York Philharmonic.
"The one sad aspect to all of this is that almost all the building is for places where west German companies can sell products made in west Germany to east German consumers," said Dr. Christoph Bockenforde, another city official who came from the west. "We're consuming here, not creating -- so far," he said.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 28; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 4247 words

HEADLINE: THE GOVERNOR;
'The People Seek Change': Transcript of Pataki's Inaugural

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of Gov. George E. Pataki's inaugural address in Albany yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
 The change of administrations that we have just witnessed marks not just a transfer of political authority but a renewal of the democratic sanction under which it occurs, a reaffirmation of our common belief in a system of government that is ultimately answerable solely to the people. 
 It is also testimony to a political environment -- a political experiment in self-rule and individual freedom that when it began in this nation and state more than two centuries ago, most of the world saw as audacious and foolhardy, but one whose enduring vigor and simple good sense is testified to by our presence here this afternoon.
 As part of this democratic tradition, we have also just completed an election campaign that saw differing political views aired and argued, sometimes dispassionately, sometimes not so dispassionately all across our state.
 This sort of temporary division and robust disagreement is as it should be in a democracy. But now that the election is concluded, we meet here today to say, as President Jefferson taught us to say long ago, that we are all Democrats and all Republicans, that today our only resolve is to put the public interest above that of any party or faction.
 So, as we meet in this spirit of unity, we pledge as one people and one state to put aside personal and political differences and get on speedily and vigorously with the people's business.
 In that spirit, let me again acknowledge gratefully the assistance of Governor Cuomo in preparing for this change of administration.
 The Governor's three terms in office -- the Governor's three terms in office have earned him a rightful place in our history of our state. And Governor, now after 12 years I hope you will permit me again on behalf of all the people of New York to thank you and to thank Matilda for your devoted service.
 
The People's Moods
 Now, in mentioning the people's business, I also think it's fitting to mention today the people's moods. There is impatience, frustration, even for many, anger.
 To those who see this public attitude as disappointing or dangerous, I would point out that just such a mood was at the heart of the American experiment in self-government and personal liberty.
 Discontent with punitive taxation and the excessive bureaucracy and an oppressive government was exactly the emotion that put the spark to our own revolution and the democratic way of life it gave us.
 The battle which took place on a farm not far from here near Saratoga was the turning point in that revolution, and I would remind those who are disturbed by the people's current mood of the lesson from that battle -- the lesson that much good can come from the people's determination to see that government remains their servant and not their master.
 I would also remind them that impatience and frustration can exist only where there are also large reserves of hope and optimism and that abiding faith in the possibility of a better future. And as everyone here knows, New Yorkers have an abundance of hope and optimism.
 Despite government's failures or burdens, we have not given up our belief in ourselves, our families, our communities or in our great state of New York.
 We seek change precisely because we believe that under our democratic way of life, change can happen, change can work, change can restore and renew New York.
 
Achieving Greatness
 The kind of change -- the kind of change that can make this state of dreamers and doers, innovators and builders, the leading state in the Union, the Empire State once again.
 To achieve that greatness, we must again understand that personal freedom and opportunity are founded on our willingness to accept individual responsibility for ourselves and for the society we live in.
 I would also note that if today some of the people are angry, that anger is a generous and optimistic anger, one not directed at our fellow citizens or any group of our fellow citizens but at a government that has lost touch with its people.
 Let us be clear then about the public mood. We, the people, believe we can build a criminal justice system that protects the law-abiding and takes repeat violent felons off our streets.
 We, the people, believe we can create a school system that ends disorder in the classroom, cuts bureaucracy and makes excellence in learning and teaching again the hallmark of New York schools.
 We, the people, believe we can rid ourselves of a system of burdensome taxation and oppressive regulation that makes it too hard for entrepreneurs and small-business men and women to expand, innovate and become the source of new jobs in our economy.
 We, the people, believe we can encourage a business climate that will continue to make New York the home of commerce, finance and industry and a state where businesses, large or small, are anxious to locate, create jobs and expand opportunity.
 We, the people, believe we can cut spending and taxes, restore incentive and initiative and reform -- return freedom and responsibility to the individual.
 We, the people, believe we can restore pride and dignity to those in need of help by breaking the cycle of dependency and replacing welfare with workfare.
 And we, the people, believe we can make government serve not the special interests but the public interest, not those in office but those who place them in office.
 We, the people, know that we must launch a new era of individual liberty, responsibility and opportunity by removing obstacles government has placed in the path of an energetic and creative people.
 And to launch that new era is why the people have placed us here today. Let us begin.
 
A Real Crisis
 Today, then, as I begin my tasks as Governor, I make a pledge that I hope will be heard in every home in New York, my pledge that on this day of inaugural festivities and New Year's celebrations that your frustrations will not be forgotten, that your problems will not be overlooked, that I understand that the crisis is real -- a crisis not of the people's making but of the government's.
 And I say, what those in government have done, those in government can undo.
 So, I say to the members of the Legislature and my new administration as we begin together our work for a better New York: the people have turned to us for change and renewal. Let us get it right.
 The people seek change. Let us give them sweeping and fundamental change that is certain and immediate.
 We can reduce spending; we can reduce taxes and regulation; we can control crime; we can improve our schools; we can create workfare to replace welfare. Others have, and so can we.
 President Clinton has already announced the privatization of some Federal agencies, $24 billion in spending cuts, innovative housing vouchers and top-to-bottom welfare reform.
 I applaud the efforts of the new Congress and the President to move in this direction. But I do not propose today that New York merely follow the example of others. New Yorkers who built the Erie Canal and the greatest city in the world shouldn't be waiting -- we should be leading -- and we will.
 Our goal is not simply to do better. Our goal is to make this state again first in new jobs and economic opportunity, first in safe streets and sound schools, first in the number of creative citizens and productive businesses it attracts.
 I want our children and grandchildren to have the opportunity to build their lives here, not elsewhere.
 Our goal, simply put, is New York as the best place to live, the best place to build a future, to find a job, create a career and raise a family. New York's children belong in New York State. What New York has been for us -- a source of economic opportunity and civic pride -- we must make it again for those who follow.
 
Hope and Optimism
 Let us renew then that same spirit of hope and optimism that led those scorned as so-called colonial rabble to begin a revolution against the greatest empire on earth and give the world the American dream.
 A renewal of the same courage and determination that led so many immigrant millions -- my grandparents, Mario Cuomo's parents, the ancestors of all in this room to find here in New York State a doorway to hope and a threshold that in places like Ellis Island they could step across to gain for themselves and their children a share in the American dream.
 We have inherited so much that is good from those who against such great odds began this nation and state, from those immigrant millions who with little more than the clothes on their backs and a few possessions kept alive the promise of a better future.
 When we consider what they left us and the obstacles they faced, we cannot feel daunted or discouraged by the problems that confront us. With the same determination and courage and hope they showed in pursuing their dreams, we will pursue our own.
 We will fulfill our dreams as they fulfilled theirs by understanding that the creativity of the individual is the true source of economic and social progress, that the family is the nurturing ground of both personal development and a larger social harmony, a place where the individual learns and grows in respect for others and develops those vital habits of responsibility to God, country and community.
 In recovering the revolutionary spirit of Saratoga and the faith and optimism of Ellis Island, let us also remember the immigrant millions and the American revolutionaries were successful not only because they were wise but because they were free and they accepted responsibility.
 The American founders understood that a prerequisite to order and freedom and public safety is effective but limited government.
 From bitter personal experience, they learned that government has a terrible appetite for more power, an appetite that as it burdens its citizens with more taxes and more bureaucracy can bring down nations and empires.
 They knew this tendency of government -- with sometimes the best of intentions -- to grow bigger and more powerful has always posed history's most serious obstacle to social progress and its greatest threat to personal freedom.
 When government accepts responsibility for people, then people no longer take responsibility for themselves. Individual responsibility and personal freedom are inevitably linked.
 Limited government, then, was not just a slogan for the American founders, it was the path to greatness and the beginning of political wisdom.
 
Size and Cost
 Let us resolve now that in the months and weeks ahead, we will return to such wisdom. We will begin where the people want us to begin -- reducing the size and cost of government and getting rid of unnecessary and counterproductive programs.
 The people believe that government has become too big, too unwieldy, too distant, too arrogant, that every day government seems to grow not to benefit the taxpayers or the people but the bureaucrats, officeholders and the special interests. The people are right. Today, today government is simply too large.
 There are now 73 volumes of government regulations in New York State, over 55,000 pages of regulations. Laid end to end, that's 12 miles of red tape, enough to stretch from Albany to Schenectady and back again. This is wrong. This has to stop. And it will.
 The facts are these: spending is too high, the regulatory burden on our people excessive, our tax burden too heavy. Let me repeat what the people of this state already know: state government is too big and it spends too much money. It's simple. It's time for a change.
 Let us, then, cut government spending and cut it again -- remembering always that by downsizing government, we can restore people's confidence in the future by expanding individual responsibility and individual freedom.
 This is the challenge of the 90's -- the challenge we face as we prepare to enter the next century: to preserve and protect personal freedom and to restore individual responsibility.
 And as we confront our state' fiscal crisis, let us remember a simple truth: more government means higher taxes and fewer jobs; less government means lower taxes and more jobs.
 Some ask: to eliminate a $5 billion deficit, will we raise taxes or will we cut essential government services? To them we say there's another way -- a way to make government less expensive and more responsive.
 Countries like Canada and England and many states at home have shown it's possible to streamline government, improve services and cut costs by privatization. I will move aggressively on this front.
 In this connection, let us also remember that government works best when it is kept close to the people, that problems are best solved by those levels of government closest to them.
 So, just as I will fight to stop Washington from imposing unfunded mandates on the state, I will work with elected officials to reduce government's burden on the people at every level.
Whether in Washington, Albany or at the local level, government is too big and too inefficient. The answer lies not in the collective wisdom of a paid and pampered bureaucracy but in the genius of the individual and the people as a whole. Unfunded state mandates must end. Too often -- too often -- too often faceless bureaucrats tell local government what it must do, and it must do it. This too must end. This Governor believes in the power -- this Governor believes in the power of the people to make decisions for themselves.
 
Grave Problems
 In confronting the other grave problems before us, we also look to apply the wisdom of the past.
 Our founders believed that one area where government should be strong and effective was maintaining pubic order and public safety. They understood society's first obligation is to those citizens who obey the law and respect the rights of others, and they expect government to protect them from those who do not.
 To that end, I will be putting before the Legislature measures to eliminate work release and abolish parole for violent felons. Violent felons belong in jail. Violent felons belong in jail, and with your support, that is where they are going to be.
 Let me also note that when a society does not express its own horror at the crime of murder by enforcing the ultimate sanction against it, innocent lives are put at risk.
 Not out of a sense of vindictiveness, then, but a sense of justice -- indeed, a sense of compassion for those who otherwise might become victims of murder -- I will ask the Legislature to pass and I will sign and enforce the death penalty.
 And let me say -- and let me say: if one police officer's life is saved, if one less child is caught in a crossfire, if one fewer cabdriver or shopkeeper is killed in a robbery, then the death penalty will have proven itself worthwhile.
 Crime is a serious concern for all New Yorkers. But far too many New Yorkers also face the trap of a failed welfare system. Sadly, today 1 in 11 New Yorkers is on welfare. The welfare system, though well meaning, has failed. It's time for workfare.
 The welfare reforms -- the welfare reforms I present will stress reductions in bureaucratic overhead, consolidation of programs -- tighten restrictions but especially learnfare and workfare. All of them based on the principle that helping those less fortunate is a solemn obligation but that one of the most valuable means of providing such help is to look on welfare not as a way of life but as a means of temporary assistance, a step toward the dignity of self-sufficiency.
 Welfare was created to be a safety net -- a safety net that should act as a trampoline so that people bounce back to full and productive lives. Instead, that safety net has become a bureaucratic spider web, a web that entangles people and from which few ever escape. We intend to help them out of that web of dependency and back to lives that are rich in dignity and opportunity.
 In this effort to change not only welfare but to bring real, certain and swift change to government, I will seek the support of New Yorkers for measures that will give government more directly back to them in accountability and give them greater control over its activities.
 I will seek legislation that will put term limits on officeholders and give the people the clear, unmistakable democratic voice that is theirs with the right of initiatives and referendum.
 Let me also make another pledge. More than any other state, we have shown right here that people of different creeds, races and ethnic backgrounds can live and work together, that all people are part of the American dream and responsible for its greatest moments.
 As long as I am Governor -- and I ask all New Yorkers to join me in this -- I will do all that I can to fight racism or religious prejudice wherever it occurs. In our New York there is no place for bigotry or for intolerance.
 Let us move forward then in all these areas to reform government, to reduce the cost and size. But when we have achieved all this, let us also remember we are only at the beginning.
 I spoke a moment ago about the hopeful spirit and common-sense wisdom of our past.
 Those who fought at Saratoga and those who came after them at Ellis Island were an optimistic and hopeful people because they were wise enough to know that the true greatness of any nation is not found in the apparatus of government or state power. It is found in the people and all their spontaneous social, economic and spiritual association, in their families, churches and synagogues, fraternal and neighborhood organizations and all those mediating institutions that are the real source of economic, social and cultural progress.
 That famous early visitor to America, de Toqueville, noted that the genius of America lay not only in the spiritual fervor of its people but also in a remarkable voluntary spirit that came with this religious faith, the capacity and willingness of Americans to form together to help each other, to combine spontaneously for the benefit of all.
 
Public Spirit
 It should be clear that our goal is not just changing government but a much broader transformation of our democratic life -- a renewal of our public spirit. Our goal is to release all the native genius and the pent-up energy of a people and state that once gave the American Revolution its turning point. A state that provided the immigrant millions with a home for their dreams, a state that built an Erie Canal, an Empire State Building, a Wall Street and a Lincoln Center; a state that from Buffalo to Brooklyn, from Plattsburgh to Peekskill; from Rochester to the Rockaways, made itself the center of every industrial, commercial, cultural, communications and even sports revolution in America.
 With this clear understanding that the real strengths of our nation and state are its people, I will seek to help of New Yorkers through their community and neighborhood organizations to renew the greatness of New York.
 As we reduce the role of government, I will ask each of us to take an interest in the quality of our schools and involve ourselves -- from our farms to our suburbs and cities -- in the safety and development of our communities and neighborhoods. New Yorkers aren't afraid of that challenge.
 Hardly a day goes by when one of us somewhere isn't doing something heroic. New York is a state of heroes -- some famous, some not.
 Only a few short weeks ago here in Albany, we saw a situation all too familiar to us from the evening news as a gunman entered the State University, took students as hostages and threatened to kill them.
 When one student, Jason McEnaney, felt the danger to his life and others was imminent, he rushed the gunman. He sustained wounds but with the help of other students overpowered him.
 I spoke with Jason recently and am glad to see him looking so well today.
 Today, ladies and gentlemen, I'd like to introduce you to Jason McEnaney and thank him on behalf of the people of this state.
 And I'd also like to introduce to you four of the brave students who came to Jason's aid after he was wounded: Mike Connors, Kevin Iacobacci, Robert Romanino and Dackri Simpson. They, too, are true New York heroes.
 So, today as we inaugurate change in government, reaffirm our commitment to personal freedom and individual responsibility and renew our public spirit, I take up my duties as Governor in a spirit of optimism, with enthusiasm and confidence that government reform and democratic transformation can be achieved. And to those who still doubt our capacity for such achievement, I would ask them to consider not only our distant but our most recent past.
 Only a few short years ago the cold and dark of the cold war was everywhere. The world seemed fated to continue its terrible struggle between the superpowers. Which of us who lived through that era can forget those dangers, the setbacks and heartbreaks.
 Among the most vivid memories of my own boyhood is watching the faces of my grandparents in tears as they watched TV images of a heroic struggle for freedom in their native land crushed by Red Army troops and tanks on the streets of Budapest.
 All this now has changed.
 Today, millions around the world have a chance for freedom, prosperity and peace. So, we have seen in our own time what American leadership and this country's native hope and optimism can achieve for our own people, for all the world.
 In this American greatness and exceptionalism, those of us from this state have a special share.
 As visitors who gaze for the first time at the Statue of Liberty, tourists who see the lights of Broadway or honeymooners who watch the falls at Niagara, as they know, there is a special pace, rhythm and magic to our state.
 Look at the names of all those who came to greatness in New York -- political figures like Al Smith, Fiorello La Guardia, Teddy and Franklin Roosevelt.
 Sports heroes like Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle and Jackie Robinson.
 Great leaders from business, commerce and the arts.
 There is a music to New York, a rich and varied music that set America to singing, a music that came from the people, from Irving Berlin to Louis Armstrong, Cole Porter and George M. Cohan.
 That music is still ours. We need only to listen for it, to become part of its hopeful chorus.
 I love this state, its people and places for many reasons. I think of the bustle and excitement of New York City and the memorable years Libby and I lived there.
 I think of how our family has enjoyed more than I can say the natural beauty of places like Montauk or the time we spent upstate, or how much our children -- Emily and Teddy and Allison and Owen -- enjoy swimming near a covered bridge on the Batinkill River and walking the fields and the farms.
 But always in my own mind I come back to the Hudson Valley, a place whose beauty -- a place whose beauty gave America schools of great writers and great painters. Proudly and humbly, I think too of a local mailman's son who grew up in that valley and found there in his hometown of Peekskill all that is rich and good in the American dream.
 So that in my mind, when I'm home, two things stand out:
 First, the goodness of the people.
 And second, the only word I can find to express my feelings: gratitude.
 As New Yorkers and Americans, we are all grateful for all the opportunity we have had in our own lives and for those who gave it to us.
 
Fears and Faith
 I think sometimes about my four grandparents -- from Hungary, Ireland and Italy -- going through those gates and lines at Ellis Island. I know that their deep religious faith and their own daring spirit sustained them. But still I am sure that Yanos and Elizabeth Pataki, Agnes Lynch or Matteo Lagana -- they must have felt -- as Governor Cuomo's or Senator D'Amato's or Senator Moynihan's parents or grandparents must have felt -- their own fears about how they would do in this new land, in this new world.
 And I sometimes wonder if, as they filed through the lines of inspectors and health officials, what they would have said or felt if some predictor of the future had been able to tell them that they would not only just make a home here in New York but also find so much opportunity that one day their grandson would be Governor of the state of New York. That they would find their grandson Governor of a state that at the time must have seemed a foreign and perhaps forbidding place.
 You know, I think they might have believed it.
 I know my father is smiling today, and I only have to look down a few seats and see that my mother is smiling.
 With gratitude to the people of New York, for the spirit of hope and daring that brought so many to the New World and made them change and renew it, for the faith in God and the freedom he enjoins that they passed on to us -- a faith that has only recently brought democracy and hope to millions of people around the world. Let us now turn to problems left too long unattended at home.
 And as we do so, let us remember that only when the personal success and liberty that is the American dream touches every life in every corner of our state can it ever truly be our own.
 So let us now go forth, get to work and together restore New York to the greatness that is its destiny.
 God bless you.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 29; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Economy And Politics Still Govern

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
NEW YORK'S new Governor took office yesterday the way he ran for it. In language as focused as the voice-overs in his campaign commercials, George E. Pataki declared war on the government he was elected to run.
 "What those in government have done, those in government can undo," Mr. Pataki told an appreciative crowd of 13,000. 
 His speech, like all inaugural addresses, was bereft of detail. But Mr. Pataki did reiterate his campaign themes: Along with streamlining government, he wants to reinstate the death penalty, reduce taxes, put welfare recipients to work and cut Medicaid.
 Can he?
 The death penalty will inevitably return, but the fate of other promises rests largely on two factors that got little mention yesterday: the economy and politics. Both have a way of molding reality in Albany.
 The economy plays a singularly powerful role. It is much easier to cut taxes and services when the economy is growing. For instance, in Michigan, which has benefited from the rebounding automobile industry, Republican Governor John M. Engler has attracted national attention for shrinking state government. Would he and his budget director, Patricia A. Woodworth, have succeeded without a healthy economy?
 Ms. Woodworth, now Mr. Pataki's new budget director, will have to contend with New York's still-limping economy. Maybe it will bounce back. If so, Mr. Pataki will make good on some promises and be a hero. If not, he will have a very tough time delivering.
CUTTING taxes is one promise that is likely to be realized, in one form or another -- probably another. Mr. Pataki made it the cornerstone of his campaign and will have to deliver or lose credibility. But some legislators predict he will have to modify his plan to cut the top income tax rate by 25 percent in four years because the state faces a budget deficit of at least $4 billion, before a tax cut.
 Unless the economy revives, or unless Mr. Pataki can shrink government with unprecedented speed and efficiency, he will have to cut state aid to localities to cut taxes, because two-thirds of all state spending goes to local governments. Then local governments would have to raise their taxes to make up the difference. "Is this a tax cut plan, or tax shift plan?" Sheldon Silver, Democratic Speaker of the State Assembly, asked in an interview.
 Mr. Silver is Mr. Pataki's most formidable obstacle because he controls the Assembly and can stop Republican legislation. Democrats are not immune to the pressure of political trends, though, and it's a good bet that even Democratic legislators from New York City will agree to some kind of tax cut.
 Mr. Silver is also prepared to have a large say in Mr. Pataki's plan to cut the growth of Medicaid. So far, the Lieutenant Governor, Elizabeth P. McCaughey, has focused on cutting home care to the elderly and disabled, and on expanding Medicaid enrollment in managed care.
 Neither she nor Mr. Pataki has mentioned reimbursement rates to hospitals and nursing homes, which account for half the state's Medicaid costs. Perhaps, suggested Mr. Silver, that's because "Republican clients, generally, are the providers, not the recipients." And Democratic clients are generally recipients, which is one reason it is hard to cut Medicaid in New York.
 Mr. Pataki does not need legislative approval to put more welfare recipients to work. "Sadly, today one in 11 New Yorkers is on welfare," he said yesterday. "The welfare system, though well-meaning, has failed. It's time for workfare." But it is misleading to suggest that every welfare recipient, or even most, can go to work. Indeed, Mr. Pataki is only contemplating workfare for recipients of Home Relief -- mainly single adults without children. Those on Home Relief account for less than a third of the state's welfare recipients, and many of them cannot work because they are addicted, homeless or elderly.
MR. PATAKI often cites the program in Westchester, run by his new Social Services Commissioner, Mary E. Glass. But the county put less than 15 percent of its Home Relief recipients in jobs. Westchester did remove many from the rolls, often because they broke the rules by secretly working. That does save money if those people stay permanently off Home Relief; nobody knows yet if they do.
 Moreover, an effective workfare program is expensive because it demands intensive supervision, and so may not save as much as Mr. Pataki hopes. Another pledge the new Governor made yesterday -- keeping more felons in jail -- wouldn't save any money. In fact, it would mean building even more costly jail cells.
 And presumably government, cast as the enemy of the people in Washington and now in Albany, would have to build them.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 763 words

HEADLINE: Bipartisan Foreign Policy

 BODY:
In the new year, President Clinton confronts a new foreign policy reality -- a Republican Congress. Republicans are less united on international issues than on their domestic agenda. But critics of specific Administration policies now lead both houses and chair key committees. They have ample constitutional power to obstruct the President's agenda and advance their own. The Senate has the authority to confirm nominees and ratify treaties, and both houses can vote down or condition appropriations for everything from foreign aid and intelligence to troop deployments.
Sharper foreign policy debate can be healthy. The Administration has not performed so brilliantly that it can afford to brush off useful criticism. No great philosophical differences divide Mr. Clinton from mainstream Republicans on many issues, and both parties need to consider how to reshape U.S. policies to a changed world. What are America's interests today? What are appropriate uses of U.S. military force? What is the right relationship between trade expansion and other objectives? 
 As a candidate, Mr. Clinton promised dramatic reversals on a few high-profile issues like Bosnia, China and Haiti. That rhetoric was soon abandoned. Aside from Haiti, Mr. Clinton has generally kept George Bush's policies in place while focusing on domestic reform. A broad consensus is likely to continue over trade, the Middle East and some elements of arms control. Congressional challenges are likely over Bosnia, NATO, Russia, China, peacekeeping and foreign aid.
Republican leaders liken foreign aid to welfare and demand that most aid not related to security or political aims be cut. But the aid budget has already been cut by nearly a third over the last five years, and most foreign aid is related to security or political aims. Of the $14 billion foreign aid budget, $5 billion is earmarked for Israel and Egypt and another $1.2 billion goes to assist countries trying to move from socialism to capitalism. Most of the remainder goes to humanitarian, environmental and population programs that are the best insurance against new Somalias and Rwandas.
Republicans will press for more aggressive efforts to lift the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government, efforts the Administration should try to harness and in some cases support. Washington should make clear to its European allies that if they prevent the U.N. from lifting the embargo, the Administration may be unable to resist Congressional pressure for the U.S. to lift it independently. The Administration should vigorously resist all calls for direct U.S. involvement in the war.
Many Republicans favor incorporating Eastern European countries in NATO, which would needlessly isolate and provoke Moscow. Eastern Europe needs economic support and early access to the European Union far more urgently than it needs new military guarantees. The Administration itself moved too hastily last year toward moving the NATO security umbrella eastward.
Mainstream Republicans favor continued support for reform and arms reduction in Russia, but want to make aid conditional on how Moscow treats the former Soviet republics. Such conditioning must be done carefully. America's security does not lie in isolating and humiliating Russia, but in encouraging its constructive participation in European and Asian affairs.
Republicans will also insist that Washington stand up more forcefully to Chinese bullying on human rights, trade, Taiwan and Tibet. A tougher line could help over time, but short-term progress is unlikely with China already in the throes of a succession struggle.
International peacekeeping has been a favorite Republican target, even though the Administration is now cautious to a fault about committing U.S. troops to such operations. Recent U.N. operations have been troubled. But peacekeeping is a cost-efficient deal for the U.S. If the U.N. were so financially hobbled that it could no longer mount operations in support of policies Washington favors, American forces might have to act alone, at far greater human and financial cost to the U.S.
This Administration still has a chance to leave a credible foreign policy legacy, but for the next two years it will have to do so in conjunction with mainstream Republicans like Senator Richard Lugar and Representative Benjamin Gilman. There will be unbridgeable differences. There should be substantive debate. But with good will and good luck, the result could be the kind of bipartisan foreign policy politicians often rhapsodize about but rarely produce.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Trade Accords Have Sown Violent Seeds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Having declared the North American Free Trade Agreement "a death sentence" for Mexico's Indians, the rebel leader Subcomandante Marcos has written to the new President, "Welcome to the nightmare" (news article, Dec. 29). 
 But the situation in Mexico is only a hint of what is to come. Just as Mexico's many corn farmers will be displaced by cheap imported corn, the millions of farmers of rice, corn and sugar in one of the next hot spots, the Philippines, will similarly find themselves displaced.
"You need to switch from basic crops to high-value crops like flowers," the Philippine Senate has told its farmers, most of whom are still using the primitive water buffalo-and-plow method to till their land. But the farmers do not have the capital to produce new crops, and the government is too broke to help.
The world's elite recently congratulated itself on its wisdom at having passed the North American Free Trade Agreement and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, despite widespread grass-roots opposition. But the same elite is due for a rude awakening. The uprising in the Mexican state of Chiapas -- and the billions of dollars that investors have lost as a result -- are a portent of the desperation and violence we will witness as a result of trade agreements that will displace millions from their livelihoods.
Regarding the economy, President Clinton said in his election campaign, "I feel your pain." Then he actively campaigned for passage of trade agreements that will only worsen that pain for many of America's workers.
The world's elite has just begun to feel the pain that will result from its actions on those two fateful trade accords.
 
GEORGE RAYMOND TYNDALL
Los Angeles, Dec. 29, 1994

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
 
When Mexico's new President goes on television tonight, the challenge he faces will be to lay out specific plans for a financial recovery that will not worsen the country's simmering social problems. President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon will also work to convince investors that the Mexican market they once adored was not imagined. Mr. Zedillo's stabilization plan will set much of Mexico's economic course for the year. [Page 39.]
 

Like other big economic losers in 1994, Mexico failed to respond quickly when the economic world around it began to change, or to realize how risky its economic strategy was until it was too late. Mexico's risks were built into a strategy of luring investors with high interest rates and a narrow currency-trading range. Economic Memo. [39.]
 
China's central bank raised interest rates on loans to financial institutions by slightly less than one-quarter of 1 percent. The move was aimed at confronting the country's continued strong growth and rising inflation by controlling some excess investment. [39.]
 
The American-style shopping mall has come to eastern Germany. Some people think that the malls, surrounded by vast parking lots with fast-food outlets and cineplexes, could have a strong effect on traditional German life. [5.]
 
The Economy
 
Do the poor deserve a minimum standard of living? That is the heart of a debate developing in Washington over entitlement programs, many of which are disliked by many of the Republicans who will take control of Congress on Wednesday. [1.]
 
Cuts in state taxes and spending were among the goals set by New York's new Governor, George E. Pataki, in his inaugural address, which promised "sweeping and fundamental change that is certain and immediate." [1.]
 
After a strong start, 1994 limped to a disappointing close for Wall Street's underwriters. New issues of stocks and bonds totaled $709 billion for the year, down nearly 33 percent from 1993's record of more than $1 trillion and the lowest total since 1991. [39.]
 
The Media Business
 
The record industry was highly prosperous and full of turmoil in 1994, and the impact of an upheaval in its executive ranks is expected to ripple through the industry this year. Sales of recorded music in the United States last year were expected to reach a new high of $11 billion, up 10 percent from 1993. Optimism remains high for this year, when many big-name releases are planned. [39.]
 
The demand for radio ads grew last year, allowing the industry to raise rates after several years of marking them down to gain business. Radio executives are optimistic that strong increases will be posted again in 1995. Part of 1994's growth spurt came in talk radio: stations carrying anything but music grew to 1,028 last year from 841 in 1993. [42.]
 
Mothers who are taking time off from their careers to raise their children are the focus of a Levi's advertising campaign that could be the forerunner of a broader marketing trend. "Although their actual numbers are small, the power wife-mother is our latest status symbol, more important than a mink coat," said an executive at the ad firm creating the Levis' commercials. [42.]
 
Today's Column
 
The inventors of a new oil filter for boats are finding it difficult to attract a manufacturer, despite the fact that the filter cuts down on water pollution. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [40.]

HEADLINE: Burden of Proof on Mexico's President Tonight

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 1

 BODY:
When President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon goes on national television Monday night to outline his plan for rebuilding the crippled Mexican economy, he will also be doing his best to convince investors that the Mexican market they once thought the world of was not a mirage.
 Mr. Zedillo worked through the New Year's weekend to put the finishing touches on an economic-stabilization plan that will limit wages, prices and Government spending while lining up the financial backing of the United States and Canada, major European nations, American commercial banks and the International Monetary Fund. 
In the United States as well as Mexico, investment bankers, money managers and financial analysts will be watching to see how Mr. Zedillo -- in office just a month -- applies the economics he learned at Stanford and refined at the Mexican central bank to this politically explosive situation. His challenge will be to lay out an economic recovery, while setting a national agenda that can keep the lid on simmering social problems bound to be worsened by the disastrous devaluation of the peso last month.
 Along with the details of a Government agreement with labor and business that will be disclosed Monday night, Mr. Zedillo's stabilization plan will set much of Mexico's economic course for 1995. The most important points are expected to be these:
 *How does Mr. Zedillo intend to control inflation without causing a recession and possibly increasing social unrest?
 *How will price controls be enforced?
 *What policy will Mexico use to set exchange rates?
 *Which Government-owned companies will be sold to investors to raise badly needed dollars?
 *What is the size and structure of the international rescue package, and will it be sufficient to restore investors' confidence?
 "The main risk is that when you already are under a lot of pressure, you have to be real convincing," said Neal M. Soss, an economic consultant in New York. "The world can be in an unforgiving frame of mind. If his plan doesn't appear to cover all the bases, and doesn't offer well-thought-out answers to all questions, he runs the risk of having another flight of capital."
 The peso's devaluation could turn out to be enormously damaging for Mexico. A study by Bear, Stearns & Company estimates that if the peso trades at a rate of about 4.90 to the dollar -- it closed at 5.0750 to the dollar on Friday --Mexico's gross domestic product could fall to $250 billion in 1995 from $333 billion in 1993. Per-capita income might decline to $2,700 from $3,600 in 1993. The national debt would increase to 40 percent of gross domestic product, up from 26 percent.
 To make his stabilization plan work, Mr. Zedillo will rely on the same sort of pact with labor and business that Mexican administrations have used for the last seven years.
 The agreement, backed by the persuasive powers of a party that has been in control for 65 years, helped get Government, labor and business to agree to hold down prices, wages and public spending. All these groups stopped making wage and price demands based on existing inflation rates and agreed instead to work toward steadily improving targets, which helped bring down inflation to 8 percent in 1993 from 159 percent in 1987.
 The President is expected to reject the old commitment to a semi-fixed exchange rate policy and adopt a more flexible system.
 In previous pacts, the Government agreed to hold the line on prices for goods it produces, like electricity and gasoline. It also pledged to keep the value of the peso within a tight trading band, no matter what changes took place in the international markets. As a result, the peso grew stronger -- which Mexicans liked because it meant that books, breakfast cereal or almost anything produced in the United States became cheaper.
 From 1985 to 1992, imports grew by 238 percent. Exports increased by only 73 percent in the same years.
 By the end of 1994, Mexico was importing so much more than it was exporting that it had accumulated a deficit of $28 billion. The Government financed the debt with foreign money, a tactic that became impossible after investors started turning away from Mexico. That led to a weeklong speculative run on the peso, which ended just before Christmas. The Government decided that it did not have enough money in reserve to defend the peso, and was forced to allow it to float freely.
 Within a few days, Mexico's currency fell in value almost 30 percent.
 Some economists have accused the Government of hubris, saying finance officials had become overly confident they could ward off any assault on the peso. They entered the crisis with $17 billion in reserves and $7 billion in standby lines of credit from the United States and Canada.
 This was not enough. More than $10 billion was pulled out of the country, first by Mexican investors, then by foreigners that week before Christmas.
 Mexico is now looking for even greater backing from its trading partners. In the package that is already lined up, the Bank for International Settlements in Switzerland, which represents the central banks of Europe, will lend Mexico $6 billion to $10 billion. In addition, several American commercial banks have been asked to syndicate a loan of $3 billion to $6 billion.
 There may also be some help from the International Monetary Fund, particularly in supervising the way Mexico handles the loans and its emergency stabilization plan. The appointment on Thursday of Guillermo Ortiz as Finance Minister -- in place of Jaime Serra Puche, who resigned -- could prove useful, as he worked as an executive director of the I.M.F. from 1984 to 1988.
 Many analysts say international backing will create confidence and help Mexico hold on to the foreign investments that have not yet been pulled out. One of Mexico's biggest concerns is the $30 billion in Government notes known as tesobonos that come due in 1995. The notes are paid in pesos but are pegged to dollars, and the devaluation has substantially increased Mexico's obligations.
 To encourage investors to roll over those notes instead of cashing them in, the central bank is expected to offer to replace mature tesobonos with something called sovereign debt bonds that will have longer terms and higher interest rates.
 Another important part of Mr. Zedillo's plan is to raise the Government's dollar revenue by speeding up the privatization of ports, petrochemical plants and electricity-generating stations. The Government will also try to exploit the short-term price advantages of the devaluation to stem the flow of imports while increasing exports. The plan calls for cutting the current-account deficit of more than $28 billion by more than half by year's end.
 Some economists think that is too optimistic. But after the 1982 devaluation, the current-account deficit fell to $6 billion from $16 billion.
 So far, the loudest complaints about devaluation have come from foreign investors. The Mexican people, preoccupied with the holidays and vacations, have not yet said much. Mexicans who have lived through other devaluations know they will again be asked to sacrifice. After the devaluation of 1982, for example, real wages fell 24 percent.
 The outlook for the new year has already changed. When Mr. Zedillo took office on Dec. 1, official estimates for 1995 were a growth rate of 4 percent, inflation of 4 percent and pay increases of 10 percent, substantially above the inflation rate.
 Now, Government economists are predicting 1 to 2 percent growth, 15 percent inflation and wage increases that do not keep up with inflation.
 Inflation ravaged Mexico in the early 1980's and is again a central concern. "The most difficult part of the recovery will be to really keep inflation in check," said Nora Lustig, an economist with the Brookings Institution in Washington.
 The prices of products made of domestic material and sold in Mexico should not be affected by the devaluation. But after a devaluation, a kind of panic sets in and pushes everyone to raise prices, regardless of whether the product is imported. Just a few days after the Government said that prices across the board had been frozen for 60 days, the federal consumer protection agency shut down 27 stores in greater Mexico City for jacking up the prices of -- among other things -- tortillas and milk.
 "The Government will probably be able to get agreement from the business leaders not to raise prices, but what if there is no discipline in the ranks?" Ms. Lustig said. "What is supposed to be a single jump in prices to reflect the devaluation could become a spiral."

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
The World Shifted, but Not Mexico

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Mexico has this in common with Orange County, Calif., and with derivatives plungers and other big losers in 1994: It failed to respond quickly when the economic world around it began to change, or to realize how risky its economic strategy was until it was too late.
 Mexico's risks were built into a strategy of luring investors with high interest rates and a narrow currency-trading range, international economists here have concluded. 
That strategy paid off handsomely from 1991 to 1993, as foreign investors who found a limited number of attractive places to put their money during a global recession poured money into Mexican bonds and notes paying 15 percent interest and bought millions of shares in the fast-rising Mexican stock market.
 Mexicans spent the money buying far more goods from abroad than the country could pay for with the proceeds from its exports -- running trade deficits three times as large as the biggest American deficits of the 1980's, if the sizes of the two economies are taken into account.
 The strategy flew in the face of advice from officials of the International Monetary Fund. The result, as President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon acknowledged in a speech last week, has been disastrous.
 The changes in the economic world that proved so devastating to Mexico's strategy came from a multitude of sources, at home and abroad. The Federal Reserve's decision in February to begin driving up interest rates made it more attractive for many to invest in the United States, rather than Mexico.
 Many other nations' economies began to emerge from recession and compete for international investment in 1994. And political violence in Mexico made loans and stock purchases there seem riskier.
 When the money stopped flowing in, the Mexican Government spent close to $20 billion in six months to defend the peso's value. When reserves ran low, top officials were forced to abandon the centerpiece of their economic policy: a guarantee that no matter what happened, a fistful of pesos would hold its value in dollars. The peso has since lost roughly 30 percent of its value.
 International Monetary Fund officials refuse to claim vindication. Financial analysts have been more outspoken.
 "If the Mexican authorities had followed more closely the exchange-rate readjustment suggested by the I.M.F. models and research, there wouldn't have been the chaos you saw in the markets," said Gregory A. Fossedal, a writer in Arlington, Va., who follows the I.M.F. closely.
 Mexico followed much, but not all, of the advice dispensed by the I.M.F., the World Bank and other international economic organizations. It sold state-owned enterprises to private buyers. It balanced the budget. And it eliminated trade barriers, most notably through the North American Free Trade Agreement, which took effect a year ago.
 But the Government chose not to run the risk of social turmoil from devaluing the peso, which would have made popular foreign goods more expensive at home.
 Consumer prices in Mexico rose 27.9 percent from the end of 1991 through the middle of this year. Yet the value of the peso in dollars fell only 9.4 percent during this period. For would-be foreign buyers with dollars to spend, the slightly cheaper currency was not nearly enough to offset the higher prices.
 Evidence that the peso needed to fall further was visible in stores in south Texas this fall. Throngs of Mexican shoppers were coming across the border because the prices were often cheaper than at home.
 The result was an immense trade deficit, reaching 8 percent of Mexico's economic output in 1994. The rule of thumb commonly used by the I.M.F. and other international economic organizations is that a developing country's trade deficit should not exceed its economic growth rate. Mexico's annual growth has ranged from 1 to 3 percent in the last couple of years.
 Such large deficits lead inevitably to disaster, said a senior economist at an international economic organization.
 A 1989 letter from the I.M.F. to the Mexican Government warned that if nothing was done, the trade balance, broadly measured to include some financial flows, would double by 1994. But Mexico allowed its line of credit at the I.M.F. to lapse in May 1993 -- which cut it free from the fund's advice, but also from its money.
 Still, Mexican policy makers had reason for optimism as a result of the successful negotiation and approval in 1993 of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The accord prompted foreign investors to pour more money into the country. But as President Zedillo pointed out in his speech on Thursday, most of that money went into stocks and bonds that could be quickly sold if confidence faltered.
 To be sure, the United States has sustained big trade deficits for many years and relied heavily on foreign investment in American stocks and bonds. One difference is that the American trade deficits have stayed under 3 percent of economic output. Another is that the United States does not try to fix the value of the dollar to other currencies, allowing it constantly to rise and fall against other money in markets around the world.
 By the end of 1993, foreign investors in Mexico were spending six times as much adding to their portfolios of Mexican stocks and bonds as to build factories or buy controlling stakes in Mexican companies. These stock and bond investors proved fickle, I.M.F. figures show.
 After a peasant insurgency began in a southern state last January and the front-running presidential candidate was assassinated in March, the pace of these investments slowed severely -- by 86 percent in three months.
 Mexico tried until Dec. 22 to maintain a minimum value in United States currency for the peso, through the use of a trading band whose lower limit declined at a very slow, steady rate. Shortly before the recent plunge, the Government had effectively guaranteed that anyone who wanted to sell 100 pesos could get $29 for them -- 29 cents apiece. It would go into the market and buy pesos at this price if no one else chose to.
 When Mexicans and foreigners wanted to sell pesos for dollars this autumn, the Mexican Government became the biggest buyer. In the last two months alone, it reportedly spent more than $10 billion buying pesos.
 By late last month, the central bank's hoard of foreign currency had fallen dangerously low. The Government lowered its guarantee level -- the process of devaluation -- to $25 for 100 pesos. A day later, with central bank reserves at just $6 billion, the Government abandoned the guarantee entirely, allowing the peso to trade freely in the currency markets. By the close of trading last Tuesday, 100 pesos were worth only $17.54, though their value had bounced back to $19.72 by the end of trading on Friday.
 Patrick Conway, an associate professor of economics at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, who specializes in the Mexican economy, said Mexico did not appear to have learned from past mistakes.
 In the late 1970's, as in 1993, Mexico abandoned its line of credit with the International Monetary Fund and pursued a strategy of fast economic growth that included huge trade deficits financed with foreign money. In 1982, as in 1994, the outcome was a collapse in the peso and the need for an international rescue.
 The parallels, Mr. Conway said, suggest that in each case Mexican officials "were perhaps too hasty in cutting their ties to the financial institutions that got them where they were."

HEADLINE: New Stock and Bond Issues Fell by Almost 33% in 1994

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
After a strong start, 1994 limped to a disappointing close for Wall Street's underwriters.
 New issues of stocks and bonds totaled $709 billion for the year, down nearly 33 percent from 1993's record of more than $1 trillion and the lowest total since 1991, according to the Securities Data Company, a Manhattan research firm. 
The large decline in underwriting volume is the best illustration of the difficulties that plagued the securities industry last year, its most trying since the downturn of the late 1980's.
 Underwriting new stocks and bonds is one of the industry's most lucrative businesses. In 1994 the total underwriting fees disclosed by Wall Street companies plunged more than 39 percent from 1993, according to Securities Data.
 But not all the news was bad for Wall Street in 1994. Mergers and takeover activity reached a record $339.4 billion, surpassing the previous record of $335.8 billion set in 1988, according to Securities Data.
 In contrast to the highly speculative takeovers typical of the merger boom of the 1980's, the 1994 deals were dominated by corporations making strategic moves to increase their reach in industries like telecommunications, health care, pharmaceuticals, financial services and high technology.
 Analysts and investment bankers expect the merger trend to continue this year, as a weak dollar and relatively strong stock market make deals attractive. And as buyers look beyond banks to finance their deals, the trend could also help to lift the junk bond market.
 The plunge in underwriting volume shows how swiftly Wall Street's fortunes can decline. The year began strongly, as the industry continued to ride a four-year boom that had seen steady declines in interest rates. With rates at a record low in 1993 and stock prices strong, many corporations took the opportunity to raise cash by issuing stocks and bonds.
 When the Federal Reserve began raising short-term interest rates in February, the issuing of debt became more expensive. At the same time, the strong economy lifted revenue for many companies, diminishing their need to tap the markets for capital.
 "Most companies had pre-funded a lot of their debt needs for the next year or two in 1993," said Seth Waugh, managing director of global debt financing at Merrill Lynch & Company, which was the industry's leading underwriter in 1994 for the seventh consecutive year.
 As the Fed continued to raise rates in each quarter, the volume of new bond issues declined. The $117 billion raised from new issues in the fourth quarter was nearly 60 percent lower than the amount raised in the first quarter. It was also the lowest quarterly total since the end of 1990, according to Securities Data.
 Over all, the underwriting of mortgage-backed securities slid the furthest last year, falling 57 percent, as the climb in interest rates ended a boom in home-mortgage refinancing. Junk-bond underwriting fell nearly 39 percent, followed by investment-grade debt, whose underwriting fell 27 percent.
 The rising rates also took their toll on the underwriting of stocks. Though the business remained relatively strong in the first half of the year, it fell off quickly as investors began to worry that the rising returns offered by bonds would divert funds from the stock market.
 "By the third quarter, the environment was very difficult on the new-issues side," said Tom Davis, head of equity capital markets at Merrill Lynch. The number of new issues dried up as companies postponed or canceled offerings.
 Though the stock markets have remained relatively strong, the equity underwriting business has stayed weak. "While the flow of funds into equities has slowed, it has not reversed," Mr. Davis said. "The concern is still out there, but the reality hasn't materialized yet."
 As domestic new issues dried up, a larger portion of new issues of both debt and equity in the second half of 1994 were foreign. That is a trend that Merrill Lynch expects to continue this year.
 "Foreigners didn't really take advantage of lower rates," Mr. Waugh said. Emerging markets in Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe are in a building phase, and if they are looking for long-term debt, they have little choice but to tap the American capital markets, he added.
 But James A. Bianco, director of research at the Arbor Trading Group in Barrington, Ill., said domestic debt issuers were scarce because they were getting better deals from banks.
 "Wall Street has a problem," he said. "It is pushing a product that is not very attractive in the current environment."
 That is because, with short-term lending rates high, banks can raise cash from depositors relatively cheaply. Meanwhile, Wall Street companies have been forced to pay higher short-term rates to finance their underwritings. And the banks are making loans at relatively high medium-term rates.
 The banks also helped fuel the record number of deals in 1994. "The level of interest rates is not as key as the availability of funds," said Eric Gleacher, an investment banker who specializes in mergers and acquisitions.
 Mr. Gleacher and other merger specialists say that the number of deals will remain high next year as industries continue to consolidate. "I think you are going to see more activity from European companies next year," he said, "because the European economy is coming back and the dollar is very weak."
