HEADLINE: Yeltsin's Next Quagmire?

BYLINE: By Andrew Meier; Andrew Meier writes frequently on Russian affairs.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Unlike Russia's secessionist crisis in Chechnya, the danger of a collapse of Tajikistan peace talks and renewal of the civil war there-- by far the bloodiest in any of the former Soviet republics -- cannot be dismissed as an internal Russian matter.
United States policy should aim to develop the small Central Asian republic of Tajikistan as an independent member of the world community. Instead, Washington has been surprisingly silent from the time war broke out in May 1992 until a cease-fire took hold in October in the small mountain country of 5.6 million, sandwiched between Afghanistan, China, Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. 
 In Tajikistan, three years after the Soviet Union crumbled, Russia has succeeded in resurrecting a piece of its old empire. Although the republic, ravaged by the civil war and nearly broke, is nominally independent, last year it uneasily accepted Russia's bear hug. The result is protection, Mafia-style.
Seventy percent of Tajikistan's state budget comes from Russia, 25,000 Russian "peacekeepers" are there to protect what President Boris Yeltsin calls Russia's border with Afghanistan and the Defense Minister is a Russian general. Moscow's main mission is to keep fighters, weapons and drugs from entering from Afghanistan.
While the Tajiks have no oil, neighboring Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan have plenty. Chevron and other American companies have invested millions of dollars in developing Central Asia's oil and gas fields. Moscow's stake is no smaller than the oil companies' in keeping the region calm, preventing the civil war from resuming and possibly spreading.
Tajikistan's economy -- it was always the poorest republic -- is crippled, and political repression is the norm. It needs Western support for reconstruction. But even though the war has taken perhaps 50,000 lives and forced more than 650,000 refugees to flee, since early 1992 Tajikistan has received only $96 million in U.S. aid. Of this, $61 million has been in food shipments (mostly wheat), $15 million in private donations and the rest in technical assistance.
J. Brian Atwood, Administrator of the Agency for International Development, said last month, "AID is the state of the art of preventive diplomacy." Yet, his agency has cut its technical assistance to Tajikistan from $18 million in fiscal 1994 to $9 million in the current, 1995 fiscal year.
 Tajikistan's autocratic regime has its human rights record partly to blame for the West's unwillingness to help. The regime has been notoriously repressive, in the opinion of Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International.
The war and its aftermath were marked by atrocities on both sides. When I visited Tajikistan in April, one pro-Government fighter told me, "No one paid much attention to any Geneva conventions." Whole villages, burned and bulldozed, were reduced to parched fields in a form of "ethnic cleansing."
The Tajiks' truce, punctuated by occasional skirmishes, is shaky. The cease-fire that began in October has been extended to Feb. 6. A fourth round of peace talks between the Government of President Imamali Rakhmonov, a diehard Communist, and an alliance of opposition factions is scheduled for later this month in Moscow. The talks were arranged by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations. By early this year, a total of 40 U.N. cease-fire observers, authorized by the Security Council last month, will have arrived.
When Tajikistan became independent in 1991, it had no national identity and no security forces, and the gross national product depended almost wholly on cotton. Since the republic lacked a unifying ethnic identity, no nationalist movement proved strong enough to fill the ideological vacuum left by the demise of Soviet rule.
In the political violence that broke out, on one side were the people in the provinces of Leninabad (renamed Khojand) and Kulyab, who ran the Government during the Soviet era. On the other side were Garmis and Pamiris, desperately poor peoples who saw an opportunity for a share in the central Government after being shouldered aside and oppressed during decades of Communist rule. They found allies with intellectuals and others in the capital, Dushanbe, who wanted a stronger Islamic presence, more democracy -- and personal power, too. Clan and regional loyalties played an important role in the fighting.
In 1992, after military intervention by Russia and Uzbekistan, the Leninabad-Kulyab alliance triumphed, and has sought to legitimize its rule ever since. On Nov. 6, the regime, now headed by Mr. Rakhmonov, staged the first presidential election since the war began and won. It was hardly democratic, since all opposition parties were banned and Mr. Rakhmonov ran against his own ambassador to Moscow, who himself charged fraud after the votes were counted.
Not surprisingly, the Tajiks have few friends in Washington. In October, Representatives Robert Andrews, Democrat of New Jersey, and Benjamin Gilman, Republican of New York, co-sponsored a successful resolution linking aid to an improvement in the regime's human rights record.
A handful of American organizations have given food and medical relief. The financier George Soros has donated $1 million, mostly to help returning refugees. And the U.N. has asked for nearly $30 million to finance humanitarian needs.
All U.S. humanitarian aid should continue unconditionally. But grants for economic development should be linked to emergence of the rule of law and respect for human rights norms.
With Senator Jesse Helms, a foe of foreign aid, soon to be chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, President Clinton would have an uphill problem trying to help the Tajiks. Clearly, bromides about building democracy would be absurd. But, with the lesson of Bosnia in mind, he can help assure peace by lending support to the talks in Moscow.
When I was visiting the Tajiks, I saw how important it was for America to try to check renewed Russian imperialism. One day I was squeezed in an elevator in the Hotel Tajikistan, in the capital, with a number of Russian officers. It stopped on a middle floor and a timid Tajik clutching Red Cross provisions peered in. "Don't worry," a colonel assured him. "There's room here for all of us." The Tajik, who appreciated the dangers of overloading Soviet-made elevators, begged off. The doors closed on the colonel's reassuring invitation, which unintentionally echoed the Soviet colonialism still fresh in Tajik memory.

HEADLINE: Mexico Delays Austerity Plan as Labor and Business Balk

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon postponed a televised address to the nation tonight after Government officials were unable to reach an agreement with labor and business leaders on an austere package of wage and price controls.
Investors in both Mexico and the United States had been awaiting the message to see how Mr. Zedillo was planning to rebuild Mexico's economy after a brutal devaluation two weeks ago that lowered the value of the Mexican peso by 30 percent. The speech also was intended to rebuild investor confidence by showing that Mr. Zedillo was firmly in control of the economy, an image undoubtedly obscured by the postponement. 
 Mexican officials did confirm tonight that Mr. Zedillo's plan includes an $18 billion international loan package -- half paid for by the United States -- to help Mexico stabilize the peso and recover from its economic crisis.
At first, the President's speech was scheduled to be delivered at 6 P.M., but it was delayed several times because of unexpectedly strong resistance from labor union leaders who were not immediately willing to accept the Government's offer of wage increases less than the anticipated rate of inflation.
Shortly after 11 P.M. the President's office announced that the speech had been postponed until sometime Tuesday morning.
Under the plan, the United States will expand a permanent $6 billion credit line to $9 billion, with one half coming from the Treasury Department's Exchange Stabilization Fund and the other half from the Federal Reserve System, the Mexican officials said. The additional money will be available for only six months.
Mexico will be able to use the money to stabilize the value of its currency by buying pesos on the foreign exchange markets. If Mexico draws on the loan, it must repay the money at an interest rate equal to the rate on the three-month United States Treasury bill at the time the withdrawal is made.
Canada also will increase its standing credit line of $1 billion Canadian to $1.5 billion. The Bank for International Settlements in Switzerland, which is owned by the European Central Banks, is providing a $5 billion credit line.
A group of about a dozen international commercial banks, including Citibank, has been asked to put up a $3 billion line of credit.
The International Monetary Fund will not lend Mexico any money but is expected to make a strong statement of support for Mexico, which could help regain the confidence of international investors.
A big part of Mr. Zedillo's planned address was to have been directed at investors in the United States and Mexico who have withdrawn billions of dollars from the Mexican market since the crisis began.
Guillermo Ortiz, the new Finance Minister, began at 9:30 A.M. to negotiate wage and price controls with business and labor leaders and representatives of peasants' organizations. Mr. Ortiz took office on Thursday, replacing Jaime Serra Puche, who acknowledged that he had bungled the devaluation and resigned.
Government officials had expected the meeting to go smoothly and Mr. Zedillo was supposed to address the nation at 6 P.M. But union members balked at the substantial cut in real wages, according to one official involved in the discussions. Government economists project that inflation in 1995 will be about 15 percent. Minimum wages are not likely to increase by more than 10 percent.
The Government's position is that wages must be restrained to keep the peso devaluation from unleashing another burst of inflation.
The inflation rate rose through most of the 1980's, peaking at 159 percent in 1987. The rate was reduced to 8 percent in 1993 and, until the devaluation, was expected to be below 10 percent again in 1994.
Financial markets in Mexico were open today, even though markets in the United States and some other countries were closed. The Mexican peso regained some strength against the dollar. The dollar was quoted today at 4.925 pesos, down from 5.075 pesos on Friday. Mexican stocks dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent, or 21.42 points, closing at 2,354.24 in light trading.
Mexico's economy was just beginning to recover from a year of stagnation when the peso crisis erupted. A major concern now is how to impose the tight controls needed to restrain inflation without choking off economic growth or causing more social unrest.
Mr. Zedillo promised that with the support of all Mexicans, the sacrifices would be temporary. The emergency plan "will make it possible to achieve as quickly as possible the benefits of the new exchange rate in terms of greater employment and production," said a statement from Mr. Zedillo's office.
The primary thrust of the plan is to whittle down the deficit caused by importing more goods and services than are exported. In 1994, that deficit was around $28 billion, which was covered by foreign capital lured by high interest rates on Government bonds.
Foreign investors eventually found less risky investments, leaving Mexico unable to support the deficit. There was a speculative run on the peso and, after spending more than $10 billion trying to defend it, the Government was forced to allow the currency to float freely.
Mr. Zedillo said that Mexico will have to cut that deficit in half during 1995, mainly by increasing exports and sharply decreasing imports.
The Government said it would improve the conditions for future investments by eliminating excessive regulations. And although the federal budget will have to be reduced, the Government pledged not to cut social programs for the poor.

HEADLINE: Boston N.A.A.C.P. Office Is in Foreclosure

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The nation's oldest chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. is 16 months behind on its mortgage, and the Federal Government, which holds the loan, has foreclosed.
The organization is being run from the house of the chapter president, Jack E. Robinson, and meetings are being held at members' homes and a local community college. 
 The chapter is $20,000 behind on payments to the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which provided a low-interest loan for renovation of its headquarters in the mid-1980's.
The chapter was formed in 1910, a year after the National Organization for the Advancement of Colored People was founded. It had been in its current office since the mid-1950's.
"What we're hoping to accomplish is that the minority community and N.A.A.C.P. members will come to the forefront and come up with the necessary funds to take the building out of foreclosure," Mr. Robinson said.
HUD officials were not available for comment today, a holiday. Mr. Robinson said the case had been turned over to an Arlington, Va., collection company.
The chapter was founded in 1910, a year after the National Organization for the Advancement of Colored People was formed. It had been in its current office since the mid-1950's.

HEADLINE: Voters Expect Upheaval In Political Landscape

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DENVER, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Not long ago, Bruce Chaffin was a throw-the-bums-out conservative. But he's not cynical about politics anymore.
"It's going to be wonderful," said the 36-year-old sales executive here, almost giddy about the Republicans' taking control of Congress this week. "You bet there's going to be some changes, and I can't wait." 
 But Nicole Avrain wore a pained expression and confessed to a new fondness for term limits. "As a liberal, I'm nervous," said the 24-year-old college student. "Real nervous."
Whether they see the Government becoming leaner, or just plain meaner, American voters of all stripes agree: the road ahead will veer to the right.
"Bill Clinton looks like a wet noodle," said Deshawn Jones, a 31-year-old Denver actor, "and Newt Gingrich is going to swallow him."
From the tobacco fields of rural Virginia to the sleek coffeehouses of San Francisco, and here in maverick Rocky Mountain country, many Americans seem to be eager, even insistent, to see a Republican slash-and-burn attack on a bureaucracy that they say is bloated.
"Let's see a reduction," said Frank Scartozzi, a 32-year-old dentist in Tenafly, N.J. "We all have to manage our budgets; it's time for Congress to manage theirs. This country has got to understand that nothing is on a silver platter."
One issue, repeated so often that nothing else comes close, strikes a raw nerve with the American electorate: welfare. Most of the nearly 70 people interviewed over the weekend said that President Clinton had not delivered on his promise to rein in welfare costs, and that the Republicans seemed more likely to pursue hard-nosed cuts.
"We've got to end the handout mentality in this country," said Tom Raddemann, a 41-year-old computer consultant in Denver who offered himself as proof that government assistance can lead to sloth. "About eight years ago I collected unemployment, and man, I didn't do a thing as long as it lasted. I just sat back, didn't even look for work. But when that sucker ran dry, let me tell you, I got focused in a hurry."
It was a sentiment that seemed to transcend class, race, sex and political affiliation, and it was usually delivered bluntly: the poor did not need a helping hand so much as they needed a swift kick in the pants.
"If you can sit home and have babies and collect more money than you'd get flipping burgers, well, that's what you do," said Isaac White, 42, a marketing executive here. "And believe me, I'm not the only black person getting fed up with it. There's a lot of us starting to vote Republican, even though people don't always admit it. It's obvious a lot of these social programs are doing more harm than good."
To be sure, not all voters are ready to embrace Republicans' welfare proposals, which include allowing states to abolish aid to young mothers. Nor do they all trust Representative Newt Gingrich, the incoming Speaker of the House.
In the view of John Sanford, a 44-year-old Chicagoan, Mr. Gingrich is "an absurd, crazy, anti-poor racist" who "probably believes that poor people should be deported from this country to another planet."
And Dan Dubrey, a 38-year-old Denver construction worker, likened Mr. Gingrich to a medieval king hungry for power. "He wants to gain control by putting fear into the hearts of the people," Mr. Dubrey said. "With him, everything that's wrong in this country is the fault of the little guy, and he just sits up there on his throne, barking orders."
But others, after hearing Mr. Gingrich described in ogre-like terms in various news reports, said they found the onetime Georgia college teacher to be surprisingly affable, even charming.
"The way the media portray him," said Janet Sherman, 46, a Denver homemaker, "you'd think he didn't want to just start up orphanages, but burn them down, too."
Jennifer Smith, 22, who works for a collection agency here, said the surest way for the Republicans to win the hearts of Americans would be through cuts in the tax code. And if the tax cuts do not go through, she added, the voters will discard the new team on Capitol Hill as surely as it dispatched the old crew.
"The mood of the public is pretty clear on taxes and welfare," Ms. Smith said. "And if it goes ignored, they're going to have a revolt on their hands."
Most voters say they fall somewhere in the middle on the political spectrum. Many of them, while favoring the cuts in the Government pledged by the Republicans, nonetheless shrink from what they see as a far-right social agenda on school prayer and hostility to homosexuals.
"On economic issues I like these Republicans, but they scare me on the other stuff, the Christian Coalition stuff," said John McCaffran, 31, a Denver auto mechanic. "I want government out of my face, period. Build the roads, run the military, but otherwise leave me alone."
Among Democrats, some said they relished seeing Republicans on the hot seat for a change, no longer able merely to sling arrows.
"The Republicans will drop the ball, fail miserably and spend the next few years whining and blaming the Democrats," said Greg Theobald, a 44-year-old Chicago lawyer, painting a scenario for Mr. Clinton's re-election.
But most voters, even Democrats, are not eager to see the Republicans fail. "I say, let's give the Republicans a fair chance," said Marcia Smith, 42, a statistician from Green Bay, Wis. "Nothing else seems to have worked."
Indeed, some people who voted for Mr. Clinton and who now express disappointment with him, see the conservative mood of the country as a golden opportunity for the President to reassert himself as a centrist, the sort of New Democrat he said he was in the 1992 campaign.
"This allows Clinton to move to the middle and make some hard choices he couldn't before," said John Duggan, a 27-year-old San Francisco salesman. "He has had to cater too far to the left."
Many voters said they simply wanted the Government to act more like a business, to "downsize" like so many American corporations.
"We have to balance our checkbooks, why not the Government?" said Derek Passarelli, 32, a bank supervisor here. "And I'm a little skeptical that the Republicans are going to be able to cut taxes, increasing spending for the military and somehow balance the budget."
One thing voters are not grousing about much is gridlock. Most Americans see Congress charging hard to the right, with Mr. Clinton close on its heels.
"Things will get done," said Barbara Maloney, a 59-year-old psychotherapist. "I'm just afraid it will be the wrong things."
Or, as Janine Jones, a homemaker in a Denver suburb put it, "What Newt wants, Newt is going to get."

HEADLINE: Knoxville Journal;
Company's Fall Is Dash of Cold Water but Not a Dashing of Hope

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 1

 BODY:
Across the street from two glass towers built by two banking brothers who went broke in the mid-80's, Jake and C. H. Butcher Jr., sits the emptying shell of the empire that Christopher Whittle built.
Some Knoxvillians call the spot, the corner of Maine and Gay Streets, Ego Intersection. 
 When Mr. Whittle, a media entrepreneur, opened a three-building complex downtown in August 1991, it was to house 2,000 workers and be the headquarters for the burgeoning ventures of Whittle Communications: Channel One, the network that took television newscasts and advertising into schools; Special Reports, a magazine-and-television venture aimed at doctors' offices, and the administrative part of the Edison Project, a grand education experiment to build private schools that would make money.
But as investors began to question the company's finances, Whittle Communications disintegrated through sell-offs and closings, and in the summer Mr. Whittle decamped to his apartment in the Dakota on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and his house in East Hampton, L.I. The Edison Project is the company's lone remaining enterprise, and its finances are shaky.
Now "Whittlesburg" is for sale, a monument to yet another failed effort here to create jobs and broaden the tax base, and the city is learning the cost of dashed expectations.
The asking price for Whittlesburg is reported to be about half its cost of $55 million, which means that taxpayers could lose more than the $7 million that they had put up to finance bonds. The money was to have been repaid as part of property taxes from Whittle.
The "potential taxpayer exposure," Mayor Victor Ashe said, is the most immediate problem. But Knoxville will lose in other ways, as well. The City Ballet received 5 percent of its budget in 1993 from Whittle. The United Way received $56,000 from the company and an equal amount from its employees.
And the Whittle Scholars program at the University of Tennessee, which Mr. Whittle financed, has been halved, to 50 recipients from 100, said Dr. Joseph E. Johnson, the university president.
Whittle has been laying off employees for years, so the economic blow is not as dramatic as it could have been. About 600 jobs have been lost, but that is a small percentage of the 350,000 jobs in the region.
Retailers are feeling the effects, nonetheless, especially in the Old City, a warehouse district that has become an area of restaurants, clubs and shops since the late 80's. The Old City's growth paralleled that of Whittle, and many former Whittle employees say their presence was instrumental in the area's success.
"In 1988 and '89," Jack Neely, who was an editor at Whittle, said, "probably more than half the people in the Old City were Whittle kids."
Frank Snowden, owner of one of the first restaurants in the area, closed a second restaurant in the neighborhood called the Summit Diner. "The collapse of Whittle has been devastating to my business," Mr. Snowden said. "I thought Whittle was going to march down Gay Street and meet up with Old City, rejuvenating the downtown. If I had known they were going to collapse, I would never have opened the Summit Diner."
But Paula Belden, whose furniture and accessory store is a few doors from Mr. Snowden's restaurant, said she was less disturbed. She pointed out that the University of Tennessee campus here had 25,000 students. "Knoxville won't suddenly become uncool without Whittle," she said.
Mayor Ashe sounded a similar note, pointing to "the many talented people Whittle brought who have decided to stay." He added, "That will be a positive, lasting benefit to the community."
Mr. Neely will be staying. He is a freelance writer for Metro Pulse, an alternative newspaper where several former Whittle employees have landed.
Ken Umansky, who moved here from New York City in 1989, will be staying to run a company that he formed with a partner in the summer to develop training programs.
Another former Whittle editor, Martha Hume, and her husband, Chet Flippo, a writer, moved here after 14 years in New York. Ms. Hume, who was born in eastern Kentucky, said she saw a "lasting cosmopolitan influence by the people who were brought here." She and her husband are writing books and plan to remain.
So does Andrew Nelson. He left Whittle, where he was a writer and an editor, when buyouts were offered in 1992 and began working on CD-ROM games with four friends. Their partnership is called Cyberflix, and their first two titles have sold almost 100,000 copies each.
Mr. Nelson calls Whittlesburg "chumps' corners."
A former fact checker, John Yates, had another name for Building 3 in Whittlesburg, where he was the last employee to leave. "I called it the Yates Wing," he said. Mr. Yates worked on the last Whittle publication, The Physician's Weekly, which was sold early last month.
Most of Whittlesburg is deserted now. One prospective buyer is the General Services Administration, which is planning a new Federal courthouse. A spokesman for the agency said on Friday that the agency hoped to decide in 10 days.
The remnants of the Whittle empire continue to occupy parts of Buildings 1 and 2. About 150 workers are left, and most of those work for Channel One, which was sold last summer to K-III Communications Corporation, based in New York. Don Johnston, in charge of liquidating the Whittle concern, oversees operations from his top-floor office.
But most of Whittlesburg is deserted. In one office, a dead ficus tree provides ghostly testimony to its former occupancy. In others, boxes of papers suggest transition. To Mr. Nelson, the abandoned files represent "what may be the saddest thing about the company's failure."
"There are boxes down here," he said, "full of great ideas just moldering."

HEADLINE: Yearning To Breathe Free

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Without being dour, Lorraine Canoe makes do with life in New York City, but it is not the same. You can find all kinds of things, but the supermarkets do not stock deer meat or boiled corn bread. In no borough are regular Mohawk ceremonies held for each of the year's 13 moons.
"And it's not easy trying to find someone I can talk Mohawk with," she said. 
 This is why, after living in Brooklyn for more than 35 years, Ms. Canoe considers her real home to be Akwesasne, the Mohawk reservation that straddles the border between New York and Canada. She was raised there, and it is only a matter of time before she returns for good to the place where everyone knows her as Kanaratitake, her given and preferred name.
Worshipful of Mohawk traditions but needing to work, the tough-spirited Ms. Canoe, 62, leads the split life of many American Indians transplanted to New York City. She savors the manic dazzle but finds her most resonant pleasure during occasional excursions, and frequent phone calls, back to the reservation.
Thousands of American Indians have moved off reservations into cities and towns across the United States to find jobs. And while many have spent years as high-rise Indians, they often suffer from a culture clash that causes them to yearn for the extended family, open spaces and time-honored ceremonies of their reservations. Those who have chosen New York have found the liabilities particularly pronounced.
"Most tribal customs are to take place on the earth," said Rosemary Richmond, the director of the American Indian Community House, a center that provides services and sponsors cultural events for Indians in New York and is currently marking its 25th year. "There is very little earth in New York City. And most of it is public and restricted. Catholics can go to a Catholic church in any city they move to. Indians have their own ways of worshiping that they can't find anywhere else."
According to the 1990 census, more than 26,000 American Indians live in New York City, nearly triple the number in 1980, making them one of the fastest-growing minorities in the city. And Indian organizations think the census figures undercount the actual population, and estimate it to be about 35,000, with the heaviest concentration in Brooklyn and Queens. New York City's Indians, thought to belong to more than 60 different nations, converge from as far away as Alaska. More Indians live in New York than on any reservation except the Oklahoma land areas and the Navajo reservation, which sprawls across Arizona, Utah and New Mexico. Among cities, only Los Angeles and Oklahoma City have higher Indian populations.
There has not been a true Indian neighborhood in New York since the 1950's and 1960's, when many Indians, principally Mohawks, congregated in downtown Brooklyn because they worked in construction and this was near the union hall. There was also a bar called the Wigwam where many of them drank. Indians have long been strongly represented in the construction industry; while most have a healthy respect for heights, they have a reputation for having little fear. A fair number of New York's Indians still work in construction, though far more are in artistic fields.
Many who come to New York today face difficulty finding work and decent housing. Indian organizations say they have a group unemployment rate of more than 45 percent, and many families live below the poverty level.
The American Indian Community House, in Greenwich Village, hopes to open a hotel within the next few years that will devote a sizable share of its space to housing Indians. The group also offers job counseling and substance abuse counseling, and it serves as a central meeting place where on any given day one is apt to find Senecas and Hopis and Shinnecocks.
Even if gainfully employed, many urban Indians wrestle with their connection to their past. Some want nothing to do with it. The children of one transplant did not even know they were Indians. Others keep up a superficial connection.
But there are many others who are attentive to their traditional customs, and for them, New York can be a lonely and constricting place. They miss the rituals. They are accustomed to open spaces. Animals are a vital part of their way of life. The simple act of going outdoors each day is starkly different from what it is on the reservation.
"People have done ceremonies in Central Park," said Ingrid Washinawatok, who came to New York in 1981 but intends to eventually move back to the Menominee Reservation in Wisconsin. "But Central Park is not truly clean so far as energy. Ceremonies aren't events. They are communications between you and whatever you want to call the creator. That should be done on the reservation."
In many ways, Ms. Canoe is typical of the urban Indian whose heart remains on the reservation. At her second-floor apartment in Sunset Park, Ms. Canoe was cooking and talking and cooing to her 7-month-old grandson -- and she was happy. That was because her daughter, Monica, was visiting from the reservation.
Ms. Canoe, who teaches a course on conquered peoples in America at Hunter College, was especially upbeat because a few weeks earlier she had been to the reservation for the Harvest Ceremony, when the last food is removed from the earth. All boys born during the year are formally named at the ceremony, and her grandson had his name announced: Kaientatiesa.
"New York is very exciting," she said. "But the reservation is my home. The belief system is not the same. My belief system is the ceremonies in the longhouse. Here they go to church or synagogue. It's not the same."
In order to worship, she tries to get to the reservation for as many ceremonies as she can. There, traditional celebrations are held in a large building known as the longhouse. They require a Mohawk water drum with a deerskin top and rattles. On ceremonial occasions, Ms. Canoe puts on fringed and beaded clothes and moccasins. Men wear headdresses boasting three eagle feathers.
Although many Indians on the reservations have assimilated into mainstream American culture and attend Christian churches rather than longhouse ceremonies, Ms. Canoe is fervidly traditional. "That genocidal thought of religion has gotten into their heads," she said of nontraditionalist Indians. "The church is a crutch. It's a white man's religion. They brought it here to conquer us and civilize us."
Ms. Canoe takes the nine-hour bus trip to the reservation for about half of the 13 annual ceremonies, and spends her summer breaks from Hunter there. She owns a house on the reservation, where her two daughters -- Monica, 26, and Sara, 23 -- live. Though both daughters were raised in New York, they moved to the reservation when they became adults. Ms. Canoe intends to retire in four years and settle there, as well.
She accompanied her husband, an ironworker, when he came to Brooklyn to work on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in 1958. The marriage eventually dissolved, but she stayed in the city and married Frank Montoia, a Mexican Indian. He is a window washer.
Not all of New York's food offerings are to Ms. Canoe's tastes, but she improvises. The three "sisters" -- beans, corn and squash -- are the sacred foods that are her staples. She makes her own boiled corn bread. She is not supposed to eat meat, like pork, that comes from an animal that would eat another animal.
She brings one of her favorites -- deer meat -- back from the reservation. She finds that Mexican restaurants serve dishes close to what she customarily eats.
Alcohol, she has come to believe, is something "the white man brought here to make us crazy." Thus she swore off drinking 20 years ago. She even refuses to use wine vinegar or to cook with any form of alcohol.
Another difficulty for urban Indians is that the public perception of them is rarely to their liking. Too often, in their view, it is an erroneous, simple-minded conception of warring heathens. "People say stupid things to us," Ms. Richmond said. "Like, 'Hey, chief,' or 'Do you live in a tepee?' You're always treated as a savage or an alcoholic."
Monica said she moved to the reservation three years ago because she felt incomplete in New York. Her husband, Ron LaFrance, is an audio-visual technician and teaches song and dance on the reservation.
"I've tried being in the city and it wasn't for me," he said. "I just feel more freer. It's not like we're living in a rain forest. But anywhere you go on the reservation, there are trees. I like to look for hawks. That's a little hard in the city."
And life on the reservation is more relaxed. "We have a thing that we call Indian time," Mr. LaFrance said. "If you set a meeting for 8, people will show up at 8:30 or a quarter to 9. It's not a fast-paced life."

HEADLINE: Somalia's Overthrown Dictator, Mohammed Siad Barre, Is Dead

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
Maj. Gen. Mohammed Siad Barre, who was overthrown as President of Somalia in 1991 after ruling that impoverished African country for more than 20 years, died yesterday in exile in Lagos, Nigeria.
Official accounts put his age near 74, but reference books place his birth variously between 1912 and 1920. 
 General Siad Barre's departure from the scene four years ago left Somalia without a central authority, on the brink of mass starvation and with a civil war among feuding clans and their militias.
As commander of the armed forces, he had taken control of Somalia, in the Horn of Africa, in 1969. The country of about nine million -- mostly nomads -- with a per capita income of about $175 a year is one of the most impoverished.
General Siad Barre's rule was marked by a war with Ethiopia, a flip-flop in political alliances from the Soviet Union to the United States, and growing allegations of human rights abuses.
In its final years, his Government steadily lost control of much of the countryside to the chiefs of warring clans, plunging the country into racking social and economic problems. Human rights groups issued reports citing a consistent pattern of political imprisonment, torture, political killings and discrimination against the Isaaks clan.
In May 1986, President Siad Barre was seriously injured in an automobile accident, but later that year he was nominated by the country's sole legal political party for re-election, ran uncontested and won a new seven-year term.
Yet there continued to be questions about the extent of his recovery. Reports of feeble health combined with the country's internal strife led to a weakening of his grasp on power, American officials believed. Toward the end, they said, he was struggling to arrange a succession that would insure that his family and clan -- the Marehan clan -- remained in power.
Many believed he was grooming his son, Maslah, who was a Soviet-trained army general.
Instead, Somalia was steeped in turmoil. United Nations and United States troops partly managed to open relief-supply lines to a famished population, but that costly effort, too, has yet to bring about a political solution and peace to the country.
According to his Government's version, General Siad Barre was born in 1919 or 1921. He was educated in private schools in Mogadishu, the capital, and attended the Military Academy in Italy and School of Administration and Politics in Somalia.
From 1941 to 1960 he served in the Somali Police Force and rose to the rank of chief inspector. In 1960, when the Somali Republic was created out of territories formerly ruled by the Italians and British, he was made a colonel and deputy commandant of the newly formed Somali National Army. He rose to brigadier general in 1962 and major general in 1966.
On Oct. 21, 1969, shortly after the President, Dr. Abdirashid Ali Shermarke, was assassinated by a police officer in a factional quarrel, General Siad Barre led a successful and bloodless coup. Assuming power, he espoused "scientific socialism," arguing there was no inconsistency with the principles of Islam, and turned to the Soviet Union for support.
In 1977, his army invaded the disputed Ogaden area of southeastern Ethiopia. At about the same time, Ethiopia split with the United States and became more closely aligned with the Soviet Union. With the help of Cuban troops and billions of dollars' worth of Soviet weapons, the Ethiopians turned back the Somalis in 1978.
General Siad Barre denounced the Russians and turned to the United States. Somalia received military and economic aid from the United States for a promise of American use of the port of Berbera on the Gulf of Aden. But aid declined drastically as allegations of human rights abuses rose. In 1989, Somalia revived contacts with Libya.
In May 1988, fierce fighting broke out in the north between the Government and rebels who contended they had been discriminated against by the Siad Barre Government and were fighting for a more democratic Government.
A report commissioned by the State Department and made public in September 1989 said the Somali Army "purposely murdered" at least 5,000 unarmed civilians over a 10-month period in the early phases. The Government denied the allegation.
More than 10,000 people were reported killed in the months that followed, with allegations that the Somali military had bombed towns and strafed fleeing residents.
Amnesty International said in August 1988 that since 1981 the Government had used torture and "widespread arbitrary arrests, ill treatment and summary executions" of civilians suspected of collaborating with the rebels.
In his last year in office, President Siad Barre promised reforms to introduce multi-party democracy.
In June 1990, a hundred prominent citizens signed a declaration called the Mogadishu Manifesto, calling for his resignation and the appointment of a transitional government pending free elections.
He called the manifesto "destructive," and jailed 45 of those who had signed it, but about a month later he ordered their release. He agreed to multi-party parliamentary elections to be scheduled in February but later canceled them and the civil war took its course.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY;
For Top Executives, Fed Is the Only Threat To Blue Skies Ahead

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Outside the Taco Bell and Dunkin' Donuts shops in the suburbs north of here, help wanted signs are about as common as strip malls. What is perhaps more surprising are the help wanted signs outside the factories.
"Thank you for considering us for employment," reads one sign outside L & L Products, a maker of gaskets and other auto parts. 
 For those industries that had been expected to lead America's industrial decline, these signs are comforting. They reflect not only the speedy burnishing of what was once the Rust Belt but also testify to widespread faith that customers will keep buying and the economy will keep growing.
"It brings a smile to your face," said G. Mustafa Mohatarem, general director of economics for the General Motors Corporation.
Like Mr. Mohatarem, his counterparts at the other auto makers -- indeed, at businesses across the country -- expect the economy to continue expanding through 1995, if at a gentler pace. However, they apply one caveat: The Federal Reserve could overshoot in its effort to mellow the expansion and stop its growth.
If the Fed raises rates further, said Allen Questrom, chairman and chief executive of Cincinnati-based Federated Department Stores, "it wouldn't surprise me to see recession in late '95 or early '96."
Some executives said that their businesses would boom as much because of their industry's idiosyncrasies as because of general economic growth. "The computer industry is positioned for strong growth in '95," said Ted Waitte, chief executive of Gateway 2000, a direct-mail computer supplier based in North Sioux City, S.D.
Mr. Waitte cited as support "a lot of things specific to the industry": a strong upgrade cycle because of new software and stiff competition on price. "People are just going to be able to buy much better products than they've ever been able to buy at much better prices than they've ever been able to buy them," he said.
But Mr. Mr. Waitte also pointed to robust consumer confidence, a sentiment heralded by manufacturers and retailers. "The consumer today feels good about the economy, clearly the best she's felt since the 80's," Mr. Questrom said. The auto makers believe that the combination of consumer confidence, pent-up demand and rising employment will provide them with strong sales well into 1997.
In fact, General Motors is convinced the expansion could continue indefinitely. "There's no law of economics that says you have to have a downturn," Mr. Mohatarem said. Since the Government cut spending and raised taxes at the recovery's start, rather than spending more and taxing less, it prevented a boom, Mr. Mohatarem said. Its action also prevented a bust, he added, guaranteeing slower growth of about 2.5 to 3 percent through next year and beyond, with mild inflation of about 3 percent.
Still Mr. Mohatarem said he worried that fiscal stimulus now -- like the tax cuts being considered by leaders of both political parties in Washington -- could ignite a boom and shorten the expansion.
For 1995, G.M. projects that sales of all vehicles in the United States will rise only about 2 percent, to 15.6 million from 15.3 million. The Ford Motor Company predicts industry sales of up to 15.9 million, while the Chrysler Corporation, which was saying last June that sales in 1995 could reach 17 million, has restrained its enthusiasm and now projects about 16.5 million. The previous record, set in 1986, was 16.3 million cars and light and heavy trucks.
Not everyone expresses such faith in the auto market's stamina, however. Asked how long auto sales would remain strong, Koichi Amemiya, president of American Honda Motor Company, laughed, and said, "I also want to know that."
If there is a fear expressed universally by business executives, it is that the Federal Reserve will raise rates too high. "The Fed appears to be trying to slay a dragon that doesn't exist," said Arthur C. Martinez, chairman of the Sears Merchandise Group, the retailing arm of Sears, Roebuck & Company in Chicago. So far, he said, "we see no discernible response by the consumer to what's happened." But he added that the effect of rising rates was hard to ascertain.
Auto executives nervously greeted each of the six interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve last year with the expressed hope that it would be the last. But in each case, after the dust had settled, they said only that the Fed's actions had taken the edge off the expansion without endangering it.
They continue to urge the Fed to go no further. "Clearly, if we were to get another rate increase, at some point it's going to put a damper on consumer confidence," said Edward E. Hagenlocker, president of Ford Automotive Operations.
The absence so far of a clear consumer response to rising rates may simply reflect the lengthy lag between cause and effect. The Fed's increases may not bite until this year's second or third quarter, said Ira Silver, manager of planning and forecasting for J. C. Penney in Dallas.
Mr. Silver said he expected the economy to still be growing at the end of 1995, but at less than 2 percent rate. "I think the Fed will get basically the soft landing they're looking for," he said.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: Forecasting 1994 Proved Hazardous;
He Was Close, If for Wrong Reasons...

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Among forecasters of 1994 economic growth, Larry J. Kimball was one of the few who was at least able to get his nose above water. His forecast was almost high enough to match what actually happened.
When he laid out his 1994 projection more than a year ago, Mr. Kimball, director of the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles, anticipated strong home construction, strong business investment and strong auto sales. All three happened. 
 But the economy did not play out according to Mr. Kimball's outlook, although his forecast -- higher than anyone else's -- came close to the mark.
"I did not foresee the sharp rise in interest rates," Mr. Kimball said. "I saw the Federal Reserve as nudging the rates up only a little."
In fact, if he had been more prescient about the Fed, Mr. Kimball might not have been as optimistic in his 1994 forecast. He would have worried that rising rates would inhibit home construction and auto sales. That had not happened by December.
Mr. Kimball also did not expect the economy to add as many jobs as it did: more than three million in 1994. "It was the new jobs and the new incomes that came with those jobs that propelled the economy upward," he said. "Incomes themselves did not change much."
Another error marred his forecast. Given the low inflation rate, Mr. Kimball thought American companies would have no reason to add much to their stockpiles of merchandise, to beat price increases.
But companies built up their inventories of goods in warehouses and on store shelves anyway, in anticipation of strong sales, at home and abroad.
"I think my biggest numerical mistake was in inventories," Mr. Kimball said. "I just saw sales in line with production, and instead production was stronger than sales."
But Mr. Kimball was lucky. His mistakes offset each other, and the outcome led to his relatively favorable forecast.
He predicted that the gross domestic product, measuring the value of all of the nation's goods and services, would grow by 3.7 percent in calendar 1994. That was the highest estimate submitted by any of the 50 prominent forecasters surveyed in December 1993 by Blue Chip Economic Indicators.
Still, Mr. Kimball was not bullish enough. While the final quarter's results are not yet in, it appears all but certain that the economy grew by about 4 percent last year.
For the first time, none of the forecasters in the Blue Chip survey submitted a prediction that was greater than what happened. The forecasts ranged from Mr. Kimball's 3.7 percent down to 1.7 percent, with the average at 2.9 percent.
The Clinton Administration was an encouraging factor in Mr. Kimball's forecast. "Their policies were pro-business," he said. "Their biggest risk, as Democrats, was that they would be budget busters. Clinton avoided that by reducing the deficit."
Indeed, in Mr. Kimball's view, Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction program, enacted in 1993, "set the stage for a sound expansion, with 1994 likely to be the strongest year."
This year is another matter.
The Kimball forecast for this calendar year is economic growth of 3.2 percent. Ten other forecasters surveyed by Blue Chip are more optimistic.
What colors Mr. Kimball's view of 1995 are interest rates and the Federal Reserve. Mr. Kimball thinks the Fed will try to slow the economy and raise the unemployment rate from the present 5.6 percent to 6 percent. In theory, at least, that would lessen inflationary pressures by making it harder for workers to bid up wages.
But he acknowledges that his crystal ball might be cloudy.
"What would get in the way of slowing the economy," Mr. Kimball said, "would be a big, stimulative middle-income tax cut that was not offset by spending cuts."

Some Economists Look Into the New Year

Statistics will probably show that the economy throttled back at the end of 1994 to about the 2.5 percent growth rate that the Federal Reserve and most private analysts had considered sustainable. SECTION: Section C; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1269 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995;
A Lingering Unease Despite Strong Growth

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
RARELY since World War II have the world's most powerful economies surged forward so successfully at one time. And rarely have their citizens been so worried that the good times are about to end before they get a share of the bounty.
In the United States, economic growth was the best in a decade, yet that did nothing to help Bill Clinton avoid the revenge of the middle class that led to the first Congress in 40 years controlled entirely by Republicans. In Europe, even though prosperity is returning after a painful recession that sent the jobless rate back into double digits, Helmut Kohl held on to power in Germany only by his fingertips, John Major seems on his last legs in Britain, France is turning inward and Italy has returned to its perpetual state of political chaos. 
 Meanwhile, from Los Angeles to Berlin, the rise in economic output has done little to dampen xenophobia, whether the concern is an influx of Mexicans or Eastern Europeans.
In Asia, Japan is finally seeing the end of a grueling recession that destroyed the national sense of confidence -- some would say arrogance -- that Tokyo had invented a recession-proof form of capitalism that would trump all Western versions. Few think that today: Where just three years ago more than half the country thought Japan would be the world's premier economic power in the next century, now only 25 percent think so.
It is hard to put a finger on why everyone seems so jittery at a time when celebration seems more in order. Perhaps this will turn out to be just a passing bout of economic angst. But that seems unlikely.
Some at the White House blame their problems on the stagnation of real wages in the United States, a 20-year-long phenomenon that has left ordinary workers convinced that economic upturns benefit everyone but them. But that is only a partial explanation and does little to account for the mood elsewhere. A more far-reaching explanation lies in the fact that the global economy is being profoundly reordered, with countries most people still label "developing" expected to account for 40 percent of the world's output early in the next century. That raises fears, whether rightly or wrongly, that the high living standards of the industrial world will be eroded by cheap labor in Asia and Latin America.
Whatever the cause, edginess -- on both a personal and a national scale -- seems bound to worsen if, as seems likely , the world's biggest economies drift out of sync this year. The most probable outcome is a slowdown in the American economy, as the drumbeat of interest-rate increases orchestrated last year by the Federal Reserve finally hits home.
"It's not a question of whether the U.S. will slow down, but when and how much," said David Hale, the chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. "The next issue will be how much that will take the steam out of other recoveries around the world."
A lot rides on how that slowdown is managed, starting with Bill Clinton's chances for re-election in 1996. The White House is haunted by the experience of George Bush, who might have been re-elected had the economy improved earlier. Abroad, an American economy moving ahead at a slower pace is all it takes to raise tensions with economic competitors, particularly Japan. In the post-cold war era those tensions are more visible and potentially more volatile than ever. Meanwhile, China, once dealt with so gingerly by American policy makers, is now being viewed as more and more of an economic menace, with a trade surplus with the United States that has grown to $30 billion.
"These are the countries that are a lightning rod for Americans worried about change, or about their own futures, and so they are potentially a big political problem," said Jeffrey E. Garten, the Undersecretary of Commerce for international trade and the author a few years ago of a book that was presciently titled "A Cold Peace."
President Clinton's strategy for allaying those worries is to convince the country that the new era of freer trade he has promoted so successfully in the last year will ultimately benefit American workers far more than it will hurt them. That was the underlying argument for the North American Free Trade Agreement when it was adopted a year ago, and it resurfaced during the Congressional battle this fall over revising the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Atop these victories, Mr. Clinton traveled to Indonesia to press for an Asian free trade zone, then zipped to Miami to win approval of a parallel zone that will stretch from Tierra del Fuego, at the southern tip of Argentina, to Alaska.
It is an ambitious vision, and it may well prove to be Mr. Clinton's greatest foreign policy legacy. Frustrated by two years of bilateral trade talks with Japan that yielded little, the Administration has turned attention to the tantalizing big emerging markets that only a few years ago were barely on the radar screen. Those markets are hard to define, but most of them have fast economic growth -- Brazil, China, even India and Poland -- and an insatiable demand for imports to build everything from phone systems to software houses. These big emerging markets are expected to increase imports by $972 billion between 1990 and 2010, while the world's industrialized countries will likely increase their imports by $658 billion, according to estimates by the Commerce Department. But if anyone is tempted to conclude that the enthusiastic talk about free trade means a gradual end to the national and regional boundaries that have been used for centuries to keep rich and poor apart, think again.
For a taste of where the world is going, just look at the world's newest economic arbiter created by the new GATT deal -- the World Trade Organization. The organization is supposed to enforce the global trade accord and press for new openings around the world. But when it came into existence two days ago it was still without a director general. The Europeans, the Americans and the Asians are all sponsoring different candidates, and no one wants to give in. The result is an inauspicious start for the organization dedicated to world harmony through trade.
Behind the standoff lie three very different visions of the future of the world economy.
The Europeans would like to create the world trading system in their image, promoting free markets but willing to subordinate them, when necessary, to programs that place social welfare or regional interests ahead of unfettered capitalism. The Americas, under the flag of former Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the best-known candidate to lead the organization, is pressing an agenda of deregulation, deregulation and more deregulation, though his chances are not likely to be helped by the recent debacle with the peso. And the Asians, fronting a little-known South Korean candidate, want to promote their own model of economic development: state capitalism, where the government invests heavily in business enterprises and often engages in detailed industrial policy while political dissent is subordinated to the demands of national development.
For the United States, like it or not, this is the new stuff of foreign policy. Picking a head for the trade organization hardly has the grip of stopping the destruction in Bosnia or the clarity of preventing North Korea from getting the bomb.
But as President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, said recently: "What we are doing now is setting the ground rules for the next century. If it looks messy and complicated, that's because it is."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY;
2 Games for Fed Watchers: Waiting and Guessing

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
By the middle of 1995, either a lot of professional economists or a lot of bond traders and investors will be very, very embarrassed.
The consensus of traders and investors, as shown by prices in bond and futures markets, is that the Federal Reserve will push overnight interest rates up to 7 1/2 percent by June, from 5 1/2 percent now. But economic forecasters are much less gloomy; one recent survey found that blue-chip forecasters' average estimate was for overnight rates of just 6.1 percent for the second quarter. 
 "Somebody's very right, somebody's very wrong," said David C. Munro, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a New York consulting company.
Who is right will depend on the Fed's willingness to raise interest rates again next spring without waiting for its six interest rate increases of 1994 to take effect fully. The Fed's goal is to slow the economy and forestall inflationary shortages of raw materials and skilled workers.
Higher interest rates affect the economy gradually, over six months to two years. If companies decide today that they must cut back on borrowing, their canceled orders will slowly trickle back to factories, which will gradually trim output and hiring.
Economists and traders can both cite recent comments by top Fed officials to justify their opposite views on whether the Fed will wait or act again.
Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has sounded the most confident that the Fed has done enough. He said at a news conference on Dec. 9 that although the economy had expanded 4.4 percent over the 12 months ended in September, growth would slow in the next year to between 2 1/2 percent and 2 3/4 percent.
Most Fed officials believe that with the economy already operating at full tilt, with factories full and unemployment low, further growth of 3 percent or more would be inflationary. So Mr. Blinder's comment that growth would slow -- coupled with other comments he made that most of the effect of the 1994 interest rate increases had not yet been felt -- suggested a reluctance to raise rates further.
Some outsiders echo Mr. Blinder's views. "The wise thing for them to do is to wait and see how things turn out," said Andrew F. Brimmer, a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board.
Another reason to think the central bank will be less aggressive in raising rates this year than last is the shift among the voting members of the Fed's top interest rate panel, the Federal Open Market Committee.
The presidents of four regional Federal Reserve banks rotated off the panel on Jan. 1, and three of them were leaders in the move toward higher interest rates last year. Only one of their replacements -- Thomas C. Melzer, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis -- has a reputation as someone who will push strongly for higher rates at the committee's eight meetings this year.
While Mr. Blinder played down the importance of the turnover, Manuel H. Johnson, one of his predecessors as vice chairman, said that it could make a difference.
Still, there are many traders who expect that rates will continue to rise. They can point to remarks by Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress on Dec. 7. "There is very little evidence throughout this economy of any degree of slowdown," he said.
While Mr. Blinder emphasized that consumer inflation has been low, Mr. Greenspan warned that this might not be true for long. Raw material prices have been rising, and so have prices for so-called intermediate goods like flour that are used in making finished goods like bread.
According to the Labor Department, the prices that producers charge for finished goods rose half a percentage point in November, the most recent month available. But raw material prices rose a full 1 percent, and intermediate goods 1.1 percent.
Susan M. Phillips, a Fed governor, said in an interview last autumn that these increases in raw material and intermediate good prices have not shown up in consumer price inflation yet because labor cost increases were small. Labor accounts for at least two-thirds of the cost of finished goods.
One of the key questions for Fed officials has been whether labor costs will continue to stay low, even as unemployment has fallen to 5.6 percent. That level has been associated in the past with shortages of some types of skilled workers as well as rising labor costs.
Improving productivity -- meaning each worker produces more goods in the same amount of time -- helped hold down companies' labor costs last year, as did small increases in wages.
Sending a strong message that inflation will stay low is especially important to the Federal Reserve now because many big labor union contracts are up for negotiation. Central bankers do not want to see large wage increases granted by companies or state and local governments on the assumption that higher labor costs can readily be passed on to consumers or taxpayers.
The Labor Department has calculated that bargaining will be under way for 42 percent of all contracts covering at least 1,000 workers, the highest percentage since the department began calculating such figures 11 years ago.
Although the 3.4 million workers covered by collective bargaining this year account for only 3 percent of the nation's work force, they tend to exert a disproportionate influence on wages.
Few changes in the economy would be as likely to provoke the Fed into further interest rate increases as a sharp rise in wages not offset by rising productivity. Yet few experts think it likely. The shrinkage of American companies and the expanded use of high-technology devices to replace jobs have made workers more reluctant to demand higher pay.
If wages do not rise quickly, and the economy does begin to slow, then traders betting on overnight interest rates of 7 1/2 percent could be proved wrong. "I think 6 could very well be the top," Mr. Munro said, "but many in the market have much higher expectations and could be disappointed."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY;
In G.O.P. Plans, a World of Change

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
From Madison Avenue image-meisters to West Coast petrochemical producers, from mutual fund operators in Boston to cigarette makers in Virginia and the Carolinas, American business has a lot riding on the new Republican leadership that will take control of Congress this year.
The "Contract With America," the House Republican statement of policy priorities drafted before the election that gave the G.O.P. control of Congress for the first time in 40 years, sets out the early agenda. It calls for sweeping changes in the handling of business lawsuits, substantial tax reductions for capital gains, new incentives to spur investment by industry, additional tax cuts for individuals who put aside savings and curbs on the Federal regulatory burden. 
 But just as important as what Congress does, industry leaders and lobbyists caution, is what it leaves undone. And in some areas, they are still puzzling over just how the fine print in the G.O.P. contract would affect them in real life.
"Take 'tax code reform,' " said Wally Snyder, president of the American Advertising Federation, an umbrella organization of advertising firms and professionals. Under that rubric, eliminating advertising from the roster of deductible business expenses "might be seen by some as a way to bring in more money," Mr. Snyder said. "That's why we're putting so much emphasis on educating this new group of members of Congress," he added. "We're taking no chances."
A host of industries are likely to be affected by the changes on Capitol Hill. These are among the highlights:
*For Wall Street, says Marc Lackritz, president of the Securities Industry Association, the industry's trade association, there are several areas worthy of attention. All financial services firms, especially mutual fund managers and marketers, stand to benefit if Congress widens the availability of individual retirement accounts and makes them more attractive. Investment banking firms would be big winners if the new Congress promotes business capital investment and rescinds rules requiring early disclosure of plant closings caused by takeovers or mergers. Wall Street also sees a lower capital gains tax as encouraging investment, and thus spurring commissions. But other high-priority proposals affecting the financial markets are not so easy to call: The Glass-Steagall Act, which restricts certain securities activities by banks, is certain to undergo changes, but bankers and brokers are at odds over the most likely outcome. Similarly, several new Congressional leaders support freer trade in financial services, but Wall Street is unsure what it would have to offer to foreigners in return for access to their markets.
*The banking industry, apart from the Glass-Steagall issue, will be looking to the new Congress to rein in the Justice Department's aggressive efforts to enforce the Community Reinvestment Act's fair-lending provisons, industry analysts said.
*The insurance industry is paying attention to two big issues. Most important is the revision of the Superfund law, which determines liability for cleaning up industrial waste sites. It died in Congress last year. There is also the long-simmering debate over whether insurers should be subject to Federal, rather than state, supervision. Insurers, even more than most other businesses, also stand to gain from the far-reaching changes proposed to make it more difficult to sue for damages since they are frequently the "deep pocket" of last resort in product liability cases and other similar lawsuits.
*The petrochemical industry and many heavy manufacturers, while sharing the insurance industry's interest in the fate of the Superfund, will also be looking for a more sympathetic handling of various pollution control laws that in industry's view impose an unfair burden on manufacturers.
*Agribusiness fears the budget ax, which could finally chop away at a lot of Depression-era farm programs. Still, the industry has well-placed allies among the newly powerful Republicans, from Thomas J. Bliley Jr., a Virginia tobacco belt loyalist who will head the House Commerce Committee, to Senator Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina, a wealthy hog farmer friendly to the pork industry.
*Consumer products companies are generally optimistic about the change in leadership, especially cigarette manufacturers, which endured last year's Congressional hearings on the health risks of tobacco. The new commitment to reducing the burden of regulation may also help consumer products companies resolve troublesome conflicts between the labeling and advertising rules of the Federal Trade Commission and the Food and Drug Administration, executives said.
Broadly speaking, many business leaders believe that agencies like the Occupational Safety and Health Administration will be reined in by the new Congress. They may be too optimistic about that, but, at the very least, it will probably be much harder for agencies in the executive branch to impose new rules on business without a big fight on Capitol Hill.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: Forecasting 1994 Proved Hazardous;
...But He Was Way Too Low

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
None of the nation's most prominent forecasters was more pessimistic about what 1994 would bring for the American economy than Irwin L. Kellner, senior economic adviser at Chemical Bank. "Everything pointed to weakness," he recalled recently.
Mr. Kellner said he thought a year ago that the Clinton tax increase for the wealthy would inhibit spending among the rich, and that would have a ripple effect on the less affluent. Neither happened. 
 Mr. Kellner also thought low inflation would hold back spending. After all, why hurry to buy to beat price increases if none is on the horizon? People bought anyway. And he never dreamed that the money many homeowners saved by refinancing their mortgages would be spent so lavishly on consumer goods.
In retrospect, Mr. Kellner said, he underestimated the power of low interest rates and plentiful credit, not to mention the pent-up demand for new cars and the cleverness of the auto manufacturers in designing leasing plans to move cars from showrooms to the nation's garages.
Finally, European economies recovered more strongly than Mr. Kellner had expected. As a result, Europeans bought ever larger quantities of American goods. A weak dollar helped by making United States goods more competitive in price.
"In sum, whatever could converge to boost the economy in 1994 converged, including the California earthquake, which resulted in billions of dollars in spending for reconstruction," he said. "But anyone who was right about the economy in 1994 was right for the wrong reason. We were wrong for the right reasons."
Mr. Kellner, who is, as he puts it, "always on the lookout for what could upset the apple cart," decided a year ago that 1994 would produce a rise in the nation's output of goods and services of only 1.7 percent. Among the 50 forecasters surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators in December 1993, his estimate of the growth in gross domestic product was the lowest. Even the most optimistic forecasters, however, fell short of the approximately 4 percent that has turned out to be the actual growth rate in calendar 1994.
The average forecast of 2.9 percent growth was way off the mark as well. But the Blue Chip forecasters, as a whole, were much closer to the actual 2.6 percent inflation rate this year. Mr. Kellner gave the low-ball estimate there too: 1.5 percent.
None of the forecasters expected the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as much as it did.
The expectation that jobs and incomes would stagnate shaped Mr. Kellner's thinking. This has been a successful theme of his for years. Like a modern-day Cassandra, Mr. Kellner was almost alone in the late 1980's in forecasting the recession that finally appeared in the summer of 1990. And that summer, Mr. Kellner was among the first to recognize that a recession had begun. He urged the Federal Reserve to ease up on interest rates, which it finally did in the early fall.
"For the first year of this recovery, employment declined and the unemployment rate kept rising," he said. "I was impressed with the lack of job creation in 1992 and 1993, and I was also impressed with the low quality of pay. But people are sophisticated; they have found offsets, although one wonders how long they can continue to do so."
All of which brings Mr. Kellner to 1995. His forecast is for economic growth of 2.5 percent to 3 percent, which puts him close to the consensus forecast of 2.9 percent in the Blue Chip survey.
"The economy has a lot of momentum," Mr. Kellner said, "and we don't think the Federal Reserve will create a recession by raising interest rates too much. In this case, we are optimistic in our forecast that the Fed can engineer a slowdown."
