HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTING: A Wild Ride for Emerging Markets;
A Choppy Ride for Europe?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The major markets in Europe generally did not do much last year, but there was plenty of action out on the volatile new frontiers of emerging markets, enriching some investors and impoverishing others.
 In Brazil, the Bovespa equity index finished the year up by well over half in dollar terms, and other markets in Peru and Chile were not far behind. But the losers were almost as conspicuous as the winners. The new stock markets in China's burgeoning cities of Shanghai and Shenzhen ended 1994 down by more than a third. The most embarrassing performance was turned in by Turkey's stock market, whose value was cut 49 percent over the year. The Turkish market was a big winner in 1993. 
In Europe, stock markets moved circumspectly in response to elections at home and skittishly in anticipation of rising interest rates in the United States. The weaker dollar against major currencies from Frankfurt to Tokyo made European and Japanese exports more expensive and left some industry stocks overpriced for foreigners.
 Swings in exchange rates also skewered market returns for foreign investors. Mexico's Bolsa ended the year off by nearly 41 percent, dragged down by the peso's devaluation. But the Nikkei index in Japan finished up 27 percent after the stronger Japanese yen moved into double digits against the dollar.
 Emerging markets promise the most exciting opportunities again in 1995, perhaps too exciting for the faint of heart.
 With the unexpectedly early and sharp rise in interest rates in the United States driving down stock prices in most major markets, 1994 was not much of a year for investors in Europe.
 In London, Europe's financial center, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares tumbled from a record of 3,520 early in 1994 to a low of 2,877 and ended the year around 3,000.
 The markets in Germany and France registered drops of similar scale amid concern among equity investors that rising rates would dampen hopes for earnings growth and siphon funds from stocks into bonds. Indeed, every major European market ended well below its high for the year, with a particularly volatile market like Italy's down more than 25 percent.
 What is in store for 1995? Mike Young, the director of European investment strategy at Merrill Lynch in London, said the European markets over all could be in for a choppy ride, especially if the market in the United States declined and European short-term interest rates and bond yields rose.
 "The next move may well be down rather than up," Mr. Young said.
 But there are pockets of opportunity. Finland, Norway, the Netherlands and Britain are currently Merrill Lynch's favorite European markets, he said.
 Many stocks in Finland and Norway, especially cyclical and commodity stocks like paper companies, could still see enhanced earnings from the worldwide economic recovery. Many stocks in the Netherlands could post surprisingly good earnings gains and may benefit from improving market valuations. And Britain, Mr. Young said, is the cheapest of the major markets and has suffered from too much pessimism about the earnings outlook.
 Financial services, energy and consumer-oriented companies all have potential for next year, said Joe Rooney, the strategist at Lehman Brothers in London.
 Lehman Brothers is recommending stocks such as Banco Popular of Spain andABN-Amro of the Netherlands in the banking field. Royal Dutch/Shell of the Netherlands and Total of France are among the major oil companies Lehman is recommending, and A.B. Astra of Sweden, LVMH of France, Heineken of the Netherlands and B.A.T. Industries of Britain are among its favorite consumer-driven stocks. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTORS;
Talk of Middle-Class Tax Cut Makes Wall St. Uneasy

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
Wall Street is watching warily as leaders of the new Republican majority in Congress and the Clinton Administration vie for the hearts and minds of the middle class with promises of tax relief.
 Topping the Republican proposals is a bonus for investors -- an exclusion of 50 percent of long-term capital gains from taxable income. The measure would lower capital gains taxes to a range of 7.5 percent to 19.6 percent. President Clinton has countered with a 30 percent exclusion, resulting in taxes of 10.5 to 28 percent, the top rate now. 
As much as it welcomes any cut in the gains tax, Wall Street fears the cut will be just the tip of a deficit-worsening package.
 Among the measures on the table are a $500 refundable credit for children, elimination of the marriage tax penalty, an expanded individual retirement account and fewer taxes on Social Security benefits. It's not that these measures are inherently bad; in fact, several would encourage investment in the same way a capital gains tax cut would. But without specific spending cuts to compensate for any loss in revenue, such a package could spook the markets.
"It would be devastating to the bond market, and would affect stocks also," said Joel Isaacson, president of Joel S. Isaacson & Company, a New York accounting firm that specializes in personal financial planning. "The bond market wants to see spending cuts to offset the deficit."
 Edward J. Campbell, senior economist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, the investment banking firm, said the financial markets had not yet factored in the impact of a tax cut because so little was known about its final shape.
 "There are a lot of staunch Republicans" on Wall Street, Dr. Campbell said, "and they believe in the 'Contract With America,' but every time you talk to them, you get a sense they have their fingers crossed" that the final program will be fiscally sound.
 The normal rationale for cutting taxes -- aside from the political appeal of winning votes -- is to stimulate a sagging economy by freeing money for consumer spending. In turn, demand for goods and services increases, leading to greater output and employment.
 That prescription is scarcely the right one now. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates six times in 1994 to keep a robust economy from overheating and becoming inflationary. And that is in spite of a package of tax increases passed in November 1993. To reverse course and cut taxes now could only add fuel to the economy, doubtless leading the Fed to ratchet up interest rates even further.
 As rates rise, the value of debt issued at lower rates drops, while money tends to move away from equities into new bonds, causing stock prices to slump as well.
 A tax cut that promises the American middle class that it can have something for nothing can only grease the skids under an already sliding bond market, said David A. Berenson, a managing partner of the accounting firm Berenson & Company and a former national director of tax policy for Ernst & Young.
 As with a family that lives beyond its means by using one credit card to pay another, the United States has lived with a $203 billion Federal deficit by selling Treasury bonds to investors in Japan, Germany and the Middle East, Mr. Berenson said.
 "Japan has cracks in the economy," he said. "Russia is capital starved and may swing to a right-wing dictatorship without a capital infusion, and Eastern Europe is a basket case."
 Germany, meanwhile, is busily absorbing the former East Germany. America cannot continue "financing folly and mistakes with foreign borrowing," he said.
 Not everyone was so negative about the impact of new tax cuts. Robert Willens, managing director of Lehman Brothers, said, "It could wind up a net nothing."
 In addition to the capital gains cut, the proposal to expand I.R.A.'s and to create a new "American dream account" would have a "dramatic, positive effect on the markets, both stocks and bonds," he said. Like I.R.A. money, some of the disposable income created by any tax cuts would find its way into the financial markets.
 "The other side is that tax cuts are bearish for the bond markets," Mr. Willens continued. "They see deficit spending and inflation." The bad and the good of a package, he suggested, could cancel each other out.
 David D. Hale, chief economist of Kemper Securities Inc., wrote in a recent Economic Review that tax cuts could attract foreign capital immediately. "The Republican takeover of Congress could boost the dollar during the first quarter if the new Congress moves quickly to reduce capital gains taxes and pursue other policies favorable for U.S. savings and investment," he wrote.
 Concerns about the economic impact aside, tax cuts would have positive repercussions for some.
 Avery E. Neumark, a partner in the accounting firm of Rosen Seymour Shapss Martin & Company and its director of employee benefits and executive compensation, expressed enthusiasm for the proposed American dream savings accounts. People would put in after-tax money, which would grow tax-free and be tax-free upon withdrawal if used for retirement after age 59 1/2, for first-home purchases or for college costs.
 "These accounts will encourage young people," he said. "This may encourage investments, and the better the performance, the better the tax break."
 Some tax relief for capital gains is considered a fait accompli, Mr. Neumark said, and that should be positive for the stock market, as people bid up growth stocks.
 Which stocks specifically? Brown Brothers points out that the Republicans' Contract With America calls for less Government, which could mean less pressure on drug makers. Although generally negative about the outlook for equities, the firm is recommending Abbott Laboratories, Pfizer and SmithKline Beecham.
 Reasoning that the Republicans will exert less regulatory pressure on the tobacco industry, the firm's chief financial analyst, Ronald J. Hill, also expects Philip Morris to benefit.
 Energy is another promising sector, says Mr. Hill, who favors Amoco, Royal Dutch, Apache Corporation, Enron and Noble Affiliates.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY;
Southeast's Lure: Jobs, Jobs, Jobs

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN

 BODY:
Across America, the economy of the 1990's is shaping up as the mirror image of the 1980's.
 A decade ago, California and the East Coast were booming; today, they lag behind the rest of the country. The Midwest, then known as the Rust Belt, buckled. Now an industrial revival is restoring much of the original finish to the region. 
Through much of the 1980's, blue-collar workers suffered as manufacturing underwent a painful restructuring to meet tougher world competition. In the 1990's, white-collar employees were lashed by a similar make-over of office-centered services.
 Remember the cold war? The nation's huge military buildup of the 1980's is now being matched by an equally rapid shrinkage of the military industry.
 The computer hardware surge of the last decade, symbolized by I.B.M. and Apple Computer Inc., has been supplanted by the software and networking revolution led by the Microsoft Corporation and Novell Inc.
 Wall Street remains on a roller coaster. Financial services slumped after the stock market crash in 1987. After a revival of the industry in the early 1990's, new traumas were created in 1994 by rising interest rates, the collapse of the bond market, the comeuppance of the hedge funds and the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.
 And through the decades, people and jobs continued to be drawn to suburbia and to regions, like the South and the Rocky Mountain states, with a reputation for livable comfort.
 One region that is likely to continue performing strongly, especially in job growth, will be the Southeast, according to many economists.
 Led by Atlanta, the fastest-growing urban economy in the country, the region will probably see slightly higher job growth than other parts of the United States. But at the same time, the pace of growth will begin to slow from the last two years of robust expansion. Job growth for 1995, most economists predict, will be up to 3 percent.
 "The region will do better than the national average," said Thomas J. Cunningham, senior regional economist for the Federal Reserve Bank in Atlanta, "and we have for a long time."
 This view is enthusiastically shared by Mark Vintner, a vice president of the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., which owns banks throughout the region.
 "The Southeast is incredibly strong," he said. "It is extremely hard to find any signs of weakness. The only exception would be in the apparel industry."
 Both he and Mr. Cunningham base their 1995 forecasts on strong job growth.
 "Job growth is the best proxy of overall growth," Mr. Vintner said. "Going forward, I'm expecting about 3 percent job growth. At this stage of business expansion, real state gross product is not going to increase faster than job growth.
 "When you look at the number of companies coming to the South, it's overwhelming," Mr. Vintner said. "Companies want to come to a place where they have a good supply of labor and can lower costs, where utility costs are lower, taxes are lower and the quality of life is better. And some of these states are nonunion."
 After a long downturn in foreign corporate investment -- punctuated by several high-visibility manufacturing projects like a Mercedes-Benz plant in Alabama and a BMW plant in South Carolina -- there are signs that foreign interest in the Southeast is increasing, according to Donald Ratajczak, the director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University in Atlanta.
 "Foreign investors are slowly coming back," he said. "They are important to our area. The Japanese are in optics, into some of the sporting goods. The Germans in automobiles and auto parts and trucking. The Dutch into all kinds of retailing. The Canadians are into forest products. These are all important players."
 Mr. Ratajczak cautioned, however, that rising interest rates threatened to dampen housing starts, which in turn would affect the region's strong household industries.
 "We're very concerned about what is going to happen to housing," he said. "As interest rates go up, housing will be caught. My forecast is housing will slow, and this will hit our lumber, furniture and carpet industries. We can handle it for six to nine months; then we go down."
 Mr. Vintner says one of the strongest states will be Florida, where he is predicting job growth of 200,000 in 1995, on top of the 220,000 jobs created there in 1994. "There's really solid growth throughout the state," he said.
 In North Carolina, only a shortage of labor is likely to hold growth back. "North Carolina hits the perennial problem of unemployment of 4.1 percent," Mr. Ratajczak said. "How can it possibly grow? It doesn't have the people. North Carolina has to mark time." EDWARD A. GARGAN

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY
Industry Groups Cope With Cost-Cutting and Consolidation;
Retailers Battle Mostly Over Prices

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Retailing has become a commodity business in many ways.
 These days stores are distinguished less by their merchandising flair than by their pricing strategies, which give consumers a powerful weapon. 
And shoppers are increasingly adept at wielding it. Look at what happened to Toys 'R' Us during the holiday selling season: Even though the mighty toy retailer offered more than $1,000 worth of coupons for popular toys and video games, discount stores gave customers even better deals.
 Consequently, whatever sales gains Toys 'R' Us does report today were achieved mostly by sacrificing profits.
 Some chains have reached abroad for their expansion, but the international scene is proving more difficult to conquer than many had expected. Several retailers that took advantage of the North American Free Trade Agreement to expand into Mexico have quietly begun pulling back.
 A few retail companies still have costs they can eliminate. The Kmart Corporation, for example, has embarked on a program to close underperforming stores and reduce its head count in hopes of becoming more competitive with Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
 That kind of cost-cutting -- as well as consolidation -- will continue, although its consequences are not necessarily rosy. Only four companies control the warehouse club business now, but none of them are faring particularly well. Consumers are playing them off against each other, and price is still the merchant's weapon of choice. STEPHANIE STROM

HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Most Markets Take Holiday, but 2 Fall

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
On a day when many exchanges worldwide were closed, German stocks fell sharply yesterday and the Mexican market also closed lower.
 While some exchanges were open in Asia, Europe and Latin America, all banks and financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday for the New Year holiday. 
Stocks fell in Frankfurt, undoing a rally on Friday, and German bonds continued a decline that had pushed their yields to a three-month high.
German stocks were lower across many industries, with the heaviest losses in chemicals and financial services. The DAX index of 30 leading stocks fell 1.29 percent, or 27.13 points, to close at 2,079.45.
 Commenting on the drop in German bond prices, Rainhard Vennekold, a trader at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, said, "We're watching the bond future go down step by step."
 Elsewhere, stocks rose in the Netherlands and Spain, but were slightly lower in Italy. The EOE index in Amsterdam closed up 2.72 points, at 417.19. In Madrid, the Ibex index of 35 leading issues gained 4.56 points, to close at 3,092.24. In Milan, the all-share index closed 39 points lower at 10,152.
 Markets were closed in London, Paris and in Switzerland.
 Swedish stocks rose almost 1 percent as optimism over strong corporate earnings offset concerns about a budget to be announced on Jan. 10. "People feel they have fresh money and the whole year to trade on," said Mats Ericsson, a trader at Merchant Fondkommission. "We are seeing some new-year optimism."
 In Hong Kong, stocks were trading sharply lower today after yesterday's holiday. In early afternoon trading, the Hang Seng index was down 252.79 points, or 3.09 percent, to 7,938.25. Japanese markets will be closed until tomorrow.
 Mexico was the only market open in North America yesterday. Stocks closed slightly lower there as investors awaited a speech by President Ernest Zedillo Ponce de Leon outlining Mexico's response to its recent peso crisis. The Bolsa index of 37 stocks closed down 21.42 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 2,354.24 in very light trading.
 In currency dealings in Mexico, the peso rose against the dollar as investors bet that the President's emergency economic plan would calm the financial markets.
 It rebounded after falling nearly 5 percent, to 5.40 pesos to the dollar, in morning trading, and closed in Mexico City at 4.925, compared with 5.075 to the dollar on Friday.
 "There is a little bit more confidence," said Jesus Mendez, a foreign-exchange trader at Banpais S.A.
 In other Latin American equity trading yesterday, Brazilian stocks drifted lower. The Bovespa index of the Sao Paulo stock exchange fell 348 points, to 43,191.

HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTING: Market Place;
Risk Abroad May Keep U.S. Investors Close to Home

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
STOCK market investors didn't make much money last year though corporate profits were stunningly high. The good news of profits being well above forecasts was offset by the fact that the Federal Reserve decided to push up interest rates -- and to keep doing so.
 As 1995 begins, there is general confidence that the economy will remain strong at least for this year, although talk of a 1996 recession has emerged. Corporate profits are generally viewed much more favorably than they were a year ago. There is hope that the dollar has bottomed and that bonds will not fall much more. 
And, perhaps, the American market will benefit from the realization that going abroad can be risky, propelling more Americans to keep their money at home. The rush to stock markets in developing countries -- so profitable earlier in the 1990's -- produced some big disappointments. "If 1993 was the year of emerging markets, 1995 may be the year of emerging companies," said Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairman of Goldman, Sach's investment policy committee, who thinks this will be a good year for smaller companies, which as a group trailed big companies last year.
 Stock analysts, whether by nature or because they are paid by firms whose business is selling stocks, are generally an optimistic bunch. And so, year after year, they begin January with rosy forecasts for profits and then spend much of the year cutting their estimates as reality intrudes. But that didn't happen in 1994. For the first time since 1988, many more profit forecasts were raised during the year than were cut.
 Why? Because the economy was 1994's first big surprise. After years of recession and slow growth, few foresaw just how vibrant the economy would be. The best stocks to be in were ones that benefited directly from a stronger economy -- commodity producers and technology companies, for example -- and that were not severely affected by higher interest rates. Utilities and home builders were not industries to own last year, but they may have been beaten down enough to be worth checking out now.
 A year ago, most stocks looked expensive by traditional valuation measures. Now, with the broad averages about where they were a year ago but both dividends and profits higher, they look more reasonable, although still not cheap. A gain of 10 percent or so in corporate profits is expected this year, but that could prove to be optimistic if the economy begins to slow.
 Among those to react to the strong economy was the Federal Reserve, which raised interest rates six times during the year, beginning on Feb. 4. As 1994 began, it was conventional wisdom that the Fed would act sometime in the year, but few had actually invested as if they believed it. The biggest investing story of the year was the disasters stemming from leveraged bets -- some using derivatives -- on lower interest rates.
 A lot of the gambling was done by companies that insisted they were only hedging. Perhaps the most amazing disclosure was Procter & Gamble's admission that it had entered into a contract that could force it to pay annual interest rates of more than 40 percent if market interest rates rose a few percentage points. P.& G. sued Bankers Trust, saying it was suckered into a bad deal, and got a new corporate treasurer.
 It was the last of the Fed's 1994 rate increases, on Nov. 15, that now looks most interesting. For one thing, as Ed Yardeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence notes, it was the first time the Fed ever pushed up
short-term rates by three-quarters of a percentage point at a time when there was no immediate and obvious inflation crisis. That caught Wall Street's attention, and long-term bonds have actually risen a bit in price since then.
 As the year ended, rates on Treasuries from 2 to 30 years were not far apart, a drastic change from the last few years. The conventional wisdom now is that the Fed will tighten one or two more times this year, pushing short-term rates almost as high as long-term rates, but will then stop. While it is not clear whether the public believes them, a lot of pros are talking about how attractive bond yields are. Money continues to flow out of bond mutual funds, as a new generation of investors learns that it is quite possible to lose money in bonds.
 It was not only profits that kept the stock market from falling. A lot of money came in from mutual fund investors, although their enthusiasm seemed to wane a bit in the last couple of months of 1994. There is a concern in the fund industry that when investors focus on their annual returns this year, they will discover they did not make any money and -- amazingly enough -- take money out. As a group, stock funds have not seen a month when investors took money out in more than four years.
 For a good part of 1994, the search was on for evidence of inflation. It was there in some industrial commodities, notably copper. But gold -- the eternal inflation hedge -- did nothing. And some farm commodities that leapt in 1993 fell back in 1994, with corn down almost 25 percent. Crude oil made a nice rally from depressed prices, but natural gas sank.
 Late in the year, action in the stock market made it look like recession, not inflation, might soon be the most feared threat, and economically sensitive stocks began to slip. Should the yield curve invert later this year -- that is, should short-term rates be higher than long-term rates -- the recession talk will intensify.
 For an investor who simply bought and held a big index like the Standard & Poor's 500, which was down a bit in price but slightly profitable when dividends were counted, the year as a whole was hardly an eye-opener.
 Maybe that is just as well, for it is getting more expensive just to get up in the morning. On the commodity markets, coffee was up 136 percent in 1994. And sugar leapt 41 percent.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY;
Patchy Fog Hovers Over the Northeast

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Across America, the economy of the 1990's is shaping up as the mirror image of the 1980's.
 A decade ago, California and the East Coast were booming; today, they lag behind the rest of the country. The Midwest, then known as the Rust Belt, buckled. Now an industrial revival is restoring much of the original finish to the region. 
Through much of the 1980's, blue-collar workers suffered as manufacturing underwent a painful restructuring to meet tougher world competition. In the 1990's, white-collar employees were lashed by a similar make-over of office-centered services.
 Remember the cold war? The nation's huge military buildup of the 1980's is now being matched by an equally rapid shrinkage of the military industry.
 The computer hardware surge of the last decade, symbolized by I.B.M. and Apple Computer Inc., has been supplanted by the software and networking revolution led by the Microsoft Corporation and Novell Inc.
 Wall Street remains on a roller coaster. Financial services slumped after the stock market crash in 1987. After a revival of the industry in the early 1990's, new traumas were created in 1994 by rising interest rates, the collapse of the bond market, the comeuppance of the hedge funds and the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.
 And through the decades, people and jobs continued to be drawn to suburbia and to regions, like the South and the Rocky Mountain states, with a reputation for livable comfort.
 Having finally shaken off a severe recession, the Northeastern states are making a gradual economic comeback. But the incipient recovery is uneven and none of the states are back to their peak employment levels of the late 1980's. While Massachusetts, the strongest, is experiencing fairly robust job growth, in neighboring Connecticut there is almost none at all.
 Over all, the eight Northeastern states -- Massachusetts, New York, Connecticut, New Jersey, Vermont, New Hampshire, Maine and Rhode Island -- have just enjoyed their best year since 1988, immediately before the region plunged into a recession. The hard times did not really begin to lift until 1993.
 "The Northeast as a whole is no longer holding back the national economy," said Sara Johnson, a regional economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting and data gathering concern in Lexington, Mass.
 The mix of industries in each state seems to govern its prosperity. The Boston area, the heart of the Massachusetts economy, is a center for computer software companies, and they are booming. Financial service companies in Boston, particularly mutual fund companies, have been expanding and hiring all year. And construction is strong, especially the rebuilding of Interstate 93 through Boston, a federally financed multibillion-dollar project.
 New Hampshire was hit early in the decade by the collapse of several major banks, but now the banking industry is lending again. Construction is also making a comeback in the state.
 New York benefited from robust Wall Street hiring through most of 1994, but that started to falter by midsummer. Upstate, expanding paper and petrochemical companies helped various cities. But layoffs at Xerox, Eastman Kodak, Grumman and several other major corporations upstate and on Long Island have offset some of the gains.
 New Jersey also enjoyed greater prosperity, some of it from the transfer of back office operations by financial institutions away from Manhattan.
 The weak Canadian dollar meant fewer Canadian tourists in northern Vermont, dampening economic growth in that state. Connecticut, Rhode Island and Maine also lagged behind, but mostly because of cutbacks in military spending, particularly warship construction in all three states, and aerospace cutbacks in Connecticut, where Allied Signal and United Technologies are major military contractors. LOUIS UCHITELLE

HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTING: A Wild Ride for Emerging Markets;
Pacific Markets Wait for Dawn

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The major markets in Europe generally did not do much last year, but there was plenty of action out on the volatile new frontiers of emerging markets, enriching some investors and impoverishing others.
 In Brazil, the Bovespa equity index finished the year up by well over half in dollar terms, and other markets in Peru and Chile were not far behind. But the losers were almost as conspicuous as the winners. The new stock markets in China's burgeoning cities of Shanghai and Shenzhen ended 1994 down by more than a third. The most embarrassing performance was turned in by Turkey's stock market, whose value was cut 49 percent over the year. The Turkish market was a big winner in 1993. 
In Europe, stock markets moved circumspectly in response to elections at home and skittishly in anticipation of rising interest rates in the United States. The weaker dollar against major currencies from Frankfurt to Tokyo made European and Japanese exports more expensive and left some industry stocks overpriced for foreigners.
 Swings in exchange rates also skewered market returns for foreign investors. Mexico's Bolsa ended the year off by nearly 41 percent, dragged down by the peso's devaluation. But the Nikkei index in Japan finished up 27 percent after the stronger Japanese yen moved into double digits against the dollar.
 Emerging markets promise the most exciting opportunities again in 1995, perhaps too exciting for the faint of heart.
 Everyone is talking about the dawning of the Pacific century, but this has not been the year of Pacific stock markets.
 After a string of successes, several stock markets in East Asia slumped in 1994 or saw their growth rates cut sharply. They fell victim to economic slowdowns, political uncertainty and, in some instances, economic bottlenecks that are threatening to slow growth in this otherwise dynamic region.
 Analysts say 1995 may bring more of the same. Investment experts are not losing hope in East Asia but they are tending to hedge their bets.
 In perhaps the most important sign of this attitude shift, some analysts are rediscovering an Asian market that had been given short shrift: Japan. A consensus is growing that Japan may be set for a sustained rebound as corporate profits take off.
 Tom Hill, an analyst at S. G. Warburg Securities (Japan), said that if Japan's nascent economic recovery remained on track, the earnings per share of companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange would soar 20 percent in the fiscal year ending March 31 and 55 percent in the following year.
 Mike Allen, a strategist here with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities, said his firm had shifted its focus slightly from the emerging markets of Southeast Asia toward Japan. The firm's model global portfolio has increased its holdings in Japan to 18 percent of the total from 14 percent.
 Part of the reason for the slight waning of interest in other Asian markets is the uncertain economic climate in the United States, Mr. Allen said. Any American slowdown could hit the export-dependent economies of Asia. But Japan is at the beginning of a recovery that appears likely to hold, he said.
 Mr. Allen said his firm still favored Taiwan and Indonesia but was less optimistic about Hong Kong, Singapore and Thailand.
Kathy Matsui of Goldman, Sachs said her firm was somewhat more optimistic about East Asia.
 "Just about everything depends on whether the U.S. can create a soft landing," she said. "It could be very rocky in the short term as the Asian markets try to get a grip on what is happening." JAMES STERNGOLD

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY;
A Trim Heartland Flexes Its Muscles

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Across America, the economy of the 1990's is shaping up as the mirror image of the 1980's.
 A decade ago, California and the East Coast were booming; today, they lag behind the rest of the country. The Midwest, then known as the Rust Belt, buckled. Now an industrial revival is restoring much of the original finish to the region. 
Through much of the 1980's, blue-collar workers suffered as manufacturing underwent a painful restructuring to meet tougher world competition. In the 1990's, white-collar employees were lashed by a similar make-over of office-centered services.
 Remember the cold war? The nation's huge military buildup of the 1980's is now being matched by an equally rapid shrinkage of the military industry.
 The computer hardware surge of the last decade, symbolized by I.B.M. and Apple Computer Inc., has been supplanted by the software and networking revolution led by the Microsoft Corporation and Novell Inc.
 Wall Street remains on a roller coaster. Financial services slumped after the stock market crash in 1987. After a revival of the industry in the early 1990's, new traumas were created in 1994 by rising interest rates, the collapse of the bond market, the comeuppance of the hedge funds and the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.
 And through the decades, people and jobs continued to be drawn to suburbia and to regions, like the South and the Rocky Mountain states, with a reputation for livable comfort.
 After a year that exceeded most expectations, manufacturers, retailers and farmers in the Middle West are looking forward to another strong performance in 1995.
 Orders from auto makers, appliance companies and manufacturers of heavy trucks, rail equipment and construction machinery for components and equipment have factories humming -- and hiring -- from Pennsylvania to the Rockies. And the new jobs are expected to add enough to consumer spending power to protect regional retailers from sales declines despite rising interest rates.
 The manufacturers are reaping the benefits of their 1980's streamlining and of growing export markets. Caterpillar Inc., the strike-ridden Peoria, Ill., manufacturer of heavy construction machinery, expects record earnings this year regardless of how its labor woes play out.
 At the Inland Steel Company, which returned to profitability in 1994 after four years of losses, marketers are reveling in the challenges of allocating production among eager customers.
 A few manufacturers are constructing new factories at home, including Motorola Inc., which is building a $100 million cellular phone factory at Harvard, Ill., and the Whirlpool Corporation, which is spending at least as much on a new appliance factory near Tulsa, Okla.
 Many others, though, are counting on continuing profits from the current economic boom to finance expansion into faster-growing foreign markets, especially Asia and Latin America.
 Record harvests last year led the Agriculture Department to force farmers in its subsidy programs to take 7.5 percent of their corn land out of production this year. But agricultural experts say good weather could easily result in more big harvests because farmers will take their least productive land out of crops while continuing to upgrade equipment and seed quality.
 Net profits could decline, though, because the cost of fertilizer and other supplies is climbing.
 One bleak spot for many farmers is the price of pork, which has fallen below the cost of production. Agricultural economists say that many smaller producers may be driven out of business this year unless prices rebound sharply. BARNABY J. FEDER

HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTING;
A Market Guru Whose Advice Worked in Bad Times

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA

 BODY:
A standout performer among investment newsletter writers last year was a stock market bear whose most recent gains came thanks to a frothy market.
 But, in a business where gurus run hot then cold, perhaps more noteworthy is that this bear has managed to do well in markets good and bad. 
He is Norman Fosback, the editor of eight publications including New Issues, which gives opinions on the merits of soon-to-be-public companies. New Issues turned up among the winners not just for 1994, but for a period of more than seven years. Other Fosback publications have also done well over the long haul, suggesting that his good performance might be more than a case of being in the right place at the right time.
 An investor who diligently followed the advice of New Issues since August 1987 would have had a 132.8 percent portfolio gain, according to Mark Hulbert, whose Alexandria, Va., company ranks the performance of investment newsletter writers. That compares with a 72.8 percent total return for the Wilshire 5000 index, a broad stock gauge.
 For 1994 through November, Mr. Fosback's followers had a paper gain of 5.6 percent, while the Wilshire index dropped 1.4 percent.
 Only 14 of 72 newsletters beat the index both last year and over the longer period, according to Mr. Hulbert. (August 1987 was used as a starting date for a long-term track record because it includes the stock market crash later that year that devastated so many prognosticators.) Among the newsletters with winning performances in both periods, Mr. Fosback ranked No. 1.
 A proud winner? Not exactly. "I'd love to take the opportunity to criticize Mark's system when I come out on top," he says. "I have always disagreed with Hulbert's methodology, and I've particularly disagreed with him with regard to the way he rates the New Issues newsletter."
 So much for gratitude.
 Mr. Fosback isn't the only newsletter editor who takes issue with Mr. Hulbert's rankings, but he is one of the only long-term gainers willing to bite the hand that feeds him.
 When Mr. Hulbert began setting up computer models to follow the advice of newsletter writers in 1980, some of the worst performers declared all-out war, some bringing lawsuits. They did not like how Mr. Hulbert applied some of their investment advice. Among the practices they found irksome was Mr. Hulbert's using stock prices on the day a newsletter arrived in the mail -- as opposed to the date of publication.
 Still, some of the biggest grumblers have been swift to trumpet in their advertising the short periods when they have done well in the Hulbert rankings, evidently pleased with the system when it favors them.
 Mr. Fosback, though, continues to assail Mr. Hulbert, and to do well in the rankings. Although the lofty performance of New Issues could fizzle fast whenever the current boom in fresh stock offerings ends, Mr. Fosback's other publications from his Institute for Econometric Research in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have done well, too.
 The Insiders, which recommends stocks based on the buying and selling by corporate officers at public companies, made the list of letters that beat the Wilshire 5000 since August 1987. Its recommendations gained 6.9 percent in the 11 months that ended Nov. 30, popping up on the list of winners among the 162 letters tracked in 1994 by Mr. Hulbert. The market picks of two other Fosback publications, Market Logic and Mutual Fund Forecaster, each gained 1.4 percent.
 In all, 54 newsletters beat the Wilshire index this year, led by The Timing Device, up 45.8 percent. For the seven-year period, 20 letters beat the Wilshire, led by OTC Insight, up 258.2 percent.
 Mr. Fosback expressed surprise that New Issues was the big winner when both periods were combined "because the deck is stacked against us." He complained that Mr. Hulbert did not give him credit for buying a new issue that went public, say, at $10 a share, if the stock began trading in the open market at a premium, say, $15 a share. "If we tell readers don't pay a premium on the initial public offering, Mark assumes we never bought it," Mr. Fosback said.
 Mr. Hulbert defends the practice, noting that real people trading in real markets simply cannot get the hot issues that immediately jump in price. "For me to give him credit at the initial public offering price is to give him too much benefit," Mr. Hulbert says.
 Investors eager to follow the advice of Mr. Fosback should select stocks cautiously -- sticking to his overall recommendation that less than half of investable assets be allocated to stocks. They might also take cues from the actions of corporate insiders. For example, executives at real estate, savings and loan, and utility companies have been big buyers of their own stocks lately, he said.
 Although Mr. Fosback does not recommend that investors sell short -- bet on falling prices by selling borrowed shares in the hope that they can be bought back cheaper -- he does note that executives of railroad and computer companies have been selling, suggesting that those are stocks to avoid.
 Mr. Fosback, who told investors in May 1992 to scale back their stock allocation to 50 percent of assets, cut that recommendation further to 40 percent in August.
 While some analysts are becoming less skittish about stocks as price-to-earnings ratios decline, Mr. Fosback sticks to his bearish stance. "Earnings are subject to the vagaries of accounting," he says, "so they just haven't been that reliable."
 He is most concerned that stock dividend yields are at relatively low levels -- just below 3 percent. "Dividends represent cold hard cash being paid out to stockholders by companies, so yields have historically been a consistent and sound basis for judging the financial health of companies," he said.
 And companies just aren't coughing up enough money right now to justify the high prices of their stocks, Mr. Fosback added.

HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTING;
For Funds in '94, There Was No Place to Hide

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
FOR the millions of Americans who invest in mutual funds, 1994 feels like the punchline of a not-very-funny joke.
 How bad was it? 
It was so bad that money market funds -- one step away from cash in the mattress -- proved to be the best class of investments.
 It was so bad that stock funds had a worse year than they did in 1987, when the market crashed.
 It was so bad that some supposedly safe fixed-income funds racked up double-digit losses, and long-term bonds turned in their worst performance of this century.
 It was so bad that with few exceptions, international investing just offered Americans new ways to say, "I lost money."
 So 1995 has got to be better, right?
 Well, maybe.
 Back-to-back bad years are not unknown in the stock market (1973 and 1974), and are even more common in bonds (where returns were negative every year from 1977 through 1980), according to data from Ibbotson Associates, a Chicago research firm.
 Few investment experts are expecting a banner year in 1995 -- and some actually expect the next 12 months to be even more awful than the last. In general, Wall Street's crystal balls seem even cloudier than usual.
 "It's a frustrating time -- you hear that from a lot of people," said Bettina Doulton, who runs Fidelity Advisor Equity Income and is one of the few money managers to navigate 1994's treacherous markets and end up with a gain. "Investors are trying to balance what they see in the economy, interest rates, and money flows, which is a big issue as we go into the year."
 To some extent, fund investors may hold the future in their own hands. The billions of dollars they poured into stock funds last year was one of the few bright spots, and may have been responsible for equities' relative strength as interest rates soared. True, domestic stock funds fell an average 1.6 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., but that loss pales in comparison to bond funds' negative 3.5 percent return. And those mediocre averages mask some really big hits: American Heritage, an aggressive stock fund, plunged 35 percent, and Piper Jaffray Institutional Government Income lost 28.5 percent because of heavy holdings of very volatile securities derived from mortgages.
 But the rout in bonds might not have been quite so bad if investors had not fled those funds, forcing managers to sell into a depressed market, which pushed prices down further. The downward spiral was especially pronounced in the thinly traded market for municipal bonds. Municipal funds were hit with a record wave of selling in November -- even before Orange County, Calif., became the biggest municipal bankruptcy in American history. Tax-exempt funds lost 5.8 percent last year; California and New York funds fared even worse.
 And the end of the carnage may not be in sight. "I'm still pretty negative, though 1995 won't be like 1994," said Laurie Kirby, who manages municipal bond funds for 20th Century Investors, which is better known for growth-stock investing but sponsors one of the year's top-performing tax-exempt bond funds.
 If, as she expects, munis rally a little this month, she plans to sell bonds and buy them back after the Federal Reserve raises interest rates again. "I still believe, even if the market doesn't, that long-term rates are going to 8.25 percent," she said, from their current rate of nearly 7.9 percent.
 A slightly more optimistic view comes from Hotchkis and Wiley, whose Low Duration fund's 5.2 percent return was the best among United States bond funds in 1994. "It's definitely not an environment where you jump in with all hands and legs," said Tad Rivelle, one of the fund's managers. "But given where rates are, you could lock in 7.5 percent for two years, 7.75 percent for five years."
 And that, he noted, is not a bad return, if you believe that the Fed will succeed in slowing the economy and in keeping inflation down. Mr. Rivelle and his partner, Laird Landmann, suspect that the Fed may do its work too well and that a recession may be on the horizon.
 Surprisingly strong earnings spurred one stock market sector: technology. Funds that specialize in high-tech zoomed 12.3 percent, the year's only double-digit gain.
 Over the long haul, which in technology investing is a year or two, high-tech funds ought to do well, even if the American economy slows, said Chris Toub, a portfolio manager for Alliance Capital Management, which runs a top technology fund. "Technology is a big export sector, and we are looking for Europe and the Far East to grow more next year than in '94," he said. But first, Mr. Toub said, he expects tech stocks to tumble, as investors take some of profits.
 Until late last month, another bright spot was international funds, which benefited from a rally in Japan and the decline of the dollar. Then Mexico devalued the peso, and many funds plunged. Among stock funds hit the hardest, with a loss of 23.7 percent for the year, was TCW/DW Latin American Growth, which is sold by Dean Witter and managed by Trust Company of the West. But Alliance North American Government fund, which buys debt, fared even worse, dropping more than 30 percent.
 That decline may signal an opportunity for investors like Helen Young Hayes, who manages international portfolios for Janus Capital. "Emerging markets generally I'm still very bullish on, as soon as short-term interest rates in the U.S. peak," she said. But individuals often have trouble taking such a contrarian tack: "They tend to buy at the top and sell at the bottom," she added.
 Which leads to the really big question of 1995: Will Americans continue to pile into stock funds? The fund industry says yes, arguing that the money is coming from people saving for far-off goals. But the flow of money did slow sharply in November, and dwindled to almost nothing last month, according to AMG Data Services, a firm that tracks funds in Arcata, Calif.
 Truth is, many investors pay attention only to year-end results. And those people will not much like what they see, even if their losses are relatively small. Particularly if they can make more than 5 percent a year without taking any risk, just by opting for a money market fund or bank certificate of deposit.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY;
Far From the Courtrooms, Tobacco's Rituals Endure

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
What is the 1995 outlook for tobacco? Fraught and turbulent, but not inevitably disastrous. If the industry was under a microscope in Washington last year, it is likely to be caught by television lights in 1995.
 For the first time, a class-action suit of smokers who say they are addicted and diseased is going ahead, in a Florida state court. So is a separate Florida class-action suit involving flight attendants who say they are ill from second-hand smoke. 
Furthermore, 60 powerhouse personal-injury law firms have banded together to concentrate on a class-action suit against the five largest American tobacco companies. It could represent all smokers, draw upon last spring's Congressional testimony contending that a cigarette company sought to addict smokers by deliberately manipulating the level of nicotine in cigarettes.
 Government regulatory action that could classify tobacco as an addictive drug, or ban it from all public spaces in the United States, is a possibility as well. But beyond the legal and legislative concerns, there is the person-to-person combat in the nation's offices, restaurants and public spaces, where smokers feel ever more like a persecuted minority.
 Indeed, only 25 percent of Americans smoke, the lowest level since the Government began taking surveys.
 Yet the five big cigarette makers remain feisty, confident and supremely unrepentant. After all, they are likely to face less-strident criticism in the new Republican Congress. And they are secure in the knowledge that in more than four decades of legal action, the tobacco makers have never paid monetary penalties. In contrast to previous successful class-action cases, as when the insurance companies pressured the asbestos makers to settle, tobacco companies have no insurance. And they have looked America straight in the eye and vowed never to settle.
 Despite the nervousness of investors about tobacco's downside potential, many analysts expect no basic alteration in the fundamental nature of the industry in 1995. This will reassure millions of Americans whose livelihood is dependent upon a crop that was first grown commercially in the United States in 1612 at a farm in Virginia.
 Still a mainstay of the economies of North Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee, Virginia, South Carolina and Georgia, tobacco products generate $48 billion a year in revenue from the 1.68 billion pounds of tobacco harvested, produced and domestically distributed annually by 426,000 workers, according to the Tobacco Institute in a statistical report drawn from Agriculture Department data and audited by Price Waterhouse.
 America's seventh-largest cash crop produces 502 billion cigarettes and cigars, and generates excise and sales taxes of $13.3 billion for Federal, state and local governments. American tobacco exports earn an additional $6 billion a year.
 The rich fields are dormant now, marking time until late winter, when the seeds go into earth. This year's rhythms of cultivating, harvesting, curing, auctioning and manufacturing, though abetted by new technology, will be a replay of venerable rituals that have scarcely varied through the centuries.
 The life is as hard, and unpredictable, as it always was. It's just the society that has changed.

HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Derivatives Draw More Scrutiny

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Well, at least the financial system didn't collapse last year and cause worldwide chaos.
 For the beleaguered Wall Street rocket scientists who create and sell the newfangled deals broadly known as derivatives, that is as good as news got in 1994. 
Derivatives are a range of financial agreements with value linked to an underlying market like stock prices or interest rates. What differentiates derivatives from traditional investments like stocks and bonds is that they are custom designed for each user. They are often used to reduce risk -- to protect a company, for example, from a rise in the interest rates on its debt. But they can also be used as a substitute for direct investments to make speculative bets on the performance of a particular market.
 All of the dozens of problems that were revealed last year fit into that speculative category: betting that interest rates would remain stable while taking on a huge risk of losses if they rose.
 Such speculative bets may be fine for hedge funds charged with gambling with rich people's spare fun money, but they are not appropriate for next month's teachers' salaries.
 While the first reports in February of huge losses in derivatives came from sophisticated hedge funds, what followed was a steady stream of announcements of unusually large losses from investors and institutions, like Orange County, Calif., that were meant to have very conservative investment strategies.
 And so derivatives are far more controversial today than a year ago and subject to even more intense scrutiny from the Government. And, in fact, the fastest growing segment of the derivatives business these days is the consulting firms owned by former derivative traders, who specialize in what they call "financial forensics." They defuse derivative bets before they go bad, clean up the mess after a bad bet and try help companies avoid trouble in the future.
 For the Government, and the industry, there are two key issues: how the derivatives were sold and how they were bought.
 The issue that has gotten the most attention has been sales practices; questions have been raised about whether dealers properly explained the terms and risks of derivatives to their clients.
 In the case of Gibson Greetings Inc., the Government found that the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, one of the leading derivatives dealers, actually committed fraud by hiding losses on derivatives from Gibson for a period of two years. Gibson, a greeting card company in Cincinnati, lost $20 million.
 Although Bankers Trust does not admit guilt, it paid a fine to the Government of $10 million and settled with the company, covering $14 million of its losses.
 The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which imposed sanctions on Bankers Trust, is trying to promulgate a code of conduct for derivatives dealers, which would require specific disclosures to customers of risk and the current value of derivatives.
 More attention will also be paid to whether the customers who buy derivatives have adequate controls in place to make sure they are not getting in over their heads. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is investigating whether certain investors that had been allowed to buy derivatives, such as mutual funds and municipalities, should be under more restrictions.
 And the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Gibson and some of the other companies that suffered derivatives losses adequately disclosed their positions to their investors.
 This scrutiny is a mixed blessing for Wall Street. New regulations and possible new laws may increase the cost of doing business and may limit the sales to certain types of customers.
 It certainly does not help the market, moreover, when the Government accuses a prominent derivatives dealer of fraud and many other customers claim losses.
 "The dealers are beleaguered," said Paul Spraos, editor of Swaps Monitor, a trade newsletter in New York.
 Still, many dealers say they think that the attention paid to derivatives may be beneficial in the long run.
 "Senior management for the first time had to look in detail at the issues raised," said Peter Hancock, the head of derivatives at J.P. Morgan & Company. "Once they get educated, the vast majority find that they are very satisfied they can use derivatives to avoid costs and reduce risk."
 For all the bad publicity, the derivatives business has not suffered as much as other parts of Wall Street. Profits from derivatives dealings are down about 15 percent compared to the boom year of 1993, Mr. Spraos estimates. Profits on Wall Street were down 80 percent during the first nine months of the year.
 And volume in the market continues to grow. Over all, the face value of all the derivatives contracts outstanding, Mr. Spraos said, increased to $12.3 trillion from $8.2 trillion at the end of 1993.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1995: THE ECONOMY;
A Quieter Hum In the Southwest

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Across America, the economy of the 1990's is shaping up as the mirror image of the 1980's.
 A decade ago, California and the East Coast were booming; today, they lag behind the rest of the country. The Midwest, then known as the Rust Belt, buckled. Now an industrial revival is restoring much of the original finish to the region. 
Through much of the 1980's, blue-collar workers suffered as manufacturing underwent a painful restructuring to meet tougher world competition. In the 1990's, white-collar employees were lashed by a similar make-over of office-centered services.
 Remember the cold war? The nation's huge military buildup of the 1980's is now being matched by an equally rapid shrinkage of the military industry.
 The computer hardware surge of the last decade, symbolized by I.B.M. and Apple Computer Inc., has been supplanted by the software and networking revolution led by the Microsoft Corporation and Novell Inc.
 Wall Street remains on a roller coaster. Financial services slumped after the stock market crash in 1987. After a revival of the industry in the early 1990's, new traumas were created in 1994 by rising interest rates, the collapse of the bond market, the comeuppance of the hedge funds and the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.
 And through the decades, people and jobs continued to be drawn to suburbia and to regions, like the South and the Rocky Mountain states, with a reputation for livable comfort.
 The Southwest built, manufactured and traded its way to faster growth than the nation as a whole last year. This year, economists expect the region to stay ahead, but in a slower race.
 The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas predicts that employment in Texas, Louisiana and New Mexico will grow by 2.8 percent to 3.4 percent this year, compared with 3.6 percent last year. Higher interest rates and an aging expansion, the bank says, will moderate the Southwest's growth. "A slowing national economy is reflected in the state," said Stephen Brown, the bank's senior economist, regarding Texas.
 The rig count may no longer be the prime guide to the region's outlook, but the petroleum industry could still determine whether the economy runs or just walks. Last year, low prices for oil and natural gas were a drag on the economies of Texas and Oklahoma. Corporate cost-cutting chopped thousands of petroleum industry jobs. In recent months, oil prices have recovered, but natural gas remains inexpensive.
 If the rest of the United States was deaf to Southwestern pleas for industry subsidies or import tariffs, Texans found new friends in Mexico. The nation's exports to Mexico soared after the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect a year ago. Nearly half those exports came from Texas, and nearly 75 percent rolled across on Texas highways.
 But now that the peso has been sharply devalued, making American goods more expensive in Mexico and raising doubts about the Mexican economic recovery, exports from the Southwest to Mexico could slow.
 Construction also promoted the Southwest's growth last year, as the region's appetite for new homes, warehouses and factories, if not downtown office space, sharpened. In the region as elsewhere, rising interest rates might start causing potential home buyers to think twice.
 Southwestern manufacturing, apart from military sales, is likely to continue expanding more rapidly than in the rest of the nation. Manufacturers still tend to favor a region where their dollars buy more labor and a higher standard of living than they can get in the country's cooler quarters. ALLEN R. MYERSON

HEADLINE: MEXICO'S RESCUE PACKAGE: THE OVERVIEW;
MEXICO'S LEADER GIVES THE NATION A RECOVERY PLAN

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, who had promised Mexicans personal prosperity during his election campaign last year, announced an economic-stabilization plan today that reduces the purchasing power of workers, cuts corporate profit, trims the nation's budget and sells some state-owned resources.
Investors and financial analysts reacted cautiously to Mr. Zedillo's announcement, which had been delayed by unexpectedly strong resistance from labor union leaders. 
 Some analysts said the austerity measures were not strong enough to help Mexico recover from the shock of the peso's 30 percent devaluation and the flight of billions of dollars in foreign investment over the last two weeks. Others said they had hoped the President would address the worries of international investors more directly.
In a 25-minute address carried on national television, Mr. Zedillo, a 43-year-old Yale-educated economist, appealed to the Mexican people, trying to soften the edges of his harsh recovery plan with calls for patriotism and self-sacrifice.
"As President, I am perfectly aware that many of the measures and actions we must carry out are difficult," he said. "Nevertheless, I am also aware that those measures and actions are essential."
Mr. Zedillo's speech did nothing to impress the financial markets in New York or here in Mexico City. The Mexican stock exchange dropped 3.2 percent today to close at 2,278.47, down 75.77 points. In New York, American depository receipts of the bellwether Mexican stock, Telefonos de Mexico, lost 5.8 percent. The dollar rose to 5.275 pesos todayfrom 4.925 pesos on Monday.
"I don't think many people were impressed," said Jonathan Heath, director of Macro Asesoria Economica, a consulting firmhere. "In general, the market wanted more specifics."
Mr. Zedillo did briefly mention the aid offered by Mexico's international trading partners. This includes an $18 billion line of credit, half of it from the United States. Canada agreed to increase its credit line with Mexico to $1.5 billion (Canadian). The Bank for International Settlements in Switzerland, representing several European central banks, is making available a $5 billion credit line, and international commercial banks, including Citibank, are going to syndicate a $3 billion loan.
The Mexican central bank acknowledges that it holds $6.15 billion in international reserves it can use to avert further turmoil in the domestic financial market, buying pesos when the currency falls in value. Whatever funds Mexico uses would have to be repaid, with interest.
The agreement with its international partners prohibits the Mexican Government from using the credit lines to finance its $28 billion current-account deficit, a broad measure of trade, which has resulted from an excess of imports over exports in recent years.
The International Monetary Fund gave prompt approval to the Mexican plan. Stanley Fischer, the fund's acting managing director, said in a statement that the policies outlined today by Mr. Zedillo "show the capacity of authorities to respond promptly and effectively to economic and financial developments."
Mr. Zedillo's plan abandons the narrow trading band Mexico had used to restrict the currency-exchange rate and control inflation. Instead, the value of the peso will be determined by buyers and sellers in currency markets, as it has been since the Government was forced to allow it to float freely on the night of Dec. 21.
To address another big problem, the Government says it is working with investment banks to come up with new bonds that offer longer terms and higher rates. The intention of such bonds is to encourage investors not to pull out any more of the $7 billion in treasury bonds that fall due by the end of March.
Mr. Zedillo's speech was postponed from Monday night after union leaders had maintained their strong objections to the harsh terms of the plan. Today, they dropped their opposition, though not their reservations, and signed the pact.
"It's the workers who once more are bearing the greatest cost," said Elba Esther Gordillo, general secretary of the national teachers' Union.
In September, the unions had signed a somewhat similar agreement with Government and business that allowed a 7 percent wage increase for 1995. That agreement also included income-tax credits for the lowest-paid workers and some productivity bonuses in contracts.
The 7 percent wage package was considered a good deal then because the Government estimated that inflation would be only 4 percent this year. With the loss of purchasing power and rises in prices resulting from the peso's devaluation, Government economists now think inflation might reach 15 percent in 1995, and some private economists say it will exceed 20 percent.
Mexican workers still have not recovered the standard of living they had in 1980, now three devaluations ago. Francisco Hernandez Juarez, general secretary of the union representing telephone workers, a major labor figure, said that he, too, thought it was unfair to ask workers to sacrifice again. But he finally accepted the Government's terms, he said, because he was convinced that it was the only way for Mexico to overcome its current crisis.
The pact signed by labor and business groups today retains the 7 percent wage increase. In exchange, the Government pledged to minimize price increases and keep inflation from spiraling.
But the strong price controls that some investors had hoped to see were not included in the plan. Instead, businesses agreed to make "an extraordinary effort to mitigate price increases by reducing profit margins." Prices for imported goods could still increase by as much as 30 percent to compensate for the peso's devaluation, officials said.
The Government agreed to gradual rises of no more than 10 percent in prices for electricity, gasoline and most other goods and services it provides.It also plans to cut in half the trade deficit of $28 billion expected for 1994. Costlier imports and cheaper exports resulting from the devaluation of the peso are expected to help reduce the trade imbalance.
The 1995 federal budget will be reduced by 1.3 percent of the gross domestic product, representing a cut of about 7 percent in Government spending. Officials said they expected to end up with a modest surplus.
But economists in the United States questioned those estimates. "I just don't see how they get that," said James M. Nash, chief Latin American economist for Nomura Research Institute America. Mr. Nash said the budget cut would have to be almost double the Government's figure to achieve such savings and produce a surplus.
Mexico also plans to raise money by selling some of its companies and services to private owners. Investors are likely to be interested in the nation's telecommunications satellites and in plans to accelerate the opening of local and long-distance telephone markets to competition.
There is likely to be far less interest in the Government's plans to sell parts of the creaky national railroad or four seaports that often lose money. Mr. Zedillo did not mention any plans to privatize the Government-owned oil monopoly, Pemex, although it is believed that petrochemical plants and natural-gas pipelines offered for sale once before, without success, will be put on sale again.
"I was expecting something more," said Juan-Carlos Garcia, an analyst at Salomon Brothers in New York, alluding to the privatizations.
Mr. Zedillo accepted responsibility for the sacrifices that he asked every Mexican to make.
"Before any concern for the presidential image or the renown of public officials, my commitment is to act responsibly, without evading or trying to conceal reality," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Listening to the announcement of Mexico's economic plan were Luis German Carcoba Garcia, left, president of the Business Coordinating Council, and Fidel Velazquez, head of the labor federation. (Associated Press) (pg. D4)
 
Chart: "The Austerity Measures"
 Mexico's effort to guide an overvalued currency gently downward collapsed in December from the combined weight of a swelling trade deficit and a stampede of foreign investors pulling their money out of Mexican stocks and bonds. After two weeks of intense negotiations with business leaders, trade unions and creditors, the Zedillo Government has put together a package of steps to see the country through the crisis. The chart outlines this package. (pg. D4) (Source: Mexican Government)

HEADLINE: Brazil's Horizons Widening With New Common Market

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Brazil, South America's industrial giant, has just won more legroom with the start of the Southern Common Market, a customs union that expands by 50 percent the duty-free area open to Brazilian manufacturers.
On New Year's Day, tariffs were ended on 95 percent of goods traded among Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. At the same time, the four neighbors adopted common tariffs -- averaging 12 percent -- for goods imported from outside their borders. 
 "Brazil has just discovered its Canada," a Brazilian ambassador exulted. "Argentina is Brazil's natural extension south, in the same way that Canada is the United States' natural extension north."
Brazilian exporters and investors have been quick to follow the diplomats. In the four years since the Southern Common Market treaty was signed and a gradual reduction in tariffs began, regional trade has more than tripled, reaching $12 billion in 1994.
Once a hostile rival of Argentina, Brazil has become its largest trading partner, displacing the United States; Argentina is now the leading recipient of Brazilian foreign investment.
"Three years ago, it was almost unimaginable that this could happen," Brazil's new President, Fernando Enrique Cardozo, said here Monday. "Yet, today, we are in a full customs union."
With flights now shuttling hourly between Buenos Aires and Sao Paulo, manufacturers calculate their economies of scale according to the size of the new, expanded market -- 190 million people and $800 billion in economic activity. Largely forgotten is the skeptical talk that once lampooned the Southern Common Market as "a club of the poor."
"There are now over 300 joint business ventures between Brazil and Argentina," said Jose Artur Denot Medeiros, Brazil's negotiator for the common market, known in Portuguese as Mercosul, a contraction for Southern Common Market. "Five years ago, there were only 5 or 10 Brazilian companies in Buenos Aires."
Brazil's South American trade and investment drive seems destined to accelerate after the inauguration on Sunday of Mr. Cardozo, a former Foreign Minister and the first Brazilian President in modern times to speak Spanish.
"It will make South America one of the most dynamic, growing areas of the world," Mr. Medeiros said of an expanding network of free-trade agreements that is to be called the South American Free Trade Area. Last month in Miami, hemispheric leaders agreed to negotiate during the next decade the formation of a free-trade area that would stretch from Alaska to Argentina.
As President-elect, Mr. Cardozo visited the capitals of Brazil's three Mercosul partners in November. On Monday, his first day on the job, he was host at a meeting of the four Presidents of the southern market countries along with the Presidents of Chile and Bolivia, two neighbors that have promised to sign free-trade treaties with the Southern Common Market by June.
"Let's forget a little about the 19th century and start looking at the 21st century," Bolivia's President, Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, said, referring to national barriers that split South America after independence from Spain and Portugal in the early 1800's. "There is a lot of enthusiasm for moving toward a united region, not separated by borders."
By the end of this year, free-trade treaties are to link the southern market with the four remaining Spanish-speaking nations of the continent -- Peru, Ecuador, Colombia and Venezuela.
"Peru's economy is already getting ready to join Mercosul in two or three years," Peru's President, Alberto K. Fujimori, said after meeting with President Cardozo here on Monday.
Betting on the duty-free zone, Bolivia is promoting a plan to supply natural gas to the region. Under this plan, pipelines are to built over the next five years from Bolivia to Brazil, to Paraguay and to northern Chile. A gas line already links Bolivia and Argentina.
