HEADLINE: Part-Time College Teaching Rises, as Do Worries

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CLAREMONT, Calif., Jan. 2

 BODY:
They call themselves "freeway fliers," the Ph.D. graduates who cannot find full-time faculty teaching jobs and who spend their days commuting back and forth among part-time jobs at various colleges where they have no certainty of employment from one semester to the next.
They are a sign of the times as colleges and universities seek economies by leaving staff jobs vacant, relying on part-time teachers to fill the gaps and save them money on higher salaries and benefits. And they have aroused debate in academia over whether institutions have acted responsibly in turning out so many highly qualified specialists only to leave them stranded. 
 "In one day I drive 100 miles and teach 100 students at three different colleges," said Susan Imbarrato, an English instructor who has been commuting this way for five years. "I feel like this information machine, sort of Teach "R" Us. What are we doing in our cars, all these Ph.D.'s on the freeways, listening to talk radio?"
At the annual convention of the Modern Language Association last week in San Diego, the group's president, Patricia Meyer Spacks, called the growing reliance on part-time college instructors an urgent problem. Their schedules, she said, are "insanely demanding."
David Merkowitz, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, which represents 1,600 colleges and universities, said the use of part-time faculty members had risen sharply in the 1990's after cutbacks in state support for higher education. He said more than half of the colleges had increased their use in 1993 and another one-third last year.
About 40 percent of the college faculty members today are part-timers, twice as many as two decades ago, said Jack H. Schuster, professor of education and public policy at the Claremont Graduate School, who has studied the numbers for the Modern Language Association. Among these part-timers, he said, "the raw numbers of frustrated would-be full-time faculty members has surely expanded considerably in recent years."
The situation, Professor Schuster said, is the result of a delay in the expected widespread retirement of professors hired in the 1960's and the slowness of many institutions in replacing those who do retire.
The retirements are inevitable over the next decade or more, he said, and should coincide with the increase in college enrollments predicted by demographers, creating an active job market. But several experts said that with graduate schools continuing to turn out more specialists, Ms. Imbarrato's generation of scholars could fall through the cracks.
"I walk around and I think, All I want to do is teach," said Ms. Imbarrato, who specializes in early American literature. "It's not like I want to rob a bank. What else can I do with a Ph.D. in English?"
This is how she describes her schedule:
"I remember last year I taught at 8 A.M., drove 30 miles from Claremont to Cal State, taught two hours, had office hours, got back in my car and drove 20 miles to teach a community college class. Then I would get back in the car, eat a candy bar and drink some juice and drive 20 miles back to the campus I was at in the morning. I'd get caffeinated, walk in and teach another two hours."
The exhaustion of driving back and forth while full-time teachers can meet with students, work on committees and produce their own academic work is compounded by a daily diet of humiliation, some part-timers said.
They must accept the early morning and late evening classes, they said, and even these offers often do not come until days before a semester starts. Their colleagues often do not know their names, they added, and their students sometimes treat them with less respect.
"The worst thing is the sense of alienation," said Amanda Donta, a 31-year-old English instructor who has been a part-timer for six years and is now working on a master's degree in classical flute performance.
"I don't even have a phone extension," she said. "All I have is a mailbox, and it changes every term. Once it was a Cheez Whiz box, just a cardboard Cheez Whiz box. That was my home base."
People like Ms. Imbarrato and Ms. Donta sometimes juggle the schedules of different colleges on the quarter and semester systems. For each course they are paid a fee that ranges from about $900 a semester at a community college to as much as $3,000 at a private college. Together, the patchwork of classes they put together may equal the annual $28,000 to $30,000 starting salary for a Ph.D. at a California state college.
By using part-time instructors, several of them said, colleges can avoid providing the benefits they would be entitled to if they had more than a minimum teaching load.
Iris Molotsky, a spokeswoman for the American Association of University professors, agreed. "Administrators say they use part-time faculty because they want greater flexibility," she said. "But the reality is that these people are just hired over and over again. What they really want is not to pay health benefits and life insurance and so on. It's just exploitation."
Professor Schuster said the nationwide proportion of part-time college faculty members, also known as gypsies or nomads, had risen to the current 40 percent from about 33 percent in the mid-1980's and 22 percent in the early 1970's.
By the year 2008, he calculated, nearly half the 595,000 full-time college faculty members in the nation are likely to retire. But he said it appeared clear from current trends that not all would be replaced by full-time teachers.
As college faculty hiring has slowed sharply, the number of people seeking jobs in higher education has risen, said William Zumeta, a professor at the graduate school of public affairs at the University of Washington.
"In the last five years or so the numbers of Ph.D.'s granted in this country has jumped by about 5,000 a year, up from about 33,000, where it was for a long time, to about 38,000," Professor Zumeta said. "More people are seeking fewer jobs."
These job-seekers make up 15 percent to 20 percent of part-time faculty members, said Howard Tuckman, dean of the college of business at Virginia Commonwealth University, who has written books on part-time faculty members.
Dr. Tuckman has dubbed them part-mooners, as opposed to full-mooners, who may have a full-time job in another field, as lawyers or businessmen or journalists, or may be spouses of full-time faculty members or writers who are happy with a part-time teaching job.
Some institutions, like junior colleges, rely more heavily than others on part-time faculty members. At California State University at San Bernardino, Ms. Imbarrato is one of 237 part-timers on a faculty that totals 626. At Pomona College last semester, she was one of just 20 part-timers on a faculty of 180.
Though part-time faculty members may bring high qualifications and enthusiasm to their jobs, an increasing reliance on their work could do long-term damage to academic institutions, said Emory Elliott, the former head of the English department at Princeton University, who now teaches English at the University of California at Riverside.
"A pretty important shift has happened in the last five years that is clearest in California," Professor Elliott said. "The senior ranks of the professoriate are being really emptied by early retirements, and not only are they not being replaced but there is no plan to replace them because people are not working their way up through the system."
A result, he said, is that some departments have no senior faculty members to give them focus or to direct graduate studies.
Some part-time professors settle in for years, like Jean Mather, who said she had "flown the freeways" since 1981 and called her part-time arrangements, which earn her about $25,000 a year, "the perfect job for a mom with a family."
Some, like Deborah Dietrich, who managed to compose an article for publication while she drove on the freeways, do win full-time jobs. She is now an assistant professor of English at California State at Fullerton.
Others, like Julie LaMay Abner, keep driving and hoping.
Ms. Abner, 36, who specializes in Native American literature, has been a freeway flier for three years. She calculated that she traveled 758 miles every five-day week last semester to classes at various institutions, including Boron Men's Prison in Boron, Calif.
"We are not guaranteed any more employment from one semester to the next," she said, "so every semester we have to be dynamic and energetic and productive and not complain.
"But I do have a goal in life. My goal in life -- my ultimate goal -- is to drive somewhere, park my car, teach all day, get in my car and drive home. That's it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As many colleges economize by cutting back on full-time teachers, part-time teachers like Susan Imbarrato, left, at California State University at San Bernardino, fill the gap. Ms. Imbarrato, like many others in her position, must spend hours on the road to get to jobs at different universities. (Marissa Roth for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Girls Don't Want To Have Gym

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J.

 BODY:
WHEN asked to describe how they felt about gym class, nearly all of the 15 teen-age girls wrinkled their noses with disgust.
"When I was little, I used to love it," said Rachael Ludlow, 15, a sophomore at Edison High School. "But most girls don't like to mess up their hair, to get changed or like, you know, be bothered." 
 Sports were no more popular. Neither were workout videotapes, health clubs or long walks. These girls are far from alone.
Indeed, a national increase in inactivity among all age groups seems especially pronounced among teen-age girls and is leading them on a path toward obesity and serious health problems that will linger into adulthood, health and nutrition experts say.
Making matters even more worrisome, surveys also show that teen-age girls are continuing to smoke at high rates and are using drugs as frequently as boys do -- habits that make them less likely to be active.
According to recent research by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, only 25 percent of female high school seniors exercise vigorously on a regular basis, compared with 50 percent of boys the same age. Although there are no figures on girls' exercise habits in the 1980's, the researchers believe that girls are becoming less active. The centers cited a fitness survey that showed that in 1990, only 37 percent of students in grades 10 through 12 exercised vigorously, down from 68 percent in 1984.
While the reasons for the laziness elude many scientists, they blame a combination of factors that can stymie anyone's efforts to slim down, including watching television and eating inexpensive high-fat foods.
Girls are at a particular disadvantage, the experts said, for reasons as varied as a lack of engaging athletic programs to the needs of their working parents, who want them to pitch in more at home, leaving little time for physical recreation.
"Teen-age girls feel they shouldn't sweat," said Dr. William Dietz, director of the Boston Obesity/Nutrition Research Center. "As a country, we have a lot of cause for worry over that, because the propensity for obesity is epidemic, and the consequences for health-care costs could be enormous."
According to recent studies of the exercise patterns of high school students, teen-age girls drop away from sports or exercise activities steadily as they age. "I just don't want to do all that exercise," said Rebecca Alexander, 16, another Edison High School student. "I just feel too lazy."
In a 1990 survey of 11,000 students and in follow-up research done as recently as this year, the Centers for Disease Control found that 35 percent of ninth-grade girls participated in 20 minutes of "vigorous activity" three times a week, compared with 53 percent of their male classmates. The numbers decreased to 25 and 50 percent respectively for the youths once they reached their senior year. Because adolescence is the time that young women begin to get more body fat, these exercise patterns contribute greatly to their battles with unwanted weight gain.
"It was disappointing to see that the pattern of activity dropped over grade levels," said Dr. Gregory Heath, an epidemiologist at the centers. "If indeed we are sowing a sedentary life style, it will likely carry over into adulthood, and what we are going to reap are the effects, like an increase in diabetes, obesity and heart disease."
In discussions with dozens of girls at Edison High School, many of them said that between the pressures of school and the needs of their working parents for help around the house, little time was left at the end of their days for running and jumping.
"When you go home from school at night," said Angela Carrizosa, a 16-year-old freshman, "you have dishes to do, the house to clean and you have homework. There really isn't time for anything else."
She is required to take a gym class for at least one-quarter of the school year, she said, but that is the extent to which she exerts herself.
According to the Centers for Disease Control study, at greatest risk were black girls, who rated lowest on activity scales, and children who lived in poor neighborhoods. While there were some patterns among girls of the same race or ethnic group, researchers said that one of the most significant correlations with exercise was economic class.
"In the private school in the Chicago area, we found that the upper-middle-class girls were extremely competitive," said Wynn Updyke, the assistant dean for academic affairs and research in the School of Health, Physical Education and Recreation at Indiana University in Bloomington, which conducted a study on the recreational habits of 3,000 children in five cities.
"In the inner city, we saw that girls were not competitive at all," Mr. Updyke said. "We observed that if one girl did poorly in physical testing, the rest of the group would do poorly, too, just to not make her feel bad." A lack of resources and safe parks and little access to things like private tennis lessons and nice swimming pools contributed to the disparity, he said.
Mr. Updyke also noted that Hispanic girls in Chicago, often from new immigrant groups, tended to be far less active than Hispanic girls in California, because children of newer immigrants were expected to stay home and care for younger children, rather than play sports.
Girls are not only less active than boys, but are also less likely to quit smoking. "We would have expected to see a continuing decline as we do with adults," said Dr. Michael Eriksen, the director of the office on smoking and health at the Centers for Disease Control. "But we've virtually stopped making progress to get teens to stop. In 1993, the office found that more than 18 percent of female high school seniors smoked every day, about the same number as in 1988. The use of cigarettes as a weight control tool by young girls is extremely serious."
And in a recent survey by the National Institute on Drug Use, researchers found that teen-age girls were steadily using more marijuana, cocaine and LSD than they were about four years ago. Among 10th-grade girls, for example, 28 percent were said to use marijuana, nearly double the figure for 1992.
In interviews, girls sheepishly raised their hands when asked if they smoked pot, and all hands went up when they were asked if their friends used drugs. "People here do smoke a lot of pot," said Kori Scott, 15. "For them, it is a feeling of pleasure, and then they don't care about what they do."
Something has to fill the void left when the textbooks are closed and the dinner dishes have been washed, and it is often television.
While the authors of the Centers for Disease Control study stressed that they were unable to demonstrate a direct link between television watching and poor health, they did note that girls who were vigorously active were less likely to watch as much television as their peers who were physically inactive.
But beyond a decrease in physical education programs (the centers found that only 19 percent of female students went to a gym class every day, and Illinois is the only state that requires physical education), many experts talk about less tangible forms of pressure that leave young women conflicted and in trouble.
"Girls are no longer supposed to be submissive, and there is more pressure to succeed academically now," said Kelly Brownell, a professor of psychology at Yale University. "Fewer of them have parents around to pay attention to them, and there is more danger in their reactions to stress."
Many of the girls talked about the conflict of trying to meet their parents' expectations while still appearing attractive to boys, who they said still expected girls to keep to traditional roles.
"The boys here always say, 'My wife is going to be home cooking me dinner when I get home,' " said Stella Kim, an 18-year-old senior. "Then they laugh. But we know they're serious."
And despite a lack of interest in exercise, girls still express an obsession with weight loss.
"Heaven forbid you should ask for a size 9, or even a 7, when everyone else is in a 5," said Christie Zehnder, a senior, referring to the yearly cheerleading squad ritual of picking out short little skirts.
Still, the few girls who expressed an interest in physical activity said they exercised with gusto. One girl practices karate several hours a week, and others are three-season athletes.
Kristie Titcomb, a tiny 15-year-old sophomore, said that karate made her feel invulnerable. "Guys don't really like it," she said. "My boyfriend gets annoyed if I hit him, but I will only use this stuff if I have to."

HEADLINE: Red Phillips, 74, A Basketball Star With City College

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Claude (Red) Phillips, a former New York City high school basketball star who gained wider fame when he teamed with Red Holzman to form an indomitable backcourt combination at City College in the early 1940's, died in New York last Wednesday. He was 74.
Robert Williams, the president of the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame, said the cause was a heart attack. 
 Mr. Phillips, who was inducted into the hall in September, was a native of Harlem who combined with another noted teammate, William (Pop) Gates, to lead Benjamin Franklin High School to the Public Schools Athletic League championship in 1938.
But it was under Nat Holman at City College that Phillips, playing alongside Holzman, emerged as a dazzling guard.
During the two Phillips-Holzman seasons, 1940-41 and 1941-42, City College had records of 17-5 and 16-3, plus at least one other distinction, according to Holzman: The Beavers never lost to another New York City college.
"I was the passer, and he was the shooter," said Holzman, the former Knick coach, who ranked Phillips among the game's great guards, alongside two Basketball Hall of Fame members, Bob Davies and Bobby Wanzer of the Rochester Royals, with whom Holzman played professionally.
Phillips's chance for a professional career was dashed by the economic realities of the day: marriage and the need for a steady job. With the newly created National Basketball Association offering an uncertain financial future, Mr. Phillips became a New York City policeman, rising to the rank of sergeant before spending 11 years as the chief senior inspector of the New York State Drug Abuse Control Program.
He is survived by three sons, Claude Jr., Sidney and Alvin, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Official Quits AT&T To Run A Software Company

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

 BODY:
One of the AT&T Corporation's top executives announced yesterday that he was quitting as president of the company's Global Information Solutions subsidiary, less than two years after he took the job and midway through his effort to turn around the struggling $7 billion computer unit.
The executive, Jerre L. Stead, will become chief executive of the Legent Corporation, a computer software company in Herndon, Va., with sales of $501 million -- a small fraction of the size of the AT&T subsidiary, which was previously known as the NCR Corporation. 
 The move surprised many analysts, because Mr. Stead, who is 51, had been viewed as a star at AT&T who had previously orchestrated a turnaround at its business communication products division and appeared to be having success at the computer unit.
Some industry analysts said Mr. Stead's departure could jeopardize efforts to revitalize Global Information Solutions, which has been AT&T's poorest-performing unit for the last few years. Mr. Stead, who was put in charge of the company in May 1993, has cut jobs while refocusing the company on new markets and putting a stronger emphasis on reaching out to customers.
"This is a big loss for AT&T here," said George F. Colony, president of Forrester Research, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "This is the time they should be accelerating, and they need Jerre as a coach. The turnaround at GIS was so personality-driven."
The departure also appeared to surprise AT&T's top management. The AT&T chairman and chief executive, Robert E. Allen, said the company had not settled on a permanent replacement. William O'Shea, a longtime AT&T executive who is head of worldwide marketing at the Global Information Solutions, will take over as interim president.
For his part, Mr. Stead said he could not resist the opportunity to take charge of an entire company. "The Legent opportunity was unique, and one I was delighted to take part in," he said in an interview yesterday.
AT&T executives dismissed concerns about Mr. Stead's departure, saying the computer company was on its way to executing the strategy that Mr. Stead and others had devised.
"We have a strategy we are absolutely convinced is right," Mr. O'Shea said. "Our focus now is on executing the plans we've put in place."
The Global Information Solutions division has performed poorly since the company acquired it for $7.5 billion in 1991, though it had gained ground in the last year. Based in Dayton, Ohio, it was in the process of shifting from proprietary mainframe computers to "open" systems that run software from many vendors and a family of machines built around the Intel Corporation's microprocessors.
But the company had struggled with high costs and slumping sales overseas, which led to several quarterly losses. Mr. Stead was brought in to set things right.
The results have begun to show, though the task is not complete. After losing $172 million in 1993 on sales of $7.2 billion, Global Information Solutions broke even for most of 1994. Analysts say the company will show a profit for the final quarter of 1994, on sales approaching $8 billion.
Mr. Stead's decision is a big boost for Legent, a company that made its name developing system management software to run large mainframe computers more efficiently. Legent had been searching for a new chief since last August, when its chief executive, John F. Burton, announced that he would not renew his contract when it expired this March.
Mr. Stead will earn a base salary of $750,000 a year and will receive stock options to buy up to 700,000 shares of Legent stock -- about 2 percent of the company -- at its closing price last Friday: $28.75 a share.
At AT&T, Mr. Stead received $1.2 million in salary and other cash compensation, as well as stock options and other "long-term incentives" valued at $425,250.
"It's hard to turn down the C.E.O. job at a major company," said Daniel P. Reingold, a telecommunications analyst for Merrill Lynch, adding that Mr. Stead was unlikely to have succeeded Mr. Allen as chairman of AT&T. "There are a lot of major jobs at AT&T, but there is only one guy who can get the top job."
Mr. Stead said Legent was poised for rapid growth, saying that it had a niche in providing software to bridge the gap between old-fashioned "legacy" systems based on mainframe computers and newer distributed networks built around microprocessors and smaller computers.
The company has shifted in recent years to develop products for networks of microprocessor-based computers, known as client-server networks, but much of the business is still based on older mainframes.
Legent grew rapidly during the 1980's, but its profits have been erratic in recent years.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Metals, Oil and Grain Fall On a Spate of Profit Taking

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Commodity futures prices fell broadly yesterday as speculators took profits in markets bloated by a holiday-season rally. Precious metals, copper, crude oil and cotton all fell sharply.
Most grain futures also retreated, but cattle rose to a nearly nine-month high. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 products fell 1.88 points, to 234.76. 
 "I think people have returned from the holidays with the idea interest rates have not peaked yet," said James Steel, an analyst for a big commodities-brokerage firm, Refco Inc., "but growth in general may be slowing down. That combination is anti-inflationary, which is definitely hitting the precious metals, and it's not that good for the industrial commodities."
Gold and other precious metals are traditionally regarded as a hedge against inflation.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, gold for February delivery fell $3.50, to $380.90 an ounce, and March silver plunged 15.5 cents, to $4.762 an ounce.
March copper fell 4.9 cents, to $1.337 a pound.
All three metals had posted strong gains in recent weeks. Copper, which is heavily used in the electronics and construction industries, had reached a six-year high on Friday.
Analysts also cited profit taking in the energy markets after a two-week advance in crude oil prices.
On the New York Merc, light sweet crude oil for February delivery fell 32 cents, to $17.44 a barrel; February heating oil dropped 1.29 cents, to 49.94 cents a gallon; February unleaded gasoline was off 1.03 cents, at 52.75 cents a gallon, and February natural gas dropped 4.2 cents, to $1.683 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Cotton futures fell sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange from the three-and-a-half-year highs reached last week. March deliveries dropped the permitted daily limit of 2 cents, to 88.35 cents a pound.
Corn and soybean futures sagged, and wheat futures fell sharply. March wheat plunged 6 cents, to $3.955 a bushel; March corn fell 2.5 cents, to $2.285 a bushel; March oats rose 3.75 cents, to $1.255 a bushel, and January soybeans fell 3 cents, to $5.4775 a bushel.
Cattle futures climbed above 73 cents a pound for the first time since April on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, driven by meatpackers' strong demand.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Traders See Higher Rates as More Likely

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday as a report indicating an increase in inflation heightened expectations of higher interest rates ahead.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.5565 German marks, down from 1.5597 marks in European trading on Monday, but up from 1.5495 marks in New York on Friday. The dollar rose to 100.68 Japanese yen, from 99.58 yen on Friday. The British pound slipped to $1.5630, from $1.5647 on Friday. 
 Foreign-exchange desks were closed for the New Year's holiday in many countries on Monday, but trading was conducted in several others, including Germany and Italy.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday that its prices-paid index surged last month to its highest level in almost 14 years, rising to 83 percent from 77.9 percent in November.
"The prices-paid component spooked some people," said Richard Vullo, currency sales manager at the Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank in New York.
While United States bond prices fell after the report, the increase in the price index reassured currency dealers that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates again at a meeting of its policy-making committee on Jan. 31-Feb. 1. The Fed has raised short-term rates six times since February.
Another rate increase is expected to bolster the dollar, market participants said. "There's still a slight bias toward a higher dollar, because it still looks like we'll see higher interest rates," said Belal Khan, chief customer dealer at the Bank of Tokyo in New York.
Rising interest rates often help a currency by making bonds and bank deposits denominated in the currency more attractive.
Yesterday, for example, one-month Eurodollar deposits yielded 5.94 percent, compared with 5.13 percent for one-month Euromark deposits and 2.31 percent for Euroyen deposits.
The dollar's rise against the yen yesterday resulted from speculative traders purchasing marks for yen, market participants said. To accomplish such a transaction, traders frequently buy dollars for yen and then sell the dollars for marks.
Traders continued to monitor the Mexican peso, although they said it was not having much impact on the dollar against other currencies. In late New York trading, the dollar stood at 5.2750 pesos, up from 4.925 pesos yesterday.

HEADLINE: MEXICO'S RESCUE PACKAGE: THE IMPLICATIONS;
A Darker Side for U.S. In the Mexican Solution

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Just before the peso crisis began two weeks ago, Clinton Administration officials celebrated the anniversary of the approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement by proudly announcing the first fruits of victory: Mexico had overtaken Japan as the No. 2 consumer of American exports.
Now the Administration is facing the darker side of the broad economic alliance it pressed so hard to bring to pass. To restore confidence in the Mexican economy, it has supported -- and helped shape -- a plan that is almost certain to cut back the pace at which American goods flow across the border. Moreover, it is a plan that seems certain to increase the inducements for Mexican workers to come to the United States illegally. 
 For one thing, the decision announced today by President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon to let the peso float freely at its devalued levels will mean that American wages are now about 30 percent more valuable to Mexican workers than they were just a few weeks ago.
The result, Administration officials conceded today, will likely be visible within weeks along the 2,000-mile-long border. In the name of stabilizing the Mexican economy over the next year or two, Mr. Clinton's aides have decided to run the risk of another wave of illegal immigration into regions of the United States that are growing increasingly intolerant of the cost it imposes on American workers and taxpayers.
"In the end there is no choice," one Administration official who has been involved in the growing trade with Mexico said today. "Mexico has become an integral part of the North American market. That started way before Nafta. The two economies are intertwined in trade, in commerce, in the movement of people. And in the end, the bigger need is to have a stable country on our border."
Throughout the currency crisis, the White House has been acutely aware that while the political stakes are enormous for Mr. Zedillo; they may also loom large for Mr. Clinton.
After a contentious debate in the fall of 1993 before approval, the North American trade agreement faded as an issue, costing Mr. Clinton little. But that calculation may now change, especially in Texas and California, two states that are critical to his re-election hopes. Many residents there are among those most suspicious that they are paying the price for helping Mexico overcome its economic problems. Opponents of the trade accord, who said American workers would be hurt more than they were helped, may look more prescient in coming months if the flow of both low-priced goods and low-wage immigrants from Mexico to the United States sharply increases.
"The Clinton Administration has fallen into the same trap as the Reagan and Bush Administrations," said Jeffrey J. Schott, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, who has written extensively about the benefits of the trade accord. "It has been forced to oversell the effects of a trade deal on American economic growth. And sometimes, it comes back to haunt you."
Certainly there is good news as well for Washington in the economic recovery package announced today by Mr. Zedillo, who has been in office for less than a month. Mr. Zedillo's insistence that unions agree to wage increases of no more than 7 percent, and that corporations keep their profits minimal in an effort to keep prices down, seem likely to cut off the momentum of devaluation and inflation that many feared could cause the economy to spin out of control.
More important, Mr. Zedillo has chosen to speed changes in the economy that the North American Free Trade Accord set in motion. He is allowing private investment in railroads and satellite operations, promising to further liberalize foreign investment rules and promoting more competition in domestic telephone services.
All those steps are likely to eventually benefit American companies racing for a firmer foothold in the Mexican economy. In some areas, Mr. Zedillo is handing Washington openings it sought -- and was denied -- when the trade agreement was negotiated under the Bush Administration.
The Mexican President is also hoping to wean his country from its dependence on short-term investments to finance its current-account deficit -- the difference between what it takes in from exports and what it pays for imports and to meet its foreign-debt obligations. Those investments make the economy more vulnerable to market speculators, who helped send the peso on its fall.
Instead, Mr. Zedillo hopes to pay for Mexico's deficit with more direct investment from foreign companies, getting them to build factories and businesses in the country. That may be more attractive than ever, because the cost of investing in Mexico has declined by a third.
But American companies will have to be convinced that Mr. Zedillo has the unions and the country's elite behind him. They also have to be persuaded that they will not suffer a similar fate to that of investors of recent months and years, who have been hit with millions of dollars in losses in the last two weeks.
And they must learn to live with slower growth -- much slower than the 4 to 6 percent growth that Mr. Zedillo was confidently predicting in Washington a few weeks ago, before his inauguration.
Such problems, of course, are not inherent to investors in Mexico. China, the largest potential investment market of all for American companies, already has a surging inflation rate of 24 percent and seems ripe for a Mexico-style market correction. Throughout much of Eastern Europe, the kinds of tough economic choices that Mexico deferred during its presidential election last year have also been avoided.
But as President Clinton learned during the national debate in 1993 over the North American trade deal, there is something special about Mexico. The specter of more illegal immigration and of political trouble on the United States' border gives a vivid immediacy to the country's economic troubles that outweigh Mexico's size or influence on the American economy.
What the Clinton White House still has not learned, some experts contend, is that its much touted foreign economic policy must be approached like arms control: The focus has to be on prevention, not response.
"What we need now is a new method for consultation and support between the two countries to reduce the likelihood that problems like this become crises," said Robert A. Pastor, the director of the Latin American and Caribbean program at the Carter Center at Emory University in Atlanta. "That will be the most important long-term change."

HEADLINE: Survey of Manufacturers Shows Growth Is Slowing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Growth among United States manufacturers weakened moderately in December, one of the first signs that the economy is starting to lose strength from higher interest rates, a trade group's survey indicated yesterday.
Still, the survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management showed that manufacturing continued to expand, even if at a slower pace. Moreover, inflation at the producer level rose, giving the Federal Reserve Board more justification to raise interest rates again, according to economists who reviewed the survey results. 
 The association, which conducts the survey of executives who do the buying for the nation's factories, said its index of manufacturing growth fell to 57.8 percent in December from 61.2 percent in November.
The December number was both the lowest reading and the first monthly drop in the index since August.
Manufacturing has been one of the strongest parts of the economy, and analysts said the report was among the first significant indications of a general slowdown. Data from the housing industry released last week showed that higher interest rates had slowed sales. The Federal Reserve Board raised rates six times last year to restrain the economy's brisk expansion.
"This is one of the first signs, other than the housing sector, that the economy is slowing," David Bostian, an economist at Herzog, Heine, Geduld, a New York investment firm, said of yesterday's report.
A index at 57.8 percent still signifies that manufacturing is expanding. A reading of more than 50 percent indicates an expansion of industrial activity, while a reading of less than 50 percent indicates a decline.
Coupled with the report's evidence of rising prices for factories, the growth index provides support for another rate increase when the Fed's policy makers meet at the end of this month, economists said.
"Even though the report showed a contraction in growth, it's still relatively high," said Kathleen Stephansen, senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.
The purchasing managers assocation surveys managers at more than 300 industrial companies.
The association's price index surged to 83 percent in December from 77.9 percent in November. TheDecember figure was the highest since March 1980 and represented the fourth rise in five months.
The number of companies reporting higher prices also grew. Seventy-one percent of survey respondents paid higher materials prices, compared with 68 percent in November.
Despite the higher inflation component, other pieces of the survey showed weakness.
Factory production increased at its lowest rate in three months. The level of new orders grew, but at a slower pace than in November. The order backlog, an indication of manufacturers' ability to keep up with demand, increased at a lower rate than in the preceding month.
In addition, factory employment declined in December after three consecutive months of growth.

HEADLINE: MEXICO'S RESCUE PACKAGE: THE PRICE;
Chemical Tells of Big Peso Loss

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Chemical Bank said yesterday that a foreign exchange trader in New York had lost $70 million while making unauthorized deals in Mexican pesos.
The loss will cut the bank's fourth-quarter trading revenue by $40 million after taxes, the bank said. 
 Chemical said the trader had made trades in excess of his authorized limits and hid the transactions from the bank. A Chemical spokesman declined to identify the trader.
A person familiar with the bank identified the trader as Victor Gomez, a vice president in the foreign exchange group and a Chemical employee for five years. Mr. Gomez has been dismissed, the person said. No other employees have been dismissed, but the bank is continuing its investigation. Mr. Gomez could not be reached for comment.
Chemical's unexpected peso holdings became vulnerable after the sudden devaluation of the peso on Dec. 20 and its subsequent further fall. The peso closed yesterday at 5.275 to the dollar, down 34 percent from its level a month ago.
The devaluation and the subsequent sharp decline in stock and bond markets throughout Latin America are likely to cause some problems for most banks and brokerage firms. But in contrast to the Latin debt crisis of a decade ago, the banks' losses will be limited because few have invested large sums of their own money in Latin securities. The losses will be much larger for mutual funds and other investors that bought large amounts of Mexican stocks and bonds from the banks.
The person familiar with the bank said that Mr. Gomez operated under strict risk limits that stipulated that whenever he bought pesos from a customer he was immediately to find someone to sell them to, avoiding both big gains or losses. Apparently, he entered false trades into Chemical's computer system indicating he had sold pesos when in fact he had not, the person said.
 Chemical's problem somewhat resembles the plight of Kidder, Peabody & Company, which said last year that one of its government bond traders, Orlando Joseph Jett, had entered phantom trades that created $350 million in false profits.
 Other banks and brokerage firms have had problems caused by traders who did transactions but did not report them promptly. The largest of these involved a trader of mortgage-backed securities at Merrill Lynch who hid two deals in 1987 that eventually caused a $377 million loss for Merrill.
Traders who have amassed big losses are tempted to hide their positions in hopes of gaining time to recoup their losses by placing bigger bets than they are allowed.
 It is unclear what the motivation was for Mr. Gomez. But in August, he told the Reuters news service that he expected the peso to rise in value after Mexico's presidential election if there was a victory by Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, the candidate of the Institutional Revolutionary Party. Mr. Zedillo did win the election and took office on Dec. 1, three weeks before Mexico's currency crisis erupted.
 Chemical, which is one of the largest currency dealers, is active in trading pesos. The biggest peso dealers, however, are the Mexican banks and Citibank, which is the only United States-based bank with significant operations in Mexico. Mexican banks have a trading advantage because they can buy and sell pesos from Mexico's central bank.
Investors discounted the report from Chemical. Shares of the Chemical Banking Corporation rose 37.5 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $36.25, a gain in line with that of other bank stocks.
 "It's not all that significant, because everyone has basically known that trading in emerging markets would be foul this quarter," said Frank R. DeSantis Jr., a bank-stock analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
 "You do stop and wonder what went wrong from a control standpoint," Mr. DeSantis added. "It's not a good thing, but I seriously doubt that this is indicative of a control problem at Chemical."
 Even before the peso devaluation, large trading banks like J. P. Morgan & Company and Bankers Trust said that their trading profits would be down in the fourth quarter from the already-depressed levels of the third quarter.
 While the large banks and brokerage firms will probably take some losses from their Mexican and other Latin American securities, investors have been prepared for these. Moreover, Latin debt is a relatively small portion of most banks' business, compared with securities and derivatives from from developed markets
 "Many banks will be bruised in emerging markets, but their overall trading numbers will be down, but not negative," Mr. DeSantis said.
 Other analysts and fund managers, however, said that Chemical's loss was not an isolated incident, but rather the tip of the iceberg.
"Given that the devaluation was a complete surprise and all the firms have been making a big push to get into emerging markets, there will be significant losses," said a Latin American strategist at a securities company who insisted on anonymity.
Banks and Wall Street companies holding so-called Brady bonds, named after the former Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who created them to help overhaul Latin American debt, have also seen losses as the bonds' values have plunged.
Still, the losses may not be cataclysmic for commercial banks in part because Mexican, not American banks, dominated the trade in pesos. As a result, the Mexican banks were more likely to have large peso holdings. when their value started to plunge. In addition, the value of the peso had become increasingly volatile over the last two years, causing banks and securities companies to hedge their positions. For example, holders of tesobonos, short-term bonds that are peso-denominated but indexed to the dollar, have virtually no currency risk because Mexico is bound to repay the dollar value of the debt at whatever the exchange rate is when they mature.
"If people were playing the game the way they had been for the last two years, there won't be a large amount of damage," said an investment banker who specializes in emerging markets and insisted on anonymity. However, if they began speculating after the peso began its slide, they may have been seriously hurt, he added.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Fewer Dividends Being Trimmed

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
American companies are making fewer cuts in or omissions of dividends than at any time in at least four decades -- a confirmation of the strength of the economy and of corporate profits.
But even as companies are cutting back on this kind of bad news, they are showing signs of being less willing to send out good news -- even when higher profits would seem to justify larger dividends. That could indicate that board room optimism about the economy has peaked and is starting to turn lower. 
 The Standard & Poor's Corporation reported yesterday that just 136 companies sent bad news about dividends in 1994, with 77 omitting payouts and 59 reducing them. That was down 30 percent from 1993 and 67 percent below the recession year of 1990, when 409 companies sent out bad news.
At the same time, 1,826 companies announced dividend increases, the highest for any year since 1983. That was up 12 percent from 1993 and was 45 percent above the 1990 figure.
But while 1994 was a banner year, the pace of the increase in dividends slowed. In 1992 and 1993, the number of companies announcing dividend increases rose 23 percent each year.
Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.& P.'s Outlook newsletter, noted that the fourth quarter saw the same number of companies raise dividends as had done so a year earlier. "In view of the many double-digit earnings gains indicated for 1994, it was something of a surprise that the number of dividend increases" was not larger, he said.
Mr. Kaufman also said that 173 companies announced increases in December, just two more than in the December 1993, while the November figure fell to 155, a decline of 19 from November 1993. For the quarter, there were 493 increases, the same as in the last quarter of 1993.
It was the first time since the third quarter of 1991 that a quarter had failed to show an increase in the number of companies raising payouts.
Actions on dividends often lag behind corporate results because companies hate to cut payouts. So corporate boards often delay increases until they are sure that the higher level of profits will endure, and the slowdown in the growth of increases may indicate that some companies are less confident about the future.
Another measure of dividend activity is the payout on the S.& P. 500, or more accurately on the 500 stocks that make up the index. The figure is computed on the assumption that an investor owns fractional shares in each stock, with a total value at the end of the year of $459.27, the level of the index. That individual would have collected $13.18 in dividends during the year, up 4.8 percent from the $12.58 paid in 1993.
With the increases recorded during the year, 1994 ended with the S.& P. 500 paying at an annual rate of $13.31, the amount owners would get in 1994 if none of the 500 changed their payout rates during the year. That would provide a yield of 2.9 percent.
That rate is low by historical standards, but well above the 2.75 percent low reached early last February, when stock prices were peaking but dividend payouts were lower. The only previous times the S.& P. 500 payouts had dipped that low were in January 1973 and August 1987, both market peaks that were followed by sharp selloffs.
Prices came down from that level, but not by nearly as much as in the past. To bears, that reflects the impact of public investors rushing into equity mutual funds and thereby sustaining high valuations. Bulls, however, argue that dividends are not as important as they used to be.
They note that many companies -- exact statistics are hard to come by -- use share repurchases to get money to shareholders. That is said to be better because dividends are taxed at ordinary income tax rates, while the proceeds from share repurchases become capital gains for those who sell, taxed at a rate that now is lower for many taxpayers and is likely to go down even further if the Republicans who control Congress keep a campaign promise.
Dividend cuts are unambiguous bad news, and are often resisted by corporate boards and managements that hope things will turn around. So it is no surprise that they fall to low levels a couple of years into an economic recovery, after all the damage from the previous recession has had ample time to be recognized.
In the years since 1955, when S.& P. began collecting the figures on companies raising and cutting dividends, the lowest figure for companies providing bad news came in 1973, when just 151 reductions and omissions were announced. That figure was held down by the fact that in earlier years dividend increases had been held back by Federal wage and price controls, meaning that many companies had forgone increases that they might have had to reconsider.
The number of dividend omissions in 1994 was just 77, also a low for the period since 1955, while the number of reductions, 59, was the lowest since 1979.
Because many companies make dividend decisions once a year, there is a heavy seasonal trend to the results. And it is in the first quarter that the most decisions are made, as companies act after getting results for the previous year.
In the first quarter of 1994, the number of companies raising payouts was 551, up 24 percent from the same level of 1993 and the highest for any quarter since the first quarter of 1981. Topping that number this year will be a tall order, and failure to do so could indicate that corporate managements are less optimistic than they were a year ago.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Many Facing Hard '95 Remain Determined to Give

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
In the first days of 1995, many New Yorkers are wondering how impending government budget cuts and an unstable economy will affect their lives. Some have not yet recovered jobs lost during the long recession. Others depend on publicly financed health or child care programs that face decreases in financing.
Letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund suggest many donors will face hardships of their own in 1995. But even among those with uncertain futures, the spirit of giving persists. 
 "We had a bad year, but probably not as bad as some of the people who you will see to it receive this check," wrote Randy and Sidney Friedfertig of Manhattan, who sent $50 to the fund. "Maybe next year, it will be more."
Several months ago, Harriet Hendel of Highland Mills, N.Y., lost her job as a special-education teacher because of downsizing. But she could not break a 28-year-old tradition of contributing to Neediest Cases.
"For the first time in 30 years I am out of work," wrote Mrs. Hendel, who sent $25 with her husband, Stan. "But I count myself lucky, as I have a husband to support me. I wish my contribution could be greater, but it is all I can give at this time."
Since 1911, the Neediest Cases Fund has helped the city's poor, sick, disabled and elderly. Contributions are split among seven charities and used for services like foster care, homeless shelters and job rehabilitation for the disabled. The fund also provides food, clothing and rent money for people who find themselves in unexpected crises.
Since Thanksgiving, the fund has received gifts totaling $2,749,926.10 from thousands of individuals and foundations. And while large donations might seem more important, smaller gifts from thousands of concerned individuals ultimately make the greatest difference.
While many donors write of the long-term troubles they face, others describe sudden bits of bad luck that complicated their lives in 1994. In December, Dennis Appleton was robbed of several hundred dollars on the street. But the incident did not deter him from sending his annual gift of $365 -- a dollar a day -- to Neediest Cases.
"After the initial anger passed, I decided that I was not going to let this incident transform me into the very stereotype of a New Yorker I have always worked so hard to avoid becoming," wrote Mr. Appleton, a Manhattan resident. "And so, it is with special defiant pleasure that I can again find that 'dollar a day' out of my life to send to your fund."
Some donors have no source of income other than gifts -- or in the case of children, allowances. But still, they are eager to share their wealth.
"As sisters, we do not have money of our own to give away," wrote Sister Mary Michael, a nun with the Sisters of St. Margaret in Manhattan. "The enclosed check represents money given me for Christmas." She sent $50.
For Julia and James Hall of Brooklyn, personal struggles made them realize the importance of giving what they could to help solve the city's broader problems. Last month, the Brooklyn couple sent $200 to Neediest Cases.
"At a time when our 'improving economy' is adversely affecting my husband and me -- along with legions of others -- we are impelled to double our contribution," the Halls wrote. "The crying need seems to more than double every year."

HEADLINE: Pataki to Stress Basic Themes in State of the State Address

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Only three days after his inauguration, Gov. George E. Pataki will restate his priorities and set the tone for his relationship with the Legislature in his first State of the State address on Wednesday.
Unlike his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, who used his State of the State speeches to catalogue a vast range of legislative initiatives, Mr. Pataki is expected to stick to the basic themes he repeated throughout his campaign and transition: tax cuts, controlling state spending, work requirements for welfare recipients, reducing Medicaid costs, privatization, restoration of the death penalty, ending parole for violent felons, ending work release, term limits and giving citizens the right to petition for ballot initiatives. 
 "I think people are going to be amazed by the consistency of the message," Mr. Pataki told reporters on Monday. "I hope it doesn't make your lives too boring, but the things we talked about are the things we believe in and we believe them very deeply. They're going to be continually hammered home until the changes we talked about in fact occur."
Many of Mr. Pataki's advisers have urged him to stick to the few issues that most concern voters: taxes, jobs and crime. "There are a lot of second- and third-level issues that he will be forced to deal with as Governor, but that's not where he's going to spend his time and energy," said Thomas W. Carroll, president of the anti-tax group Change-N.Y. "You can't mobilize the public behind a 400-point agenda."
Pataki advisers said they expected Mr. Pataki to announce few new detailed proposals in his first address to the Legislature.
For instance, rather than recommending which state assets and services should be privatized, Mr. Pataki is expected to announce that Ronald S. Lauder will lead a commission to study the issue, according to Nelson Warfield, an aide to Mr. Lauder.
Mr. Lauder, a cosmetics executive and a 1989 candidate for mayor of New York City, headed a similar commission for the Republican-led State Senate in 1991. But few of that commission's recommendations, including the sale of La Guardia and John F. Kennedy International Airports, were carried out during Mario M. Cuomo's administration.
Early in the speechwriting process, Pataki aides considered using the speech to propose a merger of the Health and Social Services Departments, state officials said today. The departments are two of the largest in state government, and they share some similar functions, primarily in administering the Medicaid system.
But Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, said tonight that the proposal would not be included in the speech. Ms. Mucha would not say whether Mr. Pataki was inclined to endorse the proposal, which has been recommended over the years by several groups studying ways to streamline state government.
Mr. Pataki and his advisers worked feverishly on the speech throughout the day, even while traveling by helicopter to and from the funeral of Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro in Manhattan. Mr. Pataki had been scheduled to rehearse the 30-minute speech in a locked Assembly chamber early this evening, but the practice session was delayed indefinitely as he continued to make revisions.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who attended last year's State of the State speech by Mr. Cuomo, will not return for Wednesday's address because of scheduling conflicts and because he traveled here three days ago for the inaugural, said Cristyne F. Lategano, Mr. Giuliani's press secretary.
Mr. Pataki, who spent eight years in the Assembly and two in the Senate, has pledged to lobby lawmakers more directly than Mr. Cuomo, who dealt primarily with legislative leaders. If he cannot forge a consensus with the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, particularly on his fiscal proposals, he may try to build a majority by persuading 20 Democrats to join the 56 Assembly Republicans.
The chief fight with Mr. Silver is likely to revolve around Mr. Pataki's proposal to cut income taxes by 25 percent over four years. Mr. Silver has said that he is not averse to tax-cutting in principle but that such a large cut may be unaffordable and that cuts in other taxes might be preferable.
Chastened by the experience of 1987, Mr. Silver has recommended that Mr. Pataki propose his tax cuts one year at a time, rather than tying the Legislature to a four-year plan that may be difficult to sustain if economic conditions worsen. In 1987, the Legislature and Mr. Cuomo enacted a five-year, phased-in reduction of income taxes, only to defer the last two years of the plan for the last five years.
But Mr. Pataki has been advised by many of his top aides to push for legislation in the first year that would lock the entire tax cut plan in place.
Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, released calculations today showing that 32 percent of the state's taxpayers would receive a tax increase under the 1987 plan, including 54 percent of those with incomes below $40,000. Mr. Brodsky said that 98 percent of the reduction in taxes would benefit taxpayers with incomes above $40,000.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 625 words

HEADLINE: Day One

 BODY:
On the first day of the 104th Congress, the new Republican majority will immediately pass the following major reforms, aimed at restoring the faith and trust of the American people in their government.
That promise is part of the House Republicans' "Contract With America," and the first day of the Republican-controlled 104th Congress is today. The House agenda for this afternoon calls for 20 minutes' debate and a vote on each of eight reforms. 
 Six of the reforms, aimed at reshaping the way the House does its day-to-day business, are healthy attempts to make it a more efficient and open institution. Regrettably, neither these rules nor any other part of the contract addresses big-money campaign financing or the freedom of members to take lobbyists' gifts -- though the Democrats may try to force the question of a gift ban.
The two proposals that bear on the actual substance of legislation -- as distinct from procedure -- are harmful. One, profoundly undemocratic and possibly unconstitutional, would defy majority rule on bills to raise taxes; the other would introduce misleading budget calculations.
Topping the agenda is a worthy proposal to eliminate 3 committees, 25 subcommittees and 600 committee staff employees. At the least, that could make the House more cost-efficient, which is also the aim of a second item -- a comprehensive outside audit to search out Congressional "waste, fraud and abuse." A third proposal, aimed at breaking authoritarian rule by senior members, would impose a six-year limit on committee chairmanships and an eight-year limit for the Speaker. Two others would limit the frequency of closed committee meetings and require committee members to vote in person, not by proxy.
The two proposals that deal with fiscal matters are bad policy. One would require a three-fifths majority to raise taxes, allowing a two-fifths-plus-one minority to block the majority. Since the contract also promises a balanced budget by 2002, the three-fifths rule would seem to mandate steep spending cuts, because it would make it almost impossible to legislate higher taxes. Those cuts would fall heavily on programs for the poor.
The other fiscal reform is called "Truth-in-Budgeting." Under existing rules, if a program's budget expands by no more than the rate of inflation, it is not counted as an increase in spending because the new funding only covers the higher cost of the same services. The new rule would count as an increase new spending that simply tries to keep pace with inflation. It would enable conservatives to ridicule liberal colleagues as "big spenders" even if they vote only to protect existing benefits.
The measures that the full House will consider and presumably adopt today have already been approved by its new Republican majority in party conference last month. They would change the way the House operates, but would not directly affect the Senate, where the "Contract With America" does not apply and the new Republican majority is considerably less fired up. But the three-fifths rule on taxes could nonetheless frustrate Senate action, because it would govern House voting on bills negotiated in House-Senate conference committees.
In one case -- a responsible proposal to make members obey laws they impose on the rest of America -- the House Republican leadership wants to adopt it in two forms, as a rule for the House and as a bill to become law for both houses, the Library of Congress and the other Congressional agencies. It makes more sense as law, so the same conditions prevail throughout the Congressional branch.
The Republicans have the strength to pass the whole package. It is a shame they have added harmful budget legislation to their useful reforms.

HEADLINE: In America;
A Reckless Journey

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
In a segment of "Eyes on the Prize," the brilliant documentary series on the civil rights movement, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is shown at a press conference, saying, "There is nothing more dangerous than to build a society with a large segment of people in that society who feel that they have no stake in it, who feel that they have nothing to lose."
Aristotle understood this. "Poverty," he said, "is the parent of revolution and crime." 
 In some sense, the American people understand it. A national survey conducted last fall showed that 72 percent of Americans believe that reducing poverty would help reduce racial tension and crime.
And yet, in a reckless new journey, with maps scrawled by sneering, cynical men with an utter contempt for history, the nation is moving fast toward policies guaranteed to increase poverty and suffering and to expand radically that dangerous segment of the population that feels it has nothing to lose.
Henry Hampton, executive producer of "Eyes on the Prize" and "The Great Depression," has completed a five-hour documentary series called "America's War on Poverty," which will appear on PBS on Jan. 16, 17 and 18. It's an honest look at a period in American history that has been profoundly misrepresented, distorted and lied about by politicians and others who have built marvelous careers exploiting misery.
Mr. Hampton's series arrives at a crucial moment. The number of Americans in poverty is growing, as is the number of middle-class Americans who are falling into poverty. One might have expected a sense of urgency to develop, a sense that these are serious problems that must be dealt with -- trends that must be reversed. Instead, the opposite is happening. The newest and most successful leaders in government have gotten where they are by promising to mug the poor.
"It seems to me so obvious that we have to do something about poverty," said Mr. Hampton during an interview at the headquarters of his production company, Blackside Inc., in Boston. "But this obvious need to act is buried in this litany that we've heard for so long: 'They don't want to work, they're taking your money, they want to sit and drink and watch television.' That kind of blatant appeal continues to work."
An "unconditional war on poverty" was declared by President Lyndon Johnson in his State of the Union address on Jan. 8, 1964. It was an appeal to the best in America at a time when the country seemed economically strong, militarily powerful and, in some quarters, deeply idealistic. It was also a time when the nation was hurtling into the tragedy of Vietnam, and when violence at home was eroding important reserves of good will and depriving the nation of some of its greatest leaders.
The war on poverty went forward but it was handicapped. Nevertheless there was progress. A companion volume to Mr. Hampton's series points out that in 1965, some 33.2 million Americans -- 17 percent of the population -- lived in poverty. By 1973, both the absolute numbers and the rate of poverty had declined, to 23 million and 11 percent, respectively. And then came the reversal. By 1988, after eight years of the Reagan revolution and its cruel assault on social services, the number of people in poverty had risen to 31.9 million, or 13.1 percent of the population, and the numbers are still rising.
It would have been enormously helpful to the country and to the various segments of its population if we had built on the successes of the war on poverty (there were many) and learned from the failures, which should have been corrected or eliminated. That is not what happened. Cheap politics and widespread ill will prevailed. The poor got poorer and, according to a study that looked at the years 1978 to 1986, the percentage of adults in the middle class in that period declined from 75 to 67 percent.
The rich got richer, of course. And the demagogues -- who do all in their power to foment hatred of the lower classes -- flourished.
This won't go on indefinitely. At some point a reckoning is inevitable. Echoing Dr. King, Mr. Hampton said, "A nation cannot live peaceably when the gap between affluence and poverty becomes as wide as ours is becoming."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Computer Error Has a Snowball Effect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
John Hockenberry's rather blithe "Pentium and Our Crisis of Faith" (Op-Ed, Dec. 28) will mislead readers into believing that an arithmetic error in the 16th decimal place is nothing to get bent out of shape about. I am referring to his remark "it's hard to imagine how this kind of accuracy matters." Then he asks: "When was the last time anyone checked the 16th decimal place of an economic forecast in Washington or in a corporate boardroom?" 
 What makes the problem with the Pentium chip serious is the growth in error that takes place in computations involving a long series of arithmetic steps, especially if those include highly nonlinear mathematical functions. Many computer programs, from those used in economic and weather forecasting to those that perform geometrical calculations for computer graphics and fluid-flow simulations, do not produce their results after a single division, but only after the data are processed by a long sequence of steps, each able to cause a diminution in accuracy from the previous step.
While all computers possess only finite precision, that precision has to be enough so that for all the intended applications of the machine the growth in error that takes place as computations are cascaded on data stays within bounds.
 
AVI KAK
Professor of Electrical & Computer
Engineering, Purdue University
West Lafayette, Ind., Dec. 29, 1994

HEADLINE: Orange County Sales Set

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Salomon Brothers said yesterday that it would auction nearly $1.5 billion in corporate securities this week from the Orange County, Calif., investment fund.
Orange County declared bankruptcy on Dec. 6 after disclosing huge investment losses, now estimated at more than $2 billion, in its portfolio. The county is selling off its securities to restructure its investment portfolio. 
 The investment pool's losses were caused by investments made on the assumption that interest rates would fall, but they rose instead.
Salomon, the county's financial adviser, said it would auction today $458 million of corporate securities, made up of medium-term notes from Ford Motor Credit and Salomon Inc. Tomorrow, Salomon will auction up to $1.08 billion of structured corporate securities, which may include derivatives.
The amount of securities for tomorrow's auction constitutes substantially all of the county's holdings of the structured corporate securities.
The county has sold off more than $4.5 billion in investments and collateral and sharply cut its exposure to interest rate swings.
Separately, Orange County officials said they were negotiating the sale or swap of risky securities to two Government-sponsored enterprises, the Federal Home Loan Bank System and the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae.
Just last week, the county completed a $634 million sale of structured notes to the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae.

HEADLINE: Real Estate

BYLINE: By Morris Newman 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
A TEAM of developers and architects has been selected to build a commercial and residential project in South-Central Los Angeles in an attempt to revitalize an area devastated by neglect and the riots of nearly three years ago.
The project is the fruit of an effort by businesses to promote growth in an inner-city area. Officials of the First Interstate Bank selected a site in the neighborhood and sponsored a design competition. 
 Bank officials said they hoped the 58,000-square-foot project on South Vermont Avenue would serve as a prototype for similar projects that could restore commercial activity to Vermont, a wide thoroughfare that was formerly a busy streetcar route and one of the leading commercial strips of South Los Angeles.
The project combines office space, stores and 35 town houses. The $11 million budget represents "the largest single investment in the area, in dollar terms, in the last quarter-century," said City Councilman Mark Ridley-Thomas, who served on a panel that picked the project from several offered by competing teams of architects and developers.
Building the project is a team made up of the Caleb Development Corporation of Los Angeles; the architectural firm of Solomon Inc. of San Francisco; the Related Companies of California, a Los Angeles-based developer; John Maloney Architecture of Santa Monica, Calif.; S. J. Amoroso Inc. of Irvine, Calif., a contractor, and the Related Management Company of Palmdale, Calif., a property manager.
South Vermont Avenue is a wide, formerly gracious street now pocked with vacant lots, serving as reminders of the properties that burned in the 1992 disturbances.
"In some ways, South Vermont is the inner-city problem par excellence," said Dan Solomon, a principal of Solomon Inc. "It has gone through waves of disinvestment and isolation, and had the life bled out of it."
The 75,000-square-foot First Interstate property posed a challenge for architects because it straddles the middle-class Vermont Knolls residential neighborhood on one side and the depressed thoroughfare on the other. When the bank first announced its intent to finance a mixed-use project with affordable housing on the site, the homeowners of Vermont Knolls were angered by their belief that the project would bring in low-income renters.
The finished project attempts to resolve that quarrel by providing about 7,000 square feet of retail space, enough for about seven stores, and by offering homes in the affordable range for sale rather than rental housing.
The winning design envisions a row of houses behind the commercial space with access available from an alley behind the project. Other housing units are set above the street-level stores. Office space is to be provided in a refurbished Art Deco tower, a neighborhood landmark built in 1931.
The Business Expansion Network, staffed by the University of Southern California School of Business Administration, plans to provide office space for fledgling businesses, some of which are expected to take root on Vermont Avenue.
The effort is part of a $2 billion program in depressed areas of Los Angeles that First Interstate began in March 1993, nearly a year after many businesses in the area were burned and looted. Construction is scheduled to start on the project in midyear.
After announcing the competition in 1994, First Interstate received 66 entries and whittled that number down to three finalists, each of which was required to put together a development team. The finalists were also required to glean from community meetings a better sense of what residents wanted in the project. A panel largely composed of residents chose the winning project in December.
"One of our motivations in doing this competition was to become more visible in South-Central Los Angeles, so we have more opportunities to do more financings," said John Gray, the bank's executive vice president in charge of commercial real estate lending in California. "We hope this project is the catalyst to start other developments and we'd be very happy to finance those," said.
Mr. Solomon, the architect, speaking to the design panel in December, cautioned that the project must not attempt "the unlikely the impossible or the unknown."
"Each of its parts should be simple to finance, simple to build and simple to market," he said.
