HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT'S NEW GOVERNOR: THE OVERVIEW;
ROWLAND AVOIDS PARTISAN APPEAL

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 4

 BODY:
While Republicans around the nation were basking in their newly-won power, John G. Rowland, the first Republican governor of Connecticut in 20 years, took office today with a speech that never mentioned his party, avoided appeals to partisanship and called on legislators to work together as a team.
In the State of the State address that Mr. Rowland delivered this afternoon, he did not include the more strident language of his campaign. He did not mention throwing people off the welfare roles or fume about possible court-enforced busing. 
 Instead, the 37-year-old Mr. Rowland, once considered the most conservative member of the Connecticut Congressional delegation, said he wanted to "help our young and old, our ill and our afflicted, when they need help and have no other resources." He described welfare reform in broad terms that no one could reject, saying, "A sense of civility dictates that we can and should help our neighbors, but a sense of individual accountability and responsibility must permeate a work ethic here in Connecticut." [Excerpts, page B8.]
On education, Mr. Rowland, the youngest governor in Connecticut history, did not refer to the controversial court case in which a judge may order Hartford schools to desegregate, an emotionally charged issue for him in the campaign. Rather, he talked about educating each child to the "maximum potential" and insuring that communities and parents have "some say as to where their children go to school."
And while Mr. Rowland spent the months before the November election skewering the economic policies of his predecessor, Governor Lowell P. Weicker Jr., today Mr. Rowland hailed him as a "memorable figure" and urged people to thank him for his 30 years of service to the state.
It was a speech that extended a hand to Democratic legislators, a move perhaps borne out of political necessity -- Mr. Rowland was elected with just 36 percent of the vote. If he is to succeed in his overall plan to shrink the government and phase out the state income tax, he must win the trust of the state's Democratic-controlled House of Representatives. And although some prominent Democrats criticized Mr. Rowland today, others said that the general nature of his speech, identifying shared concerns, was an encouraging step.
"I was pleased that he spoke in generalities," said Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat and the Speaker of the House. "He was making his best effort to work in a bipartisan fashion. If he had too many specifics, it would have alienated some legislators because we've had no input."
The 20-minute speech to the State Legislature was the highlight of Mr. Rowland's Inauguration Day celebration. After a luncheon given by Governor Weicker and a one-mile parade through downtown Hartford, Mr. Rowland was sworn in by his father, Sherwood, a former city comptroller of Waterbury, on a dais outside the State Capitol. On a sunny but bitterly cold afternoon, roughly 1,200 people gathered to watch him take his oath of office.
With that, Mr. Rowland, of Waterbury, became the state's 86th governor. "It's been a long time coming, and it's hard to believe the day is actually here," he told the crowd.
The moment was the culmination of a five-year quest that began in 1990, when Mr. Rowland lost the governorship to Mr. Weicker, who was running as an independent representing a newly-formed third party. This year, he defeated three major opponents in the general election, a substantial accomplishment in a state where the Democrats outnumber Republicans about 3-to-2.
Many Republicans celebrated today as the end to a long travail: the Democrats' domination of Connecticut state government for much of the last four decades. Thomas J. Meskill, the last Republican governor, left office after one term in 1974.
As Republicans rejoiced, they vowed that this time the change in parties would not be limited to one term. In addition to Mr. Rowland's taking office, the Republicans have taken control of the State Senate for the first time in 12 years.
George L. (Doc) Gunther, a 14-term Republican State Senator, remarked: "This is excellent. It's been 20 long years."
Although Mr. Rowland avoided specifically partisan language in his speech this afternoon, he echoed the script of Republicans in New York, New Jersey and Washington. He vowed to shrink state government, to return more control to localities and individuals and to get tough on crime, expanding the death penalty.
Lamenting the impact that government has had on people, Mr. Rowland remarked: "From a nation of pioneers governed by heroes, we have become a nation of form filers -- taxpayers who work in the midst of poverty and crime for nearly six months of every year just to pay for the very bureaucracies which send us the forms."
Despite Mr. Rowland's effort not to alienate Democrats, their reaction was subdued. Edward L. Marcus, that party's state chairman, called the speech "too general" and asked when Mr. Rowland would "provide more meat on the bones."
But other Democratic legislators commended Mr. Rowland. "It was a good first speech," said State Senator Kevin B. Sullivan. "At this point, I would not dismiss the prospects for a lot of bipartisanship."

HEADLINE: Peso Down; Mexican Stocks Fall

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Uncertain over the Government's plan to overcome Mexico's economic crisis, stock markets in both the United States and Mexico lost ground today as the peso sank further against the dollar.
Earlier in the day, the Mexican market saw some panic selling, sliding almost 6 percent at one point. It recovered after investors learned that the Mexican Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, was scheduled to meet with foreign investors in New York on Thursday morning. 
 Mr. Ortiz will try to explain the recovery plan to as many as 400 investors and analysts who are expected to attend the meeting at the Pierre Hotel. He was on the phone today talking with New York bankers.
The Mexican stock market ended the day at 2,269.87, down 8.26 points, or 0.36 percent. On the New York Stock Exchange, American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico were the most heavily traded issue, closing at $38.125, down 50 cents. Other big Latin American stock markets in Brazil and Argentina were also down, in part due to the Mexican crisis.
In currency trading, the peso was pounded again today, falling more than 5 percent, to 5.575 pesos to the dollar. That means a peso is worth 17.9 cents compared with 28.9 cents before the devaluation on Dec. 20.
Investors said they were generally unimpressed with the economic emergency plan announced on Tuesday by President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon. The plan holds down wages and prices and slashes the federal budget to help control inflation and recover from devaluation.
"The most important thing that was missing was any clear idea from the Government of where the currency will settle," said Geoffrey E. J. Dennis, Latin American equity strategist for Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. Foreign investors were also disappointed that Mr. Zedillo did not clearly say how the Government intended to pay for some $7 billion in short-term bonds that are scheduled to mature over the next month. And still other investors said that the Government should have proposed selling some attractive state-run businesses, including parts of the oil and natural-gas monopoly.
The plan includes an $18 billion credit line provided by the United States, Canada and other nations to help Mexico stabilize the peso.
Financial analysts in New York said they hoped that Mr. Ortiz's presentation Thursday would turn out better than the one held in the first week of crisis by the former Finance Minister, Jaime Serra Puche. Mr. Serra addressed about 60 investment bankers and analysts in New York, who were openly skeptical of the Government's ability to control the crisis. He was forced to resign a week later.
The pressure will be on Mr. Ortiz, a former finance under secretary respected by many New York investment officials, to provide important details that were left out of Mr. Zedillo's address.
After Mexico's central bank decided that it could no longer defend the peso from speculators, the Government was forced to let the currency float against the dollar on Dec. 21.
In a break from tradition that one Mexican official said responded to the concerns of foreign investors, the central bank made known the level of its foreign reserves -- $6.148 billion, down from $17 billion on Nov. 1. Until now, the reserves figure was given only two or three times a year.
At the central bank's weekly auction of treasury certificates, interest on the 28-day certificate was 33 percent, up from 31 percent last week.
Mr. Zedillo's stabilization plan sets caps for wage increases and some prices, but is silent on where the Government expects the free-floating peso to settle. However, late tonight, the central bank announced that the peso would be pegged at a target rate of 4.5 to the dollar.
The Government bonds scheduled to mature over the next month, called tesobonos, are paid in pesos but pegged to dollars, meaning that the Government's obligations have soared since the devaluation.
A document from Mr. Zedillo's office says the Government is working with leading investment banks to devise more attractive bonds that can be swapped for the existing bonds when they fall due.
Luis R. Luis, head of research for emerging markets at Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the mutual-fund company in Boston, said that although the Government's plans for the bonds were unclear, there was a positive sign on Tuesday. The Mexican central bank set a rate of 5.5 pesos to the dollar that it would pay the holders of about $670 million worth of bonds this week.
Mr. Luis said it was possible for Mexico to come up with bonds that investors would want, if the terms were right and the risks were reduced. He said that tesobonos were resold on the secondary market at interest rates of 20 to 22 percent. Mr. Luis predicted that new bonds payable in dollars at slightly lower rates would be attractive enough for investors to consider keeping their money in Mexico.
Many investors felt let down by the modest scale of the Government's plan to sell some of the companies it owns. In particular, they had expected to see the petrochemical plants and small natural-gas pipeline network of the state oil monopoly, Pemex, being offered for sale.
However, mention of Pemex was dropped after labor unions had expressed strong opposition to Mr. Zedillo's plan to hold down union wage increases in spite of rising inflation. Analysts said the Government feared that the unions might have rebelled if asked to accept the job losses that would be likely, should part of Pemex be sold.
Some analysts were not convinced that the Government had the power to maintain the 7 percent cap on wages this year, especially if prices started to rise out of control.
"Even though the unions were dragged to the tables at the end and signed the agreement, there's a real concern that wage inflation cannot be held at the level they agreed upon," Mr. Dennis said.
While investors will be pressing Mr. Ortiz for details, they will also push him to clarify aspects of the plan that have been confused. The Finance Ministry today released a statement disavowing responsibility for an English-language version of the stabilization plan, sent to foreign investors, that sets an inflation target for 1995 of 16 percent and states that the corporate income-tax rate will increase to 35 percent.
A ministry spokesman said neither of those figures was part of the actual plan.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Gain in Price, Ending a Losing Streak

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday for the first time in five trading sessions but most traders viewed the rise as a technical correction rather than as a precursor to even higher prices.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 22/32 , to 96, for a yield of 7.85 percent, down from 7.92 percent on Tuesday or about where it was last Thursday. A three-month bill fell 9 basis points, to 5.68 percent, and a six-month issue dropped 10 points, to 6.27 percent. 
 One of the factors behind the price gains was a stronger dollar, which makes dollar-denominated investments like bonds more attractive to foreign investors. Also, gold was down sharply, and the Commodity Research Bureau's index of various commodity futures rose only slightly, by 0.46 point, to 235.22
Tony Crescenzi, director of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, a New York brokerage firm, said, "Retail buyers are still somewhat reluctant to commit themselves fully to the market, but they're clearly warming up to it."
He said the market's gains were influenced by a drop in the prices of industrial materials, as the very short maturities and very long maturities reversed their previous declines. "The move in industrial materials," Mr. Crescenzi said, "is clearly tangible evidence that the pace of economic activity could be peaking and that a change is in the making. Price gains in industrial materials have been one of the market's biggest headaches."
Yesterday's strong performance put the long bond back into its monthlong trading range. Basically the Federal Reserve has been responsible for the recent bouts of buying, including yesterday's. Its last interest rate increase, on Nov. 15, which was aggressive, changed the market's perception of how well the Fed was doing its job. "It went from following the market to leading the market," Mr. Crescenzi said. "Since the last tightening, the market has been trading well."
Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said: "Bonds headed higher on the back of strong buying from institutional investors. They made their first significant appearance of the new year, buying paper in the two-year to five-year sectors. That left dealers a little short, and eager to cover their positions quickly in the thin market."
The yield on the two-year note dropped 11 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.62 percent, while the yield on a five-year note fell 8 basis points, to 7.80 percent.
Some market watchers expect the economic data this week to give bond prices an additional lift. Traders expect chain-store sales, which are due today, to be soft relative to the early forecast; the employment report due tomorrow could also reflect some adjustment in areas affected by colder weather. These include seasonal declines in some job sectors that were not captured in November because of the early reporting dates.
Today, the Treasury will auction $ 17.25 billion of new one-year bills. Yesterday, the one-year rate was 6.67 percent in late trading.
Elsewhere, municipal bond prices rose for the first time in three days amid investor demand for securities with intermediate maturities.
Some trading desks said that investors were favoring debt securities maturing in 15 to 20 years because their principal was subject to smaller fluctuations than longer maturities, while still offering higher coupons than short maturities.

HEADLINE: Dole Offers Foreign Policy Initiatives

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Bob Dole took up his role as Senate majority leader today with a two-pronged attack on the Administration's foreign policy, introducing legislation to stop observing the arms embargo against Bosnia and to give Congress more control over the scope and financing of United Nations peacekeeping.
The move represented the first foreign policy confrontation between the new Republican majority in Congress and the Administration. And it underscored the intention of the Republican-dominated Congress in general -- and Mr. Dole in particular -- to put the Administration on the defensive and try to wrest control of at least part of the foreign policy agenda from the Democrats. 
 In another sign of things to come, Mr. Dole also pledged that the Senate would question the legality of giving economic aid to North Korea as part of a far-reaching nuclear agreement, and examine closely the cost of helping Haiti.
In recent weeks the Kansas Senator has cast himself as a sort of shadow secretary of state, challenging NATO generals during a visit to Brussels on their inaction on Bosnia and Herzegovina, chastising the Europeans for failing to arm the Bosnian Government and threatening to block the nuclear deal with North Korea in the days before an American pilot was freed.
Under one bill by Mr. Dole, the United States would cease to honor the United Nations arms embargo on Bosnia either at the request of the Bosnian Government or at the end of a four-month cease-fire on May 1.
Mr. Dole's move could not have come as a total surprise to the Administration, because it largely repeated the language of a similar Dole initiative that passed the Senate in August. But it complicates Administration efforts to assure the allies that Washington will not unilaterally allow the sale of arms to the Bosnian Government.
Although the Administration stopped enforcing the embargo, it has opposed violating it on its own, arguing that such a move would set a precedent for other countries to ignore United Nations resolutions and would widen the war.
In denouncing the move, the State Department spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said, "If you take on the unilateral responsibility of lifting the arms embargo, the United States would also unilaterally take on the consequences of that action, and that would include, in our view as a moral responsibility, the arming, training and equipping of the Bosnian Muslims who would have to defend themselves." Another consequence, he said, would be to legitimize Iran's shipment of weapons to the Muslims in Bosnia.
Today's bill confounded the Administration because it would allow the United States to send arms to the Bosnian Government in violation of the United Nations embargo, but would prohibit the United States from sending ground troops to deliver the arms or train the Bosnians in how to use them.
"How that could be achieved without massive use of U.S. force unilaterally, and very, very likely the introduction of U.S. ground troops, is a question that someone I hope will pose to Senator Dole," Mr. McCurry told reporters.
Mr. Dole also proposed a "Post-Cold War Powers Act" that would redesign and restrict the American contribution to the financing of United Nations peacekeeping operations and place strict limits on allowing American troops to serve under United Nations command.
It would require the Administration to identify specific budget sources of financing before it votes to create or extend a peacekeeping mission, and under a complicated formula, would allow the Pentagon to charge the United Nations for much of the equipment and services it now provides for free.
The bill would also set a maximum of 25 percent for the United States share of the total United Nations peacekeeping budget, down from the current share of 31 percent. That goal is shared by the Administration as well.
Mr. Dole's proposal would also eliminate all but two sections of the War Powers Resolution, apparently in an effort to increase the authority of a President to keep combat troops abroad without explicit approval from Congress and to trim the law to its least sensitive provisions.
As the Vietnam War was nearing its end in 1973, Congress enacted the law in an effort to reassert its authority while not compromising a President's need to act quickly. The law requires a President to notify Congress in a timely fashion when American troops are being sent abroad with a strong probability that they will engage in combat. The troops must be withdrawn within 90 days unless Congress explicitly approves their mission.
But the law has proved largely ineffective because of Presidential resistance, and because Congress is usually willing to let the White House assume the political risk of sending troops abroad. In practice, Presidents have consulted with Congress about sending troops abroad but have rejected the part of the law that requires them to bring troops home unless they are given Congressional approval. Mr. Dole's proposal would bring the law into line with that practice.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK'S NEW GOVERNOR: THE OVERVIEW;
PATAKI PROMISES A REDUCED BUDGET AND LOWER TAXES

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Emphasizing his pledge to reduce the size of state government, Gov. George E. Pataki promised today in his first address to the Legislature to propose a budget for the coming year that would spend less than the state will spend this year.
In his 45-minute State of the State address, Mr. Pataki, the first Republican Governor in 20 years, also rededicated himself to cutting state income taxes by 25 percent over four years. And he announced that he would sign an executive order declaring a moratorium on new state regulations, except those needed to protect public health and safety or to promote job creation. 
 "Members of the Legislature, we begin here today by acknowledging a simple fact: The government of New York is too big and it spends too much money," Mr. Pataki said, looking out on an Assembly chamber packed with lawmakers and dignitaries. "Today, and in the foreseeable future, we must and we will cut spending, and then cut it again." [Excerpts, page B6.]
The new Governor, the first chief executive to come directly from the Legislature since 1855, used his speech to reach out to his former colleagues, urging them to join him in building a bipartisan partnership. In contrast to former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who often addressed the legislators caustically, once even referring to them as "monkeys," Mr. Pataki said that lawmaking was "an honorable endeavor." [Analysis, page B7.]
He paid tribute to the leaders of both houses by name, and paid a special welcome to Assemblyman Jay J. Dinga, a freshman Republican from Broome County who was sitting in the brown leather chair that Mr. Pataki occupied during his eight years in the Assembly.
"The difference, I guess, from Mario Cuomo to George Pataki, was clearly that he had a deep respect for the Legislature," said the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat who more than anyone else can stand in the way of the Governor's proposals.
But Mr. Pataki also pointedly warned the lawmakers that he would take drastic action if they continued their 10-year tradition of failing to pass a budget by April 1, the start of the fiscal year. Should the legislators fail to pass a budget on time, the Governor said, he would refuse to send them the emergency appropriation bills that would be needed to keep government functioning. "You won't be paid, and neither will I," he said.
Mr. Pataki also reminded the leaders of the Democratic-controlled Assembly that he plans to lobby Democratic lawmakers individually to support his fiscal proposals. In an effort to break Albany's tradition of party-line voting, Mr. Pataki has said that if he cannot forge a consensus with Mr. Silver, he will not hesitate to try to build a majority in that 150-member House by persuading 20 Democrats to join the 56 Republicans. The Senate has a Republican majority that broadly supports Mr. Pataki's initiatives.
In another overture to the Legislature, Mr. Pataki stepped back from his campaign call for term limits on both lawmakers and statewide officials.
"I understand your natural reluctance to pass a constitutional amendment that would impose term limits on the State Legislature, so let's start with me," he said. "Let's enact first passage of a constitutional amendment that would limit the governor, lieutenant governor, comptroller and attorney general to two consecutive terms."
The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican from Rensselaer County who had announced his opposition to term limits only four days ago, said he could live with the new proposal. "I think there's a big distinction because the people can get at us and are closer to us and we to them," he said, referring to the Legislature.
Mr. Silver said he would consider the proposal, but said that in principle, he remains opposed to term limits.
Mr. Pataki's proposal to cut spending below this year's level is an alien notion in a town where spending increased during the 12 years of the Cuomo administration by an average of nearly 7 percent a year. State budget officials said the last Governor to propose a real cut in spending was Thomas E. Dewey in 1943, and the Legislature that year enacted a budget that was smaller than in 1942.
While Mr. Cuomo never proposed a cut in spending, the state ended up spending less in one of his years, 1991, than it had the year before. That is because the recession dried up state revenues, forcing the Governor and Legislature to slash state spending in the middle of the fiscal year in order to balance the budget.
Mr. Pataki's proposal is similar to that made last year by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who did not travel to Albany today to hear Mr. Pataki's speech. The Mayor used the honeymoon of his first year in office to persuade the City Council to enact a budget that cut city spending for the first time in 16 years.
Officials in the Pataki administration and the Legislature said they could not yet estimate how much they would have to cut to eliminate the annual growth that results from inflation and factors like increased school attendance and health care costs. But Mr. Pataki has said that he must find nearly $5 billion in savings to balance next year's budget and to pay for $1 billion in proposed tax cuts. The state's general fund budget this year is $34 billion.
Mr. Pataki has said he will consider an array of spending cuts, including layoffs of state workers, restrictions on Medicaid benefits and the elimination and consolidation of state agencies. He is scheduled to present his budget proposal to the Legislature on Feb. 1.
He offered few details about his plans today, and those he disclosed would save relatively small sums. He said, for instance, that he would propose eliminating the State Energy Office, which has 214 employees and a budget of $17 million, and the Commission on Cable Television, which has 60 employees and a budget of $4.5 million.
He also suggested merging several economic development authorities into one and consolidating several construction financing agencies. But his office could not estimate the savings that would be produced by those moves.
Mr. Pataki did not mention environmental protection or children's issues at any point during the speech. But he repeated his campaign pledges to sign the death penalty into law, to end parole for violent felons, to end work release for dangerous convicts and to enact mandatory sentences for crimes committed with deadly weapons.
He reiterated his support for welfare programs that require able-bodied recipients to work and that cut benefits for parents whose children fail to attend school.
On education policy, he proposed setting a statewide election day for voting for local school board members and approving school budgets, a move intended to increase voter turnout. And he called for abolishing the Board of Regents, a proposal that would require a constitutional amendment and that has little support in the Legislature, which appoints the regents.

HEADLINE: Warning for Brazil in Mexican Crisis

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Jan. 3

 BODY:
After Mexico, what major Latin country has an overvalued currency, a growing appetite for imports and a new president?
Brazil. 
 "Mexico is a warning to Brazilians not to play around with an overvalued exchange rate," said Ernane Galveas, who served as Finance Minister in the early 1980's. "We are frittering away the export surpluses we built up during the 1980's."
Surging imports, a dwindling trade surplus and nervousness over Mexico's rocky peso devaluation could test the financial policies of Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who was inaugurated on Sunday as Brazil's new President. But some trade experts argue that the similarities are superficial. Brazil is in far better shape, they say, to absorb foreign goods and add that many of the products arriving in the country presage business growth.
Armed with a stronger new currency, the real, and aided by far fewer import restrictions, Brazilians doubled their monthly imports this year. In November, Brazil recorded its first monthly trade deficit since 1987 and its largest since 1980.
The import boom here is evident on supermarket shelves stocked with American products like Smucker's jam, Budweiser beer, Heinz mustard and Wella shampoo.
Flush with the nation's first strong currency in years, so many Brazilians flocked to duty-free border shops in neighboring Paraguay over the Christmas season that the authorities opened a private service road across the world's largest dam, at Itaipu, to relieve the congestion of tour buses. On one Saturday last month, 2,300 Brazilian buses laid siege to Ciudad del Este, a border town.
Over all, Brazil finished 1994 with an $11 billion trade surplus. But economists predict that this surplus will drop by more than half this year. Factoring in Brazil's foreign debt payments and remittances, the nation's current-account deficit -- the difference between what is taken in from exports, plus new net investment, and what is paid for imports and interest on foreign debt -- is expected to climb to $10 billion this year from $1 billion in 1994.
As recently as the early 1990's, Brazil was in the opposite situation. It had the world's third-largest trade surplus, after Japan and Germany.
But some trade experts say Brazil is far less vulnerable to a crisis because, in contrast to Mexico, its economy is both larger and stronger. "Brazil's current-account deficit is less than 2 percent of G.N.P. -- and that is easily financed by external borrowing," said Alden Brewster, a New York partner of Banco Icatu, a Brazilian investment bank.
In Mexico, where the trade deficit ballooned to $30 billion, authorities were forced to devalue the peso, and the new President, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, has imposed austerity measures. Brazil, on the other hand, has sufficient reserves to cover 16 months of imports, which leaves room to maneuver.
Brazil is a huge export market to Americans. According to a recent survey by Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, 77 percent of American international trade executives surveyed cited Brazil as offering the best trade opportunities in Central and South America. This year, Brazil displaced Venezuela as Florida's largest export destination.
"Brazil ranks as one of the highest priorities we have for deepening trade relations with the big emerging markets," Jeffrey E. Garten, United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said by telephone from Washington. "We are determined to develop the commercial ties way beyond what they have been in recent decades."
Mr. Garten is scheduled to visit here in February, and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown in March. Later this year, the Commerce Department will bring to Brazil American executives from companies in telecommunications, transportation, power generating and environmental technology.
Air cargo traffic from the United States to Brazil has jumped by 50 percent since July 1, when Brazil adopted an anti-inflation effort known as the Real Plan.
With a two-week backlog for air cargo at Miami, Emery Worldwide has started chartering wide-body planes to meet Brazilian demand. In Europe, Lufthansa customers face a one-month wait to ship cargo from Frankfurt to Sao Paulo.
At Sao Paulo's international airport, imported cargo awaiting customs clearance is stacked under tarpaulins or in inflatable warehouses.
To ease the entry of foreign goods, Brazilian authorities plan in April to abolish an import-permit system in place since 1948. Over the last 15 years, the Government has abolished an index of 3,000 imported products that had been barred because they threatened Brazilian industries. It has cut the average import duty to 12 percent from 88 percent. "Until recently, Brazil was as closed as Albania or Tibet," Veja, a weekly magazine, said of Government efforts to reduce nontariff barriers.
The flood of imports last year provoked a dozen investigations by Brazil's Industry and Trade Ministry, which is trying to determine if goods like American cotton, Chinese fans and Korean textiles were sold here at unrealistically low prices. Dozens of Brazilian textile producers have gone bankrupt. Hobbled by a strong currency, many shoe manufacturers are directing production away from exports to the home market.
The blow of increasing imports has been cushioned by the boom in Brazil's broad economy. Industrial growth was 6.4 percent in 1994, one of the highest levels since the early 1970's.
Although auto imports hit 190,000 last year, almost triple the level of 1993, Brazilian car manufacturers muted their complaints because they operated at near capacity, producing a record 1.7 million cars. And domestic toy production was up 18 percent this Christmas, even though foreign toy companies took 10 percent of the Brazilian market.
And though the volume of Christmas sales jumped by 50 percent last month, Brazil's monthly inflation rate dropped to 2 percent in December.
"It's a real mistake to just look at trade figures and say that something has gone wrong," Mr. Garten of the Commerce Department said. "The imports will help in the anti-inflation fight. The capital equipment will help with future growth."
In fact, oil, raw materials and machinery and factory equipment account for 75 percent of Brazil's imports.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Cleaning the environment gets harder, but there are solutions.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
CLEANER is better -- but at what price? Last month, 31 counties in New York and Pennsylvania backed away from a voluntary commitment to reduce smog by burning a more expensive blend of gasoline in privately owned cars. And while small acts of resistance do not make a counterrevolution, the message can be ignored only at environmentalists' peril.
For two decades Washington has been basing policy on the conventional wisdom that Americans will happily pay to make it safe for anyone to drink the water and breathe the air anywhere in the country. But now that the easy cleanup battles have been won -- and politicians without ties to the environmental lobbies dominate Congress -- the assumption is sure to be questioned. 
 And in the view of Paul Portney of Resources for the Future, not a moment too soon: The alternative to a rethinking of the basics, he believes, is a piecemeal rebellion against Big Green. If costs are not weighed against benefits, argues Mr. Portney, the vice president of the Washington-based environmental research group, "we are in danger of losing the whole kit and caboodle."
The reformulated gasoline story is only a straw in the political wind, but an instructive one. As of this week, drivers in nine cities (including New York and Philadelphia) were required to switch to a fuel blend that cuts emissions of toxic chemicals and carbon monoxide as well as the "volatile hydrocarbons" that are precursors to ozone smog. Places with lesser smog problems were given the option of making the switch, too, and many did. But when prices started going up at the pump (by roughly a dime a gallon), three counties in New York and 28 in Pennsylvania petitioned Washington for a reprieve.
This is not a simple tale of the victory of populist common sense over environmental elitism. Counties that opted out of reformulated gasoline will generally have to find some means of reducing emissions. And Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, estimates that the "first phase" gasoline blend mandated for 1995 is more cost-effective than many of the alternatives. But it does suggest that Americans are no longer lining up to pay the bill for any environmental service rendered.
By the same token, notes Tom Lareau, an economist at the American Petroleum Institute, motorists are resisting tougher pollution inspection programs -- especially ones that require testing in one place and repair in another. And the politics of ozone containment are likely to get a lot rougher, as states require auto companies to sell expensive, inconvenient electric vehicles.
How might Congress defuse the backlash without rolling back a generation of achievement?
REQUIRE COST ANALYSIS. Five major environmental acts, including those setting standards for air, water and toxic waste, actually prohibit regulators from weighing costs against benefits -- the legacy, notes Robert Stavins, an economist at Harvard, of Democrats' suspicion that Republicans would sabotage environmental regulation.
Mr. Portney argues that the new crowd could (and should) undo those prohibitions, allowing agencies to consider cost in setting regulations. "It's the big enchilada of environmental reform," Mr. Portney says, one giving regulators the flexibility to bend without breaking.
PERMIT VARIABLE STANDARDS. Under Federal law, New York must someday be as clean as Boise. But these uniform standards are "a fiction," Mr. Hahn argues: when the crunch comes, onerous requirements are postponed.
That informal process breeds cynicism, however, and creates enormous headaches for businesses that must plan pollution-control investments years in advance. Mr. Hahn would permit "local solutions to local problems," giving, say, Southern California the option of setting a lower standard for ozone. This may mean that the small minority most seriously at risk would be forced to live elsewhere. But loss of the entitlement might be worth the social price -- especially since few believe the entitlement will ever be honored.
James Krier of the University of Michigan Law School offers a variation on the theme, redefining "uniform" to apply to antipollution effort rather than result. Los Angeles, for example, might be required only to spend as much per resident on cleanup regulation as the national average.
EXPLOIT MARKET INCENTIVES. Every environmental regulator now talks the talk of free markets, but relatively few walk the walk. In the case of ozone, for example, state regulators have ignored the option of letting polluters pay others to reduce emissions. And that failure, Mr. Hahn estimates, could raise the cost of compliance in the Northeast by tens of billions of dollars a year.
Congress might require regulators to consider market solutions to antipollution mandates, the way the law now requires localities to estimate the environmental impact of new highways. It wouldn't assure least-cost results, but it would give markets a chance to solve problems that government cannot solve efficiently.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Decline Sharply On Interest Rate Concerns

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold prices fell to their lowest levels in eight months yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve would soon push up interest rates to keep inflation in check.
Other precious metals followed, extending the steep losses posted on Tuesday. Gold and other precious metals are seen as hedges against inflation. 
 Still, the Commodity Research Bureau's index rose 0.46 point, to 235.22, pulled up in part by sharp rises in cotton, cocoa and sugar futures.
Gold has fallen nearly 6 percent from its 12-month high in October, including a drop of 2 percent in the last two days.
Yesterday, gold for February delivery fell $5.60 an ounce, to $375.30, on the Commodity Exchange in New York, the lowest price for an active near-term futures contract since May 5.
Also on the Commodity Exchange, March silver tumbled 12.7 cents an ounce, to $4.635. April platinum fell $10.10 an ounce, to $405.70, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Many traders expect the Federal Reserve to increase short-term interest rates at its policy-making meeting at the end of the month to dampen inflationary pressures. Such a move would reduce investment demand for precious metals and could also slow industrial demand for metals.
"Investor psychology is that they believe monetary authorities are intent on restraining inflation," a commodities analyst for Paine Webber Inc. in New York, Bernard Savaiko, said. "There's really little incentive to hold metals in this climate."
David Rinehimer of Smith Barney Inc. said precious metals usually declined in the first quarter, following the Christmas spike in jewelry demand. But he said the magnitude of this week's drop was unusual.
On other commodity markets, cotton futures rose in anticipations of increased demand from Pakistan and India. March cotton gained 1.77 cents, to 90.12 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.

HEADLINE: French Brace For Violence From Algeria

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Bracing for new reprisals for the deaths of four Algerian militants who hijacked a French airliner to Marseilles late last month, France has stepped up surveillance of Islamic groups in France and canceled Air France flights to and from Algeria.
Foreign Minister Alain Juppe said today that France would also send a team of experts to Algeria to improve security for the dwindling community of French oil workers, business executives, missionaries and diplomats still living in the convulsed former French colony. 
 He acknowledged that there are conflicting reports whether Islamic militants planned to carry their war against Algeria's military Government onto French soil, but he noted, "On French territory, the Government is determined -- we will not let terrorism rot our society."
The Armed Islamic Group, which took credit for the hijacking, has until now focused on driving foreigners out of Algeria. In the last 16 months, it has killed 80 foreigners, including four Catholic priests last week to avenge the killing of the hijackers by French commandos.
The United States, France, Britain, Germany and several other Western governments have received letters at their embassies in Bern, Switzerland, supposedly signed by the Armed Islamic Group, setting a Jan. 7 deadline to close their embassies in Algiers. After that, it said, "all infidels will be killed in cold blood."
In Washington, the State Department confirmed that the American Embassy had received such a letter but could not vouch for its authenticity. "But obviously," said the spokesman, Michael McCurry, "we take threats like that seriously." He added that security in Alergia had been a concern for some time and that the embassy staff there had been reduced "to a level that we consider appropriate."
A different group, the Islamic Salvation Army, reportedly declared war on France in a statement last weekend. Later, it denied mentioning "taking the war to France," but claimed the right to do so.
France endorsed the Algerian Government's decision in December 1991 to cancel a second round of parliamentary elections that seemed likely to bring the broad-based Islamic Salvation Front to power. Since then, France has provided the Algerian Government with weapons, helicopters and extensive economic aid.
. Reports from Algiers today said Algeria's former governing party, the National Liberation Front, had held talks with two leaders from the front, Abassi Madani and Ali Belhadj, who are currently under house arrest. A spokesman for the front, Brahim Younessi, told a French daily Tuesday that the front had no interest in spreading the conflict to France or anywhere else in Europe. But with memories still fresh of a bombing campaign carried out by pro-Iranian Islamic groups in Paris in 1986, France is taking no chances, tightening security along its borders and renewing appeals for Britain and Germany to clamp down on Islamic militants on their soil.
French assertions that militants are using Britain as a base were reinforced last weekend when The Sunday Times of London reported that Britain's internal security service, M.I.5, believed the Armed Islamic Group was using mosques in Britain to raise money to buy weapons for its war in Algeria.
The report also said M.I.5 had identified 20 "hard-core activists," some of whom had traveled to Algeria to carry out killings before returning to London. Last weekend, French newspapers reported that three Islamic militants had arrived from Britain by ferry and were being urgently sought by the French police.
The French police, who last year carried out several raids on Islamic militant hideouts in France and subsequently deported 25 alleged militants, are reportedly convinced that strong ties still exist between the Algerian rebels and the 800,000 Algerians in France.
Last week, the French Justice Ministry ordered an investigating magistrate to establish whether the hijackers of the Air France airliner last month had any accomplices in France.
In an interview with the daily newspaper Liberation, a crew member of the hijacked plane, identified only as Claude, gave the first detailed account of the 54-hour hijacking that ended when French commandos freed the 159 passengers and 12 crew members who were still on board. French Government officials later said the militants planned to blow up the aircraft over Paris.
She said two hostages were killed without warning. The third victim, a young French embassy employee, was killed when the Algerian authorities refused to allow the plane to leave for France.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Reach a Six-Year High

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Despite repeated interest rate increases last year, automobile makers today reported substantial sales gains for both cars and trucks.
The final industry figures will not be available until Thursday, but analysts said the results from the Chrysler Corporation and most Japanese auto makers indicated that the industry achieved its best sales performance in six years. 
 "It's the best total light-vehicle sales year since 1988, when they sold 15.4 million vehicles," said Michael Luckey of the Luckey Consulting Group.
When all the figures are in, he said, the industry's total should be 15 million to 15.1 million vehicles, up from 13.9 million in 1993. The General Motors Corporation's report was delayed by data gathering problems, and the Ford Motor Company elected to wait until Thursday to disclose its figures.
Chrysler, the nation's No. 3 auto maker, said it sold 2.2 million cars and trucks in 1994, up 8 percent from 1993. Once again, sales of pickup trucks, mini-vans and Jeeps led the way, rising 15 percent in 1994, while sales of passenger cars slipped 3 percent.
Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, Robert J. Eaton, speaking to reporters at the North American International Auto Show here, said 1994 marked the most profitable year in the company's 69-year history. The company said on Tuesday that it generated enough cash last year to wipe out its pension debt and pay hourly workers bonuses averaging almost $7,500 each.
"We won't have final financial numbers for about two weeks, but if you can add, you know it will be a record year," Mr. Eaton said.
Through the first nine months of 1994, Chrysler earned $2.5 billion, surpassing the previous full-year profit of $2.4 billion, set in 1984.
Industry analysts estimate that the company's 1994 profits will be $3.6 billion, in contrast to a loss of $2.55 billion in 1993, when the company had a one-time accounting charge of $5 billion.
Many auto executives and analysts predict that sales of new cars and trucks could reach a new record this year or next, as consumer confidence is pushed up by the economic recovery.
"Consumer confidence is excellent right now," said John G. Middlebrook, general manager of G.M.'s Pontiac division. "Obviously a continued racheting up of interest rates is going to slow our business, but with the capacity situation we're in now, slow growth is what we want, and I think it takes some of those interest rates to assure that."
Ford's chairman, Alexander J. Trotman, speaking with reporters at the auto show on Tuesday, said, "It's in the cards" that it could be a record in 1995 and 1996.
United States auto sales peaked at 16.3 million vehicles in 1986, the last year the Federal Government allowed consumers to take an income tax deduction for interest payments on auto loans.
"I think this year we broke the record for breaking records," Chrysler's executive vice president for sales and marketing, Theodor R. Cunningham, said. "It was our best year ever for mini-vans -- despite growing competition -- best year ever for Dodge Truck, best year ever for Jeep and for the Jeep-Eagle Division, and the list goes on."
Mr. Eaton of Chrysler said the record 1994 profits enabled the auto maker to fully finance its pension plan for the first time since 1957 and pay bonuses averaging nearly two months' salary to each employee.
Last year Chrysler paid more than $279.5 million in bonuses, with the average check coming to $4,300, the largest bonus in the history of the United States auto industry.
Among the big Japanese auto makers, the Nissan Motor Company reported the biggest yearly increase, with total car and truck sales rising 12.6 percent in 1994. The Honda Motor Company was next, with gains of 10 percent, while Japan's largest auto maker, the Toyota Motor Corporation, posted an increase of 5.3 percent last year.
Honda said it sold 367,615 Accord models in the United States last year. That makes it virtually certain that Ford's Taurus sedan, which has been America's best-selling car since 1992, will retain the title for 1994. Through November, Ford had sold 354,839 Taurus models, meaning it needed to sell only about 13,000 cars in December to win the annual sales race. Ford usually sells about 32,000 Taurus cars a month.

HEADLINE: Peace Program Is in Danger, Salvadorans Tell the U.N.'s Chief

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 4

 BODY:
El Salvador's program of reconstruction and reconciliation is short $137 million and in danger of losing momentum in its critical last phase, the country's Vice President and leading members of the former rebel army told Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali today.
"Peace is not enough," the Vice President, Enrique Borgo Bustamante, said Tuesday. "We need social peace. We need to remake whatever was Salvador. We need to walk that last part of the road, and we feel so short of breath." 
 He spoke in a joint interview with Salvador Sanchez Ceren, secretary general of the former rebel group, the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. The front is now a political party in opposition, but is split by internal differences.
The United Nations has been formally involved since 1991 in a comprehensive plan to restore peace and rebuild an economy destroyed by a 12-year civil war.
Two years ago this month, the Secretary General presided over the signing of a peace treaty in Mexico City, followed by the establishment of a recovery fund of more than $1.5 billion. Two-thirds of this was pledged by the Salvadoran Government and the rest raised by assessment of United Nations members.
Government officials say they cannot provide any more money without levying new taxes or cutting into social programs like education and health.
United Nations peacekeeping officials hold up the Salvadoran accord as one of the organization's post-cold-war success stories. The accord covers a wide range of activities, from human rights accounting to restructuring the military and redistributing land.
The Bush Administration, which played a leading part in bringing the Salvadoran Government to the negotiating table, encouraged the United Nations to take the lead in the peace effort. United Nations involvement would end on April 30 of this year, a final extension of a Security Council mandate that was to expire on Nov. 30, 1994.
Both Vice President Borgo and Mr. Sanchez said that the process of disarming the national police and creating a new integrated force had perhaps done the most to rebuild the confidence of Salvadorans on both sides of the conflict.
Under an international team of advisers, the formation of the new National Civil Police was completed at the end of last month, ahead of schedule. The police officers are being trained in a two-year-old professional National Public Security Academy.
"The political parties have also agreed on a new Supreme Court," Mr. Borgo said. "They are trying to evaluate all the judges and get rid of those not doing their work. The 15 members were elected by the Congress, representing all the political parties in Salvador."
Both sides are concerned that impatience and the appearance of foot-dragging could lead the country into a renewed crisis.
A large number of former rebels, their supporters, government soldiers and others displaced by war have still not been resettled. Of the 41,000 people for whom land had to be found, 15,000 are still without new homes. Others complain that the land they have been given is unproductive or otherwise unsuitable.
In October, when Mr. Boutros-Ghali asked that the mandate of the United Nations mission be extended, he listed other tasks still to be completed. These included the carrying out of recommendations by the commission set up to look into human rights crimes committed during the war years.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: THE PRESIDENT;
Far From Capitol's Din, A Hero at Clinton School

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 4

 BODY:
The library is named for his wife. The recreation room is named for his mother. But the whole shebang is named for him, and if President Clinton was not the tallest timber in Washington today, he was a proud bastion of beige concrete block and shiny new linoleum at the William Jefferson Clinton Elementary Magnet School.
As the new Newtonian era dawned in Washington, Mr. Clinton was out among the people who helped him get there in the first place as he dedicated the school in the suburban community of Sherwood this morning. In doing so, he once again styled himself as the determined outsider intent on grappling with the nation's problems, even in the face of a Republican Congress abuzz with big, bold notions. 
 "I'm going back to challenge the Congress to do what is necessary to guarantee the future of the next generation of Americans," Mr. Clinton told an ebullient audience of more than 600 students, teachers and local officials in the school's "cafetorium."
"Anybody can come up and say, 'I want to give you a tax cut,' and make people happy in the short run," he said. "What I want to do is reduce taxes for people to invest in the education of their children and their own training and skills, so we can go forward and grow this economy."
Mr. Clinton worked as Governor of Arkansas to improve education, and he used the dedication ceremony to paint his Presidency as a continuation of such efforts, and to make a renewed pitch for his proposed "Middle Class Bill of Rights" of tax deductions for college and technical education. He also suggested that reports of his political demise were greatly exaggerated.
"You know, I was apprehensive when I heard that you were going to name this school after me," said the President, who was winding up a 48-hour vacation here. "Most people don't have a school named after them until they're not around anymore. And here I am, apparently healthy and able to enjoy it."
Incumbent Presidents from Harry S. Truman to Ronald Reagan have fled the White House for Main Street when their administrations were becalmed or floundering. Mr. Reagan went around the country for months in the summer of 1987 touting his "Economic Bill of Rights" of Republican free-market ideas to help repair the damage of the Iran-contra affair and stabilize himself for new ventures in foreign diplomacy.
"It sounds like the President's returning to the campaign mode that was successful for him in the past," Marlin Fitzwater, who was press secretary for Mr. Reagan and George Bush, said in a telephone interview. "It is what he does best, the town meeting, the moving around the country, the talking with groups informally. A lot of people would say he's never done as well since he was inaugurated as he did in the campaign."
White House aides dismiss suggestions that they are gearing up for the 1996 campaign, but also acknowledge that the President intends to get out into the country, where he can still be an automatic star in local news media markets, instead of an "also said" on the national stage.
Next Tuesday, he is likely to visit Galesburg, Ill., the birthplace of the poet Carl Sandburg, to press his proposed tax breaks, including a credit of up to $500 per child for families with adjusted gross incomes of up to $75,000 a year. He may also stop in Cleveland, Atlanta and California in the next two weeks.
"He did something today that was very important to him personally," said Ginny Terzano, the deputy White House press secretary traveling with him. "As Governor, he made a lot of progress to improve education, not only at the state but at the national level. In his remarks today, he made really clear that we have a lot to do, and whether you say that in Arkansas or Washington, the message is clear."
The tone of the day was set by the school choir's rendition of the state song, whose final chorus is: "Oh, I may wander, but when I do, I will never be far from you. You're in my blood and you'll always be. Arkansas, you run deep in me."
As the First Lady of Arkansas, Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary, helped foster the creation of interracial magnet schools like Clinton Elementary, which is intended to draw diverse students by offering special programs. Its library is the "Hillary Rodham Clinton Media Center," and another room, the "Virginia Kelley Multi-Purpose Center," is named for the President's mother, who died a year ago. Down the hall is the "Clinton Room," a glassed-in cubicle with a display of campaign and personal artifacts, including a scrap of pink-rose wallpaper from his boyhood home in Hope.
Before the dedication, the Clintons met with student representatives in the library, one of whom asked the President how he coped with criticism. He answered with Benjamin Franklin's maxim, "Our critics are our friends, for they show us our faults."
"But it's important not to take criticism personally," he said. "That is, a lot of times people try to hurt you personally, and you can't let that happen. So if someone criticizes you, ask yourself, 'Is it true what they're saying?' And if it's true, then say, 'Well, I'm going to try to improve, I'm going to try to do better."'

GRAPHIC: Photo: As a political storm raged in Washington, all was calm in Arkansas, where President Clinton arrived yesterday for the dedication of the William Jefferson Clinton Elementary Magnet School in Sherwood, Ark. On hand to greet him was Ryan Montgomery, a prekindergarten student. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: NEW YORK'S NEW GOVERNOR;
'A New Era': Excerpts From the State of the State

 BODY:
Following are excepts from Gov. George E. Pataki's State of the State message yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The agenda of reform and renewal that I will put forward is specific and extensive. It sets out clear priorities but let me also say it's not meant as a list of everything that we will try to accomplish together in 1995. I know there is much to do; that each and every lawmaker here has ideas worthy of attention by this Legislature and by this administration. 
 This is a new era, a new beginning in which bipartisanship and participation together can make a difference in the future of New York State.
Today, I want you to know that our administration looks forward to working closely with the Legislature, that I consider bipartisanship a two-way street.
And I especially want you to know that -- because, for me, friends always stay friends -- the door to this Governor's office is always open to each and every one of you.
But we also have to point out that under our democratic system our first duty must be to keep faith with the people of this state.
Assembly Speaker Shelly Silver, you have a proven record of putting principle ahead of politics. Shelly, you're a good leader and a good friend, and I look forward to working with you to meet together the challenges we must face.
And Joe Bruno, my good friend and the new Senate majority leader, Joe, you've been the source of wise counsel to me often in the past. Just as I've sought your help then, I'm sure I will rely on you time and again in the future. Thank you, Joe.
In recent elections, the people have shown themselves not only willing to make change, but to go right on making changes until those of us elected to office get it right.
What I said a few days ago I repeat today: the people have called for smaller, more effective, more efficient government. We must not fail to give them the change they seek. Let us get it right.
The agenda I am putting before you today is one that seeks change that is immediate and real, sweeping and fundamental, the kind of change the people have demanded of us. The people are waiting and watching. They have demanded change. They expect action. Starting here, starting today, we must give them both.
The challenges we face are great, the budget deficit is approaching $5 billion -- a deficit the magnitude of which we did not learn until only a few short days ago.
Now, as many of you know here, I've long been one who's argued for realism and openness in the budget process and I'll admit that in one sense I was finally glad to see that we got the facts. But while I appreciate the candor about the size of the deficit, I've got to tell you I also feel a little bit like John Jacob Astor, a passenger on the Titanic who remarked shortly after the iceberg struck: "I asked for ice, but this is ridiculous."
Surely, the size of this deficit is a crisis, a crisis as I've stated before not of the people's making but of government's, and what government has done, government can undo.

 	 	 		. . .	 	From the time I present the Executive Budget message on [Feb. 1] to the start of the new fiscal year on April 1st, we have two brief months to complete our work. Meeting the April budget deadline is essential.
That's why today I am asking you to approve budget bills by early March, to have full and public debate in the light of day as we move toward the April 1st deadline.
On this first point let me be clear: The practice of back-room budget making must end.
And when I talk about opening the budget process I mean not just to the press and the public, I mean opening it up to all lawmakers, to Rapp Rappleyea and the Assembly Republicans; to Marty Connor and the Senate Democrats. I know from personal experience what it was like. The quality of your ideas is not dependent on whether you are a Republican or a Democrat, whether you are a member of the majority or minority party. The people elected every legislator to speak for them here in Albany.
I believe an open budget process can help us meet the budget deadline and we must be on time. I want to put everyone in this great legislative hall on notice here and now: If the April 1st deadline is not met I will not initiate, nor will I approve legislation to provide interim appropriations for any state function except those that directly affect the health and safety of New Yorkers.
And that means that if we don't have the budget done on time there will be no emergency appropriations to pay the executive or the Legislature -- you won't be paid and neither will I.
The people are asked to take more responsibility for their actions; we must take more responsibility for our own. We must enact the budget on time.
Controller Carl McCall has publicly stated his views about the importance of an on-time budget and his belief that we must end the practice and abuse of temporary appropriations. I look forward to his support on this important issue.
By cutting spending and taxes we will create a smaller, more effective, more efficient government which will allow us to create a climate where individuals can excel and businesses can prosper. To protect personal freedom government must stop unnecessarily burdening individuals and families with massive taxes which stifle initiative, creativity and job production.
These dollars do not belong to the government. These dollars belong to the individuals who earned them. We will not so much be cutting taxes as protecting the people's right to keep the fruits of their own labors.
And as the first step towards the economic renewal of New York we must finally keep the income tax cut promise the Legislature made in 1987. Let me make another point very clear: I will veto any legislation that continues to break that tax cut promise by further delay.

 	 	 		. . .	 	And I don't think you're going to like this one a whole lot, but let me keep going.
As we empower the citizens of New York State, we must also encourage change by taking the first steps towards term limits for state officials. I expected the reaction I'm getting from most of you out here. Term limits will help create a government filled with new ideas and fresh perspectives. The time for term limits is at hand.
Now, I understand your natural reluctance to pass a constitutional amendment that would impose term limits on the State Legislature, so let's start with me. Let's enact first passage of a constitutional amendment that would limit the governor, lieutenant governor, comptroller and attorney general to two consecutive terms.
We got a few converts on that one.
It's worked in 29 other states; it can work here in New York.
I remember the day, 10 years ago, it was my first day as a member of this Assembly and I came up here with my wife, Libby, and -- Libby, I know you're somewhere in the back there and I just want to thank you and if you could just rise, for all you've done for me and for the people of this state. Now I'll be able to go home.
Ten years ago, when Libby and I did come up here, it was my first day as a member of the Assembly. And I sat here and I listened to the Governor deliver his State of the State message at that time. I sat in the seat back there where freshman Assemblyman Jay Dinga is sitting now. I felt privileged then and I feel privileged now to be a part of this great institution.
Today, let me say to Assemblyman Dinga and to all the new members of the Assembly and the Senate, the energy and the enthusiasm you feel today can and will only grow as you accept and meet the challenges of solving the problems of our state.
As my friends, those of you veterans in the Legislature -- Republicans and Democrats -- who have served with me know, you freshmen will come to share with us the deep respect for the job of lawmaker.
It is within this Legislature that the twin spirits of America's civic life -- freedom and responsibility -- live and prosper. A free people choose representatives to serve them in free and open elections. Grant those representatives the responsibility to serve the people's interests faithfully and to the best of their ability.
Every day, lawmakers here in Albany and across our nation work to reaffirm the faith of our founders. Within the democratic institutions of our nation and our state, legislators work day in and day out to fulfill the important responsibility of serving the public interest.
It is demanding, often gritty work. It is fiercely competitive among diverse interests. As our laws are made complex and conflicting elements are hammered into a new form through debate and negotiation.
It is an honorable endeavor.
The Legislature is a marketplace of ideas. It is a forum in which to achieve a fair balance among competing interests in the process of determining the public interest.
As public servants, we have a solemn duty to protect and to preserve personal freedom and restore individual responsibility, to create a more efficient, more effective government, a government that is smaller in size yet meets the essential needs of its people.
Working together, you and I can and must encourage individuals and families to build their futures here with a government that allows them the freedom to achieve, a government that gives them the opportunity to create jobs, a government that fosters tolerance, decency and hope.
It is a great challenge. It is a challenge we must meet. And together, as we meet this challenge, we will restore New York to the greatness that is its destiny.
Thank you and God bless you.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Governor Rowland's State of the State Address

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. John G. Rowland's State of the State address to the General Assembly.
Today is the moment to remake Connecticut as we rapidly approach the 21st century. Our challenge is to provide the hope and the opportunity, especially to our young people, so they will choose to make Connecticut their permanent home once again. 
 As a memorable figure in that legacy, let us together thank Governor Weicker for his distinguished service to Connecticut over more than three decades as a selectman, state legislator, U.S. Congressman, Senator and Governor. He has served us with distinction. . . .
For each generation of Connecticut, there are dreams and challenges. But lasting dreams don't come from a governor or even from a government. Real dreams spring from the hearts of individuals. They exist the first time a child sees his mother, and tries to make sense of the new world. Or when a father holds his child and looks at that miracle with wonder. . . .
In the upcoming budget address, I will discuss specific proposals that will serve to lead our state out of the stagnant status quo. But today, it's time to speak of the philosophy that animates this new administration. . . .
These are the goals of the Rowland-Rell administration: to see all our children educated to each child's maximum potential; to insure that our communities have more local control and parents can have some say as to where their children should go to school; to help our young, our elderly, our ill and our afflicted, when they need help and have no other resources; to make common cause with our neighbors, in that barn-raising spirit of our ancestors.
It's about a shared sense of decency that gives families on welfare an opportunity to make better lives for their children so that all of their neighbors and their children can live in dignity and with hope. It's about protecting the environment, both physical and economic, in a balanced fashion, so that parents have jobs and leave to their children a legacy of an even more beautiful Connecticut.
And it's about removing from our midst the predators who make our streets unsafe. The social compact of Connecticut is about an abiding sense of hope and security -- personal security, a feeling that it's once again safe to walk on our streets and through our neighborhoods. . . .
The State of Connecticut will not tolerate those who break the social compact. Those who break the social compact by hate crime or by street crime will be punished. Period. . . .
For every citizen of our state who's able to work, Connecticut is committed to fostering a climate where good jobs are always available. Real welfare reform will serve to enrich all individuals, but assistance does not mean treating adults as wards of the state. . . .
Connecticut cannot be a place where generations live and die on welfare, where a hand that was originally intended to help instead stifles and destroys the future. . . .
Unfortunately, we've become a state and a nation where individual dreams and initiatives are too often dislodged by government. From a nation of pioneers governed by heroes, we have become a nation of form filers, taxpayers who work in the midst of poverty and crime for nearly six months of every year just to pay for the very bureaucracies which send us the forms.
The state budget will be far leaner. We will help to provide services, but we'll do it smarter, we'll do it better, and we'll do it more economically. This administration will propose and vigorously pursue phasing out the income tax so that Connecticut's economy can again flourish. . . .
The team that seizes this time extends beyond those who take the oath of office today. It is more than the partisans of one party or another. . . .
It is a team that realizes that the bitter rancor of hard-fought elections is past. It is a team that realizes that everything which divides our state is a fraction of that which unites us. And it's a team that consists of all who wish to join us. . . .
One of Connecticut's greatest philosophers, who once lived here in Hartford, in a speech almost a century ago, Mark Twain, admonished young people: "Always do right," he said. "You will gratify some people and astonish the rest."
My friends, may we astonish the people of Connecticut with the quality of government in years to come.

HEADLINE: Stocks of Auto Makers Help to Lift Market

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
A brightening outlook for the automobile industry helped lift stock prices modestly yesterday in unusually heavy trading.
Long-term interest rates also eased in the bond market, the dollar strengthened, and gold fell to its lowest level in eight months. All are signs that gave the financial markets, at least for a day, reasons to be less concerned about inflation. 
 Whether the markets will continue in that consensus as the Jan. 31 policy-making meeting of the Federal Reserve approaches is an open question. The strength of the economy in the fourth quarter, the investment debacle by Orange County, Calif., and the Mexican economic difficulties could influence the deliberations since a rise in interest rates would slow the economy and increase the pain for Orange County and Mexico.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.17 points, to 3,857.65, primarily because of the performance by five stocks, including that of the General Motors Corporation. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.60 points, to 460.71, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 2.26 points, to 745.84.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above normal, with 319.5 million shares changing hands, about 10 percent more than the 1994 daily average of 290 million shares. It was the first time in seven sessions that trading was above average. Advancing stocks outpaced decliners by 1,414 to 949.
The rally in auto stocks was prompted by the Chrysler Corporation's announcement of strong monthly sales for cars and light trucks, with the best December in six years. The Ford Motor Corporation and General Motors are scheduled to release their figures today. Chrysler rose 1 7/8, to 50 7/8; G.M. rose 1 1/2, to 43 1/4, and Ford rose 3/4, to 28 5/8.
It is too early for the market to decide whether the Fed is finished raising interest rates. Some analysts believe that the move to auto stocks, considered a sector that does well in the early months of an expansion, could mean some traders believe the economy will be slowed but not choked by the Fed's previous rate increases.
Yet oil and energy stocks are thought to near their peak at the end of an economic cycle and a growing number of investment strategists have been recommending energy stocks.
Oil stocks also did well yesterday, with all companies in S.& P.'s oil group rising. The Mobil Corporation rose 1, to 85 1/8, close to the company's Oct. 31 peak of 87 1/8.
Shares of the Progress Software Corporation, a software developer, rose 2 3/4, to 40 1/8, after it said it planned to announce a new corporate strategy on Monday. Shares of the Dell Computer Corporation rose 2 3/8, to 42 1/4, after it said it had converted a line of computers to use the Intel Corporation's corrected Pentium chip.
Medex, a supplier of disposable hospital products, fell 3 3/8, to 10 3/8, after it said it anticipated lower-than-expected quarterly earnings. Recovery Engineering, a maker of water-purification equipment, fell 3, to 14 1/2, after it also said it expected quarterly earnings to be lower than analysts' estimates.
