HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Non-Token Appointees Mark Women's Advance

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
THE names were threaded through Gov. George E. Pataki's State of the State Message yesterday, the women in his government. He just mentioned their names and titles, said no more, but the message was not lost on his listeners, especially his Democratic listeners. "Look at all those women," a Democratic stalwart, who shall remain nameless at her request, fairly screeched into the telephone. "In real jobs. Look at that. Do you believe it?"
Mr. Pataki has indeed appointed a lot of women to prominent positions in his new administration -- most of them substantial jobs, not token ones or "women's" jobs. The budget director is a woman. The Health Commissioner is a woman. So is the Parks Commissioner, the communications director and the Social Services Commissioner. And of course Mr. Pataki's running mate, Elizabeth P. McCaughey, is now the Lieutenant Governor and designated Medicaid expert. 
 That is, by any measure, a large number of women, even slightly more than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo named to substantial jobs in his government at any one time. Maybe this should not come as a surprise. Mr. Pataki may be a committed feminist. It would have been hard to know that, though, because his campaign was so controlled that New Yorkers learned his views on few issues, except tax cutting and government shrinking.
It is a bit counterintuitive because the Democratic Party takes a rather proprietary interest in the women's movement, while Republicans sometimes sound hostile, letting their talk-show champions use words like "femi-Nazis" with impunity and suggesting that feminism and "family values" are warring concepts.
OF course, many Republicans favor the advancement of women; it was Ronald Reagan who named the first woman to the Supreme Court, Sandra Day O'Connor. But Democrats did take the lead in advancing opportunities for women, and here comes Mr. Pataki with his many appointments, and he is not the only one. It is as if the Democrats not only had Congress and a few statehouses taken away from them, but the potent issue of feminism, too. What happened?
Mr. Pataki's communications director, Zenia Mucha, did not respond to requests to discuss her boss's appointment philosophy. Ms. McCaughey, the Lieutenant Governor, says that, "As a very smart leader, George wants the best possible people working with him." Politics did not motivate him, she suggested.
Others guess otherwise.
"Part of it is a very strategic decision to give visibility to women that may pay off at the polls," said Harriett Woods, president of the National Women's Political Caucus. "That's fine with me. Great. I don't care. Whatever works. I guess what I'm saying is, in some strange way, it's sort of like Nixon opening up China. The Republicans may be more aggressive about bringing women in because that's not a constituency they've had, while Democrats have taken it for granted."
Another issue is timing. "Some of what we're seeing is generational," suggested Susan Estrich, a professor of law and political science at the University of Southern California, who ran Michael Dukakis's presidential campaign. "George Pataki is 49. He went to college with smart women, he's grown up around smart women, he's used to being around smart women."
AND there are more competent women in jobs outside the home. As Mr. Pataki is about to learn on other matters, change tends to be incremental in government, not revolutionary. The women's movement has been around for a generation, and at the same time, the economy pushed many women, feminists and nonfeminists, into jobs outside the home. Some have succeeded in government jobs, in Democratic and Republican administrations.
In other words, the most fundamental objective of the women's movement -- opening up opportunities to women -- must be working. Otherwise, how could Mr. Pataki, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and Gov. John M. Engler of Michigan, among others, find accomplished women to appoint?
"It proves how mainstream we've been all along in advocating that competent women should share the policy making in appointive as well as elective office," said Ms. Woods. "That is clearly not a very radical position when Republicans of all stripes are appointing women. It's a validation that there should be a level playing field."
It is also validation that politics works. "Nobody in politics is unaware that women vote, vote in very large numbers, and sometimes vote somewhat differently from men," said Ruth B. Mandel, longtime director of the Center for the American Woman and Politics at Rutgers University. "Politically it has become a matter of good practice and politics to include women in an administration."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
To build a young image, the Colombian coffee federation tries a campaign with bolder flavor.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
BEER, liquor and soft drinks are not, it turns out, the only beverages trying to establish more youthful images among consumers in their 20's and 30's. So, too, is coffee, through the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia, the world's largest individual coffee exporter.
The federation's purpose is to convince coffee drinkers that the estimated 1.85 billion pounds of arabica beans it exports annually, which are about 5 cents a pound more expensive than alternatives from other nations, are better tasting and therefore worth their premium price. And now it is also trying to create a revitalized, more contemporary image for its product. 
 The federation and DDB Needham Worldwide Marketing in New York, its longtime agency, could have embraced tactics that pandered to the intended audience. For instance, there might have been a Juan Valdez Jr., the goateed slacker son of the character who serves to symbolize Colombian beans in coffee advertising and on coffee packaging.
Instead, they are introducing a humorous campaign with a hipper, edgier attitude -- old coffee in new cups, if you will. The approach is telegraphed by the exuberant, exhortive theme: "Grab life by the beans." The television commercials and print advertisements, with an initial budget estimated at $4 million to $5 million, are meant to complement the long-running mainstream Valdez campaign, which continues to run separately.
"We're planning to have a lot of fun with that line and hope to make it stick as a concept," said Peter le Comte, president at DDB Needham Worldwide Marketing, an agency within the DDB Needham Worldwide agency in New York.
In addition to the campaign, he added, there will be promotional items emblazoned with the theme: T-shirts, posters, baseball caps and, needless to say, coffee mugs.
The goal is for the assertive "Grab life" line to supplement the Valdez character, who still "enjoys fabulous recognition and very positive image associations" after 35 years, Mr. le Comte said.
"But we thought maybe we ought to do something a little more jazzy, to capture the attention of younger audiences, than the same stuff their parents watched," he added. The target market is consumers ages 18 or 21 to 34 -- "before their midlife crises," he joked.
That demographic group "was previously ignored by us," Mr. le Comte said, "because they didn't represent good economic prospects" -- that is, if they drank coffee at all, it was less expensive brands than those bearing the Valdez logo to indicate they are made with 100 percent Colombian beans.
This is not the first attempt at altering coffee's older, stodgier image. Perhaps the best-known previous example was a campaign created in 1983 by Advertising to Women that urged young adults to "Join the coffee achievers."
But now the timing seems better, as anyone who has noticed the crowds of 20- and 30-somethings congregating in coffee bars, coffee houses and coffee cafes might have deduced.
"In the last few years, there has been a movement of younger people to drink coffee, particularly specialty coffees," said Salim Janna, managing director at the Colombian coffee federation in New York.
"The end result is benefiting the coffee grower in Colombia," he added, because that nation is "the biggest player" in the specialty coffee niche market; there are more than 40 nationally marketed coffee brands sporting the Valdez logo.
"The coffee houses poking up everywhere" also help Colombian coffee, Mr. Janna said, because the "best ones, with their upscale looks and upscale feel," reinforce the sales spiel about the product's premium status.
The premium-price pitch is apparently well ingrained in American popular culture. A recent installment of the nationally syndicated "Grin and Bear It" cartoon featured a grocer explaining to a shopper that coffee prices were rising because "all those airlines turned around and came back for Colombian coffee" -- the plot of a commercial in the mainstream campaign.
The commercials in the new campaign were filmed in black and white and include, in the retro-chic style popular among younger consumers, brief clips from old commercials -- in this instance, spots for Colombian coffee produced by a DDB Needham Worldwide predecessor agency, Doyle Dane Bernbach, which was awarded the account in 1959. (Coincidentally, a campaign introduced last month by Ogilvy & Mather New York for Kraft Foods' Maxwell House coffee, carrying the theme "Good things have a way of lasting," incorporates bits of old Maxwell House spots into its new ones.)
One youth-slanted Colombian coffee commercial, spoofing personals ads, is called "Classified"; it also has a print counterpart. The spot presents a "single male bean; rich; good taste; not part of the crowd; looking to share intimacy in steamy relationship." Another commercial promises a debate on "stirring -- clockwise or counterclockwise?"
The new campaign also has a different media schedule than the mainstream campaign, which has a 1995 budget of more than $20 million. For instance, the new spots will appear on youth-oriented cable television networks like ESPN, MTV and VH-1.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Rose 0.7% in November

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Construction spending grew in November for the fourth consecutive month, led by a sharp increase in private financing, the Commerce Department reported today.
Total spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $522.7 billion, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, the Commerce Department said. A 1.9 percent advance in private financing offset a 2.7 percent decline in government expenditures. It was the largest gain in private spending since a 2.7 percent advance last March, and the biggest drop in public spending since a 6.1 percent plunge last January. 
 Spending totaled a revised $518.9 billion annual rate in October, when spending rose nine-tenths of 1 percent. The initial October estimate was $518.1 billion. The latest advance meant that November expenditures were 6.6 percent above those of a year earlier.
Some analysts attributed the increase in private financing to warm weather in much of the nation during November. But they cautioned that higher interest rates were beginning to curb private spending, particularly in the single-family residential sector.
Indeed, higher borrowing costs were blamed for falling home sales in November. Purchases of new homes in November dropped for the first time in five months, while sales of previously owned homes plunged to the lowest level in 17 months.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, said 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.18 percent in November, up from 7.15 percent last February when the Federal Reserve began raising rates to keep inflation under control.
The increase would add more than $200 to the monthly payment on a $150,000 mortgage.
Residential spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, to a $239.3 billion annual rate, after falling half of 1 percent in October. This sector represents nearly half of overall construction outlays.
Single-family outlays edged up one-tenth of 1 percent and reversed a five-month string of decreases. Single-family construction is highly sensitive to mortgage rate changes.
Expenditures for multifamily residences -- apartments and condominiums -- jumped 5.3 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
As Japanese Bonds Dive, Dollar Rises Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied yesterday to a 21-week high against the yen, drawing strength from a bond-market selloff in Tokyo and a United States Government report favoring a stronger currency.
But the yen's broad weakening limited the dollar's gains against leading European currencies as foreign investors dumped Japanese Government bonds and then sold yen for German marks and other currencies, market participants said. 
 The dollar rose as high as 101.46 yen yesterday, its highest level since Aug. 11, before retreating to 101.36 yen in New York, up from 100.68 Tuesday. It rose to 1.5590 marks, from 1.5565 marks on Tuesday.
The gains against the yen came mostly in Asia and Europe. Traders in Tokyo returned from New Year vacations to find that the dollar had sharply risen in American dealings on Tuesday. The advance was reinforced by yen selling resulting from the move out of Japanese Government bonds.
Koichi Takenaka, a vice president of the Industrial Bank of Japan in New York, said the Tokyo bond selloff might have partly resulted from foreign investors' needing to raise cash to cover losses on slumping Mexican assets.
But in recent months, analysts have also been expecting a downturn in foreign investment in Japan as American securities become more attractive.
Amy Smith, currency strategist for a New York analytical service, IDEA, said there was considerable activity in buying of dollar-yen options and rumors of a large contract for a 102-yen dollar rate due to mature tomorrow.
The dollar was also bolstered by a statement late Tuesday from the Treasury Department, emphasizing the benefits of a higher dollar. The Treasury, in an annual report to Congress on exchange-rate policy, reiterated Clinton Administration statements favoring a stronger dollar.
The dollar has also been supported by expectations of higher interest rates in the United States. Many currency dealers expect the Federal Reserve to again raise rates after the Jan. 31-Feb. 1 meeting of its rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee.
In other currency trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.3105 Swiss francs from 1.3145 on Tuesday. The British pound fell to $1.5605 from $1.5630, while the Canadian dollar rose to 71.50 United States cents from 71.16 cents.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH Arlene Eisenberg, Heidi E. Murkoff and Sandee E. Hathaway;
The Baby Makers

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
IT was an odd sort of family reunion. A photographer had assumed command of Arlene Eisenberg's living room and seemed to be trying to cajole Ms. Eisenberg and her two daughters into a posture that at least suggested family.
The women looked stiff. The photographer persisted. Ever so solicitously, she said things like, "Is it wrong to have your hand on each other's shoulder, like you're relating physically? Would that work?" 
 When she packed up, another photographer arrived. How about some physical contact? she suggested brightly. Could the grandchildren come downstairs? she wondered. The answer was unambiguous: no.
The curiously unadvertised fact about the co-authors of the wildly successful field guides to pregnancy and parenthood, "What to Expect When You're Expecting," "What to Eat When You're Expecting," "What to Expect the First Year" and now "What to Expect the Toddler Years," is that Ms. Eisenberg, Heidi E. Murkoff and Sandee E. Hathaway are themselves a mother and her daughters.
It's not that they hide the fact, exactly. They allude to it, fleetingly, in the introductions to several of the books. But when asked to talk about it, they insist it is irrelevant. They say it plays no role in what they do.
They say they work together because, in effect, they know and admire each other's work. They say they barely remember any conflict. Maybe three times in 10 years they seriously disagreed; they can't remember about what.
"You work as professional co-authors, and you don't bring the rest of it into that," insisted Ms. Murkoff, a small, dark-haired woman of conspicuous focus and will. "Because if you did, you'd be doomed."
Is that possible? she was asked.
"Completely possible," she said crisply. "It's not an issue."
Perhaps there was a time when consumer confidence might not have been set afire by the idea of a pregnancy manual written by a mother-daughter combo (whose most successful previously published collaboration happened to be a cookbook for dinner parties attended by guests with special dietary needs). Pregnancy-book authors tended to be obstetricians with boxcars of initials appended to their names when "What to Expect When You're Expecting" came out 10 years ago.
But since that time, "What to Expect When You're Expecting" has become a phenomenon in the field. There are more than four million copies in print. (Dr. Benjamin Spock's "Baby and Child Care" has sold more than 40 million copies, but it's been in print since 1946.) "What to Expect" is a baby-shower staple on a par with receiving blankets and Onesies, the essential complement to the modern mother's bottle warmer and diaper bag. From mother to mothers, like a chain letter, it is networking its way around the globe. A Czech edition is under negotiation; 21 other foreign editions are already out or under contract.
The book has also become the cornerstone of an ever-growing electronic cottage industry operated by Ms. Eisenberg, Ms. Murkoff and Ms. Hathaway via computer and fax from three states. There are the three published sequels, two regular magazine columns, and a pregnancy planner in the works. Ms. Murkoff lectures around the country. And there is serious talk of tailoring and giving away a new version of the pregnancy book for low-income women.
What appears to distinguish the books is their accessible, nonjudgmental approach. They try to address Everyparent's every question, even those that most parents wouldn't dare ask a doctor. (Is the fetus aware that we're having sex? In a word, no.) The authors pride themselves on certain principles: every parent and every child is different; the only imperatives in child-rearing are safety, health and love.
The authors present themselves as highly informed lay people, which they are. Ms. Eisenberg, 60, of New York is a freelance journalist; Ms. Murkoff, 36, of Santa Fe, N.M., is a writer, and Ms. Hathaway, 40, of Newton, Mass., is a nonpracticing nurse. They have eight children between them. They ask smart questions, summarize conflicting evidence and land squarely in the mainstream, siding with the likes of the American Academy of Pediatrics.
Exploring the minutiae of parental preoccupations, they are meticulously evenhanded. Take their discussion of parental nudity. They weigh the pros and cons, then wind up with a homily: "What children need to learn is that the body, naked or covered, should be respected and taken care of; it should be considered beautiful, rather than embarrassing. And most important it should be under the control of the person who inhabits it."
"We can help you make an informed decision," Ms. Murkoff said. "That's all we can do."
Recently, Workman, their publisher, reunited the authors in New York and held a carnival at the Puck Building in downtown Manhattan to celebrate the 10th birthday of the first book. There were clowns on stilts, carnival games, free food and hundreds of stroller-pushing "What to Expect" families. The next morning, the authors gathered to talk in the West Side brownstone apartment where Ms. Eisenberg and her husband, Howard, have lived since moving to Manhattan from Spring Valley, N.Y., 14 years ago.
On the living-room bookshelves stood framed photographs of the Eisenbergs' three children and their children's children, along with dozens of copies of foreign editions of the "What to Expect" books.
In a small office upstairs that she and her daughters pronounced too cluttered to be photographed, Ms. Eisenberg puts in 14-hour days. She subscribes to a dozen medical newsletters and journals, tracking new developments that might need to be incorporated with each new printing, every six to eight weeks.
But the driving force behind the enterprise is Ms. Murkoff. When she was in her early 20's, she worked for an advertising firm figuring out how to sell things like spaghetti sauce. When she quit and became pregnant with her daughter, Emma, she found that every pregnancy book she read filled her with dread.
They convinced her that her fetus was doomed -- either because of the hormone her doctor had prescribed before she knew she was pregnant or because of the few drinks she had drunk before she knew. The memory still annoys her. "This fetus is now 11 years old. She has all her arms and legs and is not mentally retarded, far from it," Ms. Murkoff said. "My pregnancy was completely normal."
"And so were your fears," Ms. Eisenberg said.
Which is, of course, the point. Out of that experience came "What to Expect When You're Expecting." It was Ms. Murkoff's personal crusade. "The more women like ourselves read, the more we panic," she said. "I was determined that no one have to go through what I went through." Just hours before she delivered Emma, Ms. Murkoff and her mother delivered to their agent their proposal for the first reassuring guide to pregnancy.
Why did you turn to your mother and sister? Ms. Murkoff was asked.
"It really had nothing to do with them being related," she said.
In a way, writing had always been a family business. Though the Eisenberg children had grown up in Garden City, L.I., and in Spring Valley, they had spent two years traveling in Europe and Israel with their parents, both freelance writers, accompanying them on interviews.
All three children went on to become writers, at least in part. The Eisenbergs' son, Evan, 39, is currently writing a book. Ms. Eisenberg herself began specializing in medical topics after writing a college textbook on health. So it was natural, Ms. Murkoff said, to turn to her and Ms. Hathaway, who was working as an obstetrical nurse.
The collaboration works well. Ms. Murkoff handles the bone structure of the books -- the snappy questions and answers at which her mother says she is especially gifted. Ms. Eisenberg does the medical reporting and updating. Ms. Hathaway tends to serve as editor, applying her medically trained ear.
For the latest book, "What to Expect the Toddler Years," Ms. Hathaway's youngest child, Elizabeth, now 3, served as "test toddler," an infallible model of toddler idiosyncrasies. Ms. Murkoff wrote the bulk of the nearly 900-page tome herself. When it came out in November, it immediately hit the Publishers Weekly paperback best-seller list.
Ms. Murkoff declined to say precisely how the books' profits are divided except that the distribution reflects the distribution of labor. Asked if the books had made the family rich, she said: "We're making a nice living. I wouldn't say rich."
For their next project, inspired by the positive response their seminar at Rikers Island received, the three women hope to find a way to distribute an edition of the pregnancy book specifically tailored to low-income women.
They are well aware of certain incongruities in what they do: they are supplying information about pregnancy when most women and their babies are at less risk than ever before. But the women who are at greatest risk are the least informed.
"Ironically, we who have the least to worry about worry the most," Ms. Murkoff said. "And the women today who have the most to worry about are the women who have the least information."
Some of the advice dispensed in the books does not, of course, square with what was accepted when Ms. Eisenberg was having children. She remembers being the lone breast-feeding mother on her hospital floor, being instructed to gain no more than 15 pounds and hearing repeatedly that infants could be spoiled by being picked up too much.
These days, she runs a weekly discussion group for parents of babies under a year old. They meet every Wednesday at Ansche Chesed Temple on West 100th Street -- a few dozen women and their babies, occasionally a father or two -- to hash out such weighty matters as "Why is my kid banging on everything?"
"For me, it's important to have hands-on experience every week with babies," she said. "Besides, I get my baby fix."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Lawmakers Pursue 'Contract With Fans'

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In an effort to spur agreement on a new labor contract in baseball, members of Congress intruded on the Republicans' "Contract with America" yesterday, introducing five baseball bills ranging from complete repeal of the sport's antitrust exemption to binding arbitration to settle the nearly five-month-old strike.
A total of three bills, two calling for complete repeal of the exemption, had been expected from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and Representative Michael Bilirakis, Republican of Florida, on the first day of the 104th Congress. But two Democratic Representatives also introduced bills, both of which had seen brief life in the last term. 
 Pat Williams of Montana reintroduced his bill that would require the owners and players to submit to binding arbitration if they did not reach agreement by Feb. 1, although the date will most likely be pushed back a month.
John Conyers of Michigan offered a bill that made it out of the House Judiciary Committee last term, proposing that any unilateral implementation of new work rules become subject to the antitrust laws.
It was a flurry of legislative activity on baseball that could hardly have been expected two months ago when Republicans won control of the House for the first time in 40 years and promised to take quick action on the "Contract With America" theme that was the focal point of the party's campaign.
"Congress always has been very cautious to intervene in collective bargaining," Williams said. "With the new Republican majority and their almost Pollyanna belief to allow the marketplace its own will, passing the bill will be difficult." But he added: "An increasing number of members of Congress are beginning to understand the future of baseball as we know the game in our lifetime is in peril. That fact encourages Congress to act and perhaps act dramatically."
The interest in the labor dispute apparently won't end with yesterday's activity. Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican from Utah and new chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, is considering introducing a bill aimed at limited repeal of the exemption baseball has had since 1922. The Hatch bill probably would most closely resemble Conyers's effort.
"He hasn't said he definitely will do it, but he is considering it," Paul Smith, a Hatch spokesman, said by telephone from Washington. "He did say he thought if his bill passed, the players would be back for spring training. That, to me, says he's going to do something fast."
While the proposed bills flew into the hoppers in the Senate and the House of Representatives, baseball management people discussed not how to end the strike, but how to proceed with spring training and the season if the strike continues.
In two telephone conference calls, members of the 10-man operations committee discussed such issues as replacement players and ticket prices if they are used. John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, the committee chairman, did not return a telephone call seeking comment on the calls, and others declined to be specific.
"We had a lot of discussions that were of a preliminary basis," Dave Dombrowski, general manager of the Florida Marlins, said by telephone from his office. "We discussed a lot of different questions and issues facing us. We reached no conclusions. We'll have further discussions."
Donald Fehr, head of the players' union, was closer to the action in Washington. He and Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, met with Secretary of Labor Robert Reich for about 40 minutes.
"We brought him up to date on the current situation," Fehr said. "He asked a number of questions."
Asked if Reich requested that the players resume talks with the owners, Fehr said: "Not directly. He knows we're prepared to resume when they want to. We didn't walk away from the table; they did. We didn't impose terms; they did."
Speaking of the moves in Congress, Fehr said: "Momentum is building. It's clear the Congress is becoming more and more aware of the freak in the law that has produced this dispute. I am encouraged."
Not surprisingly, Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, did not hold a similar view.
"When you look back at the antitrust exemption, this doesn't create any potential solution; that's total mythology," he said from Milwaukee. "But more important than that, you're dealing with arguably the most successful union in labor history. They've achieved unbelievable gains with baseball having this antitrust exemption. The fact is we need a collective bargaining agreement. This is mere diversion and doesn't contribute to that end at all."
But the lawmakers who acted yesterday obviously think their bills could have an impact on the dispute, and even get the game going again.
"My approach is the most efficient way to play ball," Williams, the outgoing chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor, said in a telephone interview. "That's all I'm interested in, getting the boys back on the field."
Williams had originally targeted Feb. 1 as the deadline for an agreement before the dispute went to binding arbitration and March 15 for a decision by the three-man arbitration board. But he acknowledged yesterday the reality of the calendar probably would push those dates back a month.
Representative Conyers, the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, worked during the last term of Congress with Jack Brooks, a Texas Democrat and the former committee chairman who lost his bid for re-election in November, on a bill similar to the one he introduced yesterday.
Calling for unilaterally implemented rules to be subject to antitrust laws, Conyers said in a statement, "The end result of baseball's special treatment has been the perpetuation of a closed, cartelized industry in which the few, incumbent club owners possess inordinate power and every other party -- including players, fans and municipalities -- remain economically marginalized."
He said the current situation may "demand an even stronger response and a broader repeal," adding, "But, in my judgment, this is an appropriate starting point for developing a bipartisan consensus on the issue in the Judiciary Committee and the full House."
Conyers kept his bill narrow rather than calling for complete repeal of the exemption in the hope that the Republican majority would not see it as interfering with the "Contract With America" legislation. The bill clearly is designed to attract bipartisan support.

HEADLINE: The Gingrich Paradox

 BODY:
There is no way of telling yet whether Newt Gingrich's inaugural speech to the House of Representatives yesterday was a genuine expression of born-again statesmanship or a brilliant tactical exercise. One hopes the former is true, that his gracious speech was not merely a masterly effort to make his "Contract With America" more palatable, but the emergence of a politician larger and more generous than his agenda. In any case, it was a surprising and startlingly effective performance -- animated, anecdotal, humane. It also left little doubt that, at least for the moment, Newt Gingrich is America's pivotal political figure, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole included.
Nor is there any telling how long the Speaker's magnanimity will last. It certainly was not in evidence during the snarly press conference that preceded his swearing-in. But once he took the gavel, he could hardly have done a better job of portraying his avowedly partisan "Contract With America" as an inclusive and non-threatening document that even his opponents could embrace without fear. Nor could he have been more energetic in his efforts -- we are "commoners together," he said of the House -- to invite his critics' help. 
 The man who vowed to dismantle much of the welfare state paid effusive tribute to its chief architect, Franklin Roosevelt. The partisan who has spent every second of his waking life over the past 10 years seeking to create a Republican hegemony gave exclusive credit to the Democrats for bringing about desegregation; the man seen as insensitive to the underclass declared that even his cherished balanced budget does not have "the moral urgency of coming to grips with what's happening to the poorest Americans."
Mr. Gingrich had a wider audience in mind than the Democrats -- a public that volcanically expressed its disgust with the way Washington, and in particular Congress, runs itself. His stated determination to make the House an open, responsive institution contrasted refreshingly with the business-as-usual approach of the old leadership. The new majority missed a coup in not swiftly adding the Democrats' belated gift ban to Mr. Gingrich's own proposals to clean up committee rules and open the House to more television coverage.
The emotional high point was Mr. Gingrich's warning to his own party that privatization and profits cannot override the need for caring social programs. The lingering question, of course, is how to square the inclusive rhetoric with his divisive budget strategies.
Applause for Mr. Gingrich's political resolve should not drown out criticism of his many misguided proposals. He backs tax cuts that he says will help middle-class families and stimulate economic growth. But the proposed cuts -- on capital gains, corporate investment and retirement saving -- are ill designed to promote savings and investment and, as Representative Richard Gephardt argues, tilt toward those with incomes over $200,000.
Since Social Security, Medicare and defense are exempt, the House G.O.P.'s desired $200 billion in spending cuts would have to come from programs on which Congress now spends about $450 billion. That means cutting about 40 percent of every remaining program from border patrol to medical research. This points up the central injustice -- and hypocrisy -- about the way Mr. Gingrich wants to go about reform. He pledges to balance the budget by aiming spending cuts at the most undefended citizens. Meanwhile, the well-off would get subsidies through the tax system for such benefits as unlimited mortgage interest deductions or high-cost health insurance.
So, in its current rendition, Mr. Gingrich's fiscal austerity is inherently unfair. He hinted that middle-class entitlements like Medicare and farm subsidies, as well as defense, would eventually bear some of the burden. That suggestion and his speech raise the hope that this unusual man's zeal for reform may, in time, be tempered by grander impulses toward mercy and equity.

HEADLINE: Student Loan Program Tells a Success Story

 BODY:
To the Editor:
David Lipsky's "Young, Eager and Deep in Debt" (Op-Ed, Dec. 29) states that "by 1990, the average college student was graduating $10,000 in the red." The average student was doing no such thing. A study sponsored by the Education Department shows that 55 percent of college graduates had no educational debts upon graduation in 1990. Of the 45 percent who did have such debts, half owed less than $7,000. 
 Mr. Lipsky says that "during the recession that began in 1990, many graduates were unable to repay" their loans, leading to a 17 percent default rate. The default rate among graduates who took loans is about 6 percent and did not increase appreciably during the recession. The more education individuals receive, the less likely they are to default.
The doubling of the default rate in the 15 years before 1992 was due almost exclusively to the increase in borrowers at "schools" offering short-term training, hundreds of which have been eliminated from the loan program in the last two years. These ripoff artists left their students with few or no skills and large debts. College graduates get skills, they get jobs, and they repay their loans.
Mr. Lipsky notes that banks make a huge profit on student loans, but does not state that under the Student Loan Reform Act of 1993, most loans will be made by the Federal Government directly to students, with no subsidy going to the banks. As of next July 1, 40 percent of all student loans will be made in this fashion.
Mr. Lipsky praises President Clinton for creating a program that allows students to "pay off loans in proportion to their incomes," but criticizes him for not making the plan retroactive. Such a repayment plan was just implemented by the Department of Education and is available for students who have graduated. Information may be obtained from (800) 433-3243.
The Department of Education study showed that the average borrower spent 5 percent of income paying off college debts the year after leaving school. However, 8 percent of borrowers were spending more than 10 percent of their income repaying their student loans. It is these students who are facing serious problems, and who are the folks policy makers should worry about.
Mr. Lipsky repeats the canard that colleges use availability of Federal aid as an excuse to raise tuition, which stimulates more borrowing. But borrowing increases whenever Congress makes more people eligible or raises loan limits, as it has several times in the last 30 years. This pattern holds, whether tuitions are rising at a rate lower than inflation, as in the 1970's, or higher than inflation, as in recent years.
Most borrowers find that Federal student loans make it possible for them to attend college, and the vast majority of graduates repay their loans on schedule, without complaint, grateful for the opportunity they received.
 
TERRY W. HARTLE
Vice President, Govt. Relations
American Council on Education
Washington, Dec. 30, 1994

HEADLINE: U.S. Military Has Real Readiness Problem

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Are U.S. Forces Ready to Fight?" (editorial, Dec. 27) concludes that the military is not facing a serious readiness problem. You premise this conclusion on the assumption that since the Pentagon's operations and maintenance budgets are larger and its force structure smaller than a decade ago, when readiness was unquestioned, there ought not to be a problem today. 
 If you had done an apples-to-apples comparison of operations and maintenance financing over the last 15 years, using constant fiscal year 1995 dollars (adjusted for inflation), you would see the 1994 and 1995 defense budgets provided the lowest levels of such financing since 1982.
Moreover, in recent years overall operations and maintenance financing has had little direct correlation to readiness, since these accounts must also cover the mounting costs of nondefense initiatives that have little bearing on troop training and readiness.
You imply that my concerns over military readiness are based exclusively on three Army divisions. My conclusions were based on extensive discussions with enlisted personnel and officers of all the services. You chose not to address the evidence I presented on Navy, Marine Corps or Air Force readiness problems.
However, even if I confine myself to your narrow interpretation of my conclusions, your logic is disturbing. While the Army's 2d Armored and 24th Infantry Divisions are "heavy" and would have fought similarly "heavy" Soviet divisions in a cold war conflict, they fought Iraqi Republican Guard divisions in the post-cold war Operation Desert Storm.
Considering that the United States has deployed "heavy" forces twice in the last four years in response to aggression in the Persian Gulf, I do not believe the American public would support your advice to shortchange these units because keeping them ready in view of the Army's downsizing is a "waste of money."
The military is suffering through the early stages of a long-term readiness problem. You do Americans a disservice by explaining away this growing problem as little more than politicians grandstanding and military commanders underestimating their own readiness to manipulate the debate.
 
(Rep.) FLOYD SPENCE
Chairman, House
National Security Committee
Washington, Jan. 4, 1995

HEADLINE: Economy in New York Region Is Stagnant, Unlike the Nation's

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Economic expansion and job growth in the New York region have come to a virtual halt since July, and higher interest rates are further undermining the region's prospects, according to economists, executives and government officials.
Although the New York region shows few signs of sinking back into recession, the experts say the local economy remains one of the weakest in the nation, when business activity elsewhere is so robust that the Federal Reserve has raised interest rates six times since February to ward off inflation. 
 Whatever impact higher interest rates may have in slowing the national expansion, they seem certain to hurt New York City and the surrounding areas. Several of the region's main industries -- the banks and brokerage houses of Manhattan, the military contractors of Connecticut and Long Island, and the pharmaceutical companies of New Jersey -- are shedding thousands of workers and slashing salaries, and those cuts, along with the higher interest rates, are helping to drag down other sectors of the economy.
"Just when things started looking like they were going to improve, buyers dropped out," said Bob Sullivan, a sales associate at Prudential-Degnan Boyle Real Estate in Montclair, N.J., where, according to company records, 21 homes changed hands in November, fewer than half the number sold each month in the first half of 1994.
The lagging economy could complicate plans by the governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to cut taxes. And on Tuesday, aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said New York City's business tax revenues are expected to be $200 million lower than anticipated for the fourth quarter of 1994, largely because of weaknesses in the banking and investment industries.
The regional economy does retain pockets of growth. Tourism has soared, helped in part by the low value of the dollar, which has made the region a bargain for foreigners. In New York City, hotels report a steady increase during the last six months in occupancy and room rates, while the region's three international airports report a surge in passengers, both foreign and domestic. But while hotels may be full, many office buildings struggle to find renters for vacant space.
Economists say the local economy is lagging because of several factors. Wall Street, a traditional engine of New York City's economy, had a tough 1994 because of a poor bond market and a lackluster year for stocks. And the growth in manufacturing that has fueled the nationwide recovery has largely bypassed the Northeast's aging or abandoned plants. Furthermore, high costs in the Northeast, from housing to taxes to business expenses, have discouraged expansion.
"The contrast between the brisk job expansion that we are seeing nationally, and what we are seeing here, has grown even more striking," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
New York State has lost 13,300 jobs since July, 4,800 of them in New York City, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. Connecticut lost 4,200 jobs in November after steady employment growth. New Jersey remains a bright spot, having added 15,400 jobs from July through November.
 
Wall Street
Profits Dry Up At Growth Engine
 Among the region's leading industries, the securities sector, comprised mainly of Manhattan's brokerage houses and investment banks, has had a particularly rough time.
These companies made large profits from 1988 to 1993, and played crucial roles in leading the region to the beginning of its recovery in late 1993. But in 1994, "Wall Street has been clobbered," said Matthew Drennan, an economist at New York University.
With only 145,000 workers in a regional work force of more than 12 million, the securities industry's importance is not so much in the number it employs as in the money its workers make: in good times, salaries and bonuses for many executives far exceed $100,000, and for some they top $1 million. This money is spent on restaurants, clothing, cars and other merchandise, thereby creating other jobs.
But the securities industry, more than any other sector, has been hurt by rising interest rates. Several of the largest Manhattan firms reported huge losses from their bond trading operations -- which try to anticipate swings in the nation's credit markets -- when interest rates began to rise in the spring.
In addition, the stock markets are ending a lackluster year of modest gains. Since the region's brokerage houses trade in huge amounts of their own money as well as that of their clients, the disappointing results of the market mean reduced profits for 1994.
Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, a securities industry research firm in Summit, N.J., said he expected profits by companies that are members of the New York Stock Exchange -- which employ more than half of the region's securities industry workers -- to be less than half the $8.6 billion they reported in 1993. As a result, the year-end bonuses many in the industry got have been cut to less than half of last year's, he said.
 
Manufacturing
The Casualties Of Pentagon Cuts
 Manufacturers in the region, who have been shedding workers and abandoning plants for decades, have continued to do so, despite the robust turnaround experienced by manufacturers elsewhere in the nation.
The problems, moreover, are not confined to old industries like the garment makers of New York and machine shops of Connecticut, which had lost much business to foreign competition long before the New York region sank into recession. Some industries that had been the region's strongest are now being undermined by complex economic shifts that are unlikely to reverse course.
The industry serving the Pentagon, for instance, was long one of the most stable employers in the region, with companies like Pratt & Whitney and the Electric Boat Company of Connecticut and the Northrop Grumman Corporation on Long Island. But with sharp cuts in military spending, all three have announced large numbers of layoffs, with the cuts totaling over 10,000 jobs. More reductions are expected.
"Dozens of people here have moved to the South or the Midwest," said John Beauregard, executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Private Industry Council, which operates a job-placement service in Groton for workers laid off by the Electric Boat Company, a maker of submarines. The company has reduced its Connecticut work force from 17,000 to 12,000 since 1993, and plans to cut another 6,000 over the next four years.
In Dutchess County, N.Y., where International Business Machines has its largest concentration of plants, the company began a series of big layoffs in 1993, and the cuts continue.
Like those laid off by Electric Boat, many of those cut by I.B.M. have advanced engineering or electronic skills, and would probably find jobs if they moved to another region. But few have, said Tony Nicotra, director of the Poughkeepsie Career Center.
"Our success rate has been good, but not in finding people jobs in the same field they left," he said, adding the some of the laid-off workers have turned to jobs like truck driving, have opened art galleries or have started other small businesses.
Another once-robust part of the region's economy is the pharmaceutical industry of central and northern New Jersey, where Johnson & Johnson, Merck & Company, Ciba-Geigy and a dozen other companies operate the nation's largest concentration of drug laboratories and manufacturing plants. These companies have laid off more than 10,000 people since August 1993 as the health-care industry seeks to cut costs.
Robert Pellet, executive director of the New Jersey Health Products Council, a trade group, said the problems facing the industry are likely to continue as cost-conscious health-care companies try to economize.
 
Bright Spots
New Jersey Stands Out
 While statistics show many weak spots in the region's economy, there are pockets of hope. The region's smaller start-up companies are soaking up new workers. Dun & Bradstreet, the research firm, said the number of business starts in the region increased by 12 percent in the first 11 months of 1994, after declining in the previous year. And the number of business failures dropped by 25 percent in those first 11 months of 1994.
Among the three states in the region, New Jersey stands out as the strongest. That state gained jobs every month this year except for September, according to Federal government data through November.
Like the rest of the nation, New York City and its suburbs are reaping the gains from an upturn in some areas of consumer spending, particularly auto sales, which have been buoyed by pent-up demand from people who put off buying during the recession.
"We've got a shortage of Blazers and a shortage of Luminas," said Arnold Frankel, sales manager of Turnpike Chevrolet in East Meadow, L.I. "Once they come in the door, they'll be sold."
Christmas sales across the region, however, were a disappointment.
"The New York region underperformed the nation," said Isaac Lagnado, publisher of the Tactical Retail Monitor, an industry newsletter. He said sales in New York City and its suburbs increased by 5 percent over the 1993 holiday season, compared with a 6.5 percent gain for the nation.
 
Taxes
After Promises, Painful Reality
 The timing of the region's economic slowdown may be particularly nettlesome for four of its top political leaders -- Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City -- all of whom have promised to cut taxes, bringing about the most concerted interstate reversal of fiscal policy in the nation.
But a weak economy, generating few new jobs and little income growth, produces lower-than-expected tax revenue, and economic advisers to all four leaders are nervously revising the financial forecasts.
Indeed, in New York and New Jersey, officials are projecting large budget deficits that can only grow deeper if the economy does not improve. Advisers to Governor Pataki said the New York State deficit would be at least $100 million for the fiscal year ending March 31, and Governor Whitman faces the prospect of a deficit exceeding $1 billion for New Jersey's fiscal year, which ends June 30.
The slowdown in New York State's economy "gives us something to contend with," said Donna Arduin, that state's newly appointed first deputy budget director, in an interview on Friday.
Ms. Arduin said Mr. Pataki remains committed to cutting taxes. "A weak economy means taxpayers need to keep as much of their income as they can," she said. "It just means you cut more spending."
In New York City, forecasts of tax receipts have proven far too optimistic since its fiscal year began on July 1. By October, advisers to Mayor Giuliani said the tax shortfall amounted to $170 million, so they revised their forecasts downward for the rest of the year.
Nonetheless, tax collections in the city have continued to fall short of expectations. According to the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, the city's revenue for December from four of its biggest taxes, including the personal income and general corporation taxes, were $188.3 million less than expected.
Because of the weaker-than-expected tax receipts, Mr. Hevesi said Mayor Giuliani and Governor Pataki would be forced to move "very slowly and carefully" in their attempts to cut taxes.
Unless the economy improves, "We are looking at a lot of pain for a lot of people in both the city and the state," he said.

HEADLINE: First 81 Teachers Qualify For National Certification

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
In a move to professionalize teaching and raise its standards, a crop of veteran teachers has become the first to receive national teaching certification.
The 81 middle-school and junior high teachers, who had to pass a stringent yearlong assessment, were announced yesterday in Washington by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. 
Certification does not replace current licensing, but many educators hope that National Board teachers who move to another state will be able to avoid sometimes cumbersome recertification and start work right away. In addition, the educators hope that states and local school districts will reward these teachers with higher pay and greater responsibilities.
Already, North Carolina has promised a 4 percent raise and reimbursement of the $975 exam fee for teachers who complete the certification program. Iowa, North Carolina, New Mexico and Oklahoma have agreed to waive state licensing requirements for nationally certified teachers who relocate there. Other states, including Massachusetts and Ohio, will accept the national certification as an alternative to their own state recertification program.
Educators said the National Board initiative paralleled that for other professionals, like doctors. It sets high standards, including extensive evaluations of classroom performance and a battery of exams testing the teacher's knowledge, rather than the minimum thresholds that state licenses usually require.
"It's a moment that is every bit as historic as the changes that came about in the medical profession when they decided to set high standards," said Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina, who heads the 63-member board.
"We're going to have, for the first time, a true and recognized profession of teaching that is respected and one that I believe will be far more attractive to young people coming along who are considering their careers," Governor Hunt, a Democrat, said, "and I think one that will be attractive for teachers to stay in."
The certification program, which has been developed over the last eight years with $55 million in Federal and philanthropic support, has broad support among educators, business leaders, governors and the presidents of the nation's two largest teacher unions.
Connie Mitchell, a teacher in Detroit's public schools, was among the 81 pioneering teachers to meet the National Board's standards.
"I'm very excited," said Ms. Mitchell, who teaches reading and computer literacy at the Noble School for kindergartners to eighth-graders. "Part of the reason that people have not looked at us as a profession is because we have not had standards. Doctors have standards. Lawyers have standards. Now teachers have the same set-up, and that is going to be very important to the profession."
Over the course of several months in the 1993-94 school year, Ms. Mitchell and the 288 other candidates had to compile portfolios of their work, videotape their classroom instruction, submit lesson plans, their students' work and write reams of analyses reflecting on how they have helped students learn. The candidates then went to an assessment center, where among other things, they evaluated videos of other teachers; were tested on their own knowledge of English, science, history and health, and devised comprehensive lesson plans involving either systems of government, ecosystems or the influence of the media.
Whether the advanced certification will allow teachers to walk into many states without meeting additional state requirements remains to be seen. According to Ernest Boyer, the president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching: "It could easily establish some benchmarks that would influence state licensing and state certification and, who knows, it could also send signals to teacher training programs. It's a project that is saying that there are standards of excellence that can be defined."
In New Jersey, a spokesman for the Education Department said the state endorsed the national program and was considering how to recognize nationally certified teachers. Officials for state education departments in New York and Connecticut said they had no immediate plans to recognize national certification.
But expressing the view of some education administrators, Tom Murphy, a spokesman for the Connecticut Education Department, said, "The difference may come in how local school districts, the employing agencies, how they treat that status. They might provide stipends through their contracts but it's up to the localities."
Some local districts are already providing incentives for teachers. The Jericho, L.I., district will reimburse the application fee for all teachers who complete the process; give a one-time $4,000 stipend to nationally certified teachers and pay a one-time $2,000 stipend to teachers who try but do not pass.
But to some educators, the new process raises as many questions as it seeks to remedy. In the short term, they say, the lives of a vast majority of teachers will not be affected. Licenses to teach are still controlled at the state level; financial incentives are far from certain in an era of tightening school budgets, and there is concern that teachers in wealthier districts will be rewarded in greater numbers than teachers from poorer districts because they may have more time and money to apply.
"I think the consistent concern of this group is that the certification process will omit a whole series of individuals who are most in need of additional training," said Michael Casserly, a spokesman for the Council of Great City Schools, a nonprofit Washington group representing the country's biggest districts. "It's a good first step on a very, very long road and it's a road that is going to require all manner of vigilance to insure that urban teachers have the same opportunities for certification as others."
But a new Federal law now allows schools to use elementary and secondary school money to help teachers seek the certification, said James A. Kelly, president of the National Board, who said states and districts were being urged to support the program financially. "We are doing everything we can to look at this issue," Mr. Kelly said.
The national certification board, created in 1987, was a central recommendation of a landmark report, "A Nation Prepared: Teachers for the 21st Century," issued by the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy. The report was one of several in the mid-1980's urging drastic changes in the nation's schools, including the scathing "A Nation at Risk" in 1983 by the Department of Education that resulted in stricter graduation requirements and more emphasis on basic skills.
To be eligible to apply for national certification, teachers must have at least three years of teaching experience, a bachelor's degree and either a state license or a job in a state-accredited school.
The teachers announced yesterday, from 23 states, are all middle school and junior high school teachers who teach multiple subjects. (The Board certificate is called "Early Adolescence/Generalist.") No teacher from New York City received the certificate, but three teachers in New York State, from Stony Brook, Rochester and Penfield, N.Y., three teachers in New Jersy, from Hazlet, Englishtown and Dayton, and one from Newington, Conn.
The certificate is the first of 30 categorized by subject and grade level that will become available to the nation's 2.5 million teachers by the end of the decade. This summer, more than 250 middle-grade English teachers will learn their scores. Among other areas of expertise to be assessed are early adolescence/social studies-history and young adulthood/mathematics.
Arthur Levine, the president of Teachers College, said the establishment of national standards for teacher certification was an experiment that was bound to be complicated because every state had its own licensing procedures.
"The notion of trying to create national standards is much akin to trying to herd cats," Mr. Levine said. "What the board has done is work very hard to make the notion appealing to school systems, states and to universities and to unions. What these first awards symbolize is to provide some sense that around the country there is some agreement on what makes for a good teacher."

HEADLINE: Bombing of Rebel City Lets Up, But Not the Attacks on Yeltsin

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 5

 BODY:
There were reports today of a respite in the bombing of the embattled capital of Chechnya, as ordered by Boris N. Yeltsin. But it brought no reprieve to the Russian President, who remains under attack at home and abroad for his military offensive against the secessionist southern region.
Western press reports from Grozny, the rebel capital, supported Russia's claim that bombing was limited to the outskirts of town, but Russian reports contradicted it. 
 Two members of Russia's Parliament declared in Nazran, near the Chechen border, that Russian planes had bombed some parts of Grozny. Vesti, a news program on state-controlled television, reported that one bomb had been dropped on the presidential palace in the city's center, despite Western reports that the device was a rocket. Another television news program also reported bombing inside Grozny.
The chairman of the President's commission on human rights, Sergei Kovalyov, returned from a three-week stay in Grozny today and said the Yeltsin Government's claims about its military operation in Chechnya were lies that surpassed those of "the Communists and even Goebbels."
Outside Russia, outrage over the killing of hundreds of civilians also grew sharply.
In Washington, after weeks of calling the conflict in Chechnya an internal matter for Russia to solve, the Clinton Administration is set to open a high-level effort with Western Europeans to persuade Russia to accept a negotiated end to the crisis. [Page A8.]
For the first time since Russian troops entered Chechnya on Dec. 11, European governments threatened to try to punish Moscow economically. The European Commission in Brussels said today that it would hold up an interim trade agreement that Russia signed in December as a way of underlining Europe's concern about the killing of civilians.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said that though he still viewed the conflict in Chechnya as an internal Russian matter, he had phoned Mr. Yeltsin on Wednesday to voice his concern about Russia's use of force.
Mr. Kovalyov, who in a news conference likening the blackened, bombed-out neighborhoods of Grozny to Stalingrad in World War II, was given 10 minutes of air time tonight on state-controlled television. He lashed out at some Russian news organizations, accusing them of relying on Government claims of military success and low casualties without sufficient skepticism. He also said he expected to meet with Mr. Yeltsin on Friday to urge him to stop the war.
Today, Mr. Yeltsin's senior aides in charge of the war made contradictory assessments of the Government's efforts to gain control over Chechnya. Mr. Yeltsin's national security adviser, Yuri Baturin, said, "Normalization of the situation in Chechnya is far away." He said he was concerned about the Chechen guerrilla operations there.
But Sergei Stepashin, director of the federal counter-intelligence service, told Russian troops in Grozny that "talk about an endless guerrilla war is just bluff."
Mr. Stepashin, who is one of the Government's most zealous advocates of the war, also said that 8 out of 11 districts in Chechnya supported the Russian armed forces. Deputy Prime Minister Nikolai Yegorov, who is in charge of coordinating the operation in Chechnya, had predicted on Wednesday that Grozny would fall today or Friday.
Mr. Yeltsin's decision to send troops into Chechnya has cost Mr. Yeltsin the support of most of the democratic political leaders who helped bring him to power.
Increasingly isolated, Mr. Yeltsin moved to the right today by appointing a member of the Communist faction of Parliament, Valentin A. Kovalyov, to be his new Justice Minister. Valentin Kovalyov, who is not related to Sergei Kovalyov, had most recently served as the head of an ad hoc committee to monitor human rights in Chechnya created by Mr. Yeltsin to better reflect the Government's position.
Valentin Kovalyov's unwillingness to criticize Russian actions in Chechnya caused members of his faction to ridicule him publicly, but it evidently earned him the gratitude of Mr. Yeltsin.
Other spokesmen for the Government's actions in Chechnya have not fared as well. The head of Russia's information center on Chechnya, Valentin Sergeyev, was reportedly hospitalized in Moscow today with heart trouble. He had been sentenced to death by Islamic supporters of the Chechen leader, Dzhokhar Dudayev, who distributed his home telephone number and address.
Moscow announced that Mr. Sergeyev would be temporarily replaced by Valery Grishin. Mr. Grishin is the third person appointed to head the information center in the last three weeks. The first, Press Minister Sergei Gryzunov, resigned under a barrage of criticism from the Russian press.
And Deputy Prime Minister Sergei M. Shakrai, who strongly supported the war, admitted to the Itar-Tass news agency today that even he sometimes had trouble obtaining reliable information from the Defense Department.

HEADLINE: JAPAN KEEPS PACE IN U.S. CAR MARKET

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 5

 BODY:
American auto makers are celebrating a banner 1994, a year of ready customers and soaring profits. But one stubborn fact emerged today: The Japanese auto makers, despite offering higher-priced cars against American vehicles of improved quality, did not lose any of their share of the nation's car and truck market last year.
In fact, they gained share, and the Big Three auto makers lost some. 
 Last year demonstrated how fiercely -- and adroitly -- the Japanese auto companies will fight to retain American customers against tough odds. The Japanese auto makers were more vulnerable than they had been in years. The yen strengthened against the dollar to record levels last year, making it far more costly to import cars from Japan. And Japan's economy continued to sag, making it difficult for its car makers to use profits at home to subsidize their operations here.
But they kept bringing buyers into their showrooms, by holding down price increases on popular models, emphasizing lease deals, shifting more production to the United States and introducing new, appealing cars and trucks.
"Anyone who underestimates the Japanese is in big, big trouble," said Robert J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation.
The Big Three will probably pick up some market share in 1995, as they increase production of their new import fighters. But the sales results announced by the auto makers today show how hard it will be for Detroit to reclaim a substantial part of the market after years of neglect.
A year ago, few in Detroit would have expected the Japanese to hold their position in the short term, given the currency exchange rate. "If I had predicted a year ago that the dollar would be at 100 yen and that the Japanese would have gained market share in the interim, you would have wondered what I was smoking," said Joel Pitcoff, market analysis manager at the Ford Motor Company.
In a business where a tenth of a point of market share is contested like Helen of Troy, the Japanese companies gained two-tenths of a point to finish the year with 23.3 percent of the car and light-truck market. In reporting sales today for December and the entire year, the Big Three said they lost seven-tenths of a point to finish with 73.2 percent. Every tenth of a point this year represented 15,000 sales -- as many cars as Jaguar sold in the United States and more sales than Land Rover had.
Not that the Big Three turned in a shabby performance. Chrysler had the most profitable year in its 69-year history, and sold more vehicles than it ever had. Ford sold the most trucks in its history, as did General Motors' important Chevrolet division.
Ford finished the year with five of the eight best-selling vehicles in the United States. And Chrysler, once the industry's basket case, is widely believed to have become the world's most profitable auto maker. During 1994, it fully financed its pension plan for the first time since 1957, and is paying bonuses to its hourly workers averaging two months' pay, or almost $7,500.
On top of that, Chrysler finished the year with more than $7.5 billion in cash -- enough, Mr. Eaton said, to weather the next market downturn.
Over all, sales of cars and light trucks -- a surging category that includes pickups, mini-vans, four-wheel drives and sport utility vehicles -- grew to 15.1 million, up 8.4 percent from less from 14 million in 1993.
"It was a good year, no question about it," said John F. Smith Jr., president and chief executive of G.M., the world's largest auto maker. Like his competitors, foreign and domestic, Mr. Smith predicted continued growth in 1995, barring a sharp increase in interest rates.
The domestic auto makers, Mr. Smith noted, could not produce enough of certain cars and trucks to keep up with demand, probably sacrificing some sales to the Japanese.
At G.M., for example, long factory shutdowns to prepare for some new models deprived dealers of crucial products. It had no Chevrolet Lumina family sedans to sell for months, and still cannot make enough subcompact Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunfire cars to satisfy demand. "The market was stronger than we had anticipated," Mr. Smith said.
In addition, the Big Three argue that Japanese prices do not reflect the full impact of the strong yen, suggesting that the auto makers are taking losses on many American sales. "The strengthening of the yen has not been passed on to the U.S. market," Alexander J. Trotman, chairman and chief executive of Ford, said. "Some has, but not much."
Further, the Japanese performance was not uniform. The Toyota Motor Corporation, for example, actually lost some share in 1994, about a fifth of a percentage point, to 7.2 percent. But its sales still grew, with the Toyota division selling more than a million cars and trucks for the first time since 1986. Toyota, Japan's leading auto manufacturer, also sold a record number of its Camry family sedans, which are priced well above their Big Three competitors.
"Last year was proof-positive that a setback can become a springboard," said Dave Illingworth, senior vice president and general manager of the Toyota division in the United States. He added that he had begun seeing headlines describing Toyota's comeback.
"The question to be asked is, back from where?" he asked. "Because as far as Toyota is concerned, we never left."
To offset the strength of the yen, Toyota is increasing its production in North America. Mr. Illingworth said Toyota intended to raise North American production from 500,000 in 1994 to 790,000 units in 1996 and 900,000 in 1998.
And Toyota, like other Japanese companies, is vigorously cutting costs.
Mr. Eaton of Chrysler said, "I believe Toyota will reach their goal of being profitable at 80 or 90 yen to the dollar in the long term."
In the meantime, the Japanese showed in 1994 that to prevent the Big Three from exploiting their vulnerability they will take significant risks, like pushing leasing, a popular but financially risky marketing tool. "The Japanese have performed exceptionally well," said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, an automotive marketing firm in Rutherford, N.J.
As the Big Three increase their production capacity, they will take some share back in the next two years, Ms. Jacobs predicted. But, she added, "After 1996, I think the Big Three will hold share at best, and maybe lose share."
The European auto makers gained ground in 1994, although they remain relatively minor players in the United States. They finished the year with about 2.6 percent of the market, up four-tenths of a point. South Korean manufacturers accounted for the remaining share, about nine-tenths of a percent.
Some customers have shown that they are not quite willing to take a chance on cars from Detroit's auto makers. Dan Chiles of Springfield, Mo., considered buying a new compact sedan, the Chrysler Cirrus. But he had bought three Hondas in the past, and because he said he felt safer with that company, decided on a Honda Accord instead.
"It's so stable and so well made that what I'm buying is an investment over time," Mr. Chiles said. "It will run great and have great resale value."
But Mr. Chiles said he made his choice also because he would have had to wait six to eight weeks for the Cirrus, suggesting that Chrysler may win more customers when the cars are more widely available. Robert A. Lutz, president of Chrysler, said that 80 percent of the people ordering the Cirrus were "trading in a late-model import, or on their way to buy an import, and we caught them at the last moment."
In fact, Earl J. Hesterberg, vice president and general manager of the Nissan division of the Nissan Motor Company, predicted that the new Chrysler compact sedans, as well as the new Ford Contour and Mercury Mystique compacts, would probably bite into the heart of Japan's market in the United States, drawing some customers away.
Then, he said, the Big Three may begin to regain some market share. "If it is going to happen -- which we should expect -- this would be the time," he said.

HEADLINE: Moscow, Bowing to I.M.F., Will Loosen Controls on Oil Prices

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 5

 BODY:
In a decision that could hasten needed loans to Russia, the Government has bowed halfway to foreign pressure and agreed to start liberalizing the domestic oil market.
A decree, signed by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin but not yet published, eliminates the requirement that oil companies sell more than half their production at artificially depressed domestic prices, World Bank officials said. The International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the United States all lobbied vigorously for such a step. 
 For ordinary Russians, the decision will mean gradually higher costs for energy because domestic prices are only 30 percent of world levels. But it was good news for the I.M.F. and the World Bank, which had said the elimination of quotas would be a crucial factor in their decision to provide Moscow the $13 billion in hard-currency loans that Russia is counting on for the 1995 budget.
The decision was sudden. "That's a big change from last week, and even two days ago," said Charles R. Blitzer, chief economist for the World Bank here. While not a total victory for economic reformers in the Cabinet, he said, "it's a good sign, a move generally in the right direction."
A Western diplomat said, "Frankly it's the first really good economic news in months."
But some of the bad news is pretty sobering, especially the drain of the unfinished offensive in Chechnya, the secessionist region in southern Russia. That operation is expected to cost $2.8 billion to $5.5 billion -- between 1 percent and 2 percent of the gross national product -- and is nowhere accounted for in the draft 1995 budget.
And the rise in prices in December was 16.4 percent, the highest monthly figure since last January. Every monthly inflation figure in the last quarter was in double digits.
Fears of new inflation also drove the ruble down today, to 3,623 to the dollar, the lowest rate since the ruble crashed suddenly in October.
The draft 1995 budget is tightly drawn on the premise that monthly inflation will fall to about 3 percent and the deficit will be about 8 percent of gross national product. That gap was already too high for the I.M.F., and did not include the Chechnya operation nor any funds the military may get for much-needed reorganization and training.
A former Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar, has warned that the new spending might produce hyperinflation, a run on the ruble and even Government rationing.
There are also deepening worries abroad about the new Privatization Minister, Vladimir Polevanov, who said recently that he wants to re-nationalize some "strategic" industries, including aluminum, which is currently a glut on world markets.
He is opposed by the former Privatization Minister, Anatoly B. Chubais, who outranks him now as First Deputy Prime Minister, but he has support from more nationalist voices in the Cabinet. Mr. Polevanov is also said to be eager to expel American-funded advisers on privatization from Government offices.
Privatization seems to have been one of the great successes of Russia's economic reform, and Mr. Chubais remains one of the few strong reformers in the Cabinet. His influence was also important on the oil decision, Mr. Blitzer of the World Bank said. But if Mr. Polevanov begins to roll back on privatization, foreign investment will flee and the fledgling stock market will be hurt badly.
The abandonment of oil sales quotas, which the Government had promised would go into effect six months ago, will begin to move the industry away from state planning. It should also provide more tax revenue and more profit to domestic oil companies, which say they do not have enough money to refit aging pipelines or to dig new wells.
In large part because of such handicaps, oil production dropped 11 percent last year, to 302 million tons, the Ministry for Fuel and Energy reported today.
With the changes, domestic oil prices are to rise gradually as tax structures change. By enforcing an export tax on oil of about $3.75 a barrel, the Russians should be able to insure a good domestic supply while bringing more revenue to the strapped state budget.
Under the current system, the Government requires producers to sell up to 65 percent of their oil in the home market. Justification was offered on nationalistic grounds, but the system also kept bureaucratic control over the companies that were permitted to export oil. That created a large potential for corruption and favor-seeking.
But even the new decree reportedly retains the principle of exporting through specific companies, currently about 14 of them, which must be approved by the Government. So the issues of bureaucratic favoritism and potential corruption remain.
Foreign diplomats and bankers suggest that the Government will likely use its willingness to free the domestic oil market to argue for more indulgence on the budget from the I.M.F. That is also apparently an argument that Prime Minister Chernomyrdin used to beat back strong nationalist pressure to keep the quotas, pressure led by a bizarre intervention from Mr. Yeltsin's security chief, Maj. Gen. Aleksandr V. Korzhakov.
General Korzhakov, in a letter to Mr. Chernomyrdin, warned that ending the sales quotas would be "absolutely impermissible" because it would provide foreigners and their capital too much influence over Russian raw materials.
