HEADLINE: Kiev Journal;
Out of Ukraine's Torment, a Jewish Flowering

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
Yaakov Bleich, a 30-year-old Orthodox rabbi who came here from Brooklyn five years ago, might be expected to encourage the Jews in this city to emigrate from their birthplace, a land with a history of centuries of anti-Semitic persecution.
"When I came, I said get them out of here as quickly as possible," Rabbi Bleich said. "But I've modified my aim." 
 The major reason, he said, is that it is now possible to lead a religious life in Ukraine these days.
By any measure, there has been a lively revival of Judaism since Ukraine declared independence from the Soviet Union in 1991. The Jewish day school in Kiev has grown from 40 students three years ago to 600, and the rabbi says this makes it the largest Jewish school in Eastern Europe. There are 11 other Jewish schools across the country. Fifty synagogues are open, compared with 12 in 1990.
"At Passover we sold 120 tons of matzoh -- five years ago it was five times less," the rabbi said as he fielded a phone call about whether a brand of imported breakfast cereal was kosher.
The official attitude toward religion in general has warmed in Ukraine -- the Ukrainian Orthodox Church has undergone a renaissance -- and the Government has gone out of its way to emphasize reconciliation with Jews. Rabbi Bleich was invited by President Leonid D. Kuchma to travel on his plane on Mr. Kuchma's official visit to Washington in November. The rabbi went ahead separately, but the two men appeared together at a reception for prominent Jews that was held by the Ukrainian Government at its New York consulate.
Mr. Kuchma went one step further by visiting the Holocaust Museum in Washington, making up for what many felt was a snub by Leonid M. Kravchuk, who failed to attend the opening last year when he was President. During his visit to the museum Mr. Kuchma handed over a new list of 400 "righteous Gentiles" who protected Ukrainian Jews during World War II, a gesture that some here see as particularly important.
"Jews here, and American Jews, always remember the Ukrainians who collaborated with the Nazis," Rabbi Bleich said. "I think there were from 100,000 to 200,000 who collaborated. Of a population of 32 million at the time I think it's a small percentage."
Despite the changes in the last five years, anti-Semitism remains an undercurrent that often erupts in public. Three members of a far-right nationalist group, Una-Unso, were elected to Parliament this year. At their demonstrations in Lviv, members of the group shout anti-Semitic slogans. Far-right newspapers are filled with anti-Semitic articles. There have been a spate of muggings of elderly Jews in Lviv and Kiev.
About 70,000 Jews have left Ukraine in the last five years, mostly for Israel but also for the United States. A number of them were young scientists, seeking economic security but also more freedom from the stultified academic atmosphere here. In a speech in New York, Mr. Kuchma stressed that Ukraine respected the rights of Jews to emigrate but at the same time expressed sorrow over the departures.
The Jewish establishment here estimates that there are 550,000 Jews in Ukraine. Most of them are over the age of 40 and a high percentage are elderly and house-bound. At the turn of the century there were three million Jews in Ukraine. About a million left after a series of pogroms. In 1941, at Babi Yar in the outskirts of Kiev, more than 200,000 people, most of them Jews, were killed by Nazis; an estimated 500,000 Ukrainian Jews died in Nazi camps.
At the Jewish day school, the hallways are decorated with paper cut-out Hanukkah candles and maps of Israel and Hebrew script on the blackboards. A drawing of a yellow sun hung in one classroom with the inscription in Ukrainian, "I'm Very Happy Because I Am Jewish."
For many students, Judaism is something entirely new. "The first time I wrote on a blackboard the girls were so quiet I thought they had gone home," said Miriam Eckstein, 26, a Hebrew teacher from Israel. "It's new to them and they're very very interested."
Becoming knowledgeable about their religion is also new for some of the teachers. Svetlana Zivshytz, who worked for 20 years at a state school, now carries a book about Jewish holidays in her pocketbook.
"My parents were not very religious, but now my own faith is being revived," she said. "My child Yuri, who is 3 1/2, knows now there is such a thing as a Jewish holiday. He made a small purse, hung it around his neck and said mother and father should put something in it for Hanukkah."
Such sentiments have moved Rabbi Bleich to be less emphatic about emigration.
"The Israelis," he said, "get upset when I say, 'Don't leave.' But I say I'm a democrat and one of the basic rights is a person should live where he wants to live. My job is to teach Jews how to be Jewish."

HEADLINE: With Copter Pilot's Return, U.S. Will Send Oil to North Korea

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Less than a week after North Korea's release of a downed American helicopter pilot, the Department of Defense said today that it would begin shipments of oil to the country as part of a deal that is designed to end the North's nuclear weapons program.
That the Pentagon is paying $4.7 million to buy and ship the first 13.5 million gallons of oil to North Korea has angered many Republicans, who have charged that the Clinton Administration is propping up a rogue Government. 
 The accord requires North Korea to freeze and ultimately to dismantle its weapons-grade nuclear program in exchange for $4 billion in economic aid from the United States, Japan and South Korea.
Seeking to blunt Congressional opposition, a senior Defense Department official told reporters today that the Administration was satisfied that North Korea was complying with its commitment to open its existing nuclear complexes to inspection and to store and eventually ship its spent fuel rods, which could be used to make weapons, out of the country.
If that compliance ends, the official said at a briefing, the United States and its allies will halt the shipments of heating oil and ultimately abandon a plan to build two major reactors for North Korea that cannot produce weapons-grade fuel.
The Pentagon official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Administration chose to negotiate with North Korea last year rather than risk war. Tensions between the two countries reached a critical point last June when the United States threatened to seek international economic sanctions against the North.
Because the North said it would view sanctions as an act of war, the official said, the United States also took steps to increase the combat readiness and power of American and South Korean forces on the Korean peninsula.
"It is safe to say that it is the closest we have come to facing a major military confrontation, possibly with the exception" of the recent deployment of American troops to Kuwait to counter an Iraqi troop buildup, the senior Pentagon official said. "We faced a real possibility of military operations."
Although North Korea later acceded to the nuclear accord, Pentagon officials acknowledged that they have little insight as to who is actually running the country.
North Korea's new leader, Kim Jong Il, has made few public appearances since his father and predecessor, Kim Il Sung, died last July. The country's official Communist Party newspaper, Rodong Sinmun, reported this week that villagers were searching for wild ginseng to help cure Mr. Kim, who has been rumored to suffer from diabetes, kidney or liver problems.
North Korea's delay last month in returning Chief Warrant Officer Bobby Hall, the pilot whose helicopter was shot down after straying into the North's territory, threatened to imperil the nuclear accord.
Mr. Hall confirmed today that his captors coerced him into signing a six-page statement conceding the flight was an "illegal intrusion." Interviewed on the television program "CBS This Morning," he said the statement was "what they dictated me to write down."
Pentagon officials said that merchant ships would deliver the heating oil -- the first of three shipments over the next 22 months -- to North Korea before Jan. 21.

HEADLINE: Panel on Labor to Urge Changes Aiding Unions and Employers

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
A special commission formed to develop labor policy for the Clinton Administration will recommend that Congress change the nation's labor laws so workers can organize unions more easily and employers will have more freedom to enlist workers and managers in committees that deal with workplace issues.
The recommendations, disclosed in interviews with commission members, drew cautious responses, even from the Administration. A Labor Department spokeswoman said there would be no comment before the release of the report, which is scheduled for Monday. A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials also withheld formal comment, but union leaders privately expressed disappointment. 
 Moreover, there is little support for labor in the new Republican-controlled Congress, which is likely to be a burial ground for any new legislation affecting worker rights.
"In the current political climate, it is highly unlikely that Congress would consider any recommendations to enhance union organizing," said Dan Yager, assistant general counsel of the Labor Policy Association, a business organization that lobbies Congress on labor issues.
Conflicts over union organizing are greater today than in the past and have become the major source of hostility between labor and management, the commission said in a preliminary "fact finding" report issued last May. To remedy this, it would have Congress change laws that might help reverse the decline in union membership over the last 20 years.
The 10-member panel, headed by John T. Dunlop, Labor Secretary in the Ford Administration, sought to balance the demands of employers and workers, members said.
To help labor, the commission would require the National Labor Relations Board to act much more quickly when workers say they were unlawfully dismissed for trying to organize unions at their companies. It would also have Congress establish a dispute mechanism, including perhaps binding arbitration, in cases where a newly elected union cannot negotiate a first contract.
Most important, the commission proposed ways to speed elections in which workers vote on whether to be represented by unions. That vote would have to be held two weeks after the National Labor Relations Board certified that the employees wanted such an election. Now, these elections are frequently delayed by management challenges.
"The main problem that concerned us was that these union elections were wars," said Richard B. Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard University and a commission member. "They go on for months, and they are a nasty business, and we wanted to stop this."
Union leaders consider the commission's recommendations inadequate. Instead of elections, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. had wanted the commission to favor making a union the automatic representative of a company's workers once a majority signed cards requesting this.
In the area of worker-management committees, the commission said these committees could deal "incidentally" with wages, work schedules and similar subjects as part of a broader effort to improve the workplace. That would ease, but not abolish, the current prohibition in the National Labor Relations Act, which says that bringing such subjects under committees that have been set up by management turns them into illegal sham unions.
By modifying the restriction, the commission tried to respond to what it saw as a growing demand among workers as well as employers for workplace committees.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: FOR THE RECORD;
New House Rules

 BODY:
In its first session, on Wednesday and into early yesterday morning, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives adopted several changes in rules and procedures, all of which take effect immediately.
 
COMMITTEES -- Three standing committees -- District of Columbia, Merchant Marine and Fisheries, and Post Office and Civil Service -- and 25 subcommittees were eliminated. 

COMMITTEE STAFF -- A total of 622 staff positions were eliminated, for an estimated annual saving of $35 million.
 
LEGISLATIVE SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS -- Public financing of service organizations like the Congressional Black Caucus and the Arts Caucus was eliminated.
 
BUDGET -- A "truth in budgeting" measure was adopted, requiring lawmakers to compare spending proposals with current spending levels rather than with current levels plus estimated inflation. Republicans said the earlier practice had encouraged higher spending.
 
TERM LIMITS -- The Speaker's tenure was limited to four consecutive terms, and that of the chairman of any given committee or subcommittee to three consecutive terms.
 
OPEN MEETINGS -- All committee meetings and hearings will be open to the public "except in extraordinary circumstances." This "sunshine" resolution allows, as a right, broadcast coverage of any meeting or hearing open to the public.
 
TAXES -- A majority of three-fifths of the House will be required for passage of any bill that would increase personal or corporate income taxes. There will also be a ban on any measure or amendment that would provide a retroactive increase in the income tax rate.
 
HOUSE AUDIT -- A requirement for a comprehensive independent audit of House operations was adopted.
 
DELEGATES -- Delegates who represent the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and American territories will be prohibited from voting on the House floor, a privilege they were permitted for the last two years if their votes stood no chance of affecting the outcome.
 
COMMEMORATIONS -- A ban on commemorative legislation, for instance a measure declaring National Asparagus Day, was adopted.

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: THE OVERVIEW;
Quick Movement on a Broad Variety of Issues Before the House and Senate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
As the 104th Congress began its second day in office, attention shifted to committees considering the legislative agenda Republicans have set for their party. The new Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said he was determined to pass the legislation by mid-April.
 
The Budget
 Senators from both parties said today that Congress would soon approve a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget, even though there are profound uncertainties about how it would be enforced. 
 The Clinton Administration attacked the proposal, a central goal of the new Republican majority in Congress, saying it would worsen future recessions and create an avalanche of lawsuits by people trying to enforce or resist its spending limits.
Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said: "The deficit rises whenever the economy weakens. Such temporary increases in the deficit act as economic stabilizers." Without such stabilizers, she said, "we would have worse recessions." She asserted, "It would just exaggerate the boom-bust cycle if we had to balance the budget every year."
But at a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Republicans and some Democrats said they found the Administration's arguments unconvincing. Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, said states with balanced budget amendments had not been inundated with lawsuits.
New estimates issued today by the Congressional Budget Office show the Federal budget deficit declining from $203 billion last year to $176 billion this year, then climbing to $284 billion in the year 2000 and $351 billion in 2003.
Most states already require balanced budgets at that level. But the prospects for ratification of the Federal proposal are unclear. A constitutional amendment takes effect only if ratified by legislatures in three-fourths of the states. A proposed amendment is not submitted to the President for approval or veto.
At the hearing today, Walter Dellinger, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Office of Legal Counsel, said, "The proposed amendment fails to address the critical question of how it will be enforced." In the absence of such details, he said, "state and Federal judges may well be required to make fundamental decisions about taxing and spending in order to enforce the amendment."
Thus, he testified, "the balanced budget amendment threatens to take the power of the purse away from elected representatives of the people and put it in the hands of an unelected judiciary." And if the courts do not intervene, he said, the amendment could be just "an unenforceable promise."
The amendment might also shift power to the President. Ordinarily, the President must spend money appropriated by Congress. But Mr. Dellinger said that under the amendment, a President could take "whatever steps he deems reasonable and necessary" to achieve a balanced budget. These steps might include budget cuts, new fees and maybe even tax increases, with or without explicit authorization from Congress, he said.
Despite the Administration's arguments, the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said he supported the balanced budget amendment. Another Democrat, Mr. Simon, is a chief sponsor.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the Judiciary Committee, acknowledged there might be problems with enforcement. But he said Congress would never balance the budget "if we don't have some mechanism in the Constitution that requires us" to do so. And Senator Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, said experience showed that "Congress isn't able to deal with the problem" by statute.
Ms. Rivlin said it was wrong for Congress to start "writing algebra into the Constitution." She said supporters of the amendment ought to specify how they would balance the budget. "What will be cut?" she asked. "Medicare? Social Security? Head Start? Food stamps? Road and bridge repair? National parks, homeless shelters? The American people have a right to know." ROBERT PEAR

HEADLINE: Challenges for Governor Rowland

 BODY:
There was good reason for the conciliatory tone in John Rowland's inaugural address as Governor of Connecticut. The first Republican governor in 20 years, he faces a split Legislature, with a solid Democratic majority in the House and a new but slim Republican majority in the Senate. Indeed, Democrats gained more House seats in Connecticut in the November elections than anywhere else in the country. If Mr. Rowland really means to repeal the state income tax -- his principal campaign promise -- he is going to need help.
Mr. Rowland heaped praise on his predecessor, the maverick independent Lowell Weicker, who defeated him in 1990. He promised compassion, "to help our young and old, our ill and afflicted, when they need help and have no other resources." And, attentive to urban deterioration in Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven as well as smaller cities, he implored "each and every civic-minded resident" of the state to help revive them. 
 But his biggest applause lines came straight from the campaign. He confirmed his pledge to phase out the personal income tax. He promised to use "our ultimate sanction" -- execution -- for murderers, even though Connecticut's death penalty has been in disuse for years and should stay that way. Finally, he promised to give local communities more control over their public schools and parents a greater say over where their children go to school.
There will be more detail next month in his State of the State address. But he has already made it clear he wants tax reduction to start this year.
Governor Weicker's outstanding achievement was enactment of an equitable income tax, ending the state's reliance on regressive and unstable sales tax collections. The income tax now provides more than one-quarter of the state's general revenue, and Mr. Rowland has yet to say how he intends to offset its loss -- which programs he would cut and which taxes might rise, either state or local.
With John Rowland and George Pataki of New York in place, and Pennsylvania soon to inaugurate Tom Ridge, the Governors of the biggest Northeastern industrial states will all be Republicans. Like the others, Governor Rowland promises to shrink his government. More than the others, he must cope with a pallid economy while trying to keep his budget in balance. This challenge may yet force him to rethink his pledge to do away with the income tax.

HEADLINE: Richer Than You Feel

 BODY:
Americans may feel battered by tough economic times, but by world standards they are doing just fine. The 400,000 residents of Luxembourg, says a survey by the World Bank, were the richest people on earth in 1993. Output per person, a rough proxy for income, averaged $29,510. Residents of the U.S. ranked second, averaging almost $25,000 each.
These figures take explicit account of price differences: a dollar of income in Luxembourg was calculated to buy approximately the same amount of goods and services as a dollar spent in the United States. 
 Nations ranked in the top ten produced at least $20,400 per person. They included industrialized countries (Canada and Japan), oil producers (Qatar and the United Arab Emirates) and Asian tigers (Hong Kong and Singapore). Western Europe accounted for ranks 11 through 20, except for rank 16, which went to Australia.
Mexico, a middle-income country, produced $7,000 per person. Russia produced only $5,000 per person -- about the same as Tunisia and Fiji. China produced even less, about $2,000 per person, still almost twice as much as Bangladesh and India. The bottom of the list is grim: Mozambique and Ethiopia produced $380 per person.
Living standards this low are appalling, especially since huge populations live on much less than the average. The bleak numbers should give pause to the new leadership in Congress that seems intent on cutting off the small amount of aid that the U.S. spends in Africa because it wastes taxpayer money.

HEADLINE: A Plausible Mexican Rescue Plan

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico, addressing shaken investors and anxious citizens, has proposed a coherent strategy to counter the plunging peso. The plan may not work as advertised; it could be improved. But it is probably good enough to return the economy, after a period of painful retrenchment, to prosperity.
Mexico has run large trade deficits that it has paid for with foreign loans. To keep loans flowing, Mexico offered investors high interest rates and a stable peso -- which Mexico sustained by buying excess pesos with dollars. When dollar reserves dwindled to alarming levels, Mexico was forced to let the peso float free. It plunged about 30 percent, driving up consumer prices overnight. 
 Mr. Zedillo's task was to balance Mexico's trade accounts. To that end, he proposed clamping down on wages and prices to stimulate exports; raising interest rates to retain foreign investors, and controlling government borrowing by cutting spending and selling state-owned enterprises.
These ideas are sound. Some are courageous. The spending cuts would exceed 1 percent of domestic output -- the equivalent of the U.S. Congress whacking about $70 billion out of the budget. Mr. Zedillo cajoled labor into accepting an 8 percent cut in wages after accounting for inflation. He persuaded companies to absorb some increased costs of production due to a fallen peso -- which drives up the price of imported equipment and raw materials.
But with austerity will also come slow growth, perhaps even recession. The plan makes these risks unnecessarily high. There is no obvious mechanism for enforcing the price guidelines; the wage restraints might not hold. If wages and prices take off, Mexico's exports will remain expensive and its trade imbalance will persist. And Mr. Zedillo did not overcome internal opposition to selling key parts of the state-owned oil monopoly, Pemex. Such sales could have generated billions of foreign reserves and lessened the need to raise foreign revenue by other, more punishing means: cutting spending, raising interest rates or driving the peso lower.
Despite the flaws, the Zedillo plan should be adequate, in large part because of an $18 billion stabilization fund paid for primarily by the U.S. with help from Canada and some international private banks. The size of the fund should reassure investors that their Mexican loans are safe -- and prevent the fears that undermined the peso from spreading elsewhere throughout Latin America.
The peso crisis has obscured an enduring Mexican achievement. Its market reforms have brought inflation under control, eliminated the federal deficit and initiated growth. These policies remain firmly in place -- in part because the Nafta trade accord with the U.S. and Canada prevents Mexico from backtracking. Mexicans will pay a price for their Government's tardy response to the trade imbalance. But Mr. Zedillo has now adopted a responsible plan that should eventually pave the way for recovery.

HEADLINE: If Pataki Really Rode With Teddy Roosevelt

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Teddy Roosevelt Along as Pataki Begins Ride" (news article, Jan. 1), describing the admiration of Gov. George E. Pataki of New York for the Republican Roosevelt, raises questions about Mr. Pataki's grasp of American political history. He may have been exposed to some of the country's finest scholars as an undergraduate at Yale, but he does not seem to have retained much of what they sought to teach him. 
 His reference to "anti-government Republicans, who were the Charles Sumner social Darwinists," confuses the Massachusetts Senator who struggled to gain political, social and economic equality for African-Americans in the Civil War era, and who recognized the necessity for positive government action to achieve this, with the Yale sociologist William Graham Sumner, whose "What Social Classes Owe to Each Other" (1883) argued that the state owed its citizens nothing but law, order and basic political rights.
Despite the Governor's rejection of this philosophy, should Mr. Pataki succeed in fulfilling his campaign promise to slash state spending, the citizens of New York may well find themselves operating within a Sumnerian framework of survival of the fittest.
Similarly, Governor Pataki's assertion that "the big government Wilsonian Democrats" favored creating "an agency to regulate something" is shaky on the facts. In seeking the White House in 1912, Woodrow Wilson associated himself with those whose aspirations and opportunities were thwarted by big business and its hirelings in Washington.
"The history of liberty is the history of the limitations of governmental power, not the increase of it," declared Wilson, the former president of Princeton. The realities of power would force him to modify his views and his policies, as they might for Governor Pataki, but in taking up the quest for social justice, Wilson was following the lead of none other than Theodore Roosevelt.
It was that Roosevelt who proclaimed in 1910 that "every man holds his property subject to the general right of the community to regulate its use to whatever degree the public welfare might require."
And it was Rosevelt's Progressive Party in 1912, with its support of more supervision of manufacturing and transportation corporations, of laws setting worker maximum hours and minimum wages, of an end to child labor and of creation of Government-run insurance and pension programs, that established the welfare state agenda achieved by Franklin D. Roosevelt, Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon.
Of all the men who have occupied the White House in this century, none was a stronger advocate of a more powerful Federal Government than Theodore Roosevelt. For Governor Pataki to suggest that Theodore Roosevelt did not want "to regulate markets or people's lives in an ongoing way" is to turn the historical record upside down.
As Governor Pataki sits in his Hudson River Valley home reading biographies of Theodore Roosevelt, he should also glance at books about the Governor and President with the same last name whose family home lies 30 miles upstream. In Albany as well as in Washington, Franklin D. Roosevelt modeled himself after his distant cousin, with beneficial results for the state and the country.
The new Governor has chosen wisely in adopting Theodore Roosevelt as his idol, but Mr. Pataki can emulate his success only if he understands what both these Harvard men stood for.
 
MARK I. GELFAND
Associate Professor of History
Boston College
Chestnut Hill, Mass., Jan. 3, 1995

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Real Revolution

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL; Anthony Lewis is on vacation.

 BODY:
Special to the new Congress, here is a dispatch from the revolution.
In El Segundo, Calif., just before Christmas, Mattel Inc., the toy manufacturer, made some announcements. 
 Dividends would increase, stockholders would get a stock split 5 for 4, the company would have record high sales and earnings for the sixth year in a row, the balance sheet was strong and getting even better.
Also, the company would eliminate 1,000 jobs, about 4 percent of its work force.
There you have it. Multiplied by hundreds of American companies, affecting the lives of American workers and the middle class, diminishing old dreams and creating new fears, this kind of news adds up to the real American revolution of the 90's. It was moving fast through the country long before the election upheaval in November and will be around when the new members of Congress face their term limits.
Good show, say the analysts, way to go. No C.E.O. who intends to remain a C.E.O. has to be told the mantra: Increased production through mergers and the new technologies must lead to increased profit and decreased payrolls in a continuing cycle.
The deal most workers thought they had -- that their jobs would be safer and wages higher if things were good at the factory -- is over.
One day, if the nation is lucky, the Republican Congress may realize that its job is not simply to bring about a new revolution but to steer the revolution that was created for America in the new world market.
Felix Rohatyn, senior partner of Lazard Freres, believes that the work force will "cleave," creating an elite of 25 to 30 percent.
Mr. Rohatyn says that a huge transfer of wealth has occurred, moving from lower-skilled middle-class workers to the owners of capital assets and to a new technological aristocracy -- with a large element of compensation tied to stock values. He sees no solution to the technological-economic upheaval he thinks is the key problem of the country.
Another friend, who has created wealth for himself and jobs for thousands out of a kind of Mozartean business mind, is almost giddy with pleasure. He thinks the technological marketplace, a Republican victory, lower taxes and reduced government will liberate the private sector to produce jobs and joy. The man has been right before.
But not always. And meantime the non-elite, the 70 percent or so, become the foundering, searching, angry, anxious people. They will not be qualified to find decent jobs after they are personally downsized, work that fulfills their hopes as stakeholders in American society.
The working-middle class now take out their resentments on the very poor, very foreign or very Democratic. They will discover that will help them as much as aspirin helps a corpse. Neither welfare recipients, Mexican immigrants nor the local Democratic assemblyman have much to do with an economic-technological revolution that pushes hard-working people from the campfire.
Many of them could turn against a society that broke its deal and stuck a "loser" sticker on their foreheads. They may vote for demagogues who reject the society that has turned away from them.
There's no way to repeal the technological revolution. But there are ways to make sure it does not devour the working-middle class by destroying an expectation of job security in good times -- not too much to ask and too much to surrender.
That would need the cooperation of government and business. It would be needed to provide the training displaced workers need to equip them for decent jobs, something society has failed to do -- and to cut a trail for youngsters wandering so far from the campfire they have never felt its warmth. There might still be an elite, but not a working underclass marked "rejected."
Something important stands in the way -- the movement to make ideologies out of politics, to draw an almost theological line between conservative and liberal.
I wrote something hopeful about business not long ago. A reader from Oregon sent me the news from El Segundo to show you couldn't expect anything from American businessmen. But then he never met Felix Rohatyn or Mozart.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mexico Can Meet Its Debts, Finance Chief Tells Bankers

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
International investors seemed to increase confidence in Mexico's future yesterday as the country's new Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, told banking officials that his country could pay its debts.
In a whirlwind day in New York, Mr. Ortiz also sought to reassure investors by saying that Mexico would ask the International Monetary Fund for its stamp of approval on the economic-recovery plan it announced on Tuesday, after having devalued the peso in December. 
 Addressing a standing-room-only crowd in the ballroom of the Pierre Hotel yesterday morning, the American-educated Mr. Ortiz said Mexico now had $24 billion in new international credits and monetary reserves. They will be used, he said, to stabilize the peso and allow owners of $17 billion worth of foreign-held dollar-indexed treasury notes, known as tesobonos, to get their money out safely if they wished.
"We have a fundamentally sound economy," Mr. Ortiz said. "We do not have a solvency problem. We can pay our debts."
Objecting to comparisons with Mexico's bond default more than a decade ago, a development that ushered in a larger-scale Latin American foreign debt crisis, Mr. Ortiz declared, "The situation is completely different from what it was in 1982."
Describing the peso as "grossly undervalued," the Finance Minister said he expected to see it stabilize at about 4.50 to the dollar. But he emphasized that this was not a rate the Mexican central bank intended to defend by interventions in the currency markets.
Mr. Ortiz told the bankers that Mexico was working with leading New York investment banks and brokerage houses, including J. P. Morgan, Goldman, Sachs and Lehman Brothers, to create a series of longer-term, high-interest, dollar-indexed bonds that it would offer to foreign holders of the expiring short-term treasury notes.
Mr. Ortiz appeared to reassure most of the bankers present, who warmly applauded his two-hour presentation and the question-and-answer session.
John F. H. Purcell, director of emerging-markets research at Salomon Brothers, said an informal poll he took afterward showed that about two-thirds of those present were impressed by the Finance Minister's remarks and answers to questions.
"I see this as a turnaround point," Mr. Purcell said. "But it may take the market a while to believe it. Mr. Ortiz demonstrated that someone is in charge and that major political forces in the country are behind him."
To further strengthen confidence in the Government's economic program, Mr. Ortiz said he would visit the International Monetary Fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, in Washington today, not to ask him for more money but to win official support from the fund.
Mexico hopes to receive $14 billion in direct foreign investment, new bank loans and supplier credits this year. That should be sufficient, Mr. Ortiz insisted, to finance a current-account deficit the Government is committed to cutting by at least half -- to less than $14 billion.
Finally, the Finance Minister announced details of a plan to sell state-owned assets. The privatizations, expected to yield $12 billion to $14 billion, are to include part of the nation's electricity-generating monopoly as well as container ports, airports and satellite broadcasting and telecommunications rights. The oil industry remains out of bounds.
James Calmenares, a vice president at Morgan Stanley Asset Management, was also impressed by Mr. Ortiz's presentation. "It is very clear they are now dealing appropriately with the problem," he said.
On currency markets yesterday, the peso strengthened, rising in New York to close at 5.35 to the dollar, compared with 5.575 on Wednesday. The Mexico City stock market was up slightly, with the Bolsa index closing at 2,273.10, a gain of 0.14 percent. American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico declined slightly, closing down 12.5 cents at $38 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Ortiz's New York appearance was intended to clear away much of the confusion sowed by Mexico's bungled attempt last month at a 15 percent devaluation, which led in a day and a half to the Government's having to floating the peso instead.
Matters were only made worse by an unsuccessful attempt by then-Finance Minister Jaime Serra Puche to reassure American investors at a similar New York pep talk late last month. He resigned shortly afterward.
Mexico's new President, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, further damaged foreign confidence when he postponed his address to the nation on the crisis and then sketched in unsatisfying detail the measures his Government would take.
These include limits on wage increases to prevent the peso's fall from leading to an inflationary spiral, cuts in Government spending and a tighter monetary policy.
After the meeting yesterday at the Pierre Hotel, Mr. Ortiz held a smaller lunch with representatives of 10 major United States banks. Citibank's vice chairman, William R. Rhodes, who organized the lunch, said Mr. Ortiz gave "a forceful presentation, which impressed everyone with his realism as to what has to be done."
The Finance Minister also met yesterday with New York-based credit rating agencies and other big investors in Mexico.
Of $28 billion worth of tesobonos due to expire this year, Mr. Ortiz said $17 billion was owned by foreigners, mainly Americans. The remaining $11 billion is held by Mexican banks, which are expected to roll them over.
He gave no details of the new bonds he is planning to offer the foreign tesobono holders, except to say that they would have longer maturities and carry an attractive rate of interest. "We acknowledge that we will have to pay higher rates of interest than in the past," he said, adding, "We have to acknowledge the realities of the market."
Bankers say the Mexican central bank is likely to use some of the $24 billion stabilization package -- made up of $18 billion in new credits from the United States, Canada and the Bank for International Settlements, and $6 billion left in its reserves -- to support the peso during the turnover of the bonds, allowing investors to get their dollars back.
Mr. Ortiz said only that all the $24 billion "is available for intervention, but not for imprudent intervention."

HEADLINE: A Bankruptcy Peculiar to California

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Here's one cutting-edge California phenomenon that is not likely to make it big elsewhere in the nation: the first major bankruptcy of a local government caused by taking risky bets with taxpayers' money.
The $2 billion investment loss that forced Orange County to declare bankruptcy in December can be traced largely to local recklessness in the face of fiscal and economic pressures that are peculiar to California. Indeed, while a number of municipalities around the country have been plagued by losses from financial derivatives gone bad, the worst troubles are concentrated in this state. Apart from Orange County, for instance, a recent nationwide survey of local governments found that six other California counties stood out as engaging in "significantly more aggressive" investment strategies than was typical. 
 "Orange County's problem is not a national problem," said Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States in Albany. "Local governments across the country are strapped, but none has pursued such risky strategies to raise money because no state is as hemmed in by restrictions against raising taxes."
Those restrictions and California's own fiscal distress will also make digging out of the hole that much more difficult. Economists say that Orange County must now undergo a belt tightening it long avoided by relying so heavily on the profits from its investment pool.
"Orange County will do what it already should have, which is to cut services," said Esmail Adibi, director of the Center for Economic Research at Chapman University in the city of Orange.
Just last June, for instance, as employers like GM Hughes Electronics were drastically reducing their work forces in Orange County, the county government added 900 people to its payroll, largely to handle an increase in the welfare caseload. And it spent $1.5 million to acquire land near the John Wayne Airport to build an office building despite vast empty office space in the area left by the recession.
In fact, while the private sector in the county lost 55,000 jobs from 1990 through 1994, the local government and its districts, Mr. Adibi calculates, "managed to add 6,000 people to the payroll, paid for by bond financings and investment returns."
The roots of the problem that erupted with such fury in Orange County in December can be traced back to 1978. That's when California voters overwhelmingly approved Proposition 13, a citizen referendum that rolled back local property taxes to 1 percent of market value and limited increases to no more than 2 percent a year. It took other special circumstances, however, to put so many California counties in such difficult positions.
Shortly after Proposition 13 was adopted, the state government, bolstered by a fat surplus and a cornucopia of tax revenues received in the booming 80's, stepped in to keep local governments afloat by providing them with extra funds to carry out their duties. It also shouldered them with extra responsibilities. But when the state's economy slowed in the late 1980's and then plunged into recession, California's coffers ran dry. The obligations only increased.
Most local governments were squeezed between lower tax revenues and rising costs for education, health care and law enforcement. That pressure was intensified by a slew of additional state mandates and a continuing influx of immigrants, who put extra demands on government services. The state, in response, relaxed even further restrictions on investments so local treasurers could seek higher returns, despite the higher risks.
Robert L. Citron, the Orange County treasurer who resigned just before the county filed for bankruptcy, was a key author of the legislation allowing counties to borrow heavily and invest in riskier securities.
Orange County, while clearly the most daring, was not the only place in California to take advantage of the new freedom to speculate with taxpayer money. The risky investment practices that wreaked havoc in Orange County, Moody's Investors Service found, were also pursued actively in six other counties: San Diego, San Bernardino, Monterey, Placer, Solano and Sonoma. Only a scattering of places outside California were so aggressive.
After the bankruptcy, Moody's, a leading Wall Street credit-rating agency, surveyed 1,450 counties, cities, school districts and local agencies across the country. Orange County stood alone in the degree to which it took chancy interest rate bets, relied on borrowed money and allowed municipalities outside the county to join its pool, according to the bond rating agency. (Moody's has now vowed to alter its standards for judging municipal bonds after failing to detect Orange County's troubles in advance.)
"None has the characteristics of Orange County's pool," said David Brodsly, a vice president in Moody's San Francisco office.
But a few others deserve close attention. San Diego, for instance, whose $3.3 billion fund has dropped 11 percent in value, told investors in December that they would share in that loss if they tried to withdraw their money. The action was taken in a bid to prevent a run on its fund similar to the one that led to Orange County's bankruptcy.
Nor is Orange County the only one of California's 58 counties that is on the ropes. Verging on collapse, eight tiny counties asked the Legislature for a $15 million bailout package in the fall. They were turned down.
Merced County is negotiating with the state for $6 million in relief, while Butte received $11 million in the early 1990's, a loan that it has yet to pay back.
Perhaps the biggest blow to these communities came from the state's own hardship, and particularly, from a 1988 voter initiative, Proposition 98, that mandated specific levels of state spending on education. To fulfill that obligation, the state has largely drawn on county resources.
Over the last three fiscal years, according to Terry Brennand, a lobbyist for the California Association of County Treasurers, the state has redirected $4 billion in local property taxes to the schools. That has left counties with less money to pay for libraries, parks and other services not mandated by the state, shaving their discretionary spending, in some cases, to as little as 5 percent from an average 17 percent in the late 80's, according to Dan Wall, an official at the California State Association of Counties.
Some counties managed in part by increasing their reliance on the public markets for financing. Although California makes up about 12 percent of the national economy, it accounted for 16 percent, or $26 billion, of all long-term municipal bonds issued in 1994, according to the Securities Data Company. Merrill Lynch, the biggest municipal underwriter and deeply involved in Orange County's troubles, handled 37 percent of the business.
The squeeze also encouraged exotic local financings -- sale leasebacks, special tax assessments and fees -- that have made California's tax system among the most cumbersome in the country.
"We now have a system of government," said Jeffrey Chapman, a professor of public administration at the University of Southern California, "that is so arcane that only 15 people in the state understand it."
Counties also searched for bigger investment returns, with some following the lead of Mr. Citron, the treasurer of Orange County for more than two decades who emerged as something of a Pied Piper in the state because his investment returns were consistently higher than most municipal treasurers in the country.
But with the risks of Mr. Citron's strategies now abundantly clear, California is moving to tighten investment requirements on local governments. Curt Pringle, an Assemblyman from Garden Grove in Orange County, has introduced a bill that would limit borrowing to 10 percent of a county's portfolio, restrict the use of derivatives to 5 percent, and ban raising money from bonds strictly for investment. A similar measure is expected to be introduced soon in the State Senate, which held hearings in December on Orange County.
Still, municipal bond experts say the state government, by failing to play a more active role in repairing the damage in Orange County, could end up casting a long shadow over California's finances. Other cities on the verge of bankruptcy -- New York, Philadelphia and Cleveland among them -- relied heavily on their states to back bond offerings and other measures that helped overcome budget squeezes.
"In every other major credit crisis in government in the last 25 years, states have taken a lead role," said J. Chester Johnson, chairman of Government Finance Associates Inc., a financial adviser to state and local governments in New York. "There is an implied moral obligation of states to help their municipalities. Without the leadership and support of California in dealing with this bankruptcy, all state issues will continue to suffer in the market."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
AT&T Seeks Stake in India's Phone Market

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Following other major American companies that have set their sights on India's potentially huge markets, the AT&T Corporation said today that it would seek a share in the $7.5 billion expansion of India's creaky telephone system.
"With a population of nearly 900 million people and less than one telephone for every 100 people, it's clearly one of the largest telecommunications markets in the world," said John Legere, a senior executive of AT&T Asia/Pacific Inc., at a news conference. 
 AT&T has teamed up in its bid with one of India's most powerful industrial giants, the Aditya V. Birla Group, a conglomerate with more than $4 billion in annual revenues. Together, the companies plan to bid for contracts to provide telephone services in several of the country's largest markets, including three key industrial states: Gujarat, Karnataka and Maharashtra.
India's telephone system has been widely regarded as a major obstacle to the country's economic modernization. Since India became independent in 1947, telephone services, like other key economic sectors, have been a Government monopoly. But the Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao decided last year to introduce private competition.
The Telecommunications Ministry announced last week that on Jan. 16 it would invite bids for contracts to supply conventional telephone services in 20 zones that correspond roughly to the boundaries of India's 25 states. Bidders will also be invited to make offers for mobile phone services in 19 zones. The ministry said results of the bidding would be announced on March 31.
The Government plans to increase the number of telephones installed across India to 20 million by the end of the decade from 7.2 million at present, at an estimated cost of $7.5 billion. About half of the new phones will come from the telecommunications ministry and half from private companies.
In addition to AT&T, foreign companies that have shown interest in the new contracts include Alcatel Alsthom of France, Fujitsu of Japan and Siemens of Germany.
At the news conference, AT&T executives cited statistics that showed how India lagged behind other Asian nations in telephone service. They said that India currently had 0.8 telephone for every 100 people, compared with 1.7 telephones for every 100 Chinese, 2 for every 100 Pakistanis, and 13 for every 100 Malaysians.
In addition, Indian customers wait months and sometimes years to have phones installed, and fewer than 40 percent of all calls dialed are routed to the right number, compared with 99.9 percent in the United States.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Jumped 2.6% in November

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
American factories posted a sharp rise in new orders for November and shipped more finished products than in October, the Commerce Department said today in a report that showed the manufacturing sector was still expanding briskly.
Orders rose 2.6 percent, or $7.4 billion, in November to a seasonally adjusted $293.4 billion, following a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent in October orders. 
 It marked the eighth month in 1994 in which orders increased -- a show of industrial vigor likely to carry total 1994 orders to a level about 10 percent higher than in 1993.
Backlogs of unfilled orders kept growing, rising seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $453.9 billion in November after an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in October. It was the third consecutive month in which order backlogs rose and suggested that factories have plenty of work on hand.
"This level of backlogs points to continued momentum in the factory sector," with only a few signs on the horizon of an expected 1995 slowing, said Lynn Reaser, an economist with First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
On Tuesday, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its latest survey indicated some steam might have gone out of business in December. Although still expanding, manufacturing was less vigorous than in November.
There were other indications, too, that rising interest rates may be about to slow the pace of economic expansion to around 2.9 percent this year from an expected 3.9 percent for all of 1994.
The Commerce Department said today that housing completions dropped 1.3 percent in November to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.35 million. In addition, the Labor Department reported a pickup in claims for unemployment insurance benefits last week to 335,000 from 321,000 in the week ended Dec. 24.
The resurgent United States economy created about three million new jobs in 1994 but most private economists say that will ease to about two million jobs this year -- still a generally healthy jobs outlook.
During November, manufacturing businesses were strong by any measure. Durable goods orders that account for about half of total factory business shot up 3.4 percent after falling eight-tenths of 1 percent in October. Most of that was accounted for by a 12.7 percent jump in orders for transportation goods, including new cars and airplanes and parts, after a 9.4 percent drop in October.
 Even excluding transportation, factory orders rose 1.2 percent in November following a 1 percent rise in October.

HEADLINE: Regulators See No Need for Tougher Rules on Derivatives

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Federal regulators and members of the Senate Banking Committee expressed little enthusiasm today for putting broad new controls on the derivatives market after the heavy losses in Orange County, Calif. But they said a few narrow regulatory changes might be needed.
The Acting Treasury Secretary, Frank N. Newman, led several financial regulators in telling the committee at a hearing today that he saw no current need for Congress to introduce broad rules covering derivatives, which are financial contracts that vary widely in value with interest rates, stock prices, currencies or commodity prices. The existing legislation provides adequate discretion to regulators, he said. 
 Taking a position similar to that of Wall Street derivatives dealers, Mr. Newman said Orange County ran into trouble not because of investments in derivatives but because of a flawed investment strategy. "It purchased long-term securities with short-term loans," he said, and lost money when short-term interest rates rose sharply last year.
The committee's new Republican majority showed little enthusiasm for imposing new rules on either the sale of derivatives by Wall Street firms or their purchase by municipalities.
"Frankly, I see few Federal issues that are raised by the Orange County bankruptcy," said Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican of North Carolina. "We don't need more regulations, we need fewer."
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, also warned that it would be a mistake to impose tough new regulations on derivatives. He said the Fed's recent requirement that Bankers Trust in New York disclose more information to its customers using derivatives was an isolated decision and not indicative of any move toward more comprehensive regulation.
The broad hostility to regulating the derivatives market, however, did not extend to several narrower changes. The regulators and several senators expressed a strong interest in requiring municipalities and other buyers of derivatives to disclose more of the risks to credit rating agencies and the public.
And Mr. Newman reminded the senators that an interagency group was reviewing whether to impose rules that would define the way Wall Street went about selling a certain class of particularly risky derivatives known as structured notes.
Typically issued by Government-sponsored enterprises like the Federal National Mortgage Association, structured notes pay highly complicated interest rates. The interest earned on some of Orange County's structured notes, known as "inverse floaters," fell when interest rates rose nationwide.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development has also begun an inquiry into sales of structured notes by Government-sponsored enterprises.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Fall On Fears of Brisk Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday amid investor concern about the employment report for December that is scheduled to be released this morning. Behind much of the selling was worry that the numbers would show brisk economic growth that could cause inflation to accelerate and interest rates to rise.
The 30-year bond fell 11/32 , to a price of 9521/32 for a yield of 7.88 percent, up from 7.85 percent on Wednesday. The long bond, by the close of the New York market, gave back about half of Wednesday's gain. 
 Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management in Washington, said what worried bond traders and investors was not the overall jobs number, which some forecasters expect to show a gain of 260,000 in nonfarm payrolls. What they are more worried about, he said, is what what they find in the details.
Mr. Carpenter, whose firm has more than $9 billion under management, said he expected the average number of hours worked to rise three-tenths of a percent and because of that inflation worries would start building. He said the market would also be looking at the index of hours worked in the manufacturing sector, both for factory work as well as overtime.
"I expect both will be up from the prior month," he said, "reflecting a manufacturing sector that was humming toward the end of the year."
A stronger-than-expected report yesterday on factory orders for November added to the long list of monthly indicators that implied a healthy gain in fourth-quarter economic growth, and that weighed on market prices. Orders rose 2.6 percent in November after falling four-tenths of 1 percent in October. Economists had forecast a 2 percent rise in November.
"It really doesn't matter how you analyze the number, it was strong," Mr. Carpenter said. "Up until this point, the main strength in the manufacturing sector has derived primarily from the strength in durable goods orders. But this month, in addition to that strength, we also had a healthy 1.7 percent jump in nondurables." This suggested, he said, that the next round of factory order data would also be robust.
And with the fourth-quarter growth rate looking more like 5 percent, Mr. Carpenter said that strong momentum could be expected to carry over into the first quarter. He said he thought this growth would force the Federal Reserve to raise the Federal funds rate another three-quarters of a percentage point when its policy-making committee meets at the end of the month.
Elsewhere, housing completions were down 1.3 percent, to 1.347 million units. Jobless claims for the week ended Dec. 31 were up 14,000, to 335,000. Some forecasters had expected a small drop to 320,000. According to Kathleen Stephansen, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the level of claims for the week was the highest since July 16, when it was at 390,000.
In the municipal market, bonds were little changed. Expectations of a drop in bond issuance led some of yesterday's new sales to be priced above market levels. One of the day's largest deals was a double-A rated $107.9 million offering by the Texas A & M University Board of Regents won by Merrill Lynch. The serial bonds were priced at par to yield from 4.25 percent in 1995 to 6.40 percent in 2011 and 2012.
At yesterday's auction of new one-year bills the Treasury said the average rate rose 11 basis points from last month's auction, to 6.86 percent. That was the highest since Oct. 26, 1990, when it was 7.01 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines on Turmoil Over Spanish Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against leading currencies yesterday as traders bought German marks as a haven from turmoil in Spanish financial markets.
The dollar was also weaker from profit taking after its rise against the Japanese yen on Wednesday. 
 The Bank of Spain raised its benchmark interest rate to 8 percent from 7.35 percent on Wednesday, prompting sharp declines in Spanish stocks and the peseta.
"People were buying marks for pesetas like crazy," said Vicki Schmelzer Alicea, vice president of currency sales at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale in New York.
The flight to marks, Europe's strongest currency, weakened the dollar because traders buying marks for Spanish pesetas often execute the transaction by buying dollars for pesetas, then selling the dollars for marks. The mark neared its record high against the peseta, rising to 85.51 pesetas, from 85.04 on Wednesday. The mark reached a record of 85.87 pesetas on Dec. 28.
While higher interest rates tend to bolster a currency, the markets saw the increase by the Spanish central bank, its first since November 1992, as insufficient. Many currency dealers doubt that the Spanish Government will be able to bring inflation down to the target of 3.5 percent it set for the end of this year.
The Spanish markets will be closed today in observance of the Epiphany.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5510 marks from 1.5590 marks on Wednesday, and to 1.3005 Swiss francs from 1.3105 francs. The British pound rose to $1.5630 from $1.5605.
The dollar fell to 100.87 yen from 101.36 yen. Dollar sales by Japanese exporters helped drive up the yen, currency dealers said. The exporters sold yesterday to take advantage of the dollar's rise to a four-month high of 101.46 yen on Wednesday.
"Japanese exporters have been on holiday since before Christmas, and on their return from vacation they are finding much more attractive levels to lock in their dollar sales," said Jack Griffin, currency sales manager at Fuji Bank in New York.
Even so, dealers expect the dollar to rise in the coming sessions, bolstered by expectations of another increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve at the end of January.
The dollar could reach 1.58 marks and 102 yen this month, said Win Thin, currency analyst at MCM Currencywatch, a consulting firm.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Demand Lifts Price of Oil; African Drought Buoys Corn

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Commodities, led by gasoline, rose yesterday amid signs that demand for energy products might be unexpectedly strong this winter.
"U.S. gasoline demand will be stronger than previously thought," Morris Greenberg, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, said. 
 Recent warm weather and consumer confidence have helped prop up gasoline sales during a season when driving typically slumps.
Elsewhere, crude oil prices rose, while corn and coffee prices gained after reports overseas that exports might be reduced this year. The Commodity Research Bureau index rose 0.62 point, to 235.84, well above its 12-month average.
American gasoline inventories were little changed last week, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday. Supplies held steady even as refiners produced almost eight million barrels a day, close to the record set a month ago.
"The inventory report looked very constructive," Mr. Greenberg said. Despite high gasoline production, "stockpiles didn't build and it was the fourth consecutive week of strong delivery" to buyers by refiners, he said, adding, "There's no indication of a letup in demand."
Unleaded gasoline for February delivery rose 1.08 cents, to 54.51 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. February crude oil climbed 24 cents, to $17.72 a barrel. February heating oil gained 0.32 cent, to 49.96 cents a gallon.
Corn futures also rose in price. A drought in South Africa that has ravaged the country's crop could increase United States exports.
According to a United States agricultural attache report released this week from Pretoria, the South African capital, the drought could reduce the country's 1994-95 corn crop by 30 percent and its exports as much as 90 percent.
Corn for March delivery at the Chicago Board of Trade rose 2 cents to settle at $2.3075 a bushel.
Coffee futures prices rose as Central American producers met in El Salvador to work on a plan announced last month to withhold 20 percent of their exports from the market until coffee prices rose again. Colombia, a big South American producer, said it might adopt the plan.
March coffee futures rose 4.55 cents to settle at $1.7255 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK REGION'S ECONOMY SPUTTERS
 Economic expansion and job growth in the New York region have come to a virtual halt since July, and higher interest rates are further undermining the region's prospects, according to economists, executives and government officials. Although the New York region shows few signs of sinking back into recession, the experts say the local economy remains one of the weakest in the nation, when business activity elsewhere is so robust that the Federal Reserve has raised interest rates six times since February to ward off inflation. A1.
 
SECURITY AT MENTAL HOSPITALS CRITICIZED
 The state's top mental health official said that the man accused of pushing a woman to her death under a subway train should not have have had the freedom to walk away from a mental hospital and that the state needed to improve the security at its mental institutions. Dr. Bruce Feig, the executive deputy commissioner of mental health, said the suspect, Reuben Harris, should have been classified as dangerous -- a designation that would have required tighter control of his movements. HEADLINE: Budget Director Quits to Take State Senate Job, Forcing Giuliani to Juggle Staff

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget director resigned yesterday, forcing the Mayor to juggle his senior fiscal staff as the city faces mounting financial problems this fiscal year and a looming $2 billion deficit next year.
The budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, who was a major architect of Mr. Giuliani's strategy to reduce spending and cut the size of the municipal work force, will return to his home in Albany to become the top fiscal aide to the Republican-controlled State Senate and a special adviser to Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader. Mr. Lackman had held a lower-level fiscal position in the Senate before coming to City Hall. 
 With his preliminary plan for the 1996 fiscal year due in just a month, Mr. Giuliani immediately tapped his Finance Commissioner, Marc V. Shaw, 40, to move into the budget director's post. Mr. Shaw had worked closely with Mr. Lackman and was previously the chief fiscal aide to the City Council.
Mr. Giuliani announced the departure of Mr. Lackman just a day after telling council officials and the Comptroller that the city's fiscal position was worsening once again, this time because tax revenues were coming in below expectations. Senior aides, some of them appearing stunned, stood by as Mr. Giuliani late yesterday said that he had learned of Mr. Lackman's decision only that morning. Mr. Lackman was at a hearing at the Transit Authority, and returned to City Hall only an hour after the Mayor left.
Mr. Giuliani said he had anticipated that Mr. Lackman might be interested in returning to Albany, where his wife and a teen-age son still live. He praised Mr. Lackman as someone who "helped to turn the city around." He also expressed hope that Mr. Lackman would prove a crucial ally in Albany where he will be a key figure in negotiating the budget.
"I think he will also be very valuable to the city of New York because we will have someone in a critical position in Albany who understands in depth the real issues that face the city and the state," he said.
Mr. Shaw, who has been a close friend of Mr. Lackman for years, takes over as budget director at a time when the city faces persistent fiscal problems and difficult political choices.
Just this week, administration officials acknowledged that tax revenues for the end of 1994 had dropped at least $200 million more than they had expected because of a downturn on Wall Street. That could leave the city with a gap as high as $500 million before the fiscal year ends in June.
Further complicating the Mayor's efforts to balance the budget, a Federal judge this week ordered the city to suspend budget cuts in the agency that administers welfare benefits until it can prove the reductions will not affect aid for the poorest New Yorkers.
In addition, the city still faces a potential deficit of $2 billion next year, despite a year of deep budget cuts and the elimination of 14,000 jobs. Mr. Lackman had already begun planning for a budget that would tackle the problem in large part by cutting $1.2 billion from health and welfare grant programs for the poor. The move would mark a sharp departure from the city's tradition of sometimes unparalleled generosity toward the needy, but Mr. Lackman has said it would put New York City on the same course as Albany and Washington.
While aides to Mr. Giuliani acknowledged that Mr. Lackman's departure, which is slated for the end of the month, comes at a difficult time, they said Mr. Shaw had attended every meeting on fiscal policy and was well positioned to take over. "He's been a full partner in virtually every single decision we've made with regard to the economy, budget, the budget decisions for the city," Mr. Giuliani said.
A major fiscal question facing the Giuliani administration is how Mr. Bruno and Gov. George E. Pataki, who faces a $5 billion gap in the state budget and who is committed to cutting taxes, will view aid to New York City. Both Republicans have had a strained relationship with the Mayor because of his decision last fall to cross party lines and campaign for Democratic Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Mr. Bruno, a Pataki ally who toppled Ralph J. Marino to become majority leader after the election, had at one point referred to the Mayor as "Judas Giuliani."
Although Mr. Lackman's name had surfaced in recent months as a possible contender to be Mr. Pataki's budget director, aides to the new Governor said he had never seriously been considered for the post, largely because of Mr. Pataki's adversarial relationship with Mr. Giuliani. But Mr. Lackman, 46, had many fans in the Senate where he had been director of fiscal affairs for the Senate Finance Committee before he was recruited by Mr. Giuliani.
"I think he's one of the best," Mr. Bruno said. "He has a wealth of experience, a wealth of knowledge about government operations."
Mr. Lackman, who earned $110,000 as budget director, will be paid $99,000 in his new job, where his titles will be secretary to the Senate Finance Committee and Special Adviser to the Majority Leader.
Mr. Bruno said that he was reducing the salary of the post from its current level of $104,000 as part of cost-saving measures he has imposed since his nomination as majority leader in November. Mr. Bruno also said that the compensation for the job would no longer include a car.
Mr. Lackman dismissed the salary cut last night, saying, "Money has never been an issue for me." He said the main reason for his departure was the strain his job had put on his wife, Jeanne, and son Aaron, 16, who had remained in the Albany suburbs while Mr. Lackman moved in with in-laws in Brooklyn. He said that because of the demands of the budget director post, he had only been able to visit them once a month.
"The job puts a lot of pressure -- and it's a pressure other people face as well -- on families," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Finance Commissioner, Marc V. Shaw, left, will replace Abraham M. Lackman, right, as budget director. (Rachel Cobb for The New York Times)
 
Chronology: "Tracking
 
JULY: The 1995 fiscal year begins after the Mayor and the Council agree on more than $1 billion oncuts and other actions to close a potential gap of $2.3 billion in a $31.6 billion budget.
 
OCTOBER: After tax revenues fall and anticipated Federal and state aid fails to materialize over the summer, the Mayor proposes a second round of cuts to close a new gap of $1.1 billion that has opened in the budget.
 
NOVEMBER: Unable to reach an agreement with the Mayor on cuts to educations, youth services and social programs, the City Council passes its own version of budget cuts, restoring $96 million in spending in some areas and replacing it with equal cuts in other agencies. Mr. Giuliani vetoes the Council's plan, calling it "blatantly illegal."
 
DECEMBER: With Mr. Giuliani saying he will ignore the override of his veto, the City Council sues the Mayor for the first time since it was created in 1938. A state judge throws out both the Mayor's plan and the Council's version. As the year ends, theMayor announces that he will unilaterally impose $800 million in spending cuts to keep the budget balanced.
 
JANUARY: Officials acknowledge that the city still faces a budget gap of $500 million or more for the fiscal year that ends in June because tax revenues fell further than expected in the wake of a downturn on Wall Street. The size of the budget gap for the next fiscal year has gorwn to $2 billion. With cuts in state aid virtuallycertain because the state faces a $5 billion gap and a Governor committed to cutting taxes, the gap could grow even larger, forcing still more cuts in services.
 
YESTERAY: The Mayor's budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, resigns to take ajob with the Republicans who control the State Senate. STEVEN LEE MEYERS

HEADLINE: Rail Death: Mother, 93, Says 'Why?'

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
For more than 24 hours, La Chang Soon did not know of her daughter's fate. Her own health failing, the 93-year-old woman was told that her daughter had been hospitalized after falling ill.
But as time wore on, the truth could no longer be hidden. Yesterday the sobs of a grieving mother filled the family's small Brooklyn apartment as a steady stream of visitors offered condolences and prayers. 
 The woman's daughter, Soon Sin, herself a mother of three and grandmother of six, died on Wednesday beneath the wheels of a roaring subway train. A mentally ill homeless man had pushed her onto the tracks as she waited for a train at Herald Square, the police said. Legions of commuters watched as a lone man held the suspect in a bear hug until the police arrived.
"Why? Why? Why?" the mother cried in Korean, her native tongue, as friends and family tried to console her. "She was so good and kind. Why was my girl killed like that?"
In the well-maintained, working-class apartment building on Marine Avenue in Bay Ridge, where Soon Sin had lived with her family for more than 10 years, neighbors yesterday lamented the death of a woman whom their children called Grandma. They told of how she spoke halting English but would communicate with a smile and gifts of fresh fruit, of how she always encouraged them to go to church.
They gathered in the living room that had served as a bedroom for Mrs. Sin, 63, and her husband, Kang Sik Sin, 65, who had shared the tiny fourth-floor apartment with her elderly mother.
Mr. Sin sat stoically on a sofa, under a framed passage of Scripture written in Korean. He was surrounded by his three grown sons, who were dressed in black suits and white shirts. Sadness showed in their eyes even though no tears were shed. The women in the room did not try to hide their grief, and their wailing could be heard throughout the building's hallways.
The family, almost all their words spoken in Korean, sat and tried to understand sudden death in New York City, and how its victims are chosen.
"We weren't going to tell Grandmother at first, because we didn't want to have two funerals," said Chong Ho Sin, 41, the couple's oldest son, who is married and lives on Staten Island. "But we had to tell her because we could not explain all of the visitors."
Mrs. Sin came to the United States with her husband and three sons from Chongju, South Korea, in 1978, seeking economic opportunity and a better education for the children.
"She lived for us, my father, the church and helping people," said her son David Shin, 37, an accountant who lives in Hempstead, L.I. "Even in Korea, she was active in the church. She was always praying.
"My mom was not a woman of great intellect and knowledge," added Mr. Shin, who has changed the spelling of his surname. "But she always worked hard and she encouraged us to get a good education."
Today, all three sons are prospering. Besides David, an accountant, Chong Ho and Kum Ho, 39, own their own groceries on Staten Island.
But America was not as easy for the parents. Mrs. Sin's husband, a government employee in Korea, worked in the wholesale garment business in midtown Manhattan, importing hats, gloves and other items. Business eventually dried up and after a few years there was no more work. As for Mrs. Sin, who in Korea had owned and operated a motel, she had to work 12-hour days as a seamstress in the garment district.
After her retirement, in 1988, she dedicated her days to the United Korean Church, a Protestant church on Fourth Avenue and 76th Street in Bay Ridge, not far from her home. She made stockings that were distributed to disabled children at Christmas and cooked turkeys for the elderly at Thanksgiving.
Two months ago, one of her greatest dreams came true: She became a United States citizen after having failed the test twice before.
After a routine checkup at her doctor's office in Manhattan on Wednesday, she was headed for a Korean center for the elderly in Flushing to pick up educational material about her new citizenship and possibly look into a part-time job, said Chong Ho Sin, the oldest son.
Her son David said: "She was very glad about obtaining her citizenship. She went through a rough time and she finally made it. I think she would be angry at the man for taking her life away, but she was kindhearted enough to forgive him."
His father, speaking through a translator, said: "The only thing I want out of this case is that another person does not leave prison and not get the help he needs. Other families should not have to go through something like this."
He stared out the small window, the one that faces the concrete ramps leading to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge that soars beyond.
"It's terrible," he said. "Terrible."
