HEADLINE: For Many Subway Riders, a Greater Feeling of Fear

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
First came a firebomb that injured more than 40 people two weeks ago. Then, on Wednesday, an escaped mental patient shoved a grandmother from a subway platform, killing her.
Despite the assurances of the Metropolitan Transit Authority's $1.7 million advertising campaign that the subways are safer and more pleasant, many riders yesterday said they had had more than enough. 
 "I'm a convicted felon, and I'm scared to death," said Ernest Scott, a messenger riding the E train yesterday. Mr. Scott served time in Attica and Sing Sing for armed robbery.
Elsewhere in the system, people stood back an extra step from the platform and looked over their shoulders more than usual, a day after Soon Sin of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, was pushed to her death in front of an F train at the station at 34th Street and Avenue of the Americas.
To many passengers, the death of Mrs. Sin seemed to underline the precariousness of urban existence.
"You just pray," Miriam Alleyne, an unemployed telephone operator who lives in Queens Village, said. "Before you leave home, you pray. Then at night, you say a prayer of thanks."
Others vowed to try to ignore the death. "I try to not go around thinking about fear," said Lisa Boggs, 35, a real-estate agent in Forest Hills, Queens. "It's not a good way to live."
Aida Soler, a waitress who lives in Elmhurst, Queens, said: "You're as cautious as you can be, but if you're standing next to wrong person, that's it."
The passengers were interviewed as they awaited trains on the northbound F train platform at 34th Street. It was there, the police said, that Reuben Harris, 42, a paranoid schizophrenic who had escaped from Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island, shoved Mrs. Sin, 63, onto the tracks. The motorman on a train saw her but could not stop in time.
Bill Sheehan, 54, a carpenter who lives in Manhattan, said that on that platform the day before, he had walked past a man who was talking to himself and giggling.
"I didn't want to walk close to the guy when I heard him talking," he said. "He looked like he was really having a problem. He was laughing."
Mr. Sheehan took the B train, which arrived only seconds before the F train that struck Mrs. Sin. "I only missed it by about 10 seconds," he said. "I thought, 'I bet I know who did it.' Then I saw the picture of him."
A transit police spokesman, Albert W. O'Leary, said that last year one person was killed after being pushed in front of a train, but there were no such deaths in the previous two years. He said he did not have information on how many people might have been pushed, but not killed.
Over all, the transit police say, reported crime in the subways has declined by about 50 percent in the last four years.
Still, Mr. O'Leary urged riders to be careful as they wait for trains and to stand behind the orange warning line.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
N.H.L. Owners Say Proposal Doesn't Foster More Hope

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
Heading toward another critical Board of Governors meeting in New York tomorrow, the owners and executives of the National Hockey League teams expressed pessimism about the latest collective bargaining proposal from the Players Association.
The teams will vote on the plan submitted by the union on Wednesday in what shapes up as a last-ditch effort to end the lockout that has delayed the start of the season since Oct. 1. 
 The proposal calls for multiple concessions in arbitration, a rigid entry-level wage structure and sweeping changes in free agency that would lessen mobility for younger players while increasing it for veterans at the age of 30.
Neil Smith, president and general manager of the Rangers, would not reveal how his team would vote at the meeting but said he was "not very optimistic" about the proposal being accepted.
"It's definitely not what the owners are looking for," he said.
Smith and others said the free-agency aspect of the proposal would be difficult to accept in the absence of a tax or salary cap to discourage high payrolls.
"The player will hit the jackpot, a huge hit at age 27 or 28," Smith said.
Jack Ferreira, general manager of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks, said it is a "foregone conclusion" that the proposal would be voted down. "It doesn't fly," he said.
The league last proposed a payroll tax of up to 25 percent on entire payrolls that go above a predetermined trigger point. The union rejected it as a salary cap.
With the lockout in its 98th day, the 26 owners have several options to consider before their meeting, including:
*Accepting the proposal and announcing the start of the season, if smaller details can be worked out quickly.
*Rejecting the proposal and canceling the season.
*Rejecting the proposal and continuing the bargaining.
Even if the owners were to accept the basic concepts of the "systems issues," the sides still must negotiate issues such as pro-rated pay and bonuses for the current season, length of future seasons and continuation of neutral-site games.
If Commissioner Gary Bettman recommends the proposal, a simple majority could pass it. If not, a three-quarters majority would be needed to over-rule him. As of yesterday, Bettman had not made his decision public, although some executives said they doubted if he would endorse the proposal.
Bob Goodenow, executive director of the Players Association, spoke by conference call yesterday with player representatives and faxed them copies of the proposal. Bettman's office in New York sent the information to the owners.
"It doesn't even reflect most of the points discussed," John McMullen, the Devils' owner, said of the offer. "I don't know how Bob Goodenow dreamed it up. This is a sad state of affairs. I don't see it as a step forward. It's a disappointing document."
Last week, Bettman set a start date of Jan. 16 to play a 50-game season and four full rounds of playoffs by July 1. Allowing for a week of training, a deal is necessary this weekend to follow the league's timetable.
Should the season be canceled, the union has said it will sponsor its own tournament, involving about a dozen teams and lasting several months. Some players and agents have planned new leagues. One of them is Mark Messier, the Ranger captain, who said one could begin this winter.
Dick Patrick, president of the Washington Capitals, was asked if owners would consider imposing their own rules and open their camps, in the manner of strike-bound baseball.
"Yes, I think it's a possibility, but not until it is certain the season is lost," Patrick said. "It hasn't been discussed in any of our meetings, but it has been discussed" in private.
Highlights of the proposal include:
*New free agency rules. Players could become unfettered free agents at the age of 30 if not under contract; elimination of free agency for younger players.
*Entry-level salary structure. The three-year rookie cap would begin at $900,000 next summer, including signing bonus but excluding performance bonuses. Figure would rise to $1.225 million in year 2000. The union says this hurts wages of older stars who now get raises by comparing their pay with high-salaried rookies; mandatory "two-way" contracts for rookies, with half-pay for minor league service.
*Reductions in arbitration rights. It would be eliminated until the age of 24 and after the age of 29. Between those ages, teams would have the right to "walk away" from one award per year if they felt it is too high. The player would become a free agent.
*Shared financial help from the union, the teams and league for some Canadian teams, from smaller markets, to make up differential with American currency in retaining free agents; Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver excluded.
*Roster maximum of 24, instead of unlimited as it is now; plus injured reserve list.
Pat Quinn, the Vancouver president, said: "I was amazed to read it this afternoon. It's more inflationary than the last agreement."
Among the most optimistic of the executives was Gerry Meehan, executive vice president of the Buffalo Sabres, who said the players "have made some significant movement" and that it provides "a good framework" for more negotiation.
"As I look at the looming cancellation of the season," he said, "I'm trying to find enough positive features in it to be optimistic."

HEADLINE: The G.O.P. Squeeze on New York

 BODY:
In his first speech as House Speaker, Newt Gingrich smoothly portrayed the Republicans' "Contract With America" as an uplifting program for the nation. But tranquilizing rhetoric cannot mask the program's potential harm for a city that already exports more Federal tax dollars than it gets back. That powerful message emerges from a report, issued by Representative Charles Schumer of Brooklyn, that provides rough estimates of the impact of G.O.P. spending cuts on the residents of New York City. The chilling numbers document an obligation to protect their constituents that now falls on members of the city's Congressional delegation, especially Alfonse D'Amato, New York's influential Republican Senator.
Mr. Schumer makes a straightforward calculation. To fulfill the contract's pledge to balance the Federal budget and cut taxes, Congress would have to cut about $ 350 billion out of the budget in the year 2002. But the contract would exempt Social Security, defense and interest on the national debt, thus drastically narrowing the places to find the money. It means Congress would have to chop 30 percent out of all the non-exempt programs. 
 New Yorkers, Mr. Schumer notes, currently receive 4.3 percent of the Federal dollars spent on these non-exempt programs and could therefore expect to bear at least 4.3 percent of the proposed cuts. Using the 4.3 percent yardstick, Mr. Schumer calculates that New Yorkers would lose almost $ 2 billion in 1996, ballooning to a $ 15 billion loss -- on average about $ 2,000 per person -- in the year 2002. Of course, the poor -- who rely on Federal programs like Medicaid, food stamps and public housing -- would suffer. But so would other citizens, who would get even less for their Federal tax dollars. Subway travelers, for example, would pay perhaps 15 cents more for tokens. There would be less money for magnet schools and Federal job training programs for the unskilled.
In the G.O.P. view, Mr. Schumer's study tells only part of the story. Republicans also promise to lift a number of mandates and to cut taxes, especially on the affluent. Because New York City has many high-income families, its overall tax burden might decline a bit. But here, too, the benefits seem more designed to attract the truly greedy than help the truly needy in a town that winds up housing and feeding poor people from other states.
In any event, the spending cuts would still be more than three times the size of the tax cuts, and any attempt to make up for lost Federal dollars by raising local taxes would harm a struggling economy. New local taxes could drive upper-income families out of the city, if not the state.
Rethinking Federal programs can be healthy. But New York's Congressional delegation needs to make sure the city is not disproportionately hit by frenzied budget-cutting. Senator D'Amato, the new chairman of the Finance Committee, is uniquely positioned to help. Here, the Senator and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani may finally find common cause.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 7, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial yesterday misidentified the committee headed by Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York. It is the Banking Committee.

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Chides Security Council on Military Missions

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali accused the Security Council today of "micromanaging" peacekeeping operations at the expense of his authority and that of ground commanders. And he criticized governments he did not name for demanding strong and costly action and then failing to support it.
In a progress report on the last two years of United Nations intervention in world crises, Mr. Boutros-Ghali also said the world body should take a harder look at the negative effects of sanctions on people living under renegade governments. 
 His comments, in a paper that described the peacekeeping operations as an overstretched and underfinanced department forced to take on ever widening roles, drew a quick retort from Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate.
"It is absolutely appropriate for the Secretary General to be making this kind of report with this type of analysis in it," she said after the Security Council meeting. But then, reopening an old debate between Washington and the United Nations on the limits of the Secretary General's role, she added, "To the extent that the report seems to arrogate more power to the Secretary General -- and his discussion of micromanagement of the Security Council -- we think that that goes a little bit too far.
"And also to the extent that it assesses blame, I think it's a little bit off the mark," she went on in remarks that pre-empted Mr. Boutros-Ghali's news conference on his report, an update of the 1992 Agenda for Peace. "I think we have to guard against saying that every time there is a success, it is due to the United Nations, and every time there is a failure, it is due to the member states."
But Ms. Albright and other delegates welcomed the report as a basis for talks on streamlining operations. "Basically what I see in all this is that peacekeeping, peacemaking, peace-building is a work in progress and one in which the United Nations has to make constant adjustments," she said.
She said the debate here was mirrored in one that will take place in the United States as a Republican-led Congress talks about cutting back participation in United Nations peacekeeping operations. The Clinton Administration is already bound by law to cut the United States contribution to peacekeeping assessments to 25 percent, from 31 percent, in October.
Ms. Albright has said that disagreements notwithstanding, she plans to campaign in support of the United Nations around the United States this year, the 50th anniversary of the organization.
In his report, Mr. Boutros-Ghali suggested that the United Nations develop a supply of ready-response troops from various countries to be dispatched to crisis areas quickly and maintain larger stocks of equipment to supply them.
But he also said he was having difficulty finding qualified special emissaries to oversee missions for long periods of time. Mr. Boutros-Ghali, more than his predecessors, has developed the practice of having his own civilian representatives in charge in the field, like Yasushi Akashi in the former Yugoslavia and Shahyar Khan in Rwanda.
Some of most forthright language in the report was applied to sanctions, however. In the cases of Iraq and Serbia in particular, this issue has led to heated disagreements in the Security Council. Those two countries are to be the center of debate again next week when the Council faces a deadline on whether to extend an easing of sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro, the two republics that now make up federal Yugoslavia -- and for how long -- and reviews the compliance of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
The Iraqis have been active in promoting the idea that sanctions are damaging the health and well-being of a guiltless civilian population. In the Balkans and Eastern Europe, some countries have argued that sanctions against the Serbs are hurting neighboring economies.
Sanctions are "a blunt instrument," the Secretary General wrote. "They raise the ethical question of whether suffering inflicted on vulnerable groups in the target country is a legitimate means of exerting pressure on political leaders whose behavior is unlikely to be affected by the plight of their subjects."
Mr. Boutros-Ghali advocated the creation of a system to assess the results of sanctions before they are imposed and then to "fine tune" them to increase their political effect and keep human suffering at a minimum.
At his news conference, the Secretary General said that whatever the limitations of the United Nations, it had the "moral obligation" to go to crisis areas.
He also said he sensed that the world was moving toward the recognition that "genocide is a common threat to humanity" and that this alone should propel countries to be more active in preventive diplomacy as well as peacekeeping, even when there were no immediate strategic threats.

HEADLINE: U.S. CLOSED YEAR WITH EMPLOYMENT GROWING SHARPLY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
A surprisingly robust American economy ended the year by generating more than a quarter-million new jobs in December, making the 1994 gain in employment the greatest in a decade, the Government reported today.
The unemployment rate slipped to 5.4 percent last month, the lowest level since July 1990 and comparable with levels not widely experienced at any other time since the early 1970's. 
 Economists said the latest job figures, which provided the first broad look at the economy's performance last month, showed strength that would probably carry well into 1995. By midyear, however, most expect the economy to be slowed by the cumulative effects of the step-by-step interest rate increases begun by the Federal Reserve last February.
And with the latest indication of the underlying force of the economy, it seems all the more likely that the Fed will raise short-term interest rates again within a month, probably by at least half a percentage point.
"Vroom!" said John R. Williams, an economist at Bankers Trust Research in New York. "That sound of high-speed acceleration sums up the U.S. economic engine as the Federal Reserve diligently pumps the brakes."
The Clinton Adminstration moved quickly to trumpet the latest jobs report. "We have grown the private economy as we have cut government," President Clinton declared at a White House photo session. "That's a real recovery and a real bargain for the American people."
For the year, the economy added about 3.5 million jobs, a million more than in 1993. It was the largest annual increase in jobs since 1984.
Unemployment fell broadly across the nation in December. The jobless rate in California, one of the last states to emerge from recession, eased to 7.4 percent from 7.7 percent in the previous month. Among the 11 most populous states, North Carolina had the lowest jobless rate, at 3.3 percent, while unemployment in Texas rose to 6 percent from 5.5 percent.
While the 256,000 payroll jobs added in December represented a very healthy increase, what was even more impressive was a huge revision upward in the figures for November, to 488,000. That gave November the largest monthly increase in seven years. Originally, the Labor Department reported that 350,000 people were added to nonfarm payrolls in November.
Another indication of the growing competitiveness of American industry was a broadly based 54,000 jump in manufacturing jobs. That lifted the gain in factory jobs for the year to nearly 300,000. By contrast, the United States lost 130,000 jobs in 1993 despite a business recovery that started two years earlier.
Despite the big back-to-back monthly increases in jobs, the bond market registered little concern today about whether the surge implied that higher inflation was just around the corner. Indeed, after an early decline, bonds rallied and finished the day with modest gains, pulling down interest rates. Stock prices also climbed, paced by the industries most sensitive to the business cycle and by technology issues.
Some analysts attributed the reversal to a midmorning report suggesting that the Federal Reserve might hold further increases in short-term interest rates in abeyance because of the economic crisis in Mexico. Higher rates would tend to make the dollar stronger against the Mexican peso, which has already been battered.
While there is a certain plausibility to the belief that the Fed may proceed cautiously for that reason, most experts expressed doubts that Mexico's troubles would stay the central bank's hand.
By themselves, the figures released today included almost no sign of the widely anticipated slowdown of the economy from an annual pace that may have hit more than 5 percent for the final three months of 1994. For the year, growth in output is now all but certain to exceed 4 percent.
The Federal Reserve is widely expected, particularly by investors in the bond market, to use the only real weapon at its disposal -- higher interest rates -- to try to bring that vigorous growth rate down to a more sustainable level. The Fed could act even before its Open Market Committee holds its next meeting -- a two-day session beginning on Jan. 31 -- but few economists saw that as likely.
"I think the Fed will raise rates," said Daniel Laufenberg, an economist with the American Express Financial Corporation in Minneapolis. The December job figure, he added, "makes three-quarters of a point more likely."
While the central bank normally moves interest rates by one-quarter or one-half of a percentage point, the Fed in mid-November raised the overnight bank borrowing rate it closely controls by an unusually large three-quarters of a percentage point to a target rate of 5.5 percent. A year ago, before the Fed started raising rates, the so-called Federal funds rate was 3 percent.
Central bankers at the Fed have said repeatedly that they would like to reduce economic growth to roughly 2.5 to 3 percent -- a rate that many economists believe can be sustained without reviving higher inflation. That pace reflects population growth of about 1 percent and gains in the productivity of the work force that most analysts believe are unlikely to exceed 1.5 to 2 percent.
Some analysts, therefore, fret that the jobless rate is at about the lowest level that can be sustained without raising the inflation specter, while others are convinced that a growing economy can push the unemployment level even lower without serious risk.
Today's Labor Department report showed that average hourly earnings rose a negligible 3 cents in December, to $11.26, while average weekly earnings rose $1.04, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to $389.60. For all of 1994, hourly earnings climbed 2.8 percent and weekly earnings were up 3 percent.
Jobs in retailing gained 91,000 last month, many of them in bars and restaurants. Temporary help and computer and health services also had hefty gains.
Construction was little changed, but this followed an exceptionally big November jump that reflected warm autumn weather, analysts said.
The job figures for November were also pushed up by an extra 50,000 poll workers on Election Day who were not recorded in the initial estimate and 70,000 retail workers who also did not show up in the early figures.
There were some marked variations by region, with the Northeast's jobless rate falling to 5.6 percent from 6.1, the West's moving to 6.4 from 6.7, the South's edging down to 5.3 percent and the Midwest's dropping to 4.5 percent.
In December, 7,155,000 Americans were reported to be out of work, down from 8,696,000 in January 1994, a thinning in the ranks of the unemployed equivalent to the population of Nebraska.
The department also published its annual updating of the seasonal factors with which it smooths data by removing the effects of recurring events like severe weather. This resulted in an increase of one-tenth of a point in the unemployment rates that were initially reported for February, May and June of 1994 and declines of the same size for the rates in August, September and October.

HEADLINE: New York Region Lags

 BODY:

Business Day, page 39.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Summary

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (96%); NEW JERSEY, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: Political Memo;
Democrats Try to Cope With Their New Role

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
His famous line is from 1933, but Will Rogers might well have been commenting on the capital this week when he said, "I don't belong to any organized political faith -- I am a Democrat."
While Republicans have moved in unison, capitalizing on their new power, the Democrats have been almost paralyzed, often not knowing quite how or when to act or even react. 
 No one expects the good will and discipline among Republicans to last forever. Still, the contrast between the parties has rarely been so stark -- and has led some Democrats to wonder openly whether their party has what it takes to remake itself in the shadow of Newt Gingrich.
"Republicans are on a roll, and when you're on a roll, you feel pretty confident," said John R. Petrocik, a political science professor at the University of California at Los Angeles. "The Democrats look pretty pitiful. They're chasing after the cameras saying, 'I've got something to say,' when they don't have much to say."
While the Republicans in Congress now hold slimmer margins than the Democrats did in the last Congress, they have been far more cohesive -- at least so far. In roll call after roll call on Wednesday, every Republicans voted together -- a unanimity no one can remember the Democrats attaining when they ran the chamber. In fact, the ever-fractious House Democrats could not even get their entire caucus to vote for Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri as their leader, even though his election at that point was a formality. Two Democrats voted "present" rather than support Mr. Gephardt.
The difference was visible even beyond the Capitol grounds. The Republican National Committee, seeking to make the most of the good will toward the party, began a series of television commercials backing the Republican agenda in Congress. The first is a pitch for a balanced budget amendment. Republicans will win backing for the balanced budget, the announcer says, "because we're doing what we promised."
The public relations blitz continued today when Republican governors came to Washington to discuss the balanced budget, welfare reform and other issues.
By contrast, the Democrats' national organization appears all but shut down. In only two weeks, the Democratic National Committee is to meet here to ratify whomever the President selects as national chairman. But Mr. Clinton has not yet settled on anyone for the job, which involves raising money to pay off a $4 million debt and leading the party into the 1996 Presidential campaign.
Debra DeLee, a former education lobbyist, has replaced David Wilhelm in the post only temporarily, and each day seems to bring new rumors about whom Mr. Clinton favors. The latest names floating are Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey; Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut; former Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan, now the Ambassador to Canada, and Thomas F. McLarty 3d, a senior counselor to the President.
While Mr. Clinton spoke cordially with Republican leaders in Congress, left-wing Democrats have spoken out against them. The most outspoken voice is that of Jesse Jackson, who is toying publicly with challenging the President either in the Democratic primaries or with a third party. At a meeting here this week of his National Rainbow Coalition, Mr. Jackson sounded a battle cry intended to put the Democrats on notice: "The meeting will be a first step in making the progressive movement a stronger force inside or outside the Democratic Party."
But other Democrats said the Administration could get pointers from the Republican Party. "The Republican Party at every level -- Congressional, institutional, grass roots and in their think tanks -- understands that people want transformational leadership," said Terry Michael, a former spokesman for the Democratic National Committee. "Until Democrats figure that out, until we end our denial of the legitimacy of the anger and get leadership with the guts to be bold, we will be left in the dust."
On the other hand, the Republicans may start to look more like the Democrats, at least as far as party discipline is concerned. Republicans have traditionally been more harmonious than Democrats, in part because the party has represented a narrow range of viewpoints. But now that the Republicans control the House and Senate, and now that the party encompasses a broader coalition of sometimes conflicting factions of social-issue conservatives and country-club Republicans, there are bound to be more tensions.
"Republicans haven't had a chance to find out what they disagree on," Mr. Petrocik said. "With Democrats as the new majority party, it might be easier for them to come together and respond more cohesively by critiquing the Republican policy than formulating a policy."
Further, voters have high expectations that the Republicans may not be able to satisfy. That is a problem Mr. Clinton himself is struggling with now.
Gerald M. Pomper, a political science professor at Rutgers University, warned that people should not interpret the Democrats' disarray as a sure sign of continued failure. Part of the problem, he said, is that the party needs to get accustomed to its new role.
"There's no Democrat in the House who's ever been in the minority, so that's quite a shock," he said. But he warned Republicans not to underestimate the power of the Presidency as "the most important centralizing force in American politics."
Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster, gives the Republicans credit for putting on a good show. He said his party just needed some time.
"The glitz and the sizzle looked good," he said. "But I'm not sure there's enough steak underneath to sustain the sizzle for very long."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton in the Oval Office with top Democrats yesterday after announcing the latest unemployment figures. Mr. Clinton has yet to select someone as national chairman of the Democratic National Committee, which will meet in two weeks to ratify his choice. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: French Talk to Iraqis, Angering Allies

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Drawing sharp criticism from the United States and Britain, France received a senior Iraqi official today for the first time since the Persian Gulf war of 1991 and agreed to open a diplomatic office in Baghdad soon.
In separate statements, the United States and Britain said that they had not been consulted about the French moves and that the moment was not ripe for easing international pressure on Iraq to comply fully with Security Council resolutions. 
 The visit by the Iraqi official, Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, brought no sweeping breakthrough in Iraq's campaign to end its isolation and obtain a relaxation of United Nations sanctions, including a punishing oil-trade embargo, that have shriveled the Iraqi economy.
After a breakfast meeting with Mr. Aziz, Foreign Minister Alain Juppe told reporters that France continued to insist that Iraq comply fully with all Security Council resolutions. "Some progress has been made over the past months," he said. "More remains to be done."
Mr. Juppe described France's decision to open a diplomatic "interests section" at the Romanian Embassy in Baghdad as "a technical step that will enable us to settle questions linked to the break of diplomatic relations." There is a United States Interests Section in Iraq, at the Polish Embassy.
But the meeting today was nonetheless viewed here and in other capitals as a significant good-will gesture to Baghdad, signaling that once United Nations sanctions are lifted, France expects to be rewarded with new business opportunities. Several high-level French business delegations visited Iraq last year for preliminary talks.
France has another reason to want normal economic ties with Iraq: Before the gulf war, France was Iraq's main arms supplier and is still owed an estimated $5 billion for various military and civilian contracts. French companies are also eager to take part in the rebuilding of Iraq's oil industry.
France suggested an easing of the oil embargo after Iraq's decision late last year to recognize Kuwait's borders. The timing of the moves today was significant because the Security Council is to meet next week to review Iraq's compliance with resolutions demanding the destruction of facilities that make weapons of mass destruction.
Britain was the first to criticize France. "It is not the moment to relax pressure on Iraq to comply fully with United Nations requirements," a Foreign Office spokesman said, adding that Britain remained "very suspicious" of Iraq since it massed troops on its border with Kuwait last October.
Later in the day a State Department spokeswoman, Christine D. Shelly, said Washington did not consider France's decision to open an interests section to be "helpful or constructive." She added: "We do not believe that now is the appropriate time to make gestures toward Iraq."
Ms. Shelly said Baghdad continued to violate Security Council resolutions, notably by failing to cooperate with a United Nations special commission monitoring its weapons programs. "We believe that such behavior should not be rewarded," she said.
After his meeting with Mr. Juppe, Mr. Aziz, who served as Iraq's Foreign Minister during the gulf war, insisted that Iraq was cooperating with the United Nations commission. "But the Security Council must in return make a positive step toward the softening of sanctions against Iraq in keeping with a fair and legalistic interpretation of the Council's resolutions," he said.
Mr. Juppe, who met Mr. Aziz privately in New York four months ago, seemed to make a point today of not appearing to be too friendly toward the Iraqi official. He noted that Baghdad still had to release some 600 Kuwaiti prisoners and end human rights abuses. But he added, "The present stalemate benefits nobody."

HEADLINE: Governor Proposes Tax Cut in California

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 6

 BODY:
Gov. Pete Wilson said today that he would ask the State Legislature to cut personal and business income taxes by 15 percent over three years.
The Republican Governor, beginning his second four-year term, said he would seek the tax cuts recommended to him last month by a group of economic advisers. 
 Speaking on Rush Limbaugh's syndicated radio show, Governor Wilson said lower taxes would put California in a much better position competitively. "We are a high-tax state," he said.
Californians with adjusted gross incomes of more than $200,000 a year now pay state income taxes at a top rate of 11 percent. The Governor's proposal would cut that rate to 9.4 percent. Businesses currently pay 9.3 percent of their profit, and that rate would drop to 7.9 percent
The Governor's advisory group, which was led by former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, said the tax reductions would amount to $9.1 billion.
This year, California borrowed $7 billion to stay afloat financially, and $3 billion must be paid off in the fiscal year that ends on June 30, and another $4 billion is due in 1996. The state's total budget amounts to $52 billion this year.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
With Season at the Brink, Compromise Is Still Absent

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
Pat Quinn, a former player and coach in the National Hockey League, is the president and general manager of the Vancouver Canucks. He has a law degree and three decades of experience in professional hockey. But he has never experienced anything quite like this lockout, which is in its 99th day.
 Quinn will attend the Board of Governors meeting today in New York in which the latest collective bargaining proposal from the Players Association is expected to be rejected. 
 The owners and Commissioner Gary Bettman have threatened to cancel the season if 50 games and a full slate of playoffs do not begin by Jan. 16. Will the owners make a counterproposal or suggest further negotiations. Will they push back the starting date or simply announce a cancellation of the season?
 "There will be a lot of discussion," Quinn said. "It's at a disastrous point where nobody expected. We'll find out a lot about ourselves."
 Guy Carbonneau of St. Louis, a member of the bargaining committee, said: "We don't want to hear about any counterproposal. If the owners turn down our offer, it's all over."
 "We've given them our best offer," said Joe Sakic of Quebec. "If they reject it, the season is canceled." Bill Ranford of Edmonton said "the season is a wash" if the owners reject the deal. Bob Corkum of Anaheim said: "It's now a matter of principle. It looks grim."
 After more than three months of economic struggle, even the most strident of the owners and executives admit to deep disappointment with the current proposal from the players.
 Quinn and his colleagues say that without a payroll tax to discourage spending, the union's latest offer wouldn't solve their problem of escalating wages because free agency at age 30 would create bidding wars for stars or force the signing of them to long-term contracts at high rates of pay when they are 27 or 28 years old. The union has rejected the tax, calling it a salary cap.
 If the owners were to vote by secret ballot, there are probably six to 10 teams that would vote to play. Among them are the Rangers, the Islanders and the St. Louis Blues. The Pittsburgh Penguins, the Buffalo Sabres and the Chicago Blackhawks are among those that might be swayed in that direction.
 The Montreal Canadiens, Toronto Maple Leafs, Detroit Red Wings and Dallas Stars have never been among the hard-line hawks who have successfully steered the league on its current, confrontational course.
 But it is clear that the hawks have had control of the agenda. They include teams from New Jersey, Boston, Edmonton, Hartford, Winnipeg, Florida and Tampa. And it is also evident that their lockout has been a failure, thus far, at least according to their definition of success. Despite the loss of salary, the players haven't caved in, and don't appear about to do so.
 Before the lockout, Bettman warned the owners to be prepared to cancel the season, and such a decision is nearing. Some teams have taken on lines of credit to cover expenses. David LeFevre, governor of the Tampa Bay Lightning, said owners had "targets set since last July" that haven't yet been met.
 "This is the year selected to deal with it," he said, referring to an economic overhaul of the business. "This is the time."
 LeFevre said a shorter season of 42 or 40 games would be a mistake.
 "You can't fool the fans," he said. "You can't have a phony season. This is it. I firmly believe in the 50 games and the Jan. 16 date. I don't think fans can withstand more uncertainty about hockey. We can't afford any more wheel-spinning. It's clearly decision time. I wouldn't vote to go back to the table. I think the table is worn out."
 Players also appear to have hardened in their refusal to make more concessions. "This is our last offer," said John LeClair of Montreal, who said the owners "don't think the union is that strong."
 "But they're mistaken," he said.
 Arthur Pincus, spokesman for the N.H.L., said Bettman and his top aides were unavailable for comment.

HEADLINE: Butterflies and Bravado At Debate Competition

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 5

 BODY:
It does not matter that they are all great debaters in their own countries. The competition here this week at the 15th World Universities Debating Championship at Princeton University featuring the best student speakers from 27 nations has them all a little nervous.
 "In Canada, we get a lot of respect," said Paul Ciufo, 24, a creative writing student at York University in Canada. "But it's hard to compete with teams like Oxford who have reputations on the international circuit." He complained that the judges were too quick to be impressed with any idea delivered with a British accent.
 "The Irish go more for style than facts," said Dermot Conway, a member of the University of Cork team, which will be the host of the 1996 championship. "It's like sitting down and having a good argument with a friend."
 Nick McGrath, a kilted debater from the University of Glasgow, fretted that Americans who judge the debates were having difficulty understanding his accent and his humor.
 Enthusiasm ran high all week as 244 two-member teams from more than 100 schools paired off in a series of preliminary rounds to decide the 32 top teams that will square off this weekend to battle for the world championship. There will have been up to 1,130 separate debates by Sunday's championship finals.
 In an age when television and other electronic devices have elevated sound and diminished conversation, it is consoling to some to know that a premium on the art of persuasion and logical discourse is still embraced by young people who can go for the jugular one moment and then go out for a drink together.
 "The quality of political speeches is so poor in the United States today that it is marvelous to see students who may eventually enter public service get up on their feet and construct complete sentences and sometimes do it with a degree of spontaneous wit," said Dr. John Fleming, a Princeton professor of English and comparative literature who is master of Wilson College on campus.
 Ross Harper, 21, from the University of Glasgow, said, "I think it's a safe bet to say that many of the debaters here are going to be in the top levels of power in their countries in 10 or 20 years."
 Most of the 488 debaters will go on to careers in law and politics, said Chris Paolella, a Princeton junior who is serving as tournament director.
 It was the fate of Mr. Ciufo and his partner, Lawrence Rabie, to meet the Oxford team in the one "humorous" debate of the tournament assigned to all of the 244 teams.
 Representing Oxford was the star-quality team of Rufus Black, an Australian, and Rod Clayton. It was their duty, one they took up with alacrity, to defend the proposition "American Culture Is an Oxymoron." The Canadians, by the draw announced only 20 minutes before the start, were on the attack.
 Mr. Clayton ripped into American culture, tossing off several lines of verse in Latin in an exhibition of what he championed as real culture as compared to the "low culture" exported by Americans.
 In rebuttal, Mr. Rabie spun out a bit of verse himself.
 "Bye, bye Miss American Pie.
 "Took my Chevy to the levee but the levee was dry."
 Not to be outdone, Mr. Black, a finalist in last year's championship, relied on an old four-letter Anglo-Saxon word to characterize his sentiments about the quality of American culture, an angle of attack that likely cost him points with the judge, Steven Johnson, 26, a lecturer in rhetoric from Creighton College in Kansas.
 "Rufus is one of the best debaters in the world on a serious subject but to see him dancing around the room speaking profanities goes beyond the substance of argumentation," Mr. Johnson said.
 Oxford was awarded the match but both teams, by the end of the preliminary rounds, were among the 32 teams chosen for the semifinals, as was the Glasgow team of Mr. Harper and Mr. McGrath.
 Daily results and rankings are supposed to be a closely guarded secret but team members seemed to spend most of their time between debates trying to breach the security of the tabulation committee operated by Princeton's venerable American Whig-Cliosophic Society (charter members were James Madison and Aaron Burr), which as host for the tournament did not enter its own teams in the debates.
 "I wish there was a trophy for tab room leaks," said Mr. Rabie, the Canadian. "I'd walk away with it. My secret is to tell a judge who scored my debate that I heard I had won it and watch his reaction before he runs away from me."
 During a break in the competition, an Irish student got on the public address system and listed the charms that awaited them in Cork next year. "The judging will be appalling but the tab room will leak like a sieve," he said to cheers.

HEADLINE: Pataki Picks New Labor and Utility Chiefs

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki is expected to name John E. Sweeney, the executive director and counsel to the Republican State Committee, to be State Labor Commissioner, aides to Mr. Pataki said today.
 In addition, Mr. Pataki said today that he had named Harold A. Jerry Jr. as interim chairman of the state Public Service Commission, the state agency that regulates utilities. Mr. Jerry, a former Republican State Senator who has been a commissioner for 22 years, said he would remain in the top post only until Mr. Pataki finds a permanent chairman. 
 The news of the appointments came on a day when the new Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, named his two top legal advisers: Francis T. Collins, his longtime Senate counsel, and David R. Dudley, his former campaign manager.
 Mr. Collins, who will have the title of executive counsel, will oversee the flow of legislation through Senate committees and on to the Senate floor. Mr. Dudley, who will have the title of counsel, will handle intergovernmental relations and deal with lobbyists. Both men are expected to handle negotiations over bills with the Governor's office and the Assembly Democratic leadership. Each will be paid $90,000 a year.
 Mr. Dudley, 50, was chairman of the Rensselaer County Republican Committee from 1991 until September 1992, when a new county ethics law was approved, preventing county party officials from also holding county jobs. Mr. Dudley had been counsel to the county's Industrial Development Agency at the same time he was county party chairman.
 Mr. Dudley said the ethics law was largely aimed at him. From 1986 through 1992, his law firm received about $445,000 in legal fees for the development agency, mostly for handling bond sales. Rensselaer County Democrats charged that Mr. Dudley had used his political influence to secure his counsel position and other legal work. Mr. Dudley denied it.
Mr. Dudley ran the 1976 Senate campaign for Mr. Bruno and the 1986 campaign for the Rensselaer County Executive, John L. Buono. He is also close to the state Republican chairman, William D. Powers, himself a former Rensselaer County chairman.
 In an interview today, Mr. Dudley said he had helped revive a lackadaisical agency and brought 26 new projects to the county. "If you don't do anything, you don't get paid," he said.
 Mr. Bruno said Mr. Dudley would not do any outside legal work while in the Senate job.
 "He's coming in with no baggage and as far as I'm concerned, he'll be a tremendous asset," he said.
 As State Labor Commissioner, Mr. Sweeney will run an agency with 5,100 employees and a $733 million budget. It runs the Federal unemployment insurance program, oversees wage and job safety laws and runs a host of training programs.
 The son of a former leader of a shirt-cutter's union in Troy, Mr. Sweeney had been named just a week ago as counsel to the Office of Employee Relations, the agency that handles state labor negotiations. But aides to Mr. Pataki said Mr. Sweeney changed his mind about which job he wanted.
 Mr. Sweeney was paid $99,935 by the state Republican Party, where he has worked since 1992. The labor commissioner's job currently pays $95,635.
 In his work with the state party, Mr. Sweeney, who lives in Schaghticoke in Rensselaer County, played a major role in building the grass-roots organization that helped sweep Mr. Pataki to victory. He was also the architect of lawsuits last year that accused former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of using state aircraft for personal and political purposes during the campaign.
 Mr. Jerry, 74, the interim head of the Public Service Commission, replaces Peter A. Bradford, a Democrat. The job pays $91,957 a year.
 Mr. Jerry owns a home in Albany but lists as his official residence a log cabin without electricity in the village of Speculator in the Adirondacks. He is widely respected by environmentalists, having served on the boards of several groups, including the Wilderness Society and the Adirondack Council.
 But consumer advocates criticized his record on utility rates. "He has generally voted with the things we don't like," said Robert Ceisler, executive director of the Citizens Utility Board, a private, nonprofit group that lobbies for lower rates.

HEADLINE: Currency Markets;
Dollar Advances on Reports Of Robust Employment Data

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against leading currencies yesterday as a robust United States employment report reaffirmed expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates at the end of the month.
 "The market was looking for the right number to give the dollar a rally at the beginning of 1995," said Hillel Waxman, manager of currency trading at Bank Leumi Trust Company. 
 The Labor Department said the economy added more than 250,000 jobs in December, pushing the unemployment rate down to 5.4 percent.
 "The employment report helped the dollar," said Paul Farrell, manager of strategic currency trading at Chase Manhattan Bank. "The conclusion drawn was that this report was strong enough to convince the Fed" to raise short-term interest rates after its policy-making committee meets at the end of the month, he said. Higher rates often buoy the dollar by making dollar-denominated bank deposits more attractive.
 In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5643 German marks from 1.5510 marks on Thursday. It edged up to 101.37 Japanese yen from 100.87 yen.
 The dollar was also helped by strength in the United States bond market and by strife in Russia.
 Bonds rebounded after an initial drop on the employment report, as investors concluded that last year's explosive job growth would not continue through 1995, traders said.
 "People are keeping one eye on bonds," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank. Currency dealers monitor the bond market to gauge investors' demand for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them.
 And the dollar often rises against the mark when Russia appears unsteady because Germany is Russia's largest creditor. Russia stepped up its attack on the capital of the secessionist southern region of Chechnya yesterday despite vows by President Boris N. Yeltsin to rein in the assault.
 "The problems in Russia favor the dollar," said Varick Martin, manager of currency trading at Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company. "Between the unemployment numbers suggesting we don't have any, and the Russian situation, everything out there is pretty good for the dollar."
 In other currency trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.3105 Swiss francs from 1.3005 francs on Thursday. The British pound fell to $1.5495 from $1.5630.

HEADLINE: Mexico Asks I.M.F. for Loan Of $2.5 Billion as Peso Falls

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
As the Mexican peso fell to a new low, the nation's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, asked the International Monetary Fund yesterday for a new loan that would effectively add $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion to the country's monetary reserves in an effort to revive confidence in the Mexican economy and stabilize the peso.
 A brief statement issued after Mr. Ortiz met in Washington with the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, said discussions on the loan would start next week in Mexico City. The loan would be available on a standby basis, allowing Mexico to draw it down as needed. 
 The peso dropped about 7.7 percent yesterday, to 5.795 to the dollar -- its lowest level since the peso was devalued almost three weeks ago. The peso has now declined by 40 percent against the dollar since the Dec. 20 devaluation and is now worth about 17 cents, compared with 29 cents. Meanwhile, the Mexican stock market index fell just under 1 percent yesterday. Telefonos de Mexico's American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange fell $1.125, to $36.875.
 The peso and the Mexican stock market had rallied briefly on Thursday when Mr. Ortiz visited New York to seek support from bankers for the Government's economic strategy.
 The I.M.F. said the measures Mexico had announced for controlling inflation and reducing its payments deficit provided a solid basis for discussions on an agreement that could be supported by I.M.F. resources."
 "Accordingly," the agency said, "an I.M.F. team will travel to Mexico next week to start negotiations on a standby credit."
 Mexican officials say the decision to seek a new loan is primarily intended to strengthen international confidence in Mexico's economy by showing that the I.M.F. believes that Mexico is likely to succeed with its measures to control inflation and translate a weaker peso into an export-led recovery.
 Mexico, which last borrowed from the I.M.F. toward the end of the Latin American debt crisis in 1989, still has to repay about $3.7 billion of that loan. As a result, it is entitled to borrow up to about $2.5 billion in any single year to support a new economic adjustment program intended to make its economy more competitive, or up to $3.5 billion over the life of a multiyear program.
 As matters stand now, these officials say Mexico does not believe it will ever need to draw down the money, although the credit would still reinforce the $18 billion package of credit lines the country has already opened with the United States, Canada and the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland. In addition Mexico has about $6 billion in its official reserves.
 Immediately after Mexico's devaluation last month, investors and bankers were concerned that the Government did not have a credible plan to stabilize the peso and prevent the benefits of devaluation being worn away in inflation.
 But Mr. Ortiz, with his appearance before bankers on Thursday and his request for an I.M.F. standby loan, appears to have largely laid such fears to rest.
 Moreover, the Government has given in to foreign demands that it encourage a renewed inflow of foreign capital by privatizing attractive state properties, including Pemex's petrochemical operations and part of the electricity generating monopoly.
 But Mexico's creditors are now starting to wonder whether the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon will have the political authority to carry out the tough economic measures it has promised.
 "The general feeling is, is the P.R.I. up to this, up to imposing more austerity when real wages have been falling for several years?" said Sarah Lavers, Mexican specialist with Latin Invest, a London based research firm, referring to Mexico's long-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party.
 Jean van der Walle of Alliance Capital Management called the plan logical, but said, "The question is, can they implement it after all the political capital President Zedillo has lost?"
 The P.R.I., which has ruled Mexico for the last 60 years, is divided between a conservative old guard and a reform-minded younger wing lead by President Zedillo, whose authority has already been badly dented by the devaluation crisis.
 An early test of the Mexican Government's strategy for stabilizing the peso and taming inflation comes in the last week of this month and the first week of February, when two separate batches of dollar-indexed Mexican treasury bills, each worth $1.3 billion, mature.
 On Thursday, Mr. Ortiz promised that these foreign, mainly American-owned, bonds would be fully repaid to those who want to cash them in but that Mexico planned to offer owners longer-term dollar-indexed replacements that would pay attractive rates of interest.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rates Decline For New York Region

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Jobless rates in New York and New Jersey tumbled in December, falling to the lowest levels in several years in both New York City and New York State. But experts said the improved unemployment rates, while giving some cause for optimism in a region where the economy has lagged behind the healthy recovery experienced in most other parts of the nation, did not reflect a turnaround in the region's relatively poor performance recently.
 The December data may have been distorted by Christmas sales jobs and other temporary employment related to the holidays. 
 "Unless these numbers are confirmed with another month at the same level, we shouldn't make much of them," Rae D. Rosen, chief economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said. New York and New Jersey, she said, continued to trail the rest of the nation in economic growth.
 Indeed, while upstate New York appears to have benefited from a robust gain in jobs last month, the New York metropolitan area still looks as if it is not sharing in the gains being experienced in much of the nation.
 Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, who released the data for New York and New Jersey, said the improvement was spotty at best, and had bypassed New York City itself.
 "This does not translate into clear-cut improvement across the board," he said. "New York State did a little better, but it is difficult to contemplate a healthy regional economy without seeing growth in New York City."
 The clearest indicator of growth came not in unemployment rates, but in the number of people employed in New York State. Although employment, as measured by the survey of households, remained virtually unchanged in New Jersey, at 3.8 million jobs, and in New York City, at 3 million jobs, it rose sharply by 117,000 jobs, to 8.2 million, in New York State.
 Economists say the number of people who hold jobs is a better measure of economic activity than the unemployment rate, which is affected by vagaries like the number of people who become so discouraged that they stop looking for work. That portion of the working age population is not counted in the figures.
 The number of people who have dropped out of the working and job-seeking population may have grown in the region, particularly in New York City, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
 "In the city, it's a case of fewer people looking for jobs, not more people getting them," he said. "That is not good news."
 Nonetheless, the December data showed that the unemployment rate plummeted across the rest of the state and in New Jersey. In New York State, the jobless rate was 5.4 percent -- the same as in the nation as a whole. New York State had a 6.3 percent unemployment rate in November.
 The monthly employment data are derived from a survey of people in 7,500 homes in New York and New Jersey. Connecticut is not included in the monthly survey, and no December data were available yesterday for that state.
 In New Jersey, the jobless rate sank to 6.1 percent in December, the lowest level since August, when it was 6 percent. New Jersey had 6.6 percent of its work force unemployed in November.
 In New York City, the December rate fell to 7.5 percent from 8.2 percent in November.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MCI Venture With Paging Companies

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
MCI Communications plunged into the wireless communications business today, saying that it had signed agreements with Paging Network Inc. and the Skytel Corporation to provide nationwide messaging services.
 MCI had been searching for a wireless partner since a deal to buy a stake in Nextel Communications collapsed four months ago. By teaming with the Paging Network and Skytel, MCI hopes to become a big force in the wireless market, while bolstering its long-distance business. Pagenet, based in Dallas, is the largest paging company in the United States, with more than 4.1 million subscribers. Skytel, a unit of the Mobile Telecommunication Technologies Corporation, offers nationwide and international paging services, primarily to business customers. 
 MCI "doesn't want to be left out of the wireless revolution that is taking place," said Dorothy Salmon, paging analyst at Economic and Management Consultants International Inc., a market research firm. "They are trying to capitalize on their brand-name recognition."
 MCI, which is based here, declined to disclose financial details of the agreements.
 MCI said it would resell Pagenet and Skytel's paging services under the MCI brand name. MCI said on Thursday that it would begin offering a host of new communications services, including paging, E-mail and personal "800" toll-free services, under the MCI brand.
 MCI and AT&T are vying for large shares of the growing paging market, which has more than 22 million customers and posted $2.6 billion in revenue in 1993. The Personal Communications Industry Association, which represents paging companies, predicts that there will be 65 million paging subscribers in 2003.
 "MCI's goal is to provide, through one-stop shopping for consumers and businesses, an ever-broadening range of communication services under the MCI brand name," said Timothy F. Price, executive vice president and group president of MCI Communications Services.
 AT&T expanded its nationwide paging services last year through its acquisition of McCaw Cellular. AT&T also resells services provided by Skytel and Pagenet, a spokeswoman said.

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Advance Despite Report on Jobs

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market rose modestly in heavy trading yesterday, despite negative developments in the bond market and a plunge in AT&T, the nation's most widely held stock.
 The gain came even after the Labor Department reported the lowest unemployment rate in four years and strong numbers for job creation in December -- inflationary pressures that ought to have sent bond and stock prices tumbling. But traders said the job-creation figure of 256,000 was less than the 277,000 that some private economists had been expecting. 
 "The market seems to be running without a cause," said Tom Gallagher, head of equity trading at Oppenheimer & Company. "There is no strategy here."
 Richard Meyer, director of institutional trading at Ladenburg, Thalmann said: "Some guys are still out of town this week. The guys that are here are struggling to put their money to work."
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 16.49 points, to 3,867.41, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.34 point, to 460.68. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index advanced 4.03 points, to 749.69.
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above average, with 308.1 million shares changing hands, about 6 percent above last year's daily average of 290 million shares.
 Long-term interest rates fell, but the yield curve -- or the comparison of different interest rates among different maturities -- continued to flatten, a technical sign that short-term borrowing costs may be rising so high the rates could tip the economy into recession.
 As one indication of the flattening yield curve, the five-year note carried a higher interest rate than the 30-year bond, or 7.87 percent versus 7.86 percent, even though the long bond carries the higher risk and should carry the higher rate.
 While not uncommon when the Federal Reserve tightens short-term rates, stock traders normally regard a flattening yield curve as a negative for stocks, but they did not do so yesterday.
 At its most extreme, when the yield curve is said to "invert," the shortest-term borrowings yield far more than the long bond, and businesses find it difficult to get loans they can afford.
 Ten stocks lifted the Dow by one point or more for a total of nearly 28 points. The biggest gainer among this group was Aluminum Company of America, which rose 2 1/2, to 87 5/8. The surge was due in part to an Oppenheimer & Company analyst recommending Alcoa and other aluminum stocks on the basis of rising aluminum prices.
 International Paper, which rose 1 5/8, to 77, and Union Carbide, which gained 7/8, 30 1/4, also advanced because of the outlook for a continuing rise in paper and chemical prices.
 Computer stocks were also substantially aided by apparently unfounded speculation that Apple Computer might be acquired by Oracle, Matsushita Electric Industrial of Japan, and Philips Electronics of the Netherlands. Philips denied the report, first announced by Information Week magazine.
 Apple, the most active stock of the day at 9.6 million shares, rose 3 1/8, to 42. I.B.M. climbed 1 1/8, to 75 1/8, in part because a CS First Boston analyst raised his profit estimates for the computer giant.
 But six stocks dragged down the Dow by one point or more for a total of nearly 11 points. Chief among these stocks was AT&T, which at 5.5 million shares was the fifth-most- active stock of the session. It fell 1 3/8, to 48 1/4, in reaction to a new Sprint pricing plan for long-distance customers that traders and analysts said might touch off a price war.
 There was even more trading volume, some 7.4 million shares, for MCI Communications, the No.2 long-distance carrier. MCI fell 15/16 , to 18 1/16 . Sprint, whose pricing plan prompted the heavy trading, briefly established a 52-week low of 25 7/8 before closing at 27 1/8, up 1/2.
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.20 point, to 251.59, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,218 to 981. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.64 point, to 433.12.
 Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 rose, led by Alcoa. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 233 rose, led by I.B.M.
 In Tokyo, stocks ended the week lower. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed yesterday down 96.65 points, or half of 1 percent, at 19,519.46.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Market Quiet On Possible Cable Deal

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Wall Street showed little reaction yesterday to reports that Time Warner Inc. was looking to acquire Cablevision Industries, a cable television company with 1.3 million subscribers.
 Time Warner stock fell 25 cents yesterday, closing at $34.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. Cablevision is closely held and its stock is not traded. 
 Time Warner has indicated interest in adding cable subscribers, and those served by Cablevision are primarily in New York, North Carolina and Florida, where Time Warner also has subscribers. In merging the two operations, Time Warner, the nation's second-largest cable company, would be able to "cluster," or benefit from economies of scale.
 The Wall Street Journal said yesterday that a deal for Cablevision, which is based in Liberty, N.Y., could total $2.5 billion to $3 billion.
 An executive close to Time Warner cautioned that no formal deal had been worked out and that discussions were continuing. "We would like to have a structure that would allow us to enlarge our cluster and keep the debt off the balance sheet," the executive said.
 It was unclear yesterday how such an acquisition would be financed by Time Warner, which has much debt as a result of the merger that created the company in 1990. Some analysts, including Edward Hatch of UBS Securities, said they were leery of the giant media company taking on more debt.
 One possible outcome would be a restructuring of Time Warner Entertainment, the venture that is 25 percent owned by U S West, with 5.6 percent stakes owned by the Toshiba Corporation and the Itochu Corporation. Those companies might put more equity into the venture, which owns the company's cable interests as well as Home Box Office and Warner Brothers.
 Analysts disagreed yesterday on whether additional cable ownership, which requires heavy capital investment, was a wise move for Time Warner. Jessica Reif, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said she liked the concept of Time Warner expanding in cable. But another analyst, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he believed Time Warner had already invested enough in cable.

HEADLINE: Rate Rises To Cost PNC $190 Million

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The PNC Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would cost about $190 million before taxes to bail out some of its huge money-losing bets on interest rates that it made in recent years.
 It will lose $121 million from the sale of $1.8 billion of bonds on which prices have declined, resulting in an after-tax charge in the fourth quarter of $79 million. It will also spend $70 million this year to buy financial instruments known as derivatives that will increase in value if interest rates rise. The bank, based in Pittsburgh, hopes that these hedges will help offset the further losses it faces from rising interest rates. 
 In an effort to reduce its vulnerability in the future to interest rate swings, the bank also said that it would shrink its $64 billion in assets by 17 percent over the next two years.
 At the same time, PNC announced that it would buy back up to 10 percent of its stock in a move to bolster its share price.
 Many banks use bond investments and various derivatives to help bolster their earnings when interest rates fall and loan demand declines. But the sudden and sharp rise in interest rates last year caught a lot of banks by surprise. A derivative is a financial instrument whose value depends on the course of interest rates or other financial markets.
 A number of other regional banks, including Keycorp, based in Cleveland, and Banc One, based in Columbus, Ohio, have also announced losses from investments that were hurt because rates moved up far more than expected. Banc One, for example, said in November that it would take an after-tax charge of $170 million to cover losses on bond sales.
 While the loss numbers may look large, bank analysts argue that they can overstate the cost of rising rates. This is because banks earn greater profits investing funds in their interest-free checking accounts when rates rise.
PNC's losses are proportionally the biggest of any large bank. As of Sept. 30, the unrealized losses on the bank's $22 billion in bonds and $12 billion in derivatives totaled $1.5 billion, or 34 percent of its equity. The unrealized losses at Keycorp and Banc One, by contrast, were 20 percent of their equity.
 The bank faces the choice of selling these investments and taking the actual loss or keeping them until they mature and earning a below-market interest rate. In November, PNC disclosed that these positions would depress its interest earnings by 15 percent over the next few years if interest rates rose according to its projections. If rates go up more than the bank expects, its interest revenue would fall by an additional 10 percent.
 The moves announced by the bank yesterday were aimed at cutting this potential 10 percent drop in interest income to 5 percent. PNC is the country's 12th-largest banking company, with $64 billion in assets. More than one-third of those assets, however, are in bond investments, a much higher proportion than most banks. The bank plans to reduce its bond holdings by an additional $4.2 billion this year and $3 billion to $3.5 billion in 1996, in addition to the $1.8 billion it has already sold. And it will sell $2 billion in low-margin commercial loans.
 The bank also said that it would take an additional charge in the fourth quarter of $31 million, after taxes, to cover the costs of closing branches and opening new bank-by-phone services. PNC has said it plans to close as many as 30 percent if its branches over the next three years to cut costs, the most aggressive branch closing plan of any major bank in the country.
 While many banks have been buying back their stock, PNC's plan to acquire 10 percent of its shares is unusually large. Banks such as PNC have become quite profitable in the last two years and thus have been generating excess capital that they cannot deploy in the slow-paced banking industry.
 The company's stock closed at $22.125, down 75 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares have risen from a low of $20 in the days after its November disclosure.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
Job growth surged in December as a robust economy continued to churn out new jobs. The gains extended across the nation, and the unemployment rate fell to 5.4 percent, the lowest since July 1990. Another sign of strength was a broadly based 54,000 jump in manufacturing jobs. [Page 1.]
 
In New York and New Jersey, the job market also improved But experts said the improvement did not reflect a turnaround in the region's economy. [50.]
 
The computer is on the verge of overtaking the television set as the chief electronics product in the home. Indeed, based on the products shown at an industry trade show, the TV set is rapidly becoming a computer as digital technology is used in televisions and video recorders and combination TV-telephones. [39.]
 
 
Companies
 
Fears that the price war in long-distance telephone services would escalate roiled the shares of AT&T and MCI. Wall Street's fears were prompted by a move by Sprint to offer a flat price, which was seen as a radical departure from pricing cloaked behind complex, heavily promoted discount schemes. Sprint's shares rose. [39.]
 
PNC Bank will take a $79 million charge as part of an effort to get out of some money-losing bonds. The company will also spend $70 million to invest in derivatives that it hopes will help offset further losses it faces from rising interest rates. [39.]
 
A battle for the breakfast tables of Europe is being waged by Kellogg and General Mills. Despite their rivalry, the two cereal companies welcome the growth overseas as a respite from cut-throat price wars and lackluster gains at home. [39.]
 
Ralston Purina will sell the maker of Wonder bread and Hostess Twinkies to Interstate Bakeries in a deal valued as much as $560 million. The sale of Continental Baking would make Interstate the largest bakery company in the nation. [41.]
 
Shares of Apple Computer jumped in very heavy trading on a report that said Oracle, Matsushita and Philips had discussed acquiring Apple. Philips dismissed the report as "nonsense.' [41.]
 
A report that Time Warner was looking to acquire Cablevision Industries was shrugged off by Wall Street. [41.]
 
 
International
 
Mexico's Finance Minister asked the I.M.F. for a new loan that would effectively add $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion to the country's monetary reserves in an effort to revive confidence in the Mexican economy and stabilize the peso. [39.]
 
 
Markets
 
Stocks gained, with particularly heavy trading in computer and long-distance stocks. The S.& P. 500 rose 0.34 point. [40.]
 
Treasury prices recovered from an early decline. [48.]
 
The dollar advanced, helped by expectations of higher interest rates and by intensified fighting in Chechnya. [49.]
 
Gold prices continued to slide. Natural gas prices fell. [49.]
 
 
Your Money
 
Money managers are sticking with their stock and bond funds for the most part, despite sharp losses last year. Five mutual fund experts who created hypothetical retirement portfolios are making few, if any, changes in their investments. [36.]
 
Can computer stocks repeat last year's dazzling performance? Much depends on whether consumer demand for CD-ROM software and home computing products remains strong enough to offset a weak market for business computers. [36.]
 
Refinancing adjustable-rate mortgages may make sense for people who want a larger loan or to consolidate debt. [37.]
