HEADLINE: Five Portfolios Lose But Hold to Course

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
Time to close the book on 1994, the worst year ever for bond funds and a losing one for stock funds as well.
 Statements will soon arrive telling individual investors of the carnage, undoubtedly causing many people to consider a leap out of mutual funds into safe investments like short-term Treasuries and bank deposits, whose yields are much more attractive than a year ago. 
 Professional money managers, though, are holding onto their stock and bond funds and urging their clients to do the same. Market timing, they say, is a game that few people can ever win.
 Like many individual investors, the five mutual fund experts who created hypothetical retirement portfolios a year and a half ago for The New York Times all had losses for the quarter and a poor year. None of them, though, are making wholesale changes for 1995. At most, they are dropping a weak performer and adding a few new funds.
 John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, in Chicago, noted that his portfolio was skewed toward funds that invest in small stocks, a group that trailed last year.
 "I'm not going to get tricky and swap into larger companies," Mr. Rekenthaler said. "I'm willing to hold through the tougher period."
 Eric Kobren, editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter in Wellesley, Mass., said his portfolio suffered because of its heavy holdings in cyclical stocks, which rise and fall with the economy.
 "A lot of investors bailed out of these funds thinking that rising interest rates will put a crimp in economic growth," Mr. Kobren said. "While we certainly don't dispute that relationship, we believe the economy remains healthy and commodity prices will rise further. We're sticking to our guns."
 Among the several dozen funds in the portfolios, the biggest loser in the final quarter of the year was the Pimco Institutional Emerging Markets fund chosen by Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla. Largely because of its heavy Mexican exposure, the fund fell 18 percent in the period.
 "I expect my manager to perform as that sector of the economy does," Mr. Evensky said. "I'm not a market timer, and I believe that I should have money in that sector, so I'm going to stay with it."
 To explain why these financial advisers do not try to time the market, investors need only look at some data provided by Townley Capital Management of New York. A study it commissioned from the University of Michigan shows how just a few market-timing mistakes can destroy performance.
 An investment of $100 in the stock market at the beginning of 1963 would have earned $2,330 by the end of 1993. But if the investor was out of the market for the best 90 days in that period, the earnings would have been just $110, concluded H. Nejat Seyhun, a finance professor at Michigan. The annualized return, Dr. Seyhun calculated, would have fallen from 11.8 percent to 3.3 percent.
 So anyone who gets skittish and pulls out of stocks in favor of cash at the wrong time can do irreparable harm. Likewise, loading up on certain industries and getting out of others can mean missing surges in the unpredictable financial markets.
 For a far-off goal like retirement, financial advisers generally recommend creating a growth portfolio and making minor adjustments based on a periodic review.
 Among the five advisers who created retirement portfolios in mid-1993, Mr. Jacobs remains the overall leader. His portfolio has gained 15.1 percent since its inception, in spite of last quarter's 2.3 percent drop.
 The best performer in the last quarter of the year was Jack A. Brill, a San Diego investment adviser who specializes in "socially responsible" investing. His portfolio lost 1.5 percent, bringing his cumulative return to 4.8 percent. For the full year, the only gainer was Mr. Kobren, who gained 1.8 percent in 1994 and raised his total return to 11.1 percent.
 Since tracking began on July 7, 1993, the five portfolios have risen an average of 8.6 percent, compared with a 7.47 percent total return for the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index. As individuals, though, only Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Kobren have beaten the market.
 The portfolio performance, tracked quarterly by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. in Summit, N.J., excludes transaction costs, sales charges and taxes, since many people invest retirement money in tax-deferred accounts. The five experts can choose among funds open to new investors and can change them quarterly, although the portfolios are intended to grow for 20 years.
 Among the three financial advisers who adjusted their portfolios, no clear pattern emerges. One is moving toward a growth style of investing, which favors companies with rapid earnings growth, and one is adding some value funds, which tend to buy stocks that the managers consider cheap. Mr. Evensky, whose cumulative return is 7.3 percent, and Mr. Rekenthaler, with a gain of 4.8 percent, are standing pat.
 For the "socially responsible" investor -- who tends to avoid companies involved in gaming, tobacco, alcohol, nuclear weapons and similar concerns -- 10 funds have made their debut since Mr. Brill put his portfolio together. Taking advantage of this new-found choice, Mr. Brill is adding two value-oriented funds, Neuberger & Berman Socially Responsive Fund and MMA Praxis Growth Fund, which has ties to the Mennonite Church.
 Falling by the wayside is Progressive Environmental, a sector fund that "has been heavily hammered because the group itself is out of favor," he said. It was the only domestic fund in any of the portfolios to take a double-digit percentage hit in the last quarter. Mr. Brill is also dropping Working Assets Citizens Balanced, which keeps a portion of its assets in bonds, to reduce the portion of his assets that are sensitive to interest rate movements.
 The most aggressive investor of the group, Mr. Jacobs made several changes to increase his portfolio's risk level. He added Janus Mercury and the Yacktman Fund, both classified as growth funds, and deleted Neuberger & Berman Guardian, a value fund. He switched Europe funds, upgrading to a better performer. T. Rowe Price European Stock, which rose 4.1 percent in 1994, replaces Invesco European, which fell 3 percent.
 The keeper of the all-Fidelity portfolio, Mr. Kobren, is adding a new fund in that family. It is Fidelity Export, which buys stocks of American companies with heavy foreign sales. Such companies should profit from the global trade accord and the European economic recovery, he said. The fund supplants International Growth and Income, which has a big stake in bonds.
 Unlike the other managers, Mr. Kobren keeps his portfolio to less than half a dozen funds. People buy funds to simplify their lives, so "I like to keep it simple," he explained. "I don't mind using three funds, even if it's a $500,000 account."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Sags, With Contract Tumbling 3% in Just a Week

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold prices tumbled yesterday after an unemployment report bolstered expectations for another increase in interest rates.
 Other precious metals also fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange, extending a decline. 
 Gold and other precious metals are considered hedges against the effects of accelerating inflation. But the Federal Reserve is expected to raise short-term interest rates again at the end of the month, and such anti-inflationary measures reduce investor demand for gold.
 On other markets, warmer weather forecasts drove natural gas prices to a three-and-a-half-month low. Hog prices also dropped. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.60 point, to 235.24.
 Gold for February delivery, the most actively traded contract, sagged $4.40, to $372.20 a troy ounce. The contract has lost $12.20, or 3 percent, since last Friday. March silver plunged 8 cents, to $4.652 a troy ounce; April platinum fell $4.10, to $406.40 a troy ounce.
 George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc., said speculators saw no reason to invest in gold.
 "It's a case of 'What's gold done for me this year,' " he said. "It's gone down 3 percent already. Why own it?"
 Speculators also sold gold in anticipation of lower prices in the months ahead, said Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metals trading at the New York branch of the Swiss bank Credit Suisse.
 Gold prices typically decline in the first quarter, he said, as jeweler demand diminishes after the holiday push. Middle Eastern buying also dries up during the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, which corresponds to February this year.
 February deliveries of natural gas fell 5.3 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $1.499 for 1,000 cubic feet, the lowest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since Sept. 23.
 Prices for the heating fuel have fallen sharply all week, despite frigid temperatures in the Midwest and Northeast, because of abundant supplies, analysts said. The American Gas Association reported on Wednesday that natural gas in storage was 8 percent above a year ago.
 "Some cold weather this week is not enough to sustain a rally in this market," said George Ellis, a trader at GSC Energy in Atlanta.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Your Money Page

LENGTH: 726 words

HEADLINE: MORTGAGES;
When It Makes Sense To Trade In Adjustables

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
PEOPLE with adjustable-rate mortgages are feeling the pinch as rising interest rates push their monthly payments higher. And oddly enough, some of these homeowners are coping by refinancing into another adjustable-rate loan, well aware that their rates could rise again.
 The prime candidates are people who want to take out a larger mortgage to pay for education, home improvements or other big-ticket items and those who want to consolidate existing debt like a home equity loan. 
 Harry LeFevre, an assistant principal who lives in Amawalk, N.Y., just refinanced a loan adjustable once a year that he had since February 1992. He did so because the rate on both his mortgage and his home equity loan were set to rise two percentage points, to almost 10.25 percent and 11.25 percent, respectively.
 By waiting so long to refinance, he missed out on the bottom in interest rates last year, he conceded. But he had to complete his extensive home renovations first. Lenders generally resist making home loans at attractive rates until such work is done. "I was also too busy and since my loan anniversary date was February, I felt I had some time," he said.
 Mr. LeFevre's previous loan was for $180,000 at an initial rate of 4.25 percent with a monthly payment of $1,385, including about $500 in tax and insurance. Over the last two years, though, the rate had increased to 8.25 percent and the payments to $1,626. In February, the payments could have risen to $1,866.
 Mr. LeFevre's new loan is for the outstanding mortgage amount plus $40,000 rolled over from the home equity loan. The new loan starts at 5.875 percent, adjusts once a year and carries initial payments of $1,801 a month. The only fees he incurred, including a credit check and an appraisal, came to about $600.
 The risk of rising rates is limited since most adjustable loans can climb only two percentage points a year and six percentage points over their life, almost always 30 years. "My biggest risk is that if rates continue to increase they can now go as high as 11.875 instead of 10.25," Mr. LeFevre said, referring to the lifetime caps on the two loans.
 Bruce R. Lublin, president of the Homerica Mortgage Corporation, with offices in Harrison, N.Y., and Westport, Conn., said, "With prime rates going up, the people with home equity loans are looking to fix their costs, and this is a way to do it."
 Home refinancings are not as plentiful as they were in 1992 and 1993. They now account for less than 10 percent of new mortgages, according to HSH Associates, a mortgage research firm in Butler, N.J.
 Most refinancings are coming from homeowners with old mortgages at high fixed rates who are belatedly moving into a lower fixed-rate loan to reduce their payments, said Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH. A few people with adjustable loans are refinancing into fixed-rate loans at a slightly higher rate because they fear rates will skyrocket. "We do have people who do refinance into A.R.M.'s, but the pool is pretty small," he said, pegging it at about 20 percent of refinancers.
 Not everyone doing it wants to consolidate debt. Mr. Lublin, for example, recently refinanced a mortgage on his new home in Greenwich, Conn. At first, he took over the previous owner's mortgage, an unusual three-year adjustable-rate loan that had climbed to 9 percent and had a lifetime cap of 15 percent. He immediately refinanced into a one-year adjustable loan at 4.25 percent. (Such a loan generally costs about one point, an origination fee equal to 1 percent of the loan amount.)
 Ellen Bitton, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, a mortgage broker, said that interest in refinancing one adjustable for another has tapered off in the last few weeks as one-year rates have risen sharply. "There are, however, still some good short-term deals out there," she said.
 Homerica, for example, is offering a one-year adjustable at an initial rate of 5.125 percent, with a fee of two percentage points of the total.
 Mr. Gumbinger cautioned that refinancing into an adjustable loan might raise cash or restructure debt but it would not help retire a mortgage. "You aren't making a dent in your mortgage balance if you keep refinancing," he said. "You keep re-extending the term every year, and most of the early years of payments are mostly interest."
